column10: i didnt realise you can connect the mod manager to the steam version... fuck. thats 1000 hours with no proof :')
A classic

You don’t need to create a Square Enix account. You don’t need to fight through ancient technical difficulties for an [i]older[/i] game. You don’t need to be capped to 15fps anymore. You don’t have to have any technical expertise to [i]update[/i] FFVII. All you need is 7th Heaven – The Mod Manager for Final Fantasy VII. 

I want to point both experienced FFVII players and new players alike to the guide section on Steam, where you’ll find “Remaster your FF7 – Essential Modding Guide” created by Fawkes. For my first experience I went with all mods described there, aside from Ninostyle characters (I kept it Vanilla instead) and Echo-S (I didn’t want voices added). All mods recommended are for audio, visual and quality-of-life improvements, so they don’t look to alter the gameplay or experience significantly. 

The pre-rendered backgrounds are now sharp and defined through AI upscaling, the advanced lighting creates shadows around objects and characters, the FPS increases from an abysmal 15 frames to a sensationally higher 60 frames. Battle ambience, footsteps and other soundscapes added. Unified field textures transform 4:3 design to 16:9 widescreen format. Analogue movement. The list goes on and on..

I’m lost for words – it’s [i]so[/i] damn smooth. It generates an unbelievably modern framework to play the game on. I'm enjoying every single second of this experience.
A must-play classic.

This has been my favorite game for just about as long as I can remember. I know, even after all these years and however many play-thrus, I'll be sinking another 100 hours into yet another save file and getting that 100%

It's my all-time favorite game! From the best villain of all games, because you can relate to why he became the villain and why his life has no meaning but to destroy the world! The world is rich and deep with many mini-games, tragic love stories, and what drives a hero! I have played this game over 50 times on many platforms and Steam is the best way to collect the final fantasy to play beyond the other platforms where tech makes old games obsolete!

They should've just remade this instead of giving us whatever Remake was supposed to be. 
Its a darker feeling game overall. Story and pacing is on point. A classic.

If you want to play it and have it feel modern, get the 7th Heaven mod installed and install HD models, Textures, and if you're okay with okay-ish voice acting, get Echo-S. Thats as close as you're gonna get to anything modern sadly.

DO NOT get the New Threat mod. Aside from bugs, I lost out on a limit break and some materia cause for whatever reason the combat-only version switched some items in the world. The enemies have more HP thus becoming a choir getting into fights. 

If you want difficulty with OG, just dont grind. Its no harder or less harder than previous and next up FF games. The ones that say its easy are the ones who've played it 50 times and grind.

Truly a classic.  It does have at least one bug of serious consequence called the save crystal glitch, but if you're aware of it, then it's not really an issue because it's easy to avoid replicating the bug.

I beat the game as a kid and I remember loving it.  Now that I have played many other games, this one definitely shows some flaws.  But these flaws should be considered in the context of a game that is truly remarkable, not only for it's time, but even today,  I haven't really played the remake yet, so I can't compare the two.

As for the flaws, I found the game to be trivial in difficulty.  At no point did it ever really feel like a struggle.  Which is fine I guess, but as someone who has the amount of experience that I do, it's generally more fun when the game is more challenging.  Beginners might appreciate the relative lack of difficulty, as it enables one to better focus on the story aspects of the game, which are likely what draws people to the series in the first place.

I played in original graphics mode with high resolution and I thought it looked fine.  The transition from 2D to 3D graphics was a little awkward, as there was a brief time when the 2d graphics simply looked better than the newer 3d option.  This game, I think, did a good job of avoiding that; which is to say that it has aged quite well.

Overall, I highly recommend this game to any fan of the Final Fantasy series, and to fans of RPGs in general.  This one has a wonderful story, an excellent gameplay system called Materia that are fun to master and play around with in general.  As of this writing I've obtained a total of 15 master Materia.  It doesn't take an undue amount of time to get your characters to 99 and unlock all the achievements, nor do you have to in order to be able to beat the Ruby and Emerald weapons.  I actually beat Emerald weapon on the first try at 99, with maxed out everything except stats, and realized I absolutely could have had a lot of fun trying to down it with less developed characters.

Having played Final Fantasy 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8, and 10, and 100% completed 1, 2, 7, and 10, I would rank this one at number 2, behind 10, with 2 coming in 3rd and 1 in 4th.  I wouldn't feel comfortable ranking 3 or 4 as I have not finished the story of either game, but I'd be very surprised if they surpassed 7.

After a regular gameplay, I strongly recommend trying some of the mods made by the talented community. They bring a refreshing modern side to this game, which I'm pretty sure would get approval and praise from the makers themselves back then, had they not been so limited by the technology at the time.
Look for the 7th heaven Mod manager. It's a great tool that simplifies the modding process. I personally use the following ones in this order inside the loader to avoid conflict. Or just use the auto sorting button in the future if there are any changes 

- Tsunamods SYW V6 60FPS FMV
- 60 30 FPS Gameplay
- NinoStyle Battle Models 
- Tsunamods Avalanche Arisen Battle Textures
- TsunamodsSYWV5 Battle Textures (2nd battle texture mod that covers what 1st doesn't)
- NinoStyle Chibi Field Models OR NinoStyle HD Field Models (up to you which you prefer)
- Tsunamods SYW V5 Field Textures
- Tsunamods SYW V5 Minigame Textures
- Tsunamods SYW V5 Spell Textures
- Tsunamods Enhanced Stock UI
- Tsunamods SYW V5 Menu and Fonts
- Tsunamods SYW V5 Worldmap Textures


Also give the remakes a try if you didn't yet for a modern day experience

Even though FF7 is one of my favorite JRPGs, I can't recommend [i]this.[/i]

Mostly because of the poor quality of the port. 

Underrated? Overrated? Either way, this game is a classic.

Let's be honest though, Square Enix did not put much effort into this.

Although you can improve the experience with mods. 

There are better ways to play.

Oh well.

Read on for more info.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

Final Fantasy VII was a PlayStation game from 1997, made by the Japanese game dev studio Square (also known as SquareSoft). 

This is a re-release of the 1998 PC port developed by Square USA (and published by Eidos), updated for modern versions of Windows. 

One of the first differences you'll notice, if you've played the original version on PlayStation, is that the characters have mouths. Comparison [url=https://cdn.mos.cms.futurecdn.net/Ys9VwHw3b8TuPnAHqHh8ia-1200-80.png]here.[/url]

Why? [i]"I'm not really sure"[/i] wrote programmer Jay Fong in an email to [url=https://www.pcgamer.com/why-the-hell-do-they-have-mouths-a-final-fantasy-7-pc-retrospective/]PCGamer.[/url]

While Jason Greenberg (the only artist listed in the credits) was quoted as saying:

[i]"Great question. I'm wracking my brain to try to remember. This is not something that we added on the art side since I never changed the model files in any way. I believe I remember that the mouths were just sitting there in the original texture files for the characters. I'm pretty sure the code to drive them was probably there as well, and we just enabled it or something. I wish I could tell you more, but I just don't remember it."[/i]

Okay then... moving on. Square eventually merged with Enix (a Japanese multimedia corporation), and later Square Enix contracted DotEmu to update the PC version.

Essentially, what they've done here is add support for 1080p (no widescreen or 4K), SecuROM DRM (which has thankfully been removed), a crappy Square Enix launcher that requires a Square Enix account, and cloud saving (but not Steam Cloud, only through the launcher using Square Enix's cloud service).

The frame rates are capped at 60 FPS for menus, 30 FPS in the field, and 15 FPS for battles (including the battle UI).

The character booster only works via their website (requiring cloud saving to be enabled), and applies to all characters in your party on a specific save file. It will increase their HP to 9999, their MP to 999, and give the party 49999999 Gil. However, it doesn't affect character level (or any other stats), so it doesn't reduce the need to grind for levels.

The cloud saving feature is also known to have issues, and complications may result in save files being lost.

Final Fantasy VII is one of my favorite JRPGs, but this port is awful. They didn't even include features that the Japanese PC port had, such as high speed mode, no random encounters mode, and a max stats command.

What more could ever be said about this game. It's overrated. It's underrated. The greatest JRPG ever. The game that ruined JRPGs. But this is the one. The one final fantasy anyone and everyone should play. The one game that exists so singularly as itself that even comparing to other final fantasys seems wrong. It is the greatest story ever told in game form, bar none. It has one of the most richly detailed worlds and the most engrossing characters of any game in the series. The combat is surprisingly punchy and fast paced even today, even compared to later Final Fantasys (looking at you 9). Play this game. You owe it to your inner child and future self. 10/10

First of all, I love final Fantasy VII; it's an excellent old school JRPG from the days before Square became morally and creatively barren. The story is engaging, the world is vibrant the characters are complex and the music is awesome.

However, this version on steam gains a negative review from me because it forces you to log in to Square-Enix servers to play the game they sold you.

On the plus side of course if you want a work around then you can always use the 7th Heaven mod launcher and bypass the Bulls##t sign up requirement.

Additional, for anyone wondering if they should play this or the 'remake'...the two games are not remotely the same so play both and make up your own mind even if it means giving Square-Enix more money. (Though IMO the original is the superior product and the 'remake' is everything I don't like about modern JRPGs..but your tastes may differ).

Fantastic game, enjoyed it very much. Good music, great character models, great enemies design and cool magic animation make combat very fun to experience, also materia is such an amazing mechanic, leveling it and making builds feels so satisfying. Sadly, dungeons in this game are very short so there is almost no opportunity to use your builds. Characters are pretty cool and distinctive, they don’t say much, but by the end of the game you feel like you have known them for a while. Story is good, I felt invested in it throughout the whole game, plot twists are cool and the ending is satisfying. Presentation is great, low poly models add to that old game charm which is endearing. Great backgrounds, you can see that a lot of work went into producing them. Amazing soundtrack, music from the Forgotten City area is my favorite. Overall the game does feel timeless which explains its big fandom. Played it without looking at the playthrough, which felt very satisfying. Big recommend.

Classic wonderful JRPG. It´s wonderful to replay with 7th Heaven mod manager, TSUNAMODS, and ECHO-S 7. 

Tsunamods update the game, adding modern features and options, updated potraits, models, animations, textures, game play, etc.

Echo 7 S is a community funded voice acted mod. Lots of professional voice actors for main cast, lots of community voices for side NPCS. 

7th Heaven is a mod manager which will allow you to download all these mods. Some mods may interfere, even Tsunamods, just disable to problematic ones. 

This is as close to a modern HD Remake I would want. Original gameplay, updated graphics, voice acted. Totally worth the price for new players or veterans wanting a modern experience.

A multi-layered story revolving around the meaning of life, identity and politics with one of the best cast of JRPG characters ever assembled, if not the best of all time. Easily ahead of it's time and worth every moment of yours up until the final boss and beyond! 

Truly one of the best games ever made and that I have ever played. You can easily sink 35-100+ hours into this game depending on if you just want to complete the main game or go beyond and max out all your characters and beat the ultimate bosses and max out your materia.

After your time with FF7 has come to a close, you will want to look into other media such as Advent Children, Crisis Core and the other spinoff material. You will want to dive deeper into the lore and mindset of the world and it's characters. Hooked for life and single handedly responsible for my love of turn-based RPG's aside from Pokemon.

This was my first JRPG/RPG as a kid. I have played it countless times growing up. 

I remember borrowing my friends copy at one time and I could not believe what I was seeing and playing, "do games like this exist?", it opened up another world for me.

So I became a paperboy, I saved quarters and cents did chores for months and months and months, hoping to finally, some day, be able to buy a playstation and a copy of the game...

Suddenly one day the money was gone...my parents were addicts and spendthrifts deluxe...so they used the money I had saved and worked for...

But anyway, later down the line, some years later my grandmother actually managed to buy me a Playstation, a copy of Final Fantasy VII AND a memory card, I guess the clerk expressly expressed that this was a very important addition to the whole package...she came through so hard.

She took me aside after I had opened the present, still in disbelief, and whispered "there's memory on it", with a warm smile and a glint in her eyes, "The clerk told me to tell you, there's memory on it". <3

I love her so much.

And she made my day and years, and it wouldn't be the last time. Bless the woman. Without this game, I would have had a much tougher time growing up on the spectrum, undiagnosed, with parents that only did drugs and never payed any bills at all, and they never even spoke to me, asked me how my day was, if I was alright in school and such...

But Cloud and Tifa and Nanaki spoke to me, they were my friends. And this game is a game I will continue to come back to until I die. Nostalgia has a lot to do with it, perhaps, but mostly it's the themes, the world concept, the music and...everything else. This game is golden, not as golden as my grandmother, but close.

So yea, I definitely recommend it.

If you grew up with FFVII, stay away unless you want to spend hours modding a game that was supposed to be properly completed decades ago.
If you are new to Final Fantasy, be prepared. This game suffers from a nostalgia haze for most. The poor design of many of the many, many, many mini games that are thrown at you will have you frustrated. The losing of potentially hours of progress because "an unknown exception occurred" and crashes the game at the end of a cutscene you couldn't save before. The **** chocobo that are programmed to be able to run away while the menu is still loading that will have you grinding for hours. It's honestly not fun in many places.
The story remains interesting, and I'll push through and try to finish more of it another day. That said, if you're looking to get into Final Fantasy, there are other, better, games in the franchise that are also available here on Steam. Don't be bullied by the childhood blinders of others. This game is a product of its time, and this PC port is a product of nothing more than an attempt at a quick cash grab.

The greatest game in 1997, and still now, especially considering generation. A fantastic and extravagant epic, crossing many genres in story and gameplay. In the era of in-game secrets, the absolute definition of open world, replete with deep plots and characters down to the most insignificant NPC. The 1997 revolutionary graphics/cutscenes are still mesmeric and indulgent, with a timeless soundtrack and captivating sounds. Satisfying, grandiose turn-based combat and top tier customizability, although mostly easy for a veteran FF player. XCOM meets the Legend of Zelda, with free-roam tones of future GTA games, in upgraded JRPG style from a tradition of digitized D&D. Vastly more content and scope than FF7 Remake Intergrade (2020), a remake of the introductory section of FF7. The 1997 technology holds up surprisingly well. A truly impressive, captivating production.

Solid and memorable JRPG, crafted with the superlative quality you'd expect from the Final Fantasy series.

Fans of the genre: Final Fantasy VII is exactly what you're looking for. It's got a meaty, epic storyline that starts small, expands to a global scale, and culminates in an awesome and satisfying finale; a charismatic cast of characters hounded by an unforgettable villain shrouded in mystery; an attractive overworld map littered with secrets, just large enough to convey its sense of scale without feeling unwieldy or overwhelming; a peerless soundtrack, etc. etc. Secret party members, plenty of unlockable weapons and abilities, sidequests...there's just a ton of content here, none of it feels phoned in, and it's all remarkably well-packaged and well-paced.

Final Fantasy VII employs the well-tested fusional real-time/turn-based combat style that the series had neatly settled into by this point. The materia system is, refreshingly, as shallow or as complex as you want it to be. For folks who enjoy farming enemies to unlock massively powerful combinations of spells and passive perks, the ceiling here is quite high - and the game includes optional extreme-difficulty endgame bosses as a reward those who have labored to create truly broken party compositions.

Final Fantasy VII isn't my favorite entry in the series, though it's probably in my top 5 - and it absolutely deserves the praise that it pretty much universally receives. This game is an easy recommend for anyone who is curious about the genre (although at this point I might just advise newcomers to play the Remake instead, as it's way more accessible).

As an aside, I played both Legend of Dragoon and Xenogears prior to picking up this title for the first time a few years ago, and honestly I was surprised by just how much they all ended up resembling each other. Anyone who enjoys JRPGs might want to check those out as well; if I'm being honest, I actually found all three to be of comparable quality (barring the final disc of Xenogears, where the development studio famously ran out of funds), and I've really cherished my time with each.

Story: 9 I can't speak for the story as a whole as I never actually beat Final Fantasy 7, but what I did get to see was really good. A complex and epic story about freedom fighters against the evil Shinra corporation along with a struggle against the bio-engineered Sephiroth in a unique and interesting setting.

Graphics: 7  No game as old that I can think of holds up nearly as well as Final Fantasy 7 in terms of graphics, and it was revolutionary for how it looked at the time, both in its own series as well as in gaming as a whole. The backgrounds when not on the world map are of course the biggest highlight of the game, but many of the enemy designs are great, too. Of course, by modern standards the graphics are definitely not able to compete. 

Gameplay: 7 The gameplay in FF7 is surprisingly enjoyable for such an old game, and there's lots of little mini-games that you can play too which add even more to the game's diversity. That being said, there are often times you just want to the random encounters to end so you can get to the next story beat or boss battle.  Also some of your special animations as well as the boss's special animations take FOREVER to finish.

Music: 10 The greatest soundtrack of all time? It's definitely not easy to beat. From the heart-wrenching to the heart-poundiing, there are so many incredible songs in Final Fantasy 7 it's pretty ridiculous.

Some people think this game sucks just because they played FFVI before it. "People whose first FF was VII are noobs and wack and know nothing about FF." Exact quotes.

Well, I'm a wack noob who knows nothing about FF, because VII was my first. I had never even heard of HP or MP or random battles before 1997. I only asked for the game for Christmas because at K-Mart I saw the game said '4 discs' on the package. I didn't even have a PSX yet, and I think I had only played Tomb Raider at that point. But FFVII was there with that gigantic buster sword and four discs, while the trash all around it had only one single disc. Pathetic.

Parents and grandparents went halfsies on a PSX and FFVII for Christmas '97 or '98 (can't remember), and they even got me an ASCII second controller. But none of us knew a memory card was also required. So I replayed the first hours of the game over and over for a week until I had bugged my dad enough to fork the cash out for one (he was pretty thrifty and initially I almost shat my pants when I saw that they had ACTUALLY even got a console for me). A few weeks later I saw the official strategy guide at Blockbuster and begged for that too. In some strange twist of fate, he actually got that for me too after a while.

So I played the hell outta of the game all through 7th and 8th grade. Some of my friends and other kids in school did too. Life was good. I remember beating Emerald WEAPON the first time and calling my best friend who lived across the street to tell him (he came right over to verify). Some amount of time later, that same friend was in my living room during another strange occasion where my mom actually let me hook my game to the TV in the living room. And they sat there with me for all of the like 2.5 hours or whatever it took to beat Ruby WEAPON by miming Bahamut Zero over and over. I remember we all jumped for joy when I saw that red wire-frame and heard that whoosh sound.

I've played Final Fantasy VII through on all the devices I've owned it on through the years, and I have to admit: I don't enjoy the game much anymore. I think it's because I'm still chasing that middle school high I got back then. And as I got older, I started analyzing things more and I see why my young mind was so enthusiastic about this game, and made inferences about why my older mind would've never like this game if I was 39 in 1997.

So play it for the first time, play it again, love it, hate it, mod it.... just don't downplay it's significance.
Imagine one of your team mates is the bad guy's dad "after a series of scientific experiments involving the cells of the extraterrestrial lifeform", that'd be pretty wild right? Lmao.

The game runs well on the Steam Deck, but you need to do some additional controller tweaks beforehand.  First, you'll need to manually activate the mouse (hold Steam button while using the right trackpad) to get beyond the config screen.  Then, you'll need to map the X key (from the keyboard) to a button (I did it to one of the back buttons) to get beyond the screen where it shows you what the keys on the keyboard do; this is different than pressing the A button for "OK."  I also had to map the PgUp and PgDn keys to the shoulder buttons, and lastly, I had to map the Insert key to one of the other back buttons (needed for squats in Wall Market).

After that, I didn't need to do any additional manual button mapping, but that might change later on.  But otherwise, this plays fine on the Steam Deck from my experience.

The title speaks for itself. This a fantastic game, played for many hours upon its release (1997). 27 years later, it is still absolutely fantastic and addictive to play. For any younger players, do not be put off by the dated graphics. This one of those games that you will never forget.

Final Fantasy VII is my favourite game of all time. I played it when I was in junior high and it was the most fun I have ever had playing an RPG. Everything about this game was monumental. The graphics, the scope, the music, the plot, game play mechanics - everything was so next level my young mind was blown. I played it on the Playstation so I was able to enjoy the truly monumental OST that's just as good as the game. I had beat the game maybe three times on the playstation and until recently it was firmly part of my past. 

I always wanted to replay it in a modern sense but it's just ridiculously dated I didn't want to tarnish the memory. The new remake came out and it deviates from the story significantly and adds so much fluff to pad out a single game into three full games so I decided to not play it. Still, I wanted me some FF VII. The other day I read about a mod called COSMOS which upscales all of the background and world graphics while adding in extra art to make it truly widescreen. I thought I would just check it out for maybe 30 minutes and that would be that. 

Well, I found 7th Heaven while looking into getting the COSMOS mods to work and it made it so ridiculously easy to download and configure a bunch of mods which now is giving me that remaster experience I have always wanted. I really feel like the modding community for FF VII is one of the most dedicated communities and I am enjoying the fruits of their labour extensively. So, the graphics and music are all overhauled but also the ridiculous amount of quality of life changes and enhancements are amazing like being able speed up time to not waste your life grinding through battles to level up and get that sweet dosh. I am currently playing with 12 mods. 

Final Fantasy VII modded to hell and back is the definitive experience for me of the game and I am so happy I read that article that took me down this FF VII mod rabbit hole. I am now replaying my favourite game of all time just the way I wished it would be some day. 

Also, The OST remake by FinalFanTim is absolutely phenomenal. 

I am having so much fun it is ridiculous.

Aerith Gainsborough (Japanese: エアリス・ゲインズブール, Hepburn: Earisu Geinzubūru), transliterated as Aeris Gainsborough in the English releases of Final Fantasy VII and Final Fantasy Tactics, is a character in Square's (now Square Enix) role-playing video game Final Fantasy VII. She was designed by Tetsuya Nomura with influence from Yoshinori Kitase, Hironobu Sakaguchi and Yoshitaka Amano.

She is one of the main characters of Final Fantasy VII, a young woman allied with the eco-terrorist organization AVALANCHE. Over the course of the story, AVALANCHE begin to pursue the game's antagonist Sephiroth, and the player learns that she is the last surviving Cetra, or "Ancient", one of the planet's oldest races. She is ultimately murdered by Sephiroth. She has also appeared in the Compilation of Final Fantasy VII and Kingdom Hearts series.

She is voiced in Japanese by Maaya Sakamoto. In English, she is voiced by Mandy Moore in Kingdom Hearts, Mena Suvari in Kingdom Hearts II and Final Fantasy VII Advent Children, Andrea Bowen in Crisis Core: Final Fantasy VII and the Re Mind DLC of Kingdom Hearts III, and Briana White in Final Fantasy VII Remake and Crisis Core: Final Fantasy VII Reunion. Aerith and the events surrounding her death in Final Fantasy VII have been met with overall positive reception from critics and fans.

GREETINGS FINAL FANTASY ENJOYERS, JRPG lovers and gamers from all over the world!

After finally defeating the impossibly evil war criminal in Final Fantasy VI, it was high time for me to ride the train to the modern classic that the masterpiece Final Fantasy VII (FF7) is said to be.
This is the first time I play a FF game "as-is", as the previous 6 entries I played are from the Pixel Remaster collection.

This time around, we transition into the 3D era, in a sci-fi fantasy setting as Cloud, a merc hired by some terrorist group called Avalanche. From here on we embark on a peculiar journey that still goes in the save the world direction again, but the approach is wildly different.
This time it feels a lot more character drama centric, much more than the previous entry. Clouds entire backstory, his dynamic with Tifa & Aeris, Barrets & Cait Siths character development; the entire cast is pretty endearing and always developed in a way or another (be it side quest, or main story progression). I really liked this story, it was wild, awesome, relatable, entertaining, endearing and sad all at once, a true roller coaster that I will probably never forget.

My main gripe with the game was mostly the shoddy translation. Specific moments in the game really confused me, and some times the dialogue was super weird, so I dug a bit into it. In my opinion, Tifa & Barret really got done dirty by the translation and sometimes feel like completely different characters, what a shame. It doesn't detract much from the story in the overall grand scheme of things, but it's still a shame to know this, as the "original character" was altered. Hopefully this isn't a problem in the Remake.

Gameplay sees yet more changes from the previous entry: the Summon system is gone, relics are also gone and the party size is reduced to 3. Instead of the summon system we get the Materia system. Now each piece of gear can have materia attached to it and each materia adds skills, spells or buffs. Yet another fun mix and match system that encourages experimentation :) anyone in your party could be the tank, or the summoner, or the healer.
Visually the game is really good. In this 3D era instead of pixel backgrounds, we get prerendered backgrounds and instead of sprites we have characters with three dimensional models, made of polygons!
The environments are really impressive and very varied ranging from sci-fi steampunk-y cities to simple fantasy towns, gorgeous nature vistas to whatever the heck the ancient city is. They look really good and set a really nice mood, much more than similar games of the era like Resident Evil which used more or less the same techniques (I believe).
Despite the game being over 25 years old now the low poly models, still have a lot of charm. I initially found them rather cutesy and wonky but with time I got really attached to how they looked. The monsters however sometimes look downright terrifying, sheesh, thank goodness they're only some polygons on a screen!
There's a few animated movies/cutscenes (FMVs) and they look really good, my guess is that where all the budget really went to. If I'd see these back in the day I'd probably have my mind blown.

As far as music goes, I think this might be one of Nobuo Uematsu's greatest works. I completed the game in a little over 33 hours and somehow I still didn't get burned out by the battle theme (which in some entries got really grating even though it was remastered). Some pieces are eerily captivating, despite invoking some intense feeling of dread when hearing them, there's still something that draws me to listen more. Really good overall!
Favourite pieces in no particular order: Let the Battles Begin!, Cid's Theme, One-Winged Angel, From the Edge of Despair, JENOVA COMPLETE.

Overall, this is a great game, I think the story beats will be enjoyed the most by JRPG veterans as they're done really well. It can be definitely enjoyed as a first entry too, however as the plot doesn't stray that much from the essence of Final Fantasy. A great game throughout, 10/10 pls give it a shot, or play the remake idk if it's good I'll get to play that one day too.

1.10.2024 Big Major Edit: 

So my opinions about this game have always been kinda weird. I stand by what I said in 2021 but with a huge asterisk: I did not enjoy FF7 on initial playthroughs. It took me a very long time not to hate this game. I always thought it was over-rated garbage until I played it in a particular way and then I enjoyed it. But when I started to replay it recently, I realized the game really just is not fun until the point where you're able to recruit Yuffie.

Why do I say all this? Because literally the only way I can enjoy this game is to have Yuffie and Cid in the party. FF7 was made in a time when game dialogue varied depending on who was in your party when they reached such-and-such cutscene. This was much more of a Thing in the days before mo-cap and voice-acted cutscenes, and is also present in FF6 (and to a lesser extent, in 8). It's a shame that this sort of thing ended because depending on the characters you have in the party, the game feels radically different. It's the same story, but many serious cutscenes are rendered absolutely hilarious if you have certain characters in the party. Not every moment of weight or seriousness is completely abandoned but the entire tone of the game is much lighter with Yuffie in it. Queen.

I think the problem I have is, I'm not a man; I've gone through existential crises but the desire to be Mr. Ubermensch is one borne of male ego, which is something I've never possessed. For all its subversion of male fantasies FF7 still manages to play one completely straight, and that is that Cloud is a chick magnet who still ends up with the fanservice character by the end. I am glad, however, that the game contains the Wall Market sequence, that it hammers home that super soldiers are only made through horrific bioweapons experiments, and that you can take Barret on a "date" in the Gold Saucer - like the game clearly wants to make fun of escapism and tough guys, but it never takes it far enough imo. 

idk, it's not a bad game by any means. Probably the best thing that happened to the series if only because it spawned several of my favorite FF entries, and Sephiroth's popularity apparently convinced the devs to go harder on courting the female demographic. FF7 crawled so FF8, 9, and 10 could run. It's still pretty memorable and feels very much like one of the 2D entries, especially 6, which never ever slows down to give you a damn break.

I say it's still very much worth playing, but as someone whose first FF was 10, I just wasn't that wowed the first time I played it - and no, it had nothing to do with the graphics; my first video game console was an N64, and I feel like FF7's ugly graphics have a certain charm to them nearly 30 years later. It's still spectacular, it still has a lot of fun set pieces and bosses. I wish the series had stayed turn-based with gigantic casts of supporting characters. Half the fun of 7 is the supporting cast - but it feels like nobody really understands this, not even Squeenix themselves.

Anyway, it's a pretty solid game, I would recommend it if you can grab it on sale.

I think every gamer has one. That one first game that essentially ensured that the rest of their lives will be in some way centered around gaming. Whether it was an emotional event of a game or the shared experience with someone else as the game progresses or the story, characters, puzzles and/or battles found within the game, it does not matter. That specific game, though it varies throughout the community, will always be very important throughout that individual's life. 

For me, that game was this one. Although it is now a bit of a relic of the past when compared to the scale at which games are made now, it will always have a special place within me. What I have played through in Remake is amazing so far and I'm glad to see a lot of things were left alone. Whatever differences exist between Remake and this, I'd like to think of those differences as another person's point of view of the story they tell or a version of the story to could have been move back then had the current level of technology been available to the original developers. Nevertheless, FFVII is still a classic masterpiece which I believe that everyone should play through at least once. It has great unique characters, a rich story, and a vast set of environments to be explored. Go at your on pace, try to speedrun it, play for the first time blindly, follow any of countless walkthroughs, use any of the mods that are available and suggested by others, or just talk to everyone and explore every single space. How you play, similar to life, is up to you. It is and becomes whatever you make of it.

If Final Fantasy VI was basically just a group of wizards pushing a game system to its absolute limit in terms of capabilities, Final Fantasy VII is more akin to a ramshackle amalgamation of jankily implemented ideas, held together with old bits of duct tape. Despite how the latter option sounds though, it also fits the kind of gameplay experience that I have a certain fondness of, never being short of ideas whatsoever, just throwing more weird stuff at the wall and watching it lightly come apart at the seams, all tied together with the rest of the game going all out in making setpieces that feel utterly massive in scope. The game in general feels really big in a way that led to it having this effect where I'd often feel the need take big breaks in between play sessions and almost dread returning, but then I'd pick it up again and become enthralled all over again, and by the end I felt pretty confident in this being something that's almost as amazing as people have said for quite some time.

The game strikes this great balance of being incredibly goofy for a lot of its runtime while still maintaining just enough elements of self-seriousness to keep you engaged in the actual narrative going on. Time and time again, the stakes of what's broadly going on around the player is contrasted by a lot of funny character interactions, especially from Cloud, who continues trying to appear very solemn but ends up just being really awkward and a bit in over his head, especially with some of the dialogue options you get in the first half of the game. I really like the way that the game being so consistently off the wall in the first half also works at making the big turning point of the game hit so much harder once all of this is torn away, leaving some moments of levity, but having them be very few and far between.

In terms of the core gameplay, I felt that this took some interesting steps forward to the systems found in FF6, especially with how Materia feels like an evolution of espers in a lot of regards, and one that I like a lot more. One of my biggest problems with the mechanics of FF6 was the way that the espers essentially meant that all of your characters could do anything as long as you put a bit of time in to grind those abilities, limiting the sense of mechanical individuality each character would have outside of their core special ability. While at a glance, the ability to assign any materia to anyone seems to have the same effect, the limited materia slots each character can have will leave each party member in a certain role of your choosing anyway, since there aren't really enough slots to be able to let everyone do everything. This is further bolstered by the stat changes that the materia gives when equipping it, often lowering a couple of stats while raising others, giving a nice layer of strategy to team composition. I like this as a way to make each piece of new equipment feel a bit more interesting and exciting as well, as the more powerful pieces of gear will often come with more materia slots as well. This makes getting better gear not just feel like a statistical bonus, but an opportunity to further expand upon your battle strategy and team complexity.

The combat itself is rather easy for the most part, but provides sufficient enough roadblocks for players who try completely turning their brains off and mashing through everything, it feels comfortable, yet rewards a bit of thought as well. This leads to there being nothing in the main game that requires any grinding as long as you're smart about things, which is especially nice, given that for the first time in the FF series, the random encounters feel sparse enough to almost never be intrusive, which makes the exploration feel more fun. I also love the limit break system, not only for the spectacle of it all, but also with how it manages to make enemies using powerful attacks feel exciting, as while you're obviously damaged and now likely in a rough position, you're a lot closer to being able to unleash something big of your own, making for a wonderful bit of give and take.

This isn't to say that the combat is flawless however, as there are definitely some issues that became increasingly annoying as the game went on. I feel like with each passing game, the ATB system has felt more intrusive and annoying, with this being the peak of that for a few reasons. The reason why I thought this was a neat system in FF4 mainly was because of the little quirks in the character loadouts that specifically played out in ways that wouldn't translate quite as well in pure turn based gameplay, such as making twincast feel cooler because of its slowly charging bar, but by FF7, an instance of this stuff is almost nowhere to be seen, making it feel superfluous at best. These issues are exacerbated by the UI, as while it's visually appealing, it's so big that it barely shows any actual information either. This is most egregious when you need to scroll your inventory for an item and only 3 of them can be shown on screen at once, leading to a lot of scrolling while the enemies are still able to keep attacking, it just feels awful all around, and while the other abilities you can use aren't quite as egregious as this, it's a common problem that becomes especially frustrating once you're far enough in the game that this can become very costly. Other elements of the UI that felt bothersome were the way that targeting had a tendency to be quite finicky due to the shifting camera angles and fact that there aren't really any strong bits of feedback to let you know what you're targeting unless you press a separate button to bring up another element that clutters the screen more.

The game is still very fun despite these issues though. The constant minigames were always a highlight to me, especially with the way that no matter how simple something seemed, it was actually horribly broken in one way or another. While I get that not everyone's sentiment would quite be the same as mine here, I couldn't help but smile whenever one of these appeared and brought forth a new frontier of barely functioning nonsense. After all, how can you not at least find a bit of comedy in your ascent up to one of the most significant moments in the narrative having a random snowboarding section that controls horrifically? It's not just the jank that I find endearing in the game though, as the game can pull off some absolutely fantastic bits of spectacle when it wants to, with the fearsome power of the Weapons being especially notable, easily standing out as one of the coolest things in any of the Final Fantasy games up to this point. Thanks to them, along with a few other specific points in the story, disc 2 ends up being this constant thrill, overcoming the one other big issue I had with FF6, that being its largely uninteresting 2nd half.

This game is just awesome, everything feels so big and flashy, with the summons especially benefiting from this. The experience is undoubtedly a bit of a mess, with the seams being very visible all over the place, along with there clearly being some ideas that were added very late into development and ended up being visibly half-baked as a result, but what we got here is still a phenomenal achievement.

A classic among classics. To this day, FFVII remains one of my favorite games of all time, and its influence has had far-reaching effects on JRPGs and games since. It was pretty enjoyable to play this game again and get every last achievement. 

Since I still had to beat the Ruby Weapon and Emerald Weapon superbosses, I decided to let that be the first thing I do for the new year. With two sets of Magic Counter+Knights of the Round on Cloud and Mimic on Yuffie and Cid, it ended up being pretty overkill and each boss only got a few attacks in and no one was ever KO'd in battle. I also managed to not have Ruby Weapon use Whirlsand on any of my party members, so I think this was my first time beating Ruby without losing anyone. The theorycrafting potential in this game is fantastic and I've yet to see its equal!

However, I admit that the game feels a bit clunky now, and this port isn't particularly great, but it doesn't detract too much from it. I just wish the controller support was a bit better considering its original was from a console. The fact that Steam Cloud has been a thing for many years and Square-Enix never utilized it, instead favoring their own cloud save service that's inferior, makes me disappointed. I don't trust SE to always keep the service running.

FFVII gets 10/10 from me, and this port gets an 8.5/10.

Cold game.

14 hours in:
I am a little tired of the battle and enemy spawn systems. It starts to feel repetitive to me. However, that's probably my biggest grudge of the game. Other gameplay elements are great. It feels exciting to see my magic get more fabulous, and my weapons deal more damage. I love the story, I love the settings, and I love the music. Holy shit the music is fire. I just made my first visit to the Cosmic Canyon and this area is so beautifully designed.

57 hours in:
Beat Sephiroth.
I can now say for certain that I love Final Fantasy VII. It's a very long game, but not exactly too-repetitive. I did barely any pure-leveling outside of chasing the main story objective. As I said before, I get tired of the game here and there, but I am always motivated to pick it back up, because the story is simply intriguing. The final fight with Sephiroth has to be the best boss fight in the entire series. After dying in his second phase for 3-4 times, I became horrified of him. I even start to question myself: Is this guy even beatable? How is he this tanky and powerful? But after I did some extra leveling, and changed up my strategy to focus on survival rather than damage output in the fight, I easily strained him out and beat him. 

The reason I enjoyed this fight so much is that it taught me a very valuable lesson. Challenges are always more imposing than they really are, and the hardest part is to accept the difficulty at-hand and confronting it head-on. Once you are able to face those hurdles candidly, you will find that those hardships aren't nearly as imposing as they are.

Thank you, FF VII.

One of the best RPGs, no, *games*, of all time. The story is beautiful, the characters are so memorable and fun and *real*, the OST is jaw dropping, and the world building is some of the best I have seen. The combat is also quite innovative and still holds up very well unlike most JRPGs from this time (coming from someone who struggles to get into these kinds of games), primarily because it isn't turn based. Only real complaints are that this particular port requires not only a constant internet connection but also a Square Enix account. Also, the visuals have aged quite poorly, particularly the models, but I personally am able to look past that. If you can't, then there are plenty of mods that upgrade the visuals, increase resolution, increase framerate, etc. Anyone into story driven games or RPGs in general must play this game.

Let me start by saying how special this game actually is to me and how dearly I hold it to my heart. It was the very first game and story I ever truly fell in love with as a kid on a PS1 that inspired me as a person through and through from personality to aesthetic; only falling a tad bit behind by it's prequel PSP title, Crisis Core that paved even more of an inspiration and influence through the main character. Without any spoilers involved and going on a long winded rant... In every way, shape and form; Final Fantasy VII is a god send of a game with a colorful, deeply developed lovable cast that made way for an entire shift in the RPG genre as a whole that I strongly feel everyone should experience once in their life, FAR more than the Remake which will never hold a candle to with it's ridiculously, slap in the face leveled story shift decisions.

As sappy as it is in my review, I'd like to give a huge thank you to old school, Squaresoft. Even if you're now a memory in the shadow that is corporate, money greedy Square Enix; where you stood holding heart that's no longer there in modern day, you made these revolutionary stories that gave two whole generations everlasting stories with life lessons and single handedly gave a reason for at least one person to beat their depression and continue living onward with this amazing title.

P.S. If you're looking to play it for the first time, be sure to pick up the 7th Heaven Mod Launcher for HD Textures, recompiled music / ambience and the Echo-S Voice Mod performed by the most talented group of unpaid voice actors that deserve far more credit than they receive for the best experience. It also tracks Steam Achievements!

One of the greatest stories in video game history and the single most influential JRPG game of the modern era. Almost every design choice in this game is top notch (except for minigames). In the modern day with some mods to increase fidelity and make the experience up to date with other FF games (60fps, new textures and cinematics, gameplay tweaks, true turn based battle) this game is better than it ever was on the PS1. The shadow this game casts on the industry is among the top heavyweights of gaming history.

I LOVE THIS GAME. The story, the characters, the world, the set pieces, the combat (though that's a little more subjective-- depends on if you like ATB gauges). I'm picky with my games but I thoroughly believe that almost anyone can enjoy FF7.

Though this game is just as fun without a guide, I do recommend you use one if you don't want to miss anything (unlockable characters, side quests, etc.) Like I was trying to %100 it, but turns out I missed ONE materia early on so I have to do it all again if I wanna get the master all materia achievement...

Anyways, if you think you'll even [i]remotely[/i] enjoy this game-- GET IT!!
It's on every 'best games of all time' list and there's a good reason why.
Greatest game ever made. Period.

A legendary timeless classic final fantasy game. Probably Square's crown jewel. 

With a few mods this version can be transformed into believing this is an amazing unofficial official modern day remastered HD version in terms of improving of the visuals and presentation and other fixes. The pre-rendered background of the environment greatly helps keep the game from looking dated and helps capture the essence of this story. 

The story is interesting, the characters, not just the memorable party members but also the supporting characters, to the npcs you encounter in towns and the antagonists like the Turks are memorable. 

The location settings visited is varied with different landscapes and types of environments that tell its own stories with distinctive themes. From the dark mega dystopian like industrial city of Midgar and underneath the Midgar slums, to travelling to just regular idyllic looking villages, and then to the striking likes of Cosmo Canyon, Icicle Inn, Fort Condor, Rocket Town and the desolate North Corel, to seaside resorts and snowy plains was immersive and the whole experience along with great music captures the imagination of this whole journey.

The gameplay of the ATB(active time battle) system and the enemies is fun and engaging. The materia system of customizing different abilities into armor and weapons and combining for different effects was deep and effective part of the combat was a great system, and so was the levelling up progression of the materias and each characters individual powerful limit skills. 

It of course is a game of its time so there will be many random encounters. There are also events or items that could be missed without knowing about even if you thought you paid attention to all of the details in the game. Furthermore some parts like the Golden Saucer, Chocobo breeding and the Fort Condor battles while fun and enjoyable, it can also be excessively grindy and take much time to achieve the desired result with a lot of backtracking.

The game also has a lot of hidden depth of its symbolism like all Final Fantasy games that are worth looking into understand more of what this game represents.

Playing this with keyboard at first generally worked well even if the screen prompts did not provide clear understanding of the corresponding buttons. However once encountering mini games the experience with using a keyboard degraded to the point it is essential to play with a controller. With a Dualshock 3 controller it was smooth sailing.

Only other sticking point was the requirement to create a separate Square Enix account for specifically only this game.
Still holds up to this day.

This review is not critical of the content of Final Fantasy 7.
This review is critical of Square Enix's poorly conceived and terribly implemented release of this game on Steam.

Launching the game is locked behind a Square Enix account login and there is no way to circumvent this, which isn't and issue by itself, other games have similar systems that don't impede gameplay in any significant way.

The issue is that that Square Enix has shown that they are unable to host and maintain a user account system capable of handling the number of users they are forcing into it.
Their password recovery system does not work as intended.
Their email account confirmation does not work as intended.
their support ticketing system and their password recovery system require personal information that is in no way relevant to most technical issues.
Their system which allows account creation using an existing Steam account results in an account in which users don't know the Email, ID, or Password, preventing a player from using that account with Square Enix products on platforms other than Steam.

The problems detailed above extend well beyond a game from 1997, this issue plagues their MMOs (Final Fantasy 11 and final fantasy 14), their recent official Marvel games, their remake of Final Fantasy 7, and it will affect future releases in an equally horrible way.

This game comes from an Era of where developers cared about their games, almost as much as their own health. Back when they would go above and beyond on every aspect of a game, and kept pushing the boundary of what was possible with the hardware they had. Putting so much content in the game, not for the money, but just because they wanted to make the best game possible. It is hard to give games from that Era anything less then 10/10. And this game is no exception, lengthy FMV's that had quality for the time, a story that had you invested and wanting more, a villain who you love because he is so cool but hate at the same time, and multiple characters to interact with and play with, with mini games and side stories. It is truly a masterpiece of it's time. It is one of those games that you have to experience at least once in your life.

I played this game on modded so rip. This game is one of the most critically acclaimed JRPG of all time and I believe that it certainly does hold up in some aspects. The story is one of the most unique stories I've ever seen in a JRPG, and I definitely believe that this was a factor in FFVII's success as a world renowned game. Essentially no other game has dealt with the theme of environmentalism and whether or not humans are destructive to the planet. This is vastly different from a generic JRPG plot like FFI where you must stop the Evil Chaos from reviving and destroying the world, as the plot is actually Man Vs Nature. What is also notable is the amazing character designs. These are some of the best character designs in the series, but it also helps that they are all written very well. Final Fantasy does a good job with its characters, and making them stand out especially Cloud and Sephiroth. Even though Sephiroth looks like the most evil man alive, his reasoning for doing so is more nuanced than you would think, and seeing some of the characters in the game you may be inclined to agree with him, but Cloud brings a very nice dichotomy to the character that argues otherwise that there is hope which I do like. One thing I will say is that this gameplay sucks big ass, and the graphics are completely terrible. Out of all the other games, this game just looks completely terrible and you can tell. This is why I played with mods. The gameplay is AT system so yeah have fun, they also broke the game by allowing every character to use any kind of materia so pretty much no character is unique other than weapons. But overall I think I would recommend this game for the story alone, as there is no other game like it. I find it interesting how popular this game became, but I do think it is pretty good story wise

Otherwise, no complaints.

[i]Final Fantasy VII[/i] has quickly become on of my favourite JRPGs ever. A game that, honestly, passes the test of time in my opinion. A really intriguing plot about the lengths humanity can go in order to achieve what they want, [b]no matter the consequences[/b]. A game about identity, existential crises, and loss. A genuinely fascinating adventure... that is unfortunately hindered by this release. Because the thing is, no matter how thrilling its plot may be, no matter how exciting its world may be to explore, no matter how fun its combat system may be, and no matter how much content the game may have; if you constantly have to deal with issue, after issue, after another fucking issue,... well, it just kind of ruins the experience, honestly.

So, just as you buy and boot up the game, you'll notice something: You [b]must have[/b] a Square Enix account to even play it. I'm really not a big fan of having to make another account for a game I bought on Steam, so while this wasn't a deal breaker for me... it was a massive disappointment. Then, when you finally access the game, you'll be greeted by a gigantic wall of text explaining the controls. Pretty absurd in my opinion, but please do take a screenshot and keep it close to you, since you can't use a controller here, and while a controller has a limited amount of buttons, a keyboard has... well, just a few more keys I'd say (and no, there's no option to change the key bindings). Anyways, you're playing the game, having a jolly good time and, for whatever reason you decide to Alt+Tab. Congrats! You just froze your PC, being your only option now to reboot it. But you endure through all this and invest... about a dozen hours into the game. So you keep going, but strangely, when you reach a certain area, the screen just... goes black? That's because you were playing the game without manually enabling the W7 compatibility mode, you silly!... And let's just say you decide to take a break from the game and end up uninstalling it from your system. Well I don't know if this is a common occurance, but in my case, [b]Square Enix's cloud save system didn't work[/b]. Thanks to this I lost all my progress back then. The entirety of the first part. About [b]20 hours... Yeah I'm fine[/b].

Believe it or not, this is not a strong "[b]Not Recommended [/b]". It is one of my favourite JRPGs ever, after all. But, if possible, just avoid this version of the game... An old game's re-release (whether a port, a remake, a remaster, or whatever), should be an opportunity to bring the absolute best possible version of said classic title. But in this port's case, you have to add these outrageous issues to the ones the original had (poor translation, odd camera angles, softlocks, weird controls,...).

So yeah, in conclusion, you should play [i]Final Fantasy VII[/i] still... But there [b]must[/b] better ways to experience this absolute PS1 classic...
its ff7, if you dont know why it's great by now then you should stop living life under rocks

Final Fantasy VII is a proper JRPG experience and a revolutionary classic for its time. I personally haven't had much experience with JRPGs sadly. All the games I've played from the genre overall are so few, so I understand that making any judgemental statement regarding its dedicated certain mechanics would be equal to judging a book by its cover. I've yet to form a proper mindset about it, thus I'll avoid making any subjective comments in my review. 

Like I've stated before, Final Fantasy VII is revolutionary for the time it came out and we can easily agree to the fact that it is the most popular PSX game. Its story, along with its world are simply wonderful. The way it makes you feel for the characters in spite of the fact that its localization made by simply one guy is beyond amazing. I simply cannot stop praising Final Fantasy VII's story, universe, and soundtrack, so I'll cut it short and let you enjoy the rest without giving you any major spoilers. Although it's been 25 years since the game came out, the remake is on the horizon and I'm sure there are people out there with low-end PCs that can't handle the remake just like me, thus giving out a major spoiler would be a total dick move. 

I don't think I'm qualified to make an objective comment for its gameplay, therefore the things you're going to read in the next few sentences are ignorantly subjective. It has a great gameplay overall with lots of powers infused in magical objects called "Materia" which makes the gameplay more diverse and interesting. However, if you're aiming for the 100% completion rate, exploration may be a pain in the ass due to random encounters in some areas but keep in mind that the hard work pays off extremely well in the end. You basically end up way too OP that nothing will stand in yours and your party members' way. The special moves of the characters called "Limit Break" are also a great addition and they perfectly balance out things if you're lacking in combat. It's also worth mentioning that a lot of work went into the Summon Materias and they are also as good as Limit Breaks, if not better.

To sum up things without dragging this out any longer, Final Fantasy VII has been a game that I've enjoyed. I've played Crisis Core on my PSP a long time ago and playing this game recently gave me another reason to go through all that again - properly this time!

Is the original FInal Fantasy VII worth playing in 2023? Maybe, maybe not.

I've been playing for 20 hours, waiting to see if the game gets good. Having just finished what was originally disc one's content, can I honestly say that it finally got good by that point? Well, it got better, I guess. Around the 15 hour mark, some of my materia FINALLY started upgrading (materia are placed in slots on your equipment, which in turn equip that character with skills, healing/debuffing/buffing/offensive magic, passive bonuses, summons, etc.), giving me more options and versatility in combat, which up to this point had been rather mundane. The story is JUST starting to sorta get good, but still nothing all that special. There''s been the occasional neat FMV sequence, which I'm sure was really cool in 1997.

I think I might still end up seeing this playthrough all the way to the end... maybe. But this game has been REALLY hard for me to actually get into. Reassigning controls to my Xbox controller was confusing, and so I needed to look up help with that. Navigating 3D character models in pseudo 3D environments that are really just 2D pre-rendered scenes (kind of like a blurry painting) was confusing, and so at times, even WITH the assist feature that marks exits/entrances and SOME interactable objects, I got confused and needed a walkthrough to help me figure out how to get through a particular scene. Eventually after escaping Midgar, it becomes plain how difficult it is to know where to go on the overworld map (so I needed to look up a labeled map). Sometimes the way forward is just super cryptic, needlessly so. The world map is bland and ugly looking. You quickly forget which place on the map is which (seriously, in-game labels for each area might have been helpful). 

But the STORY, people say! The story and story-telling for FFVII was unforgettable, right? Not so much. The plot starts off as a pretty boring 'rebels vs. the big corporation' story with heavy environmentalist overtones. Then it evolves into a slightly less boring story about a different big bad guy with a bone to pick with said corporation, on a quest to basically become a god and wreak epic vengeance on the planet (you start off weak, level and gear up, learn amazing spells and become super powerful, and kill god... format of every JRPG ever). Honestly, I think Kefka from FFVI was a much better villian. Many of the other characters don't even really save the story for me (Ok, maybe Red XIII is kinda cool). Most all the characters are UGLY, for one (really not sold on these crappy looking 3D models... and I've played lots of games from that era that looked a lot better)... and outside the main party, other characters (especially the suits with Shinra) are even uglier or just boring looking. The way the party looks in combat is alright, actually... I really wish that's how they looked during all the story sequences and cut scenes. Apart from maybe Red XIII's brief arc in Cosmo Canyon, none of the character development thus far has compelled me to like or care what happens to any of them. Admittedly, I'd probably like them better if they weren't so ugly, either done with really good pixel art, or if I ever cared to play through the remake... the characters are obviously a lot more expressive there.

The combat? It's Ok, if not really slow. As I said, it's pretty bland until 15 hours or so in. I've got lots of my different starter materia now, that have mostly leveled up at least once, so I'm getting stronger and my combat menu is getting more complicated, offering more depth of strategy (FINALLY). But the menu-ing behind the scenes to set up for combat, super annoying. Your materia set-up on any given character's equipment basically determines that character's role (healer/mage/thief/summoner/etc.). In fact, a character with no materia equipped is largely a blank slate. So, you want/have to change characters? Well, plan on unequipping each materia, one by one, THEN switching out the character, and then re-equipping each of those materia. Got a bunch of epic new equipment from a shop or dungeon? Sorry, those other three characters not currently in your party, if you want to equip the new stuff so you can promptly sell the old stuff, you're going to have to exit the town (if that's even PERMITTED at that point in the story!), as you can only switch out characters on the world map or at certain pre-determined spots in the story (that's right, no equipping instantly upon purchase here).

So, an only so-so story and story-telling, some really confusing gameplay segments that frequently requires having a walkthrough open on my phone's browser, ugly art style and graphics, and lots of clunky menu mechanics (I honestly much preferred the magicite/esper system from FFVI)... I can't in all honesty recommend this game, unless, like I was, you're SUPER curious about it as a historical relic. But don't be like me buying it at full price... get it on a sale.

(PS. No, this is not merely a case of 'he just doesn't like JRPGs.' I love Chrono Trigger. FFVI was an amazing experience. Megaman X: Command Mission was awesome. I thoroughly enjoyed Bravely Default. Xenoblade Chronicles was breathtaking even on the 3DS, and well-written. First experienced most all of these titles as an adult. Yeah, I like JRPGs. I just don't like bad ones. And continuing to play this sub-par JRPG, leaves me wondering why I'm bothering with this, when I could be playing something a lot more fun, like Sea of Stars).

I wanted to play this game for more context to the changes they made to the remake and upcoming rebirth.
While I went in ready to call this game overrated, what I got was a grand adventure that I couldn't put down. Playing every spare second I had over the past week and seeking out all the side content I could find to total a 55ish hour experience over the course of 8 days (I played the midgar section back in 2020 before remake and had some idle time to get to 72 at time of review). It didn't overstay it's welcome and I didn't want it to end! This is rare for me when an rpg goes past about 30 hours these days.

Reviewing one of the greatest or at least most iconic games of all time, 26 years after the US release seems like a pointless task so I'll give quick opinions.

Highlights: The soundtrack gave me chills at every major moment. Sephiroth is a cool, layered villain. The ramp up in power level and new materia was well paced and satisfying. The materia and gear system is great, allowing you to change characters and their role in battles completely whenever you want. I found myself really experimenting with different combinations and very satisfied when I would come up with a new build for a character.

In the middle: Cloud is kind of a dull protag being way outshined by your lively and memorable party members. Although towards the end I was tired of about half of them but continued to love the likeable half. (Halfway through part 2, I was only using Barret, Tifa, and occasionally Vincent.)

Disappointment: So many mini-games that just weren't fun to play, many of which you had to participate in to unlock side content. Sometimes the "platforming" is frustrating, having to move the joystick in one direction to have cloud perform a jump or go up a staircase/ladder in a different direction. Many of the environments are quite ugly today and hard to tell what is even a walkable path. When the pre-rendered environments are beautiful, they clash extremely with the items and characters on screen, sort of ruining any admiration you may have for it.

P.S. It played great on the steam deck (once I switched to a community made button layout). Grinding limit breaks and chocobo breeding/racing and battle square seems less tedious when you are just turning on your steam deck for an hour or so while laying in bed.

Holds up pretty well. Amazing soundtrack, engaging plot and a pretty decent magic/abilities system. 

The controls can be a bit awkward - I tried to play with a controller and the dpad did not work, so I settled for the keyboard and it was generally ok, after remapping some of the controls. A few commands have in-game names such as [SWITCH] or [ASSIST], and those are initially mapped to keyboard keys like delete and insert. For the majority of the game you only need those keys occasionally and it works out fine, but for some of the minigames you would need three hands if you keep this default scheme. 

I played in fullscreen and did not mess with any of the graphic settings in the launcher, and some of the text outside of menus (like store plaques) was completely ineligible. That did not bother me enough to change stuff around in the settings, so I don't know if that can be avoided in this version or not. 

If you don't mind such minor technical problems and can deal with some dated gameplay mechanics such as random encounters, this game is well worth checking out nowadays.
Still in my top 5 all time favorite RPG's to ever play. Nostalgia keeps it at #1. The Remake looks amazing and maybe one day when it's completed (and i finish it), it will rival the original.

Playing Final Fantasy VII for the first time after 2 decades since its release and I knew nothing of the plot except that one big spoiler which I think most gamers know at this point, if not, well, prepare yourself.

Oh and by the way, there’s this weird black screen bug that occurs if you alt-tab while in fullscreen. To fix this, play it in windowed mode.

Story:

You play as a mercenary named Cloud (or change his name to whatever you desire) joining Barret and its eco-terrorist group called AVALANCHE against the megacorp Shinra Electric Power Company or just Shinra, draining the Planet’s Lifestream for energy thus weakening the Planet.

During the journey you’ll meet Aerith, a kind, cheerful, girl who is half-human, half-Cetra. Cetra, an ancient race who look just regular humans that has the power to communicate with the Planet via the Lifestream. Now being the only Cetra left alive, Shinra took an interest with Aerith and kidnapped her. Believing she’s the key in revealing the “Promised Land”.

Over the course of the game, Sephiroth reveals himself who was thought to be dead five years before the game. Your party, now, having a cat and mouse chase with Sephiroth and the president of Shinra right on your trail.

Gameplay:

The game uses the ATB system (Active Time Battle) where you have a bar gauge that determines when will your party members act. When the bar is full, that’s when you’ll choose your course of action. One you’ve chosen an action, the bar gets depleted and must wait again. This adds a bit of layer to the combat and requires quick thinking as your enemy won’t wait for you to decide an action. However, there is an option to choose “Wait” mode where your other party members and the enemies bar is paused while you’re trying to decide on what your current active party member do. So it’s your typical turn-based. You have to time it right on whether you’ll attack, heal, buff, debuff etc. Sometimes choosing an action immediately instead of waiting it out can cause you the game especially against the optional superbosses. But the game is easy enough with minimal grinding unless you go for the achievements

The game also uses the Materia system which you can give your party members various abilities and spells. This replaces the class system. I mean, yeah, sure, you can go and give them spells and commands that’s appropriate based on their design but where’s the fun in that? You want to go with a physical build for Aerith? You definitely can. Depending on what materia you equipped, it’ll give you stat bonuses. Leveling some of them up will give you new spells and abilities.

With all that said, my time spent with this game was one for the books. It definitely didn’t age well in terms of graphics and the quality of life changes from games that came after it but if you can look past that, it’s a worthwhile journey.

As a Final Fantasy fan, this game was the very first one in the series I ever played. I got it back in the 90s and played it a good amount on my family's first proper PC computer, and it was brilliant; I probably would have enjoyed this just the same on the PlayStation if my family had gotten that console before the PC, but I digress. It was so good, it was the one that hooked me into the Final Fantasy series itself.

The game, while somewhat dated, is still a pure gem and still works well on modern systems. The combat remains fun and engaging, with the materia system a sweet part of augmenting the characters for battles. The game world is enjoyable to explore, the mini-games and side activities are fun (such as the motorbike section), and the cutscenes are brilliant to watch as I remember them.

The game has a good pace to it, and some of the later battles, including some of the more trickier boss fights, are worth the effort of doing. The music is also memorable - the battle music gets me a lot - and it has its nice quirky moments, such as the bleeped swears of Barrett, the blocky nature of the characters in the game world, and the three variations of Bahamut you can summon.

While I do like to get my hands on the FFVII Remake eventually, this is a must-have game for any player. Just as Top Gear says owning an Alfo Romeo is essential to be a true petrolhead, owning the original Final Fantasy VII, amongst some of the other games from the 1990s, is essential to becoming a true gamer.
