Look, there are a lot of things bad about this game. The character models are hideous, the background graphics are bad resolution, the mini-games have clunky controls, some of the text was awkwardly translated, and the combat has some questionable design choices. 

It should tell you something that despite all these flaws, the game is considered one of the greatest of all time and is getting a full blown three-part triple-A remake over 20 years after being released. That's because under all these flaws is one of the greatest works of art ever made. The main story and even side stories are deep and emotional. The soundtrack and general atmosphere of the game is very well done. The combat system is simple to understand but allows for an almost infinite amount of creativity.

You may ask, "Is there any reason to play this once the remake is finished?" There are perks to both the original and the remake. The remake will be split across three games, so it will not only cost more for the remake, but also likely take a lot longer to experience the full story since it is very drawn out. That being said, the remakes have a lot more content in total, and have better graphics and writing. Their more detailed graphics also lets the remakes better convey minor details, like subtle character expressions. The original is almost certainly easier, and focuses more on turn-based strategy rather than real-time action that the remakes use. I think it is mostly up to personal opinion, but if you play the remakes and enjoy them, I'm sure you would also enjoy seeing the original vision of the game. I will always prefer the original, mostly just for nostalgia.

The port of the game has a few flaws. I cannot find a way to rebind the controls when using a physical controller, even using a couple of different ones. I've also noticed a few slight errors, such as music changing prematurely, or text being out of alignment. The port does have some improvements over the original PlayStation version, like allowing way more saves, and fixing some of the typos. This PC port gets the job done, but playing the game on an original PS1 or on the latest PlayStation might be better if possible.

A 10/10 story to go with an otherwise 8/10 game that's held back by so many poor design choices that make you wanna play literally anything else (I'd rather go dodge 200 lightning bolts). I swear to God, platforming and QTEs in this game are the most frustrating things ever. It shouldn't take 2-3 random encounters to get Cloud to climb a fucking ladder. And even if they removed the awful gun drills, snowboarding, "DODGE THAT PUNCH!", and other terrible forced mini-game sequences from the game, people will still defend this game with the "it was good for its time" excuse when there are other games like VI that did a lot of things better and call it a masterpiece. Hell, XIII has the same battle system but better (even with autobattle spam), even better than VIIR. But all you hear about is complaints about the linearity which for XIII is only the first 16 hours of the game, but for X, is basically the entire game. But which one do you hear about being a "masterpiece"? FF fans have their standards all over the place and clearly don't know what the hell they want and that's exactly why the devs gave you Devil May Fantasize XVI

All VII did differently from VI was 3D. False marketing drew a lot of people in to what would be the first FF for them and that's what a lot of people ended up sticking with. So when we say "for its time", that really only applies to the graphics and 3D was a really big novelty back then

Final Fantasy VII...The least favourite of mine.

FFVII is an alright game, it came out at an odd time for me so I never actually sat down and gave this one a chance, VIII and IX in my opinion shat all over this one and to say there is only 1/3 years between VII and IX the graphical difference is insane. VII really seemed to struggle with the hardware (Understandable psone was only in it's infancy) however VIII and IX seemed to where the hardware had peaked and that made me want to go to them more. I wasn't interested in the stories, I just loved FF games at that time...Roll forwards 25 years and here I am once again going through most of the Final Fantasy games to see what exactly I missed the first time around and I gotta say...it's alot! The whole Crisis Core thing with Zack! The fact FFVII is slapbang in the middle of it's timeline is why I love the idea of it being remade because I never played Crisis or Dirge of cerberus so hopefully the remake will mesh these two together cos there are a lot of plot points that are missed in VII that im sure Crisis core will explain.

FFVII begins in Midgar, not a very exciting area, just 8 Mako reactors surrounding a devious corp known as Shinra. You play as Ex-soldier Cloud Strife and join a band of misfits known an AVALANCHE and you cause chaos in your first 10-15 hours in Midgar. Upon leaving and going out into the open world you're tasked with chasing your idle - Sephiroth, who seemingly has gone mental. There's lots of talk about Ancients and Sephiroth being of a higher power and Hojo pulling strings. Getting to know a ton of party members like Yuffie and Vincent (nobody likes the cato).

All goes to shit relatively quickly and it's one hell of a bender to get your head around but being older it all makes fucking sense now and it's actually a damn good plot and it plays out really well, I enjoyed it. It still isn't to die for but for it's time it sounds good and the game plays out the way the stories tells it rather than jumping all over the place for no reason. There's just so much to this game it's ridiculous. For it's time ofc.

Graphically - as stated above, they're not the best the polygons are massive and it's what pushed me away on it's release but they have a charm too them now and it's likeable.

Sounds - Like most FF's the soundboards for spells and summons and insufferable but it's understandable with the soundboards they had at the time and again I find it oddly charming to hear such shit in 2023.

Features - Having played FFVII on the PS4 I half expected there to be features like 3x speed or auto battle but I was disappointed to find this version has none of that for some strange reason, so I had to play the old fashioned way...avoid spells and summons that take minutes upon minutes to cast just to do 9999 or something I could have done using a simple ATK command...shame they were missing. Now you can Mod these features in and I was going to using 7th Heaven but I was already on Disc 3 by the time I had found the mod and I didn't wanna corrupt my save or have to start a fresh file so I persevered.

Materia - This games strongest point, If I was playing at 3x speed I would have experimented more with magic and summoning but due to lack of wanting to watch an animation for 10mins for minimal damage I only used Purple and Yellow Materia really so all my party members were heavily melee oriented and I still managed to beat all the bosses and superbosses before I hit level 99 or did any stat farming in the Sunken ship.

The Magic - There are so many different spells in this game compared to most others and they upgrade in good time with the story too, the spells powering up felt similar to that of FFX you grind and grind to a point and get Thunder 2 or Thundera at certain points and it helps massively. 
The sheer volume of spells i'd not seen in other FF games is insane not the mention the blue magic spells which are just as over powered as regular spells, why Square decided to cut down on all these extra spells and summons i'll never know, there's 3 types of bahamut in this game and I loved watching all 3 animations not to mention Knights of the Round a summon i've never seen anywhere but here and it's just amazing to watch those damage numbers man!

The music - Time after time Final Fantasy is known for it's score and it is no different here, there are some belter tracks with this games soundtrack like most FF games, VII has some top tier music!

Overall - FFVII is a gem, I still don't favour it over say FFVIII or IX because it doesn't come close to them games, not for me. But VII is a good game for it's time and the amount of content and different things you can do with your characters is phenomenal given titles of late that don't come close to this level of freedom. 
The amount of grinding VII expects from you to get 100% achievements is also not even near as bad as VIII and IX they are much much worse.
FFVII is even easier than most FF's, you can literally just use Atk command on most enemies and the game will win itself, the only time I found myself needing to pick out a strat was vs Emerald and Ruby and when entering the final dungeon the first time as some enemies have death strike and such other status effects that will make that walk in the park turn into a sudden game over for no reason.

I'd give this a 7/10 - The features being missing is the biggest flaw for me, I could a had this done in 20-30 hours but instead i'm treading on 50 due to the time wasted flying, running and doing battles all in 1x speed.
If I were to go again at some point I would be using 7th Heaven and taking full advantage of all the mods on hand.

Considering the disaster the original release PC port was considered, this Steam release is pretty good. About the only problem we had was the controller support, but you can just play the game with keyboard anyways. Really get that "playing an almost 30 year old PS1 RPG on PC" experience.

Beautifully written game. Tackling themes like the crimes of corporations & militaries, climate crises, and the loss of self-identity. There are less characters than VI, but the development of each character is a lot better along the way. Definitely recommend having a sidequest guide because there are serious story beats you can miss along the way.

Gameplay? It's fine. It's a more simplistic use of the ATB system than VI, and while the characters feel more unique personality-wise, gameplay-wise there's little difference. Some characters are ranged, some characters are a little tankier. Ultimately, you just put whatever Materia you want on them since any character can have any ability. Basically becomes "bring along your fave" in terms of choosing your party. The real downside of the battle systems is the summons. They're your best attacks late-game but they're also just unskippable minute long cutscenes. Definitely recommend putting a podcast on or something so you're not just staring into space watching the same animation for the millionth time.

Stuff like that makes the game feel dated, and it's a specific kind of dated. It's the dated of making a killer app for the PS1. A lot of time is spent making full use of them fancy 3D graphics. The pre-rendered environment backgrounds are beautiful, but also sometimes incomprehensible. What are the exits? Where do you go? Ramps will hide in the backgrounds of walls. Some minigames are just basic 3D polygons being thrown together, making stuff like Fort Condor entirely unappealing to look at. There's also this weird thing the game does of making you press certain buttons for certain minigames. Why does one make me use Switch to fire a gun, but another uses Accept? Well, probably to get new users used to the PS1 controller, but now it's just weird and makes me spend extra time on each minigame figuring out what buttons I'm even using.

Overall, though, the game's good! It's a classic, of course it's pretty good. Where it lacks in gameplay, it makes up for with an emotional core and a memorable cast.

Finally, a huge shoutout to the walkthrough we used by bover_87: https://gamefaqs.gamespot.com/ps/197341-final-fantasy-vii/faqs/71240/introduction Fantastic walkthrough for this game, no cutscene spoilers, plenty of information on when sidequests are available, detailed bestiary,  even points out stuff you can miss forever, this thing's got it all

This has been my favorite game since I was young. It features a great story with a minimum 40 hours of active game play time (that's if you're just hitting the basics and are not doing fun side quests or retrieving additional characters). It boasts one of my favorite video game music scores as well. If you can enjoy the graphics for how revolutionary they were at the time, and look past how they stack up now, I think you would really have fun with this game. I highly recommend it for those of us with less hand function or with needs that require slower game play. The customizable settings, as well as battles consisting of selecting choices from a list and a hitting a single key, makes it so us gamers with different needs can enjoy this as well. If you're photosensitive, I do not recommend this game. There are blindingly bright, drastically changing, and some flashing lights (though it's not true strobe lighting) throughout this game. If you're hearing impaired, this game is absolutely accessible. There's no audible dialog, so all speaking and game information is printed on screen, and all play through queues are visual.

As good as I remember it being

Final Fantasy VII is my personal favorite from the series and easily the most iconic... a great place to start for newcomers! 


[h1]{ Gameplay } --- 8/10: Very good[/h1]

Its gameplay is pretty simple on face value, but there's a lot more depth than what most would give it credit for, especially for its age!

The Good:
     • The Materia system is absolutely incredible, and allows for near limitless combinations
     • Fun environmental "puzzles"
     • Allows for a decent variety of play styles
The Bad:
     • General combat can be kind of "meh" at times
     • Random encounters happen far too often, even for a veteran player


[h1]{ Difficulty } --- 5/10: Generally easy[/h1]

Because Square felt that some audiences might not finish the game if it was too difficult, they made this one a helluva lot easier. That being said, by today's standards it may still seem difficult because of how these older games are designed. If you have any clue how to play, it'll be a cakewalk, but if you can't pick up on context clues or expect the game to tell you what to do, you may struggle.

The Easy:
     • You do NOT need to grind, but doing so will always help if you get stuck
     • Fairly intuitive structure, you'll know what to do in gameplay
     • Enemies do NOT scale to your level as you progress, negating challenge as you get stronger
The Hard:
     • Easy to get lost your first time
     • Emerald and Ruby Weapon! These super-bosses can be taken down just fine with a guide and some Materia grinding, but these guys will eat you alive if you go in without the right prep.

Pro-tip: If you want more from the combat, enable "ATB" and slide the Battle Speed all the way to the left!


[h1]{ Music } --- 10/10: Masterpiece[/h1]

There's not a lot to say about Nobuo Uematsu's work that hasn't been said before, but once more, an absolutely iconic soundtrack that defined many people's childhoods. There are some deeply profound tracks, ranging from despairing, eerie, hopeful and epic, to timeless.

Some bangers include:
     • One-Winged Angel (duh!)
     • Cosmo Canyon
     • Cid's Theme
     • Aerith's Theme
     • Reunion
     • Judgment Day


[h1]{ Story } --- 9/10: Unforgettable[/h1]

While not #1 in the series, FF7's endearing cast of characters & hair-raising second and third acts leave you wanting more, while going out on a bittersweet note. While Sephiroth is no doubt a classic villain by now, this is one of those stories where the hero is actually more messed up than the villain. The plot twists near the middle of the game are incredible, and [spoiler]Aerith's death is sure to make you shed a tear.[/spoiler]

Nitpick: It's really easy to miss some of the game's optional story, which is essential to the character of Vincent and [spoiler]why Zack is relevant for Crisis Core.[/spoiler]


[h1]{ Length } --- 30-50 hours --- Lovely![/h1]

The game doesn't pad itself out, but there's plenty of optional side content and adventures that allow you to go off the path if you feel like it.


[h1]{ Graphics } --- 4/10: Not great[/h1]

I've tried getting some of my friends to experience this wonderful gem, but they never get far because of the graphics... and what a shame! They ask me why I'd choose this over the remake, and my answer never lies within the visuals. Though I find it charming since I grew up with the game, I'd be lying if I said that this aspect has aged well, and it's the number one reason that this game deserves the remake it's getting.

The Good:
     • Gorgeous, detailed field BACKGROUNDS
     • Iconic scenery like Midgar and the Northern Cave
     • Beautiful character portraits by Tetsuya Nomura
The Bad:
     • Difficult to interpret where you can and cannot go in the field, if you don't already know
     • Character models look downright goofy at times, making it hard to take things seriously
     • Cutscenes feel jarring


[h1]{ Price } --- $11.99: AN ABSOLUTE STEAL!!![/h1]

Worth every penny and then some. It goes on sale several times per year for about half off, but if you have any interest in this game, you don't have to wait to get your money's worth.


[h1]{ Bugs } --- 2/10: Quirky[/h1]

I played this copy with a mod manager, so I can't speak to how Steam handles it, but I've literally never had an issue with this game. There aren't any gamebreaking bugs, and the only problem I ever had was not being able to leave the "Mime" materia cave. But most "bugs" in this game merely serve to enhance your experience if you know how to exploit them, such as with the W-item glitch. Check 4-8Productions for the crazier ones!


[h1]{ Audience } --- Anyone 10 or older[/h1]

While this game is aimed towards teenagers and young adults, there's little that a middle schooler wouldn't be capable of handling. Many of the mature themes and concepts will be lost on younger children, but there's nothing inappropriate which prevents them from playing.

[h1]{ PC Requirements } --- It turns on[/h1]

I recommend using 7th Heaven to install some graphical and QOL mods for the game, which most modern computers should be able to handle just fine.


All in all, FFVII is a wonderful time, and a must-play for anyone that wants to explore this era of gaming. Doubtless, it revolutionized 3D JRPGs in the 90's, primarily in the west, with it being the first for many, myself included. I'm confident in recommending this game to anyone with the patience to see through its age and for what it hides underneath - a passionate soul, belonging to the artists who made it.

I was born in 1992 and my first time playing this game was during my playthrough of the entire Final Fantasy series I started in 2022.

HOO BOY, this game is fucking wild. I went into things fully aware of the FF7 continuity but never having actually played FF7 before. Gameplay isn't anything crazy or new to the series (I personally dislike the Materia system and find it inferior to F6's relic system) but I was not prepared to experience firsthand how bat-shit crazy the series started getting once Tetsuya Nomura started getting involved. Character designs and backgrounds make less sense than ever before and everything is edgy and depressing. Why is it that Hojo's solution to everything is [spoiler]"impregnate it and inject it with Alien juice"[/spoiler]? Why is everyone in this game suicidal? Why does everything and everyone suck? There are cute/funny moments but everything is just so depressing and shitty. I honestly dislike this game but it's such a well-made and iconic game that I can't bring myself to give it a negative rating.

Overall, this was a cool and convenient way to experience the original Final Fantasy 7. I think I got this for $6 which isn't bad for a piece of gaming history. Once I finish my journey of getting all the achievements in every mainline Final Fantasy game I'll explore the FF7 extended universe/spinoff games.

I feel like this game's cheese is common knowledge by now but I ended up soloing both Emerald and Ruby Weapon with the following: [spoiler] (Knights of the Round + HP Absorb) (Counter + Mimic) (Final Attack + Phoenix) (W Summon)
Cloud starts equipped with this Materia setup and his other 2 teammates already dead. At any point dualcast KOTR and then put the controller down and you will automatically win any fight. In the event that Cloud gets KOd he'll revive the entire party with Phoenix [/spoiler]

Quick:

5/5

What can I say about Final Fantasy 7 that hasn't already been said, and been said better.  Nothing.  There's nothing that I can say about this game that you haven't heard before, or heard articulated in a more impressive fashion.  But, that won't stop me from doing it anyway.  If you haven't played this game, I would suggest that you do it as soon as possible.  Try to avoid spoilers as best you can and experience it first hand.  It is well worth it.


More:

Final Fantasy 7 is a great game.  Most of the praise that this game receives is from a group of people who played it when it first released on the PlayStation in 1997.  Their opinion of the game is colored by nostalgia, yet also accurate in most cases.  The game was a success when it first released, and it still holds up today.  In my case, I did not play Final Fantasy 7 back in my middle-school days, I only played and beat the game when I became an adult.  However, I did spend my summers hanging at my friends house, and watching him play through the the entire game several times.  I did attempt to play the demo once, on a PlayStation demo disc, however it did not excite me.  

As a youngin', I had no interest in turn-based RPGs.  It wasn't until I got older that I actually understood how to play them, and became more invested in the story of a game.  Final Fantasy 7 is not a complicated game.  It does have depth in its mechanics, and the actual game-play part of the game is one of the best even to this day, in my opinion.  The story is convoluted, but it's fun and exciting.  It was way ahead of its time.

The music is great, the story is great, the characters are great... you get the idea.  I usually spend some time going into each separate element of the game, but I'm not going to do that here.  I will just say that I don't remember disliking anything about this game.  It has been a while since I rolled credits on FF7, but my memory of the game is one that suggests it was an all around good time.  

One thing I remember about playing this game was being confused.  The feeling of confusion was ever-present during my play-through.  I only got lost once, and did not know how to progress the story, but I was constantly confused about what was going on in the story.  The story is great, but it could have been told better.  Maybe there are things that were lost in translation or something, or maybe the developers wanted players to play the game several times to actually get a grasp on what was happening.  Either way, this is a nit-picky sort of complaint, because I still had a great time with the game.  

If you haven't played this, the original Final Fantasy 7, then just play it.  I think you're going to like it.

Convoluted nonsensical story, unintuitive combat system, an unlikable protagonist, generally mid-tier dialogue... Why is this a classic again?

The game is still fun as hell, it has some unique mesmerising effect on me still, after all these years. It must be the music, which has always been like the benchmark of game music for me. I have had the soundtrack in my casual listening collection for a decade. I think the visual design is the second reason, but in hindsight the graphics are not good by any means, ridiculous at points, if not obviously dated. There is however just this amazing hand drawn scenery and detail put into places which make you believe the world is real, and I still buy into it. The unique setting and story draw me in, well into a play-through in 2023, and I'm enjoying it. I don't think I could enjoy most of the games I played on the PSX, or in the late 90's now. I don't think many of them had particularly good game play anyways (at least not most), but this one is still recommendable today.  
PRO TIP [i]mod related[/i]: [spoiler] Check out "tsunamods syw launcher" in a Google search, if you decide to get it installed, here are my settings and why. Check "60fps Game" and set the 3D engine to "Vulkan" (this got all the animation frame rates stable for me). This worked perfectly for me, also I would recommend turning on all of the "HD" textures and "Real 16/9". This gives you a easy, on step mod install, to get the whole game running in  HD and at 60fps, nice right! "Dynamic Lighting" and the "Transparent" text box options are also cool, but they all had some display bugs here or there. Finally "Hide Models Moths" and "PSX Musics" get you the more original feel. I would not mess with anything else other than turning on "Steam achievements" Its a pretty easy all in one graphic upgrade mod which keeps the game nice and original otherwise! [/spoiler] Enjoy!

This is it, people. The moment I have been waiting for to show you how much of a fanboy I can be and the moment you have all been waiting for to skip to the last paragraph or the rest of my review due to the excess amount of fanboyism in this review. To those that don't know, Final Fantasy VII is the reason I am a gamer, the reason I fell in love with Role-playing games. I have repeated this game countless amounts of times and I always recount ridiculous stories to my friends of how obsessed I was with it, from losing the original copy of the game and eventually finding a copied version only to hide 5 copies all over my house in case I lose it again, to another story of my brother Hogging the PlayStation from me and playing FFVII Non-Stop, to which I emptied a bottle of water on his PlayStation as revenge. Yes, I was a devil as a kid and a stubborn idiot. But all you had to do was let me play my damn RPGs in peace. I haven't even started to what a masterpiece this was.

I could literally keep on writing as much as I have written up till now but Final Fantasy VII is a very complex game to explore in one review. It is easily one of the best games I have played in my life and is revered as one of the best games of all time. But still, after all that, it is not everyone's cup of tea but for a role-playing game fan, it is a must-have. Final Fantasy VII was remade on the PS5 and the original is already ported and modded on all platforms whether handheld or on PC so it is really tough to miss nowadays. If it is mini-games you want to waste time on or engaging puzzles in convoluted dungeons that you want to get lost in only to succumb to random encounters and fight tough and optional boss fights while customizing your characters to an intricate skill system, Final Fantasy VII is for you. Just beware not to get too involved with it and eventually obsess over it like me in hopes of finding the other games that the developers have created to be as valuable as this game. It is why I called it shitty to begin with simply because it was great once upon a time and eventually became  If it is an anime episode or prequel on the PSP or a spin-off about Vincent, nothing can replace what has already raised the bars to begin with.

Read the rest of the review on my blog: https://jaygamingreviews.wordpress.com/2023/08/11/final-fantasy-vii/

This is so much better than the remake. It's well paced, and you are experiencing a story rather than being confronted with excruciating stretches of filler content that only serve to somehow stretch a 6 hour story into 40. The controls are fast and snappy, you don't need to wait for some stupid animation every time you want to change something in your equipment, the dialogue is to the point and Cloud doesn't act like he was dropped on his head as a baby every time he gets asked a question. Sure it doesn't look as good, but it's just so much more rewarding to play. Makes me wish they had made an actual remake instead of a re-imagination that traps you in a tiny part of Midgar for 40 hours with annoying ghosts.

As long as you're willing to put up with outdated features, outdated graphics, and odd design choices here and there, you're in for a blast. The characters, world, and story have aged phenomenally, and this game is worth playing for those things alone. The combat is still fun even today, especially when you've obtained a new summon or materia that you have yet to try. Final Fantasy is worth every penny and more.

Fantastic game! I only wish there were more of it. The materia system is intuitive and engaging. The mini games are numerous and fun. The boss fights are epic and challenging. The leveling is smooth and grind free. If you like the grind then you have plenty of grinding to do on materia AP which is unnecessary but rewarding if you are trying to create a particular 'build'. The story is interesting and engaging. ON the downside, there are too many long cut scenes and this problem will only worsen with subsequent FF games. There are numerous situations in the game where you can miss important items that will become inaccessible unless you do things in a particular way. Many important items can only be obtained at the very last stage of the game, items that are very useful for beating ruby weapon and emerald weapon. It is strange to go half way to the final boss just for the materia only to double back and then spend a day doing battle squares to get one more materia so that you can run over and beat Ruby while the end of the world is only a day away.  I give this game 8/10.

There are a lot of reviews about how save files delete. I haven't experienced it..and if I do, I will add to this review and auto-thumbs down the game. 

But to me..FF7 has always been the most mediocre RPG example, that is highly overrated. But it was the big one that was the into for a lot of RPG gamers...and that has always been the problem. It set the standard. I respect that and i see the good in it too.

The game is still an enjoyable experience....so I would still recommend it. (Especially over the new style of RPGs and FF games...ugh.) You can easily drop tons and tons of hours into playing it and enjoy every second. Being cheaper than the remake, it wouldn't hurt to give it a try.

But it does have issues through Steam...especially on the controller end. You will have to set up a layout to even work a controller. And I doubt we will even see an update ever since the focus is on the remake. So 4:3 only.

Square has moved on...but what they missed is that this version has style, it has soul, and it has a lot of things that games today don't and will never have. It may be "ugly" but today's graphics standards...but can also be modded to look nicer if you want. Not me...I like the look and feel of it. 

And it is definitely worth a play through.

Classics never die but many game mechanics don't work as well anymore.
FF7 is perhaps the JRPG that most influenced the industry and perhaps the most popular (there's a movie, remake, spin off, I think there's an anime prequel...).

For those who don't know FF7 is a JRPG with ATB (Active Time Battle) battle system, it's similar to a turn system the difference is that the turn counter doesn't stop and some turns are faster and others slower it will vary with the enemy, to make it easier to understand, during the battle if I take too long to choose the move I want to use, the enemy can attack me more than once.

A point that has aged, is the encounter of the battles, they are random, you walk around the map and at any moment a battle appears. You do not see enemies on screen, only in the "arena" of battle.
The game presents the material system (which are the spells) that you equip in your character and can combine to have new effects: ex: Fire + All you will attack all enemies in the arena with fire. Matters also have an Xp system (called Ap) and can increase or decrease the character's attribute: ex: +10% strength or -10% life. There are also Summons, which are invocations that you can do during battle.

The game is from 1997 and visually, you can't demand a game from 97, the graphics were pretty bad, but with MODs you can leave the game with a very acceptable graphic.
In terms of gameplay, some things were pretty bad, some scenarios are difficult to move around or identify the path correct.
The soundtrack is very striking with beautiful compositions.
The story is quite complex and even confusing at times.

"The pain of losing her will forever linger in our hearts."

Cloud Strife, a former soldier-for-hire who joins an eco-terrorist group called AVALANCHE. Their goal is to thwart the Shinra Electric Power Company, a megacorporation draining the planet's life energy. As Cloud becomes entangled in their fight, he discovers his own dark past and a looming threat from the legendary Sephiroth. The journey takes them across the vast world of Gaia, encountering memorable allies like Aerith, Tifa, and Barrett, as well as formidable adversaries. Along the way, they confront personal struggles, loss, and the consequences of their choices. As Sephiroth's true intentions are revealed, Cloud and his companions must unite to save the planet from an impending catastrophe. The plot weaves together themes of identity, redemption, environmentalism, and the power of friendship, delivering a suspenseful and emotionally impactful narrative that has resonated with players for decades.

FINAL FANTASY VII is a timeless masterpiece that takes players on a heroic journey filled with suspense, wonder, and a story that will touch the depths of your soul. While the graphics may be dated by today's standards, the game's captivating narrative and immersive gameplay make it an absolute must-play for any fan of the RPG genre.

Set in the vast and richly detailed world of Gaia, FINAL FANTASY VII introduces us to an ensemble of memorable characters, each with their own unique personalities and motivations. At the heart of the story is Cloud Strife, a former soldier turned mercenary, who becomes entangled in a battle against the oppressive Shinra Corporation and the mysterious threat of Sephiroth. This tale of heroism, friendship, and sacrifice unfolds in a way that keeps players on the edge of their seats from start to finish.

While the visuals may not boast the graphical fidelity of modern games, the art direction and attention to detail still shine through. The world of Gaia is brought to life with a mix of pre-rendered backgrounds and character models that exude charm and personality. The beautifully crafted environments, combined with Nobuo Uematsu's iconic soundtrack, create an immersive experience that draws players deeper into the game's atmosphere.

The gameplay of FINAL FANTASY VII is a perfect blend of traditional turn-based combat and innovative mechanics. The Materia system allows for deep customization, enabling players to enhance their characters' abilities and create unique strategies. The strategic decision-making during battles, combined with the variety of enemies and bosses encountered, keeps the gameplay fresh and exciting throughout the adventure.

One of the most remarkable aspects of FINAL FANTASY VII is its ability to tackle mature themes and thought-provoking subjects. It explores concepts such as environmentalism, corporate greed, loss, and the complexity of human emotions. The game's storytelling is masterfully executed, with powerful character arcs and plot twists that will leave you breathless.

Beyond its main storyline, FINAL FANTASY VII offers a wealth of side quests and optional content that adds depth and replayability to the game. From engaging in thrilling mini-games to uncovering hidden secrets, there is always something new and exciting to discover in this expansive world.

while the graphics of FINAL FANTASY VII may show their age, the game's timeless story, immersive gameplay, and unforgettable characters make it a true gem in the realm of gaming. This heroic and suspenseful journey will captivate your heart, reminding us all that sometimes the power of a well-crafted narrative can transcend the limitations of visuals. Embrace the adventure, and let FINAL FANTASY VII transport you to a world where heroes are born and destinies are forged.

Ok, here's a couple of things that this port really needs:

-Some menus, such as tutorials, tend to double click, skipping parts of dialog. i don't know why, since the menus are 60fps like in the original PS1 version, they also don't look speed up, don't know how to fix it either. (Mods f-up steam features)

-Mouths: remove them, PS1 ver. did not have mouths, and they're bugged in this version (They are permanently waiting to bite on a glizzy (ºOº) ) having an option in the launcher to remove them or binding this to "Original Graphic" option would be cool.

-Some tracks get mixed up, playing a specific song in a place they shouldn't.

-Censorship: the PS1 ver. was barely censoring the silly words, the first PC port censored everything, and this re-release kinda halfway uncensored it? why not uncensor all of it?

-Framerate: i've seen a lot of forums and pages claiming the frame is worse in this version, it's not; 15fps FMVs 30fps Field and 60fps menu, just like PS1 Ver; you can check yourselves with emulators, but with today's tech, it should not be hard for a huge developer to make the whole thing 60fps without doubleclicking bullsht (excluding FMVs i guess)

-Controller support: it's bad, really bad. adding SDL (for ps controllers ) and a more deep Xinput compatibility should've been a minimum from the start, this time and age and with steam pushing support on their own, it's surprising how bad it is.

that's all i can think right now, pretty sure there is plenty more like deleted stuff. 
if modders where able to partially fix some of this stuff themselves i don't see why the actual developer, with access to every file, source code and all that stuff, should take 10 years to fix them...

great game tho.

I'm really disappointed, don't know why everyone gatekeeps this game as a one of the best. Honestly it's one of the worst FF I ever played (the crown of the worst FF still belongs to IV). 

I'am really not a fan of the simplified gameplay, and new gameplay mechanics: 

- characters in team are cutted down to 3 from previous 4,
- gameplay is ultra linear, to the point that world map is unnecessary and frustrating,
- getting a chocobo is now a joke, the luring system sucks hard, 

- the story is so badly written, with so many plot twist, that even main characters don't know what's going on and ask cloud to explain what happened to this point and what is the exact goal of this ridiculous journey. And the game does it just to confuse it even more in next 10 minutes. The game can't decide if it's a cyberpunk game or a copy of "Neverending story" movie. This is definitely product of it's own time, 90s, and moreover, a japanese game, but it aged very, very badly. 

- There's a lot of unnecessary content, you are forced to play stupid mini games, and sometimes win them to get the plot further. Sometimes there's whole locations, NPCs, buildings, cutscenes, dungeons and everything created just for some stupid side event that doesn't matter at all. Completely waste of time, this game is literally too long because of this.

- Sometimes you are stuck, because of badly designed story. You have to guess where you have to go next, or do next, because game left you sometimes without any hint. 

- Characters are mostly Cheesy, don't expect any good written one. 

- Active camera angles in battle mode are awful. Fortunetly you can turn it off.

- The minecraft Chibi characters are horrible. Who even thught that this is a good idea? It's not even PS1 limitations, because FF8 have normal characters.
 
Materia system is ok, I really like design of locations in FF7, they are great and unique. OST is also good. Overall this game is mid one, but I can't recommend it to anyone, better go play remake. 

PS: Why people in 90s love it so much? I guess that for many millenials FF7 was a first FF ever, and even a first RPG ever. But it doesn't mean it's a fantastic game. All game magazines gave them 10/10, for reason I don't udnerstand, maybe I was born to late to understand 90s mentality. Especially the idea that FF7 is the best looking game on this platform. (meanwhile PS1: RE1/RE2/RE3/FF8/ Legend of Dragoon /Vagrant Story / Grand Turismo 2 / tekken 3 / Dino Crisis / Parasite Eve)

[h1]The RPG by which all others are to be measured, FFVII is a cinematic wonder[/h1]

When videogames are delayed for any significant amount of time, they are usually, for some reason, far below expectations. Games like Battlecruiser 3000AD, Ultima VIII, and Stonekeep were all pushed back repeatedly, only to be either incomplete (Battlecruiser) or simply bad (Ultima, Stonekeep). But occasionally, a game comes along that bucks that trend. And in the case of Final Fantasy VII, the latest output from RPG king Square, the end result justifies the delays without question. FF7 is, without a doubt, the new benchmark for console titles. 

To begin with, FF7 is longer than every console RPG to date. The game takes place across 3 CDs. It took Next Generation Online, no stranger to RPGs, a total of 49 hours to complete the game (approximately 25 hours for disc one, 15 for disc two, and 9 for disc three - the majority of which was spent breeding and racing chocobos [q.v.]), twice the length of Final Fantasy VI (known as III in the U.S.) and Wild Arms. While it is possible for the game to be completed in less time, rushing to complete it is definitely not recommended.

Since their last Japanese-translated RPG (Chrono Trigger for Super Nintendo), Square has been known for adding "easter eggs" to their games - opportunities for players to learn more about the game's characters, bonus games, and the like. Well, Square has outdone themselves this time. At least three hours are spent uncovering the main character's past, with an additional hour each for several other characters. One of the game's "secret" characters has her own hour of backstory, complete with her own town that is not even necessary to visit during the game's normal progression.

What is necessary during the game's normal progression is the capacity for awe. FF7's graphics are light years beyond anything ever seen on the PlayStation, making Wild Arms look like a Yarouze demo (we have nothing against Wild Arms, but FF7 is that good). The game begins in an enormous industrial complex housed in a futuristic city, and remains there for the first seven or eight hours of play. Just when it appears that the entire game will take place in the city, the venue changes to a fully 3D, fully rotatable engine, and players will find that the city is a mere dot on the enormous world map.

When not travelling in the world, players will navigate through static, hand-drawn locales. And in another huge leap forward for RPGs, the corridor is no more. Players can walk in, around, on top of, and through submarines, glaciers, amusement parks, reactors, farms, and dozens of other places. Since the backgrounds are static, the developers were able to put all their attention into animating the iconic representation of the party leader, which is represented in super-deformed polygons, looking remarkably like the Wild Arms characters look in battle.

It is unknown who came up with the idea for the polygonal battles first, Sony or Square, but Square has been in the business longer, and it shows in FF7's combat engine. While only three members can be in the party at one time, the effects more than make up for the game's only shortcoming. The graphics are as "realistic" as possible, considering the genre, with each character having a distinct look. And since each character uses a different style of weapon, the animation is different for each character. But it doesn't stop there - each character also has several other attack animations, based on their equipment. The equipping of characters is perhaps the most important part of the game; the game itself devotes several pages of text just to explain it.

The special attacks and spells, however, are the game's strongest points. All nine characters have "limit breaks", which can only be used after the character takes a certain amount of damage. When the limit is reached, the character attacks and does extra damage to the target. Each character has at least four, with one having nine.

The spells are the most graphically impressive part of the game (the game's CG sequences run a close second). There are 70 in all, 16 of which are FF3-style summon monster spells. One of these (Leviathan) was in the FF7 demo disc, which may be why the demand for the game has been so huge.

The game's plot is deep and typical of Square's prior efforts quite epic. Square takes great pride in its storytelling abilities and uses a number of flashback sequences, and loads of rendered sequences and prerendered FMV to add greatly to the mood and emotion of the story.

Adult themes and even some uncensored language (Goddamn, Crap, Shit, etc.) were all left in place as per Sony's promise not to alter the work. The teen rating for the game is well deserved due to such mature sexual and violent themes.

All in all, it is impossible to not recommend Final Fanatsy VII to anyone who is even vaguely interested in RPGs.

Let's get one thing clear, I didn't grow up with Final Fantasy VII.

Final Fantasy VII is a touchstone for presentation and storytelling in games, like Metal Gear Solid, Fallout, System Shock 2, and Half Life. This is THE game which brought Japanese RPGs a true mainstream appeal and market in the West.

The core gameplay has (mostly) aged just alright. It rejects having an obtuse and convoluted leveling system (something other Final Fantasies of past and present have had problems with), and just says "here is materia, you put it on any character and it levels up with you (assuming you use weapons and armor that allow growth)." This has the double edged sword of being easy to learn, but compromising on some depth other leveling systems have had. Unfortunately the active turn based combat is very simplistic, easy (most of the time), and never introduces any new new mechanics besides some enemy gimmicks. There are some rather useless party members like Cait Sith and Yuffie (besides if you get her Ultimate Weapon early). The combat isn't one of the strong points of FF7 by the standards of today. The game has long battle animations and unskipable cutscenes (which can get really annoying if you die before reaching the next save point). For those that like side quests, there's a decent amount of that with the optional boss fights, party members, summon materia, ultimate weapons, and Chocobo breeding.

The story is pretty strong overall, but not without it's faults. The story fizzles out around the second act before turning things around towards the final act. The main highlight of FF7 is the characters and the themes. All these years later, the main characters still manage to have depth and nuance beneath their appearances. Cloud is much more than being an iconic game character with an equally recognizable weapon. He is a protagonist filled to the brim with layers and a character arc.

The soundtrack is superb, despite it's sound limitations. Bombing Mission, Let the Battles Begin, The Highwind Takes to the Skies, Aerith's Theme, Cosmo Canyon, J-E-N-O-V-A, and One Winged Angel is just a small handful of the great tracks in the game.

Even if you are someone waiting for the Remake to come to PC, do yourself a service and play this classic, it will be a few years before the remake story is complete anyway.
Aged like wine, I recommend playing this even if you've played remake and plan on playing remake part 2 and 3.

In all honesty, I played this for two years, and bought it on Steam like ten years later. I adored this game while growing up, and even if it has aged poorly, it was peak story for it's time.

No-one made a game about ecology and destroying the planet as beautiful as this, and so well executed.
All characters were made with their quirks, all had their own ideals, and all of their stories are interesting and nicely tied together.

In terms on combat, it took me two years because I got max stats for all the characters. Took me a lot of farming on Midel, got to admit, but the optional bosses were cruel to beat, the story had its fun and silly moments, love stories, sad ones. I mean, that's why it got all the love it could.

And also made an open world game with plenty of interesting things to do, not only grinding, but fun.

Overall I think it deserves its love.

For the best experience possible (in my own opinion), use these mods with 7th Heaven mod loader:

-Ninostyle models (I prefer the chibi ones becasue they fit the world better)
-Tsunamods SYW textures
-Tsunamods Cosmo Memory sound overhaul
-Tsunamods enhanced stock UI
-Tsunamods Wizard Staff (changes spell names to regular FF ones)

And most importantly, Tsunamods' quite impressive "Echo-S" mod, which includes voice acting for every line in the game. Even if the voice acting is not up to your standards you can turn it off, and there is still some great music and it basically uses the re-translation from the mod "Beacause." I find the original translation very awkward and lacking, so the improvements to that aspect alone make the mod worthwhile. Note "Beacause" is not usable with 7th Heaven.

If you want a more stock experience though, use the Reunion mod, which smooths some things out and has the aforementioned re-translation. That was how I played the game the first time.

Let me tell you, folks, Final Fantasy VII, the original one, is a tremendous game. It's got everything you need to keep you hooked for hours and hours. But I have to say, I sympathize with Shinra Corporation. They are fantastic, incredible people, just like me.

First off, the world-building in this game is tremendous. Midgar, the city where most of the action takes place, is a masterpiece. The towering steel structures, the advanced technology, it's a sight to behold. Shinra Corporation, the backbone of Midgar's progress, deserves credit for creating such an impressive city.

Now, some people might say, "But Bubble Tea Bunny, what about the Planet and the Mako energy?" Let me tell you, Mako energy is a game-changer. It powers the entire city, providing jobs and opportunities for hardworking individuals. Shinra is doing an amazing job harnessing this energy to benefit Midgar's economy and the people.

The characters in Final Fantasy VII are fantastic. You've got Cloud, the main character, who may seem like a bit of a downer at times, but he's a winner, believe me. Tifa, she's beautiful, tough, and incredibly loyal. And Aerith, she's got this incredible energy and charm. It's no wonder both Cloud and that Sephiroth guy are after her.

Speaking of Sephiroth, some people might paint him as the bad guy, but let's not forget that he was part of Shinra's elite SOLDIER unit. Shinra gave him the tools to be great, and he's making the most of it. He's ambitious, just like me, and that's something I can appreciate.

The battles in Final Fantasy VII are terrific. The materia system, the limit breaks, it's all tremendous fun. And let's not forget about the chocobos! They're like the best horses you've ever seen, but even better. You can race them, breed them, and it's so much fun. It's a tremendous distraction from the serious stuff.

Now, I know some people will argue that Shinra's methods might be a little extreme, but you know what? Sometimes you have to make tough decisions for progress. And progress is what Shinra is all about. They're creating jobs, advancing technology, and ensuring a prosperous future for Midgar. That's what I call leadership.

In conclusion, Final Fantasy VII is a tremendous game that will keep you engaged from start to finish. Sure, some people might not see eye to eye with Shinra Corporation, but I appreciate their efforts to make Midgar great again. So grab your sword, join the battle, and let's show those anti-Shinra folks what true greatness looks like!

Rating: ★★★★★

I live in the Midgar slums, in Sector 7
My name is Cloud Strife
I'm 21 years old.

There is an idea of a Cloud Strife
Some kind of abstraction, but there is no real me.
Only an entity-- something illusory.
And though I can hide my cold gaze...
and you can shake my hand and feel flesh gripping yours...
and maybe you can even sense our life styles are probably comparable...

I simply am not there.

[b]STORY: 9.5 (Phenomenal) -[/b] What is it about this game’s story that makes it so special? What magic was woven into the programming to addict so many? The answers to those questions are both laughably simple and infinitely complicated. To put it into as compact an explanation as I know how, it is the many powerful and moving themes that interweave to form the game’s tapestry and the masterful way they are threaded. There are plenty of games (and stories in all forms of media) that can and do build their entire narrative on just one of the themes found in this game. To find a game that has so many present at all is a storytelling feat. To have them interweave in perfect harmony from beginning to end and still be as relevant (if not more so) today as at it's initial launch is something several orders of magnitude more impressive and amazing.

[b]CHARACTER DEVELOPMENT: 9 (Magnificent) -[/b] As with the main story of Final Fantasy VII, the depth of the characters is what helped in making this game the legend it is. I cannot praise this game enough nor put into words the magic the original development team was gifted when making it. If you have not played it, I strongly suggest you do. The reason I did not give this category an even higher score is that I acknowledge that there are some examples of nonsensical or goofy moments that do not fit character development.

[b]MUSIC: 9.5 (Phenomenal) -[/b] Nobuo Uematsu is and always has been a musical genius. Every soundtrack he has ever touched has been pure magic in one way or another. Final Fantasy VII Remake aside, the original Final Fantasy VII soundtrack may be his greatest ever and if not, easily in the top 3 of all-time. With very rare exception, every track is distinct, unique, and captures the feel of it's corresponding scene to perfection.

[b]VISUAL PRESENTATION: 8.5 (Superb) -[/b] The art style for the original Final Fantasy VII is iconic and unmistakable. 25 years after it's release, this is still true. The art style, level designs, creature designs, use of camera angles, and other aspects are all unique to this game and easily identifiable as such. Just because something is iconic, does not mean that it is 100% good. There are some visual elements to the original Final Fantasy VII that are just...not great. Those are what keep my score in this category from being higher. But we take the good with the bad.

[b]GAMEPLAY: 8.5 (Superb) -[/b] At the time of its release, Final Fantasy VII's version of the tried and true turn based system was revolutionary. Why? The innovation of the Active Time Battle used in previous Final Fantasy titles for use with Squaresoft's first 3D game. Compared to previous titles, it was more robust and allowed for more due to the new environment. It does contain some drawbacks, hence the score I have given. Expect odd lags at random moments and enemies sometimes breaking the system.

[b]CONTENT: 9 (Magnificent) -[/b] In a time long before DLC or even the ability for game consoles to access the internet, game companies had to release completed and bug free games to the public at launch. Given the time period that this game was released in, the amount of content was unheard of. Even by modern standards, the original Final Fantasy VII contains a lot of it, so much so that it was actually a challenge for the Remake development team to incorporate into a modern setting. My one problem here is that there is not enough content for certain parts of the game where more is needed.

[b]GRAPHICS*: 8 (Outstanding) -[/b] As far as I am concerned, graphics are the least important category with regard to immersion. I simply do not see graphics as that important. Trying to even fairly rate graphics feels like an exercise in futility right out of the gate. How does one do that when dealing with titles from across the history of the art? And since mods exist to change graphics so drastically, it is difficult to accurately score this category. I do it based on the time of the game's release to be as fair as I can. At the time, these were state-of-the-art graphics. Still, there are examples throughout the game of poor use of those new graphics. You will see them scattered all across Gaia. If you are willing to delve into the modding universe, you can transform the original version into something that is almost indie modern in quality.

[b]TOTAL (CORE): 9 (Magnificent)[/b]

[b]TOTAL (EXPANDED)*: 8.9 (Superb)[/b]


[b]FUN FACTOR: 9.5 (Phenomenal) -[/b] There are very few games that I can play over and over almost endlessly. Final Fantasy VII is one of them. It is a pure joy to relive this game's magic to me.

Seeing as how two generations of gamers have had the same experience with this title, it is not entirely my bias at work here. If you have not played Final Fantasy VII, do it as soon as you are able.

It's the greatest RPG story ever told with an engrossing character roster, each with their own fleshed-out background, one of if not the best gaming sound-tracks, and materia being a fun introduction to the Final Fantasy turn-based game play. 
FF7 set the standard for RPG's that still exists today in the form of cinematic story-telling, massive world-building, large-scale exploration and diversified options for style of game play with lots of side content to optionally enjoy to the player's benefit. 
There are two downsides: 
-the graphics are obviously 1997, but the pre-rendered backgrounds and unique sprite choices does give the game it's own enjoyable quality; just don't worry too much about the hands.
-the game has been argued as "too easy" and I would agree for anyone who goes in with a guide or on multiple play-throughs. The difficulty slider is greased towards easy-mode only because once you overcome the materia learning-curve it's possible to nigh-abuse them.... but I argue that the developers thought of that and that's why the game has two mega-bosses. Just don't cheat yourself on the new-player experience and this isn't a problem; you can easily sink over 100 hours into the game learning it's ins and outs. 

I'm very biased, but I know for certain that this game is one of those once-in-a-generation experience that tells a story I think most players can immerse themselves in and enjoy. If it doesn't hold up for you: hey, that's why they made a new one! Cheers! :D

FF7 is good (obviously) and is an important milestone in gaming history. If you consider yourself someone who enjoys video games as a hobby, I think you should play this at least once. 

...However, considering this game is now over 25 years old, we should add some pretty big disclaimers to the above statement. 

First and most obvious, the graphics are tremendously dated, and they are dated in that super special way that only early 3D games can achieve. The backgrounds are mostly pretty nice. They are pre-rendered and could potentially fit in a modern pixel game. The character models, however, are just straight up colored blocks. You have to use a fair bit of imagination to immerse yourself. With that being said, I do think they fall into the "so bad that it's actually good" category. I found myself amused as Cloud raises his polygon arms to spin the buster blade around. 

On to the story - The story is charming, but can feel tonally weird at times. While FF7 is significantly better than other "Japanese to English" titles of the era, it still struggles with not quite matching how a native speaker would approach these situations. For example, there will be tense moments in the game, and the characters meet those moments often with cheesy dialogue or out of place words that someone with a better grasp of the language wouldn't use. It's not enough to ruin the experience, but there are plenty "what the f@#$ does that mean" moments.

Lastly, I would say the gameplay is fun and suits the game very well, but is pretty simple - especially when compared to modern turn-based titles. Modern turn-based RPGs, even the modern Final Fantasy titles, has significantly improved and added depth to the genre that you will notice is missing in FF7s combat. This doesn't mean it's bad. In fact, I did enjoy the battle system a lot with its many types of spells, limits, and "pseudo real-time" turn system. It just is a product of a earlier moment in gaming. 

If any of that feels like a dealbreaker, just go play the FF7 Remake. Just about everything is improved in the remake. Otherwise, I'd say that you owe it to yourself to experience a touchstone in gaming history.
It's a classic to be sure, good game.

From the first time I played FINAL FANTASY VII, I knew it was a game I would never forget. It has everything one could ask for an incredible RPG experience: great characters, memorable music, and a compelling story. It's no wonder this title is held in such high regard; it still stands up to this day even though it was released years ago.

The graphics hold up even better than many modern RPGs. You can really immerse yourself in the environment and the world of FFVII. The battle system is fast and the characters feel like real people, making every battle and cutscene more memorable. Additionally, the game introduces unique gameplay elements and mechanics that you wouldn't find in any other RPG which give it an edge.

The music is some of the best to come out of any video game. Every single battle theme is a classic and the main theme of FINAL FANTASY VII is known all over the world. It's the perfect soundtrack to compliment the stunning visuals and immense scale of the game.

In all, FINAL FANTASY VII isn't just the best FINAL FANTASY ever, it's one of the best games ever made. It stands the test of time and still provides hours of fun and excitement. If you haven't played it yet, I highly recommend doing so.

Final Fantasy VII is one of, if not the greatest RPG Squaresoft has ever produced. Which makes it no surprise that it's one of the first PSOne RPGs Squaresoft ever ported to the PC during the late 90s. Unfortunately it would also start the trend of terrible and lazy ports which has lasted to this day (Looking at you Chrono Trigger and Chrono Cross). 

Notably they've saddled it with peculiarities that make it a nightmare to run on modern systems; To start, you cannot run this game on Fullscreen Mode, it just crashes after the Title Screen. You are thus compelled to run it in a Fixed-Resolution Bordered Windowed mode which you cannot resize at all. Visual settings are moreover non-existent; You have a grand total of three visual options. FMVs always start with a stutter. And to top it off this particular port adds an open mouth to all NPCs, so it looks like everyone, from the shop girl to Sephiroth, is offering you a blowjob. 

It has also a number of non-fatal but nonetheless annoying bugs; Like speed square's targeting sensitivity being maxed out, teleportation glitches and a terrible sound bug in the long chocobo race course. 

Now I am aware that there are mods to address these issues and if you have the time to apply them have at it but honestly a decent port should not have these problems to begin with, which ultimately accounts for my negative rating.

Get it only on sale but definitely get it if you've never played it on PS One to begin with. Or just emulate it.

[h1] The World is Worth Protecting because of Who We Love in It [/h1]

My memories about this game is seeing my older brothers play through most of the game, while I sit on the side watching intently. Like I was watching a movie. Because of this, I didn’t think I would ever play it, cause why should I when I already know what happens?

But Final Fantasy VII is such a game-changer in JRPGs and storytelling in video games, I just couldn’t avoid it. It’s constantly referenced in lists about Top RPGs of all time and the like. Not only that, so many of my social circle adore this. It’s a monument everywhere. 

So, after years of not having any interest in playing it, I one day decided to give it a go. 40 plus hours later and a bunch of failed attempts to demolish the one-winged angel Sephiroth without the Knights of the Round materia, I finally finished Final Fantasy VII. 

And I love it.

I won’t go into details too much about the game mechanics since there’s not much to say about it but I do have some comments on the Steam version (more on this in the next section). 

I won’t divulge a lot about the story too, because either everyone already knows about it. But I also don’t want to spoil anything to anyone who has no idea what FFVII is about and wants to go in blind. Because it will be worth it to go in blind (more on this in the third section).


[b] Steam version would have been flawless if it had features to speed-up the game and turn off random encounters [/b] 

This isn’t exactly a criticism of the game itself, but the version on Steam. There are moments in the game where I wish I could speed things up like when walking a long path or while on the world map. Random encounters are standard in Final Fantasy games, but perhaps a feature to switch them off would be a good update.

It isn’t that big of a deal. But these days, as someone who has to work, I don’t have the privilege of time to grind (main reason why I skipped some of the side quests, fighting the other Weapons, and breeding chocobos to get the Knights of the Round materia). I also know that there are mods to do these, but I’m too lazy to do that, so that’s on me. And besides, random encounters make the game more exciting.

In the end, it doesn’t make the game per se anything less than amazing. 

[b] Memorable characters with compelling backstories in a fascinating world that's worth fighting for [/b]

Advocacy of environmentalism that fight against large corporate greed is a tried and tested formula for a good plot. But I think what makes Final Fantasy a true classic is its ensemble cast. Almost everyone has an interesting backstory. Cloud, Tifa, Barrett, Cid, Sephiroth, Hojo, the Turks, Bugenhagen, and many more. The world they inhabit has so much depth and lore that it’s worth digging deep into, and truly makes you want to fight for it. 

The solid storytelling of VII is also a testimony on why it’s revered. Being such an influential game and a cultural phenomenon back when I was younger, I’ve been aware of the main plot lines of this game for years — including the big reveal about Cloud (I won’t spoil anything for anyone who hasn’t played the game). But seeing it play out still gave me chills. So, if you’re not familiar with the events here, keep it that way. Trust me, it’s worth going in blind.

Furthermore, there’s just so much to do here. I have some memories of my brother playing minigames and side quests especially in the Golden Saucer area. But I’ve been a bit overwhelmed to see how much variety and content it has. The different minigames, side quests, and activities you can do in all the interesting locations across the map immerse you into its fascinating world. 

[b] Conclusion [/b]

I didn’t think I would one day bother playing Final Fantasy VII again. It’s just so ubiquitous in gaming. And when it’s as influential as it is, your expectations are just so high. Not only that, since so many of the people I know consider this as one of their favorite games, I did feel at some point I was getting overhyped. 

But Final Fantasy VII lives up to its legacy. I dare say as well that even playing it vanilla, it’s still one hell of an JRPG. 

On top of that, it comes with a compelling message: the world is worth protecting because of who we love in it. Authentic without being self-important. Critical but not preachy. 

There is a reason why this is considered a classic. And it deserves to be considered as such.

As someone who had never played the original, I was excited for this. 

Then I loaded the damned thing. 

First off: that "partial controller support" tag on this listing is an outright joke. As are the keybinds. We're using some PC game in 1994-level binds (X to confirm, arrows to move, etc) to get this game going. 

It HATES being alt-tabbed. I've had the game crash a few times. 

And before anyone taps your shoulder and says "just buy this on sale so you can use to files to run Echo-7" let me tell you a little something the Final Fantasy fandom won't: Echo 7's idea of a 'good fan voice' for Cloud was to make him sound like Derek Zoolander. I legitimately am going to start the game over and voice the characters myself on stream. 

Any sort of narrative gravitas has been undermined by the fact Cloud - who already has to overcome the stereotypical Bad Boy With Amnesia tropes - sounds like a Ben Stiller character. The fan translation (or perhaps just bad rewrite of the existing FF7 translation?) is abysmal, inserting swearing in places that genuinely feels it's there for shock value. A real "this isn't your momma's Final Fantasy" vibe that sincerely does not fit the tone of the game in the slightest.

Add on the fact Barret is not voiced by a Black guy and it is VERY APPARENT, and you've got a recipe for disaster. I respect the passion of all the fans who made Echo-7 but impact outweighs intent and the impact is there is one mod that EVERYONE suggests getting for this game and it retroactively makes the game feel like if Snapcube made a Final Fantasy 7 dub. 

If you do get this with intention of modding, just use some QOL mods to make it run right and enable controller use. Skip Echo-7.

Without mods, this is a port that needed polishing in 2013 when it dropped and CERTAINLY needs work now. The whole POINT of Final Fantasy 7: Remake is they presume you've played the original, yet the only legal way to play the original is this old-ass feeling port that was antique-feeling when it launched.

Come on, Square. Try. For once. It builds character.

I highly recommend this game to those who are fans and newcomers. This is the classic RPG that took the video game industry by storm back in 1997. This is not for children under 13 due to its mature themes and elements throughout the game.
Classic FF7 PC port

Pros:
+ Game still holds up mechanically; game encourages build variety with equipment and materia setups
+ Characters are likable and entertaining
+ Soundtrack is amazing, even though it's midi
+ Has the healthiest modding community out of all the FF games, adds replay value

Cons:
- Game is still not great to look at; visual presentation is off putting but your mileage may vary.
- Translations can sometimes be a miss, some scenes read sillier than others
- Plot may be confusing to some people, definitely has some unnecessarily convoluted story beats, but not that many
- Combat can be very repetitive and boring after awhile, this is common for a lot of FF games and Japanese-developed RPG's at the time

I would recommend to anyone who's enthusiastic for old games. If you don't mind PS1 era graphics and presentation, I would definitely recommend. If this is your first FF game, go in with the RIGHT expectations. Yes, the game is one of the greatest and most influential of all time, BUT other games have followed in VII's footsteps and some of the most inventive things in this game that some consider great, may now be trivial for new players.

As a fan of the original Final Fantasy VII, playing the Steam version of the game was a nostalgic and exciting experience for me. I had previously completed the game back in the day on the PS1 and again a couple of years later, so revisiting the world of Midgar was a trip down memory lane. Despite the game being over two decades old, it still holds up today and is a testament to its incredible storytelling and gameplay.

One of the new features that stood out to me in the Steam version was the addition of achievements. As someone who enjoys collecting achievements in games, it was satisfying to see the list of challenges to complete and track my progress. It added a new layer of motivation to explore the game even further.

Another improvement in the Steam version was the FMVs (Full Motion Videos). While the game's graphics and backgrounds are still in their original format, the FMVs have been enhanced to look much better than the original. The added details and clearer picture quality added to the overall immersive experience of the game.

The Steam version of Final Fantasy VII provided me with a chance to relive one of my favorite childhood games and gave me an opportunity to experience the game in a new way with the addition of achievements. The game still holds up incredibly well today, and the enhanced FMVs help immerse players even further into the world of Midgar. If you're a fan of the original game or a newcomer to the series, I highly recommend giving the Steam version a try.

Note: On a journey to 100% ALL Final Fantasy titles on Steam~

Is this the best Final Fantasy? I can't tell you that, but it sure is the most popular!
Few titles are worth calling a masterpiece. Fewer among them become a mainstream masterpiece, like FFVII achieved.

Why FFVII is a [b]must-play[/b] title:
-Story-wise, this game is ever-relevant to today with it's allegory of draining our planet to produce more energy. It really hits home and you should experience this feeling for yourself! 
-You can always judge a man by the quality of his enemies, which makes Cloud awesome by default. The game is presented by an unreliable narrator and how this twists and turns the story (+your heartstrings too) and events that happen is something that is more than unique. It is the very definition of Entertainment.
-Sephiroth is a unique villain, which can make you admire and feel sorry for him for at the same time (+his music score is lit!).
-Although I am a job system fan, the Materia system is super strategic, deep and pure fun to mess with.

I can just go on and on but everything really is on-point here! Villains, backstories, music, game systems. It all comes together to bring you a fantastic title. 

If you want to learn more about the setting, look into:
-CRISIS CORE –FINAL FANTASY VII– REUNION on Steam which takes place in the past, and plays like an action-based version of FFVII.
-Final Fantasy VII: Advent Children (Anime movie anyone?) It's really good CGI!
-Dirge of Cerberus -Final Fantasy VII: You can get this to run on a PS2 Emulator, it's some effort and the weakest of my recommendations, so do what you will with it.

If you've played this game before, and are feeling the nostalgia now, go ahead! The only problem is that you will likely hate this release if you use controllers.
If you are thinking to give this game a first try, this is possibly the most mainstream starting point. I would argue you should first try to play this title, and only after that try the Remake!
If you plan to 100% this game, I usually recommend the achievement guide posted by lylat on Steam, but in this case I cannot. The reason is that "Missable Achievement" guides should be burned with fire. Especially on a game like this, there are very hard to get "Non-Missable" Achievements, that are just plain obscure to find. I would recommend to follow any full guide instead. This will net you all Steam Achievements too with the exception of the money and Materia Exp. ones, which are just pure grind either-way!

I hope I was able to provide some unique perspective for you, and was able to help you decide whether you should play this game if you were on the fence!

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. Final Fantasy VII was the 3rd Final Fantasy game I've played, playing it again on my PC and got it on a cheap price, gotta say, this port is fine and runs very nicely even on older specs.
My only real issues with this port though, are:
* You need a Square Enix Account in order to even play the game, as Steam launches the Launcher for the game and not the game itself (which is easily avoided if you plan to mod or just launch the game outside of steam)
* The sound quality is worse than what I've seen on PlayStation consoles, they sound really compressed.
* The graphics and backgrounds, being upscaled from a PS1 game can be a little blurry/ugly coming from the port, again, not really that hard to fix since games on PC are easily moddable these days. It's not Persona 3 Portable sort of bad, but it's still pretty noticeable, especially the cutscenes where the character models are on-screen.
*Unlike the other Final Fantasy ports (particularly FFVIII and FFIX) on Steam or consoles, (since FFVII was ported earlier than the other games) it doesn't have tools to help newcomers to the older titles, making it less approachable to them, personally I don't have a problem since I'm familiar with the older games, but having the console and steam releases being different than each other seems weird.
Overall, I would recommend getting FFVII on Steam, it's still the same game everyone knows and loves, and the issues albeit mostly visual and audio related, are easy to fix.

Pros
- Great cast of characters. FF7 has some of the most popular video game characters ever created.
- Materia system is extremely fun. You get a lot of room for creativity and customization. I played various traditional JRPG's and the materia system is my favorite, no contest.
- Story, while not the most amazing, is very good.
- Excellent music.

Cons
- Outdated graphics and controls. Higher res pre-rendered backgrounds, true analog controls, and auto run would have been nice improvements.
- Inability to skip story scenes and summons. These can really drag the game down.
- Getting 100% can be quite grindy.
- Controls are all messed up. You have to use steam's controller features for the game to function properly.
- The battle menu isn't particularly responsive. Supposedly, it now runs at only 15 FPS.
- The SE launcher is unnecessary. I lost my saves multiple times using its cloud saves.
