I've been playing this game with Reunion R07 + the New Threat mod, and I gotta say I forgot how charming FF7 can be -- when it works. I think probably one of the worst aspects of these old squeenix games (and retro games in general) that we forget about today is that they're definitely not great compared to more modern games (and I'm really not just talking about graphics -- look up the mechanics and countless bugs for Steal in EVERY FF game before 9), and we look back at them with rose-tinted glasses because they were so core to our formative experiences. It's so hard to hold them accountable because of how new as a medium gaming is. People say Seinfeld isn't funny anymore, without realizing that it's not funny anymore because of how many modern sitcoms have aped their formula or in some cases stolen their jokes and done them better. These landmark games are so core to the industry now that we forget how novel they were, or never experienced it at all, when we see their descendants today.

Which is why I recommend SYW, Reunion and New Threat if you're gonna buy this game; I think mods and ROM Hacks have breathed a ton of new life into these janky old games -- FF6 T-Edition or MaternalBound or the utterly relentless swathes of Pokemon Game Boy & GBA hacks are just the beginning of a long list of creative, fan-driven efforts to remind people WHY these games are so well-loved. There's countless good ideas in this game, and the SYW, Reunion & New Threat mods do everything in a very talented, dedicated trio of team's power to bring those ideas to the forefront and let you experience them for the first time all over again. Upscaled textures, cleaner models, revamped mechanics, optional, accurate retranslations, a heated effort to make sure *every* Materia has some useful function, and even rearranged story events that let you skip tedious garbage (or still do it! you can if you want to!) all come together to make this the freshest old-ass RPG I've played in years.

Final fantasy VII is a well known and quite iconic JRPG classic. After playing it i can say that if you enjoy turn-based rpgs, especially old-school ones, and wish to play an older game with a big impact in the genre, then this game is quite the good choice. Now, I will talk more in-depth about the game:

Visuals: As it is to be expected of a 1997 game, the visuals are quite outdated, the characters outside of battle being in a sort of weird chibi style and some of the background being still images. Although this might scare some people away, I do believe the graphics are quite appealing and it won't be a problem for people used to older games. Besides, a lot of cutscenes (story and summons especially) are still really cool and well-made.

Gameplay: As already mentioned, the combat is turn-based and I believe it does its job quite well. The combat offers a lot of variety, which i believe is really important in a turn-based game. The main way of offense and defense is materia. Materia are items that you can equip on the character, thus giving them the ability to use offensive spells, healing spells, new commands and all sorts of useful stuff. There are also limit breaks, basically the characters ultimates, which can be used after taking a certain amount of damage. But materia also lowers some of the characters stats when equipped, so they must be managed carefully. Outside of combat, there are a lot of items to pick up, some hidden in the overworld and others obtained through minigames. There are also two optional characters you can obtain. Another thing to notice is that some of those things are really hard to find without the help of a guide, so the usage of one is recommended. In terms of difficulty, it varies a lot. A lot of common enemies and bosses aren't that hard, but certain enemies and bosses can be really challenging, especially when you do not have access to the stronger materias and limit breaks.

Story: The story has some really good characters and plot, with themes like identity, loss and environmentalism. I did not find it the best story I ever saw, not even close to it, but it is good, and it is most certainly a classic and deserves the praise it receives.

P.S. Another thing to take into account is that you will need a SE account to play it, and if i remember correctly, you won't be able to play it if the servers are not online. Quite the bold choice to put those restrictions in a 26 year old game but I think its still worth it. Just something to think about before buying it.

[u]What makes this unique to the series?[/u]
It's still a classic for a reason.

While the graphics and audio quality have not held up at all, it's amazing how much of the core experience still lands. I expected to struggle completing this game, but the narrative themes and characters are so strong that I quickly got over the aesthetics. The soundtrack is top-notch. The world design is iconic. The pacing and story-telling is some of the best in the series.

This is Final Fantasy firing on all cylinders.

[u]Positives[/u]:

- This is such a rich story.  All of the characters have unique, interesting conflicts that work on their own while building on larger narrative themes.  Is it still a goofy, contrived anime at points?  Yes, but it’s a really good one that you’ll think through later and appreciate fully.

- The world of FF7 is so unique and imaginative.  Midgar is such an iconic landscape that they keep revisiting in later games and movies.  There are so many little world details you notice in optional content that fleshes everything out.  The characters and world design are what caused this game to lodge in so many people’s brains.

- I feel like the pacing and structure of this game don’t get enough credit.  The story rarely drags.  The first few hours are brisk and get you immediately invested.  There are so many “big reveal” moments that, frankly, the remake completely drops the ball on.  You are missing out if you don’t play the original.

- Some top-tier Nobuo Uematsu music.  I love that the overworld theme (Cloud’s theme) changes throughout the game to reflect the current mood of the story.  I was pumped as f*** watching blocky, 90s-era characters glide around a 2D background because the music is impossible not to feel in your bones.

[u]Negatives[/u]:

- Let’s get it out of the way.  The graphics and audio quality is a** 25 years later.  When I first booted up the game and heard the wimpy *pmphf* a character’s punch made, I turned the game off.  It’s a major turn off for the game that you eventually get over.  What’s beyond the technical fidelity is well worth it, though.

- I remember loving the mini-games as a kid and now I can’t stand them.  They are so slow and tedious.  I fast tracked Fort Condor as much as I could.  Like later FF ports, this would really benefit from a speed up option.

- Cait Sith is the worst.

FANTASTIC game; one of my personal top tens. The windows port? Not so much. I originally played FFVII on the PS1 during the pandemic and it left a huge impact on me. I bought the port on sale hoping to get all the steam achievements and complete the game since I missed a lot of side quests on my first run through. However, I don't think I'll be doing that. In my opinion, the issues this port has are deal breakers for me. The controls are difficult to set up properly for a gamepad and there is some amount of input lag that I can't get rid of. The lag is most noticeable in battles, ideally you want to have quick menuing to get an action in before your opponent and the lag can make menus feel clunky at times. The graphics in battles occasionally have some issues being emulated properly too (like certain special effects and the HP/MP bars). I'm overlooking issues with the game itself (like the run button and lower framerate etc.) because those issues exist in the original release and other console ports for the game. Personally, I would rather replay my physical copy than the windows port even if it means missing steam achievements.
If you've never played FFVII and you enjoy RPGs, I would still recommend you play this at some point. Just maybe consider a different port or the original release.

Timeless masterpiece. Not ashamed to admit that I finally completed this game more than 20 years after loading it up for the very first time on my cousins' PS1. I have just finished the ending FMV and the rescue of the planet was a gratifying visual treat. 

It is my view that Nobuo Uematsu's musical talent contributed at least 60% to the success of this game. The 2D pre-rendered backgrounds were beautifully drawn for its time, but the soundtrack perfectly encapsulated the atmospherics of the game. I mean, who can forget the combat themes that get your heart pumping or even the area themes for Mako Reactor, Shinra Building, and Cosmo Canyon? Listening to Aerith's Theme again instantly transported me to the exact moment when I was 9 and first encountered her undeserved ending. Seeing it now was just as traumatic and impactful as it was back then. Fighting Sephiroth while One Winged Angel was playing in the background sent goosebumps all over me. I tried to listen to the FF7 Remake OST but I still preferred the original OST for its simplistic execution but punchy motifs. 

Putting my nostalgia aside, I strongly recommend people to play this game for its interesting characters (they all have poignant backstories), an overarching plot that enthralls you and of course the memorable soundtrack. Gameplay is old-fashioned turn-based combat. If you like it you like it. If you don't, well just slog through it. The main story can be completed fast if you don't care about grinding optional achievements. But be sure to play it with mods because the original polygonal art honestly doesn't hold up well in the eye of a modern gamer. I used 7th Heaven to install Ninostyle models and HQ field textures.

[code]Final Fantasy VII is the poster child of the entire Final Fantasy franchise for a reason, enjoying ongoing popularity to this day. That said, this 2012 PC version shouldn’t be played without some mods installed to improve the experience[/code]

[i]Final Fantasy VII[/i] is a game with such influence and legacy that I don’t feel like I need to explain what it is. As of January 2023, the game has sold [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Final_Fantasy_VII#Sales]over 14.1 million units across all platforms[/url] (!), [url=https://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation/final-fantasy-vii]received high praise[/url] and [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compilation_of_Final_Fantasy_VII]received numerous spin-offs[/url] under the “Compilation of Final Fantasy VII” brand - from a CGI movie sequel to games (even a [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Final_Fantasy_VII:_The_First_Soldier]F2P Battle Royale one[/url]!) to books. One might cynically say that publisher Square Enix is still heavily benefiting from milking the [i]Final Fantasy VII[/i] name but on the other hand, there does seem to be an audience for this cross-media universe – otherwise it wouldn’t have lasted for so long.

Which begs the question, especially with the release of the long-awaited [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1462040/FINAL_FANTASY_VII_REMAKE_INTERGRADE/]Final Fantasy VII Remake[/url]: Is there any reason to still play this version of the original 1997 game? The answer to that question is yes, sorry. There are two simple reasons for that. First, the [i]Final Fantasy VII Remake[/i] is only the first part of a planned trilogy, so playing that would only cover a fraction of the original game. Second, the [i]Final Fantasy VII Remake[/i] is aimed at fans who already played the original game and consequently introduces various story deviations to keep them on their toes. So yes, the Remake doesn’t replace the original [i]Final Fantasy VII[/i] - which leaves us with this 2012 PC port of the game.

First of, let me voice my disappointment here: [i]Final Fantasy VII[/i] received a re-release on PS4, Xbox One, Switch and the Microsoft Windows Store (?!), which is [url=https://finalfantasy.fandom.com/wiki/Final_Fantasy_VII_version_differences#PlayStation_4,_Xbox_One,_Windows_10,_Nintendo_Switch]based on this 2012 PC version sold on Steam[/url]. These re-releases include new features, like a 3x Game Speed Mode, an option to turn battle encounters off as well as a “Battle Enhancement Mode” (max out HP/MP/Limit at the press of a button). I would’ve loved to see these features added to this Steam version as well, considering how they’re especially helping those who just want to experience the best part of [i]Final Fantasy VII[/i] – the story.

Anyhow, as the PC version we’re stuck with on Steam is from 2012, there are thankfully numerous mods out there to improve the experience. I advise checking the [url=https://www.pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Final_Fantasy_VII_(2012)]PCGamingWiki[/url] for more information but I’ll briefly list my recommendations here. First of, there’s [url=https://www.ff7.live/features.html]The Reunion[/url], a mod which offers numerous improvements. Most notably, it offers a relocalization of the game, improving upon the notably bad translation the game got in the West, as well as allowing for 60 FPS during battle scenes (instead of 15 FPS without mods). This mod does disable Steam achievements unfortunately, though you can unlock those manually through the [url=http://www.blackchocobo.com/]Black Chocobo[/url] save editor. Additionally, I installed a mod for [url=https://forums.qhimm.com/index.php?topic=20311.0]upscaled backgrounds[/url], and one for an [url=https://forums.qhimm.com/index.php?topic=20234.msg283477#msg283477]HD UI[/url]. Lastly, I recommend using a program called [url=https://forums.qhimm.com/index.php?topic=14194.0]Ochu[/url], which offers multiple features (like invincibility), though I mainly used it in order to save anywhere in the game, not just at the save points.

To be clear here, these mods can only do so much. [i]Final Fantasy VII[/i] was the first [i]Final Fantasy[/i] to feature 3D graphics instead of 2D pixel art – and while those 1997 PS1 graphics might’ve turned heads back in the day, they’re far from pretty in 2022. Early 3D graphics just didn’t age as well as those SNES sprites, unfortunately. Thankfully, the same can’t be said for the rest of [i]Final Fantasy VII[/i].

Let’s briefly talk about the gameplay first. The “Active Time Battle” system makes a return, though it has received an addition with “Limit” bars – once filled, your characters can unleash an especially powerful attack. Those are nice to look at and a pleasure to unlock, though getting the best limit levels for every character takes way too long. Magic returns in form of “Materia”, which can be equipped in limited slots of weapons and armor.

Personally, I don’t like the Materia system. The benefit here is that powerful spells can easily be swapped to different characters, which is great. My problem here is that each Materia must be levelled in order to make those spells more powerful (Thunder -> Thundara -> Thundaga, for example) and you can’t buy “powered-up” versions in stores. So apart from character levels and limit levels, you might also need to grind Materia in order to succeed in battle. Summons return as well, also in form of (upgradeable) Materia – and [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0t8yQ47qvQI]really sweet cutscenes[/url].

Overall though, the general gameplay works as well as it previously did – though party size went down from four to three characters. There’s an overworld, random encounters, dungeons and bosses. [i]Final Fantasy VII[/i] also introduces several minigames as part of the journey, which are a nice little distraction. Also included is various optional content, however, this unfortunately once again includes entire party characters like in [i]Final Fantasy VI[/i]. I recommend using [url=https://jegged.com/Games/Final-Fantasy-VII/]a guide like this one[/url] to make sure you won’t miss out on them as they’re once again somewhat obtuse to unlock.

I’ll be honest here though, I feel like the star of and the reason for [i]Final Fantasy VII[/i]’s ongoing popularity are the characters and overall story. As the first 3D [i]Final Fantasy[/i], the story presentation here is above and beyond what [i]Final Fantasy VI[/i] could offer with its technical limitations. Now there are long scenes filled with nothing but dialogues and FMV cutscenes, instead of battles every 30 seconds. Characters develop and receive interesting backstories, the villain is almost as well known as the hero today and the world itself full of memorable locations. 

Admittedly though, this isn’t the verdict I reached after my first playthrough on Nintendo Switch. Back then, I was mostly confused about how a story like this would go on to become so popular. I feel like the improved translation of the Reunion mod really did wonders for me here, as my second playthrough allowed me to appreciate its characters and world much more (though the game would’ve benefitted from an epilogue), even though it’s still [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oPE-Ivy9LLg]occasionally goofy[/url] (spoilers!).

In conclusion, [i]Final Fantasy VI[/i] still holds up today – mostly thanks to its story and characters (<3 the Turks). Parts of the gameplay and especially the graphics haven’t aged as well, unfortunately, though there are mods to help with that. For those with little time and/or those not wanting to deal with Materia frustrations, I honestly recommend just playing through the game with “invincibility” enabled through Ochu in order to enjoy the story. I wish the Remake would’ve been more faithful in order to provide the same experience with better gameplay and graphics but alias, this modded PC version of the 1997 original game is the second-best option right now.

Final Fantasy VII is one of those old, beloved masterpieces that everyone talks about when they bring up JRPGs. If you've heard of video games, you've heard of FF7. This was my first time playing through it, and I can finally understand why that's the case. For it's time, FF7 is a masterwork of storytelling and spectacle, especially considering the limitations of its engine and hardware. It was incredible to see the level of cinema Squaresoft were able to achieve with the adorably quaint low-poly models and slipshod FMVs. The story itself was great, with a compelling cast of characters who all brought a different interesting aspect to the table (except Cait Sith), and some truly great and unexpected twists. I especially apreciated the aesthetic of the game, opening in an old-school cyberpunk slum, before gradually revealing that the rest of the world is much larger, and mostly untamed. The effect of leaving Midgar and seeing the huge map before me is not one I think will be replicated anytime soon. Also present is a great sense of progression in the way you traverse the map, from hoofing it town-to-town to riding chocobos and later flying, there's a notable sense of increasing freedom in traversal. The gameplay is standard Final Fantasy ATB; not my favourite, but it serves its purpose well, and the camera angles and sense of scale the 3D models brought added a much-welcome bombast to combat. Music is, of course, beautiful, though I will admit to experiencing some whiplash, moving from the iconic orchestral renditions of these famous tracks to the original PS1 soundfont. Though I have only good things to say about this game, I am judging it by the standards of when it released, and to say it's aged poorly would be an understatement. While it surely must have been a 9/10 when it released, I give my experience with it a 7.5/10. That said, its must-play status remains. If you haven't somehow experienced the original FF7, I urge you to do so, be it via a playthrough of your own or a walkthrough on YouTube. Everyone should experience this game.

At the time of its original late 90's PlayStation release this game was groundbreaking for its story, graphics, creativity, music and more. I haven't played it in decades, but recently picked it up again in early 2023 after playing the PS5 Remake (for my 2nd playthrough) and feel it is still a fantastic albeit graphically-dated story. The way the player has to solve puzzles and interact with the world through their chosen interface (controller/keyboard/etc) is still more complex than many modern games where you just have to press the same  button or two when prompted at different points throughout the game. I recommend FF 7 but, there are many issues. I liked FF5 and FF6 more than this one. I did not want to recommend it initially, but to be honest, given the price and the amount of content and the love that the developers poured into it, I will give it a recommendation. 

I played FF7 right after finishing FF6 and all the previous ones, in order. Here are the pros and cons.

Pros:
 - Enough content to keep you busy
 - Varied content: Battles, special battles, vehicles, mini-games, story, cinematics, etc.
 - It is a Final Fantasy and it evolves the series (meaning, it fits in with the previous)
 - Tifa is hot and was my girlfriend
 - The music is not bad but not always good.
 - The concepts are interesting (Materias, permanent stat incr. potions, flexible magic)
 - The characters are alive and interact and have side-quests and are 3d animated.

Cons:
 - The mini-games are boring: Especially breeding, racing, mating Chocobos.
 - Some mini-games are not optional, you need to win to progress the story.
 - The music is annoying in the Gold Saucer.
 - The 3d "Maps" are sometimes difficult to navigate.
 - The 3d "Maps" (aka Dungeons or Towns) are not beautiful. Like old 3d with awful textures.
 - The animations are very long (during battles).
 - Cinematics cannot be skipped.
 - There are some bugs, such as mastering the Underwater materia
 - The num. of items you can wear on your characters was reduced. Now only Weapon, Armor and Acc.
 - Only 3 characters in your party, and I think more is better. I liked Baldur's Gate 6 characters in your party.
 - Some bosses are not inspiring (the Turks) and I miss the ones of the previous entries.
 - Equipping, unequipping, switching the materias was long between characters.
 - The popularity of this game is mostly due to an enormous publicity and marketing campaign. Many RPGs are bigger, better, have better systems.
 - 168h to finish the game (full completion) was not long. Pathfinder Kingmaker is at 800h and still counting. But Pathfinder Kingmaker is long.

The game can feel similar to Knights of the Old Republic (KOTOR), where you also control a party and take 2 team members with you as you venture out of your ship on various planets. But KOTOR had classes with specific skills, skills trees, Light and Dark side alignment and its effects. It also had weapon customization with lightsabers. The mini-game in KOTOR is called Pazak and is a ton of fun. You can travel between planets and it is a bit of an open galaxy. Also, KOTOR is set in the future (not medieval), just like FF7. 

So comparing both, I much prefer KOTOR. It came out 5 years later, roughly, so it is not fair. But if I had to replay one of those two games today, I would pick KOTOR for sure. And this time I would do a playthrough with dark-side aligned sith lord! UNLIMITED POWAAAAA!  This is a level of replayability which is not found in FF7.

Final Fantasy VII is without a doubt the best and most impactful game I have ever played. This behemoth of a game released over 25 years ago has stood the test of time and no other game has come close to dethroning its sheer quality in both gameplay and storytelling alike.

A bit of background knowledge about me. Due to my bad experiences and disinterest in the Pokemon franchise. I grew up hating the form of combat labelled 'turn based'. I thought it was slow, dis-interesting and created a barrier between the user and the combat due to its slow and strategy based gameplay. However, this game has completely reformatted my opinion on turn based combat and it single-handedly made me fall in love with it. Whether I was fighting normal enemies out in the wilderness, or even facing off with Sephiroth in the final battle, I was completely absorbed in the gameplay and combat at every moment.

And the soundtrack is just mesmerising, Nobuo Uematsu gives it his all in creating both incredibly moving and tense scenes through his stellar composition, which helped raise the quality of this game to the very max.

The characters are honestly the best I have seen in a videogame. Instantly I was pulled in to these characters lives, relationships and personal stories and each character gets their own time to shine. Especially Cloud, the main character of this game. Starting out as a stoic, unlikable former soldier who only partakes in helping our main characters for money, eventually turns out to have a beautiful redemption story and has one of the most well crafted character arcs I have seen.

A true masterpiece, everyone should play this game at least once in their life as it is a beautiful and truly unforgettable experience.

Now, if you know absolutely nothing about final fantasy. You should know that you don't need to play FF1 to play FF2. They're all their own individual stories with their own individual worlds. There's some discussion over whether some final fantasies share the same world. But ultimately, that's very much a fringe element of the games.

Final Fantasy VII is a favourite among many players. Some argue six, some argue nine, some argue ten. (My favourite is four... or nine... or ten... or six... it's tough to choose, sorry!) But ultimately, they're all awesome!

This final fantasy starts you of as an ecological terrorist, taking out reactors that are draining energy from the planet to fuel greedy needs. Sure this grants many people more comfortable lives. But ultimately the damage to the planet will go to far, especially at the rate that SHINRA are draining Mako from the planet. You start with Cloud, before getting more awesome party members and even a few optional party members that are hidden. You'll get to experience Square Enix (or Back then, Squaresoft!) and their attempt at the time to make the old turn based combat system more exciting. It's super easy to get in to, whilst still offering a few challenging battles. Don't worry, if it's too hard, you can grind out a few levels!

Now, we've mentioned the story and the gameplay... but there's an important part that every final fantasy has in spades, and does extraordinarily well!
The Soundtrack. Final Fantasy games have phenomenal soundtracks. You can find full scale orchestras blasting them on youtube. Extremely talented musicians poured their hearts and souls into the music behind these games. FF7 is certainly no exception to that!

The cost is cheap, this game is really cheap. You might look at the graphics and think they've not aged well, but for their time the cinematics were really cutting edge. Few games from FF7's era matched the wonder, Soul Reaver and Ocarina of Time come to mind. But FF7 holds it's unique charm. The general gameplays graphics are considerably less advanced than the cinematics, but they still hold up quite well. (Apart from the bug where all the mouths are constantly open, I believe you can turn that off, it's part of the remaster, it does look funny though!) 

This game is extremely cheap for what it is. A wonderful story, with an excellent soundtrack and awesome gameplay. That could last for over 70 hours in one playthrough. Depending how many bonus things you're going for you could take longer. (If you're as slow a reader as I am, it'll be even longer still!)
And if it's your first final fantasy, you'll find roughly this quality from them all. From FF10 onward you have voice acting. (Before anyone says it's bad, it's quite good, it doesn't sync up perfectly because it was designed for another language. The voice actors themselves are very talented. John DiMaggio for instance, the voice of Bender, does Wakka)
Other games also have unique gameplay, FF3, 5 and tactics, for instance, have awesome job systems. FF10-2 has a job system too! So if you don't want your character to be a wizard, you can make them a warrior (Or a pop star XD Yes, really) FF12 onward change the turn based combat. I'm partial to turn based, but many people prefer the alternative.

Then you also have other games that follow a similar Genre, Blue Dragon, Breath of Fire, Lost Odyssey, Dragon Quest and many MANY more. 

So do consider buying this, start your journey today. If you don't like Final Fantasy 7, don't be disheartened, maybe Final Fantasy 9 is more for you. Or 10... well... there's a lot!

I hope you take the chance, and have a lovely day regardless, Kupo!

Now do not get me wrong i Loved the remake, especially the way they twisted the story to tell a new version of, a version that is more in spirit of the original in how they intented to make it, rather than the last ditch rush for release. FF7 the original is an unfinished title, some of the story got axed and without going into spoilers, just know that the new remake is indeed more in spirit of what the original was suppose to be. So do not sell the remake short it is great, not so much a fan of the action RPG take, but I can handle it.

Regardless, the original FF7 has a good story, even if some parts of it got axed due to release pressure, old time JRPG combat style which makes you able to relax rather than button mash like a crazy person, polygon characters that only your imagination can perfect. So yeah, for nostaliga purposes it is a gem, for new fans wanting to know what the hype was about then you need to set your graphic hungry brain in neutral and just let your imagination play with the polygons like I did as a kid.

Anyhow, It will always have a special place in my heart as the shared top spot in my heart for FF titles, which it shares with FF6, any title after 7? (aside for the remake that is) are a horrible mess of blergh.
Anyone that tells me Zidane or Tidus was that bomb, or Squall for that matter, should wash their mouth with SOAP! Cloud and Terra those were proper MC characters. Squall is a weak Cloud clone, Zidane is Locke (from FF6) with a tale, Tidus is a mix of Cloud and Locke so no... those titles are not good at all, watered down clones of better titles.

Anyhow, Enjoy it if you can.

One of the greatest JRPGs ever made and still absolutely worth it on sale for one casual playthrough at full price. Sadly, the replay potential is massively hindered by:

- Lack of challenge (even with mid-tier self-imposed challenges such as Materia Lockdown)
- No random loot other than (usually worthless) steals and battle drops
- Linear story with few side-quests and optional content, no branching or open sections whatsoever in any meaningful way
- One or more mandatory party members for the majority of the game
- Simple battle system (fights last 1 minute on lowest battle speed, resource management is semi-trivial in multiple ways)
- Literally one fourth of the 40-hours game-length is button-mashing through dialog cutscenes - 10 full hours of sheer fun!

Which is a genuine shame because with 9 party members; a free-form job system in the form of materia; and even a battle arena and mini-game casino in the game... you'd think all the pieces are there already for the ultimate infinitely-replayable (if a little casual) JRPG!

new review: Despite its flaws in terms of gameplay and combat, Final Fantasy VII remains a landmark in video game storytelling. It's a deep exploration of the human psyche and something everyone should get to enjoy. It's sad that this port changes or "improves" aspects of the game, though, because it does feel very different watching Sephiroth keep his mouth open all the time or getting the Tough (not Touph) Ring... if you ever play this, please be sure to find a version with the original translation and textures and such.
FF7

The reason this is unarguably one of the best games in existence is because it took me my entire childhood to complete. That reasoning may not sway you immediately, but read on. 

With the exception of NHL 1999 and a PS1 port of Space Invaders, it's the first video game I ever owned. Certainly, it’s the first one I ever bought for myself, and the first one I properly ‘played’. 7-year-old me didn't actually own a memory card at the time, but I didn’t let that stop me; for the first few weeks (until I eventually caved and splashed out what must have been a lot of hard-earned pocket-money on an 8MB memory card from a now-defunct Blockbusters outlet) I aimed to complete the game in a single sitting. Given that the game was a 3-disc epic, looking back at that seems… overly ambitious, to say the least.

One evening, I don’t know why, I simply stopped playing. When I came back to it a few weeks later, I was utterly lost. This is the curse of the JRPG; you put it away for a while and when you return your bag is filled with a dozen swords with names like “Butterblade” and you’re lost in a bog with some guy called Reginald. 

Fast forward ten years (or thereabout), and college-student me decides it’s time to start from scratch. I rediscovered how much FFVII got right, and how much of that formula still persists in modern iterations, and it disabused me of the notion that it was just my own dewy-eyed nostalgia that made the game one of my favourites. The graphics may had aged between ’02 and ‘12, but the choice of themes and depth of characters remain easily up there with the best of the medium.

Ultimately, it’s the artistry behind the world I admire, and how the sometimes-simple, sometimes-crazy story fits perfectly into it. This game was made in an era when your surroundings were a painstakingly drawn “3D” background, and it excels at these; Midgar especially is a smoky cyberpunk dream world. The opening premise is a carefully-crafted parable of the tensions between environmentalism and consumerism which we can still see today; Uematsu’s legendary soundtrack is an undeniable gold-standard; and the characters, clichéd and blocky as they are, are still immediately endearing in their own ways.

[h1]The (nearly) perfect Cyberpunk fairytale.[/h1]

How can you start playing FF VII without having sky-high expectations? It's widely believed to be the best FF game, one of the best RPGs of all time, the greatest game for the original Playstation, yada yada yada. But if you look past the nowadays dated but still charming 3D grafics, which were a first for the series in 1997, you'll quickly notice that it basically is just like every other FF game that came before: It is no doubt a great game, the story is epic and emotional, the atmosphere and artstyle are unique, the music is fantastic and in general it is just a very fun and motivating game to play (for the very most part). 
But: 
The combat system is basically still the exact same since the first game (a few notable tweaks aside) and it is still the same old Final Fantasy gameplay since 1987. In some areas FF VII was even a bit stripped back and streamlined compared to previous FF games: There is no more Job system, no more abundance of playable characters like in FF VI and you only have three active party members at once, instead of the usual four. For the very most part, FF VII is also considerably easier than its predecessors. The good thing is that there is very little to no necessary grinding whatsoever, so it flows a bit better, but it also feels a bit like on rails sometimes. All of this made me think that for me FF VII is the same case as FF VI: Yes, it's great, yes, it's epic, yes, it definitely stands out within the RPG genre, still i can't help but feel that it is slightly overrated.

The most things to complain about are really just nitpicking though: On the pre-rendered backgrounds it is sometimes very hard to see where you can actually go. The controls can get a bit fiddly, too, especially during heated battles, when you are under a lot of pressure. Finally, the german translation is full of spelling errors, missing letters (sometimes even whole words) and stuff like that, so it makes reading the dialogue a bit tedious at times.

All of this does little to take away from the overall greatness of the game. However, there is one major flaw, that keeps popping up again and again in almost every FF game i've played so far: The last third is a lot less enjoyable than the rest of the game, because it gets pretty cryptic and the difficulty spike in the final dungeon is just ridiculous. The game starts to give you only very minimal hints where to go next and either you are a very patient person who backtracks over the whole world map to check every possible location again until you find the right spot to progress, or you just have to take a look at a walkthrough. What is even more frustrating and irritating though, is the mentioned sudden increase in difficulty in the last dungeon. It is simply beyond me why every last dungeon in those older FF games just catches you completely off-guard, even though your characters are pretty strong without any problems or necessary grinding at all so far (my characters all were between lvl 60 and 70 when I reached the final boss). Battle strategies that worked flawlessly for the whole game are suddenly completely useless. To top it all off, as always the final dungeon is a quite long one (about one and a half to two hours at the very least) and the game gives you exactly ONE possibility to save your game and no shops or merchants where you could stock up on items and equipment. So, if you make the mistake to enter the final dungeon ill-equipped, with underdeveloped characters and insufficient gear, you'll probaly end up just completely f*cked-up and unable to beat a game that was ridiculously easy for 35 to 40 hours. Even though I basically knew what was coming (because I played FF III, IV plus The After Years, V and VI so far) and thought I'd be prepared, I still found the final boss fight pretty hard and unforgiving. If this would have been my first FF game, I'd have been pretty p*ssed about this unreasonable endgame difficulty. However, this flaw isn't a specific flaw of FF VII, it is the same sh*t in almost every previous FF game. The only FF game I've played so far that had a comparatively smooth endgame for me was FF V, because of the excellent Job System that provides you with a ton of flexibility, but is sadly absent since FF VI.

Overall, I can see why people were going nuts over this game 25 years ago: For 1997 standards, it is a game with pretty epic proportions and it is still as good in 2023. However, my personal favorite is still FF IV, even if it's just because FF VII still hadn't really changed things up that much since then.

I regret not playing this game sooner. I put off playing ff7 because I did not think it would stand the test of time. I was incredibly wrong and here is why this game is amazing to this day

The plot of the game can be a bit confusing at times but in my opinion still managed to impress me and keep me wanting more. What I look for in a story game is a story that makes me crave for answers and to see the end of things and ff7 did just that. I loved watching my team tackle the small problems that became world ending problems. Loved the story.

The art style of the game is probably my favorite part of the game. I had previously thought I would hate the old graphics and art and that they would be outdated but I was so off. I loved how many pretty environments and awesome towns and buildings there were. Those areas make up for the empty areas of the game that exist due to the limitations of the time. Loved the art

Lastly the characters of the game are so very likeable and well written. Notably, my favorites were Cid and the Turks. I like both of them for the same reason, and that being the humor made me laugh throughout the whole game. Cid was just always making snarky and witty remarks and the Turks were just always being stupidly goofy and I loved it. Each character's backstory gave me more of a reason to actually like them and understand their motives. I have only played ff7 and ffx but I can confidently say the ff7 crew is my favorite crew by a mile. Also worth mentioning that cloud and sephiroth are just the coolest protagainst and antagonist ever.

+ The best Final Boss I have ever seen on a game (And I have played a lot of games)

CONS:

- Requires internet connection to start the game. BOOOO!
- Dated graphics, sometimes laughable chubby arms. (Fixed with Mods)
- Has that problem most FF games have where the story momentum halts, before the big finale as you run around doing other things.
- This game is responsible for becoming Square Enix's cash cow and thus we got a plethora of bad spin offs based on this game and Cloud Strife is literally everywhere.
- Hard to enjoy today without spoilers. Mostly everyone knows the iconic final boss theme and what happens to a certain character.

Overall, FF7 Is a JRPG Masterpiece. But you are probably better off playing it on console.

There's not much I can say about Final Fantasy VII that you haven't likely already heard a million times over. This game definitely has a reputation.

FFVII was originally released in 1997, so it is definitely pretty outdated as far as graphics, sound quality, etc go. When you're outside of battle, the characters are blocky and their proportions make them look like Popeye. The soundtrack is catchy and iconic for a reason, but the instruments and sound fonts are definitely not what they are now. It was pretty ahead of its time when it was released, but now that we are 25+ years out, simply put... If you are the type of gamer that needs total immersion and amazing, state of the art graphics, you will definitely be put off by this game.

If that doesn't bother you, though, you are definitely in for a treat. This game has become a staple in gaming and JRPGs, and it got that status for a reason! Where this game really excels is its story and characters. Set in a futuristic, industrial world, an electric power company has gained too much power and authority, gaining an army for itself and taking over the large city of Midgar. Your party is a group of rebels seeking to take this company down, led by an ex-soldier from their military. As the game goes on, you learn more about the electric company's shady practices and experiments and just how much they're sucking the life force of the planet for their own greed, and all the (MANY MANY) repercussions of that. Also hey maybe greedy corporations having THEIR OWN PRIVATE MILITARY could be bad for everyone possibly???

As much as I love FFVII, it is not my favorite Final Fantasy. With that said, though, if you're new to the Final Fantasy series and not sure where to start, I would probably recommend this as your entry point to the series. The main Final Fantasy games are set in different worlds, with different settings and casts of characters, so there is no need to play them in order or dive in at any specific point. So many of FFVII's characters, themes, and concepts have become THE standard for JRPGs. FFVII has spawned sequels, prequels, remakes, movies, cameo appearances of its characters in other games... Even so many years after its initial release, this game has managed to stay relevant and keep people clamoring about it. I still see characters in newer games get compared to Cloud or Sephiroth pretty frequently.

In playing this game, you are allowing yourself to experience a vital piece of gaming history.

I have played this game twice in my life before deciding to finally play it on steam.

+The characters. Where do I start with the characters of Final Fantasy 7. Literally everyone in the world knows who Cloud is and for good reason. This game really goes out of its way to develop the main cast. All of them are lovable and it's honestly hard to hate on any of them. Aerith is such a great character honestly. 

+The story is some of the best narratives you will ever find. It is heavy yet unpredictable. Puts you into an existential crisis just the way I like it. The story had so many elements and yet they all mesh together well in a way that's not too hard to digest. Finding out about Cloud's past blew my mind away as a kid. Maybe it's a spoiler but who doesn't know about it at this point but the dam death of Aerith hit me hard as a kid and I am happy to say it still hits so dam hard now.

+This game isn't the longest but since I mentioned it already, Aerith's death happens at the end of disc 1. This game is a 3 disc game. You actually play most of the game without her but oh my god this game truly makes you care about the characters that even though we are without Aerith for longer than we are with her, she will still be missed throughout the whole story. Of course she is being mentioned constantly but dam.

+There is a fair amount of side content in this game if you want to go for all the collectibles like getting ultimate weapons and the like. Personally I just consume my Final Fantasy games for the story so I don't indulge in side content so much but if you really love the game then this game does have it for you.

+The soundtrack is timeless. You cannot find anyone who will dislike the soundtrack of this game. Hard to sum it up into words but I will just say Aerith's theme is very very emotional and hits all the heart strings, Tifa's theme is a solid ass track and of course the iconic one-winged angel. Catch me shivering in my boots throughout my many years to that piece, what a dam masterpiece of an OST.

+The world is beautiful and the places didn't feel like they were just put for the sake of content. It feels really rewarding to explore the world and talking to the npcs wasn't such a chore. I really loved Midgar. Sadly we only really explore it for like 10 hours or so but dam what a great place. The different areas were all so unique and great places too. Nibelheim is such an iconic place and dam can't believe they brought the smash bros stage to this game too in Northern Cave.

+I mentioned characters already but I have to specifically mention Sephiroth since he is so sick and one of the greatest antagonists in jrpgs. It's hard to talk about him without spoiling the story but I'll just leave it as he was truly satisfying to see in the story. In fact it is very rare to find a person who doesn't know who Sephiroth is in this day and age as he is that iconic. Maybe overrated to a degree but dam he is so dam cool. His story and his fight are very memorable to me.

+The combat is very fun with the atb gauge. It wasn't just who is faster gets to make their turn first as people will get their turn if you take too long similar to games like Child of Light. It is still turn-based but you have to be more active with your play. There is a fair amount of thinking that gets involved in here and there weren't too many bs things with the combat. Except turning into frogs... Who even thought this was a good idea... The worst thing that can possibly happen to you is getting froglocked and you didn't save recently so you will have to sit through it and hope for the best.

+Along with the combat being fun, you can pick and build anyone you so choose since there is no obvious power creep between characters. Of course there is some character-specific cheese like with Tifa and Cait Sith, but this game is perfectly fun playing whoever you like. Of course I don't even need to say I used Yuffie and Tifa for the most part. You do need to invest in 6 characters if you don't want to get messed up by the end of the game.

+Even though there are many things you can grind in this game (which personally i enjoy doing), you definitely don't need to grind to complete this game, just expect a much more difficult game if you don't grind. You will definitely have a much easier time if you go for stuff like ultimate weapons for each of the characters. I didn't bother going for those in this playthrough but it is definitely doable.

-The visuals are definitely outdated.

-The random encounters are so frustrating to deal with in this game since running takes so long. On top of this battles take so so so long which doesn't matter with bosses and the like but for random encounters it does get frustrating, especially since fleeing takes a while.

-This game definitely needs a turbo button. Exploration takes way too long. On this note everyone should try playing this with the 7th heaven mod.

-All the minigames suck. Honestly, I didn't enjoy any of them.

Overall the story and characters truly make FF7 the beloved game that it is. Hard to recommend to people who are new to JRPGs because it has so many inconveniences which are not found in modern games, but for anyone with the patience for these old games, you should definitely try it.

Hailed as a milestone by most for me the bit of VII I played (still in Midgar) was mostly not as great as expected. Therefore I recommend to play the Remake instead.

Why?
- Pacing - it's too fast, too many things happen at once where the next problem starts:
- Writing (background) - there is not enough of it, context is missing and I, as a player don't know why I should care most of the time of who is who and
- Writing (quality) who they are and why they want this. Of course, some of the information will be available later but because so much happens so fast you don't give the player enough reasons to care about it all. It needs more time. The quality of the text is just abysmal. Some texts are clearly written for 12-15 year old boys in mind, which explains why some of this even spilled over into VIIR, mostly how every female character behaves towards Cloud. It's just way, way, worse here.
- Background design - it's an old game, so you have to expect old graphics, but in a lot of scenes I had no idea where I can go. It's not clear. Also where VIII and IX are mostly similar in background quality VII is worse than those two, so expect that.
- Funny enough, VIIR improved the battle system by a lot by copying some things from IX in context to materia and weapons

And now how this was ported:
- Controls are terrible. The game doesn't show you the actual buttons when giving instructions but the placeholder name for the function, there is also no support for XBox controllers, some buttons work, most don't. It works well enough, but I expected more. The d-pad for example doesn't work at all which forces you to use the sticks to navigate, which, for menues is terrible
- If you intend to use the booster - you need to activate the cloud saving for that, for whatever reason
- I expected to get at least some QoL improvements, but they just seemed to port it as cheaply as they can. It works in full HD though, just upscaled with bars on the side, fine enough by me.

My main reason to suggest to play VIIR instead are still the pacing and writing though. VIIR does a better job in portraying the characters and their relationships to each other and there have been some significant changes to the writing quality, the amount of writing, the amount of stuff happening and some plot elements that make it better for a modern audience without nostalgia googles on.
It's true though that you will understand some hints to the original plot only when playing the original. But in my experience, VIIR is a superior experience overal and playing the original is not worth it. I will continue out of curiousity though, but I rather experience all the plots and characters in the Remake first.

Doesn't have the best dialogue or graphics but the story so far is pretty good and rich. It even explores the backstories of side characters which I really appreciate. The fight mechanics are pretty fun but may not be for everyone. Long story short, play the game for its story and maybe check out the remake.

I genuinely recommend this game. It has all sorts of things from Dragons to Aliens to Massive Bio-mechanical Kaiju this game has it all.

Your main team consists of a Talking Dog, a Florist,Amputated Coal Miner, Bartender,Gambling Robot Cat, and an Angry Swearing Pilot all led by an amnesiac with an incredibly large amount of trauma in his quest to kill a silver haired mama's boy who intends to become one with the planet. This game is incredibly weird and wacky but can also switch to incredibly deep and emotional moments despite its general cast of weirdos and misfits.

[h1] An All Time Classic that absolutely deserve its "Cult" reputation [/h1]

Words themselves are hardly enough to share my love for FF7, and somehow, it wasn't exactly love at first sight. This is not going to be another basic review to tell you how great this game is. To truly capture my relationship with it, I gotta share a bit of my story towards it.

I started my steam account on June 2013, I had always been a console player. But in 2012, an important member of my family died of cancer, for about a year, it was merely impossible to get satisfaction and distraction out of my usual hobbies, video games included. I tried my best to dive back into games that I loved, with very engaging and moving scenarios.. No luck there. On June, a friend of mine, told me that I should install steam and play with him, mostly prop hunt and CS Source. So I did, and I opened myself to PC gaming. Then a month later, Final Fantasy VII released. I was already familiar with the characters of the universe, don't ask me why but I had watched Advent Children a couple times before. So I tried, told myself, "hell, everyone's pissing on my FFIX opinion by saying VII is better, let's find out".

I think that, nothing could have prepared me for such an adventure...

You all know the basics, you play Cloud, a former SOLDIER from the Shinra Electric Company turned mercenary. He's running around the world with his buddies from the AVALANCHE eco terrorist group, fighting against Shinra. Why you may ask ? Because Shinra is siphoning the planet's life blood, redeemed as Mako energy, pumped out by Reactors. And cut, that's basically all you need to know. Of course given the immense pop culture reach of this game, you probably know a lot more than you think.

And this is where the fun begins. Seeing Cloud and his little party of misfits run around made me reflect on adulthood with more strenght than any other game. Final Fantasy related, I strongly believe this FF has the widest variety of themes ever explored. From Grief to loss, through hate to survivor's guilt. From asking yourself why you are the way you are to who you are. The mature themes developped will leave a stain of philosophical reflection you'll have a hard time washing off.

Gameplay wise, this FF uses a "materia system" that pushes the possibility to a new horizon compared to previous titles. Materias have specific uses, like magic action or support spells, but they offer a wide selections of posibilities you'll probably need help figuring out, giving this title, a true and unique energy that is kind of unmatched when you look at the series. Materia's aside, it's basic ATB turn based gameplay, works like a charm, nothing to see.

The PC port is rather good, community is insanely good: Mods, help guides, someone will answer you, if you ask nicely. A small downside, I am French (that's not the downside) and the translation is a mess, I don't know if it's the case everywhere. You should opt for an English language playthrough, if you can. Wide support is present, although it doesn't respect the screen ratio, you'll have to tweak around to set it up, however I had no issues whatsoever with controller support, but I saw people making a big deal out it, so I guess it depends on the controller.

In the end, this game helped getting me out of my depression, like I said I couldn't play anything more than 20min before feeling bored and unattracted. Without realizing it, I put 15 hours in FFVII the day I started it. The plot, its loving and interesting characters, everything is perfectly fitted to make a masterpiece. And here I am, 9 years later, writing about it.
While FFIX was there during my entire childhood, to shape my identity and the very basis of who I am, FFVII pushed me further in life, pushed me harder, deeper into adulthood, in order to understand what life is all about.

Give it a shot, one day or another, there will always be time.

Final Fantasy 7 is one of the most influential games in history and most people know that.. but I think the game's legacy doesn't end there, FF7 didn't only change the dimensions of the series but it transformed the whole series into a mainstream one, that every gamer should know about.
Don't let me start on the story.. It's one that has many twists yet each one of them is very fitting and don't feel forced at all, great characters with amazing writing and well-structured motives, captivating world-building that is on par with the greatest novels ever written, and ultimately a truly shocking ending that had people tear down all over the world. 
I can't express how much I find this game amazing and how much I love it, it's way ahead of it's time and most certainly deserves all the recognition it had and it still has.

This game is truly amazing, it really hits your heart really deep. It's story rich and you can tell the emotions that went into the game. 

For example, Aerith's theme song, the producer of FF7 in Hironobu Sakaguchi made this game as a memory to his recently deceased mother. That's why the theme of memory is so prevalent in this game. The memory of Zach. The memory of Cloud. Sephiroth's past. Aerith and her mother's memory. The memory of the planet itself. Red 13, Yuffie, Barret, Cid, Tifa, Vincent and others deal with their own pasts as well. And this theme captures all the emotions of motherhood of characters like Aerith. Caring, loving but also sentimental, nostalgic and sad, especially when they pass on and leave their children.You can tell the musical direction is a unique mix of optimism and somberness to reflect the producer's feelings as he was crafting this game.

There is more depth to this game than you'd think. And there's so much content, replaying the game might change your entire story since there's just so much you could miss potentially. 

This game is absolutely amazing, and without question or argument, it is one of the top Final Fantasy games ever made

Undoubtedly one of the greatest games ever made. It's a perfect mix of great characters with interesting personalities that grow over the course of the game, and incredible tragic story, one of the best music soundtracks, and a fun materia system. The PS1 graphics are a bit dated now, but the pre-rendered backgrounds are still pretty nice, even if pixellated. Playing this on an old CRT screen, you never noticed how low the resolution was, and the backgrounds looked much more seamless with the character graphics. On PC, the easiest way to recognize that an object can be interacted with is that the object is high-resolution against the background.

Final Fantasy for me was something I grew up with very indirectly. I never played the games, never even seen a whole lot of game-play, but I saw how it seeped into the early 2000s culture both in the niche and mainstream growing up, and the late 90s before I was born. In a lot of my early memories, this mysterious, yet oddly deeply nostalgic series was just put on discussion forms, talked about at second-hand game markets I went to as a kid, and had Yoshitaka Amano's artwork plastered all over the early internet.

And I've just beaten VII. My first Final Fantasy. And while I still don't 100% agree with the rabid levels of hype, I understand why it's been able to stay relevant in culture as long as it has. If you already know about this game, this is a great port as far as I can tell! If you don't, then I really would consider jumping in blind, pretty much how I did. It's an incredibly solid RPG, with a ridiculous amount of depth and detail. Now, Onto VIII.

I have played this game since my childhood on PS1. I played it on PS2, and I played it on PC, passing the game on practically each available console. Lifelong, I have collected more than 2000 hours on this one. 

For sure, we are talking about the greatest story written in gaming, being extremely rich in content, but also allowing room for "those who want to know more". Some would say this game is simple, and yes you can beat the final boss in 40-60 hours of gameplay, but this game is so much more than it seems. The story arc is so beautifully designed that it covers every type of gamer, as you can select some key paths to take or not, and therefore tailor your own experience. This also allows the game to be very re-playable.

From my own experience, I feel you would need around 100-120 hours to complete the game in a "100% fashion", meaning you unlock and defeat all the extra bosses and see all the extra stories and animations. And that is if you know exactly what you are doing, or follow a walkthrough. I simply cannot imagine how many hours would it take for someone who never played this game to finish it completely in their first run. And this is what I adore about FFVII, it is simply as complex as you want it to be and become.

Understanding it dates from 1997., one might say that graphics suck or that it is not playable to this date, and first go for the remake or simply grab another game, but the fact that this game is so advanced in it's story and approach just crushes everything else, including other games. [spoiler] I mean, you can make the protagonist date different characters at a certain point of game, which is an outcome of around 8 different dialog decisions you make across the previous chapters, which can lead even to a homosexual date. This is just one little "spoiler" which represents how advanced this game actually is, and the rest is for you to discover. [/spoiler]

The game's main quest is interesting and fun, while it provides a mountain of extra value like side quests, hidden characters, weapons and so much more. It also has additional in-game mini-games which just add more fun to it all, while Chocobo breeding deserves a book or a game for itself how well it is designed.

For a beginner, this might be a challenging game to conquer, as some bosses require either serious skill in the Materia combination or the story reading part, as there are some hints and tricks hidden in the story itself. This mechanic leads to diving deeper in the story, trying to understand it even better. For someone who played this before, but hasn't played it for years, I highly recommend re-playing the game, as there is so much extra value to it coming from new perspective of the player, as we grow older and older.

Characters are very detailed in their design and their stories are remarkable as well, but what makes this game completely unforgettable is it's soundtrack, the music. The music is so carefully well crafted that it emotionally adds on to the entire story all the time. It adds that kick to it. Simple, maybe, but very catchy tunes that you will either whistle, dream, or use as a ringtone on your cellphones.

All in all, and to this very date, this is the best game I have ever played!

So, if you love great stories and RPGs, it is always a good time to (re)try Final Fantasy VII!

p.s. shame that The Steam Awards don't support nomination for the best game ever

Final Fantasy 7 is the most overrated game I've ever played. And I'm not talking about this crappy port, but the game itself.

Remember that cave in Pokemon Red/Blue/Yellow that is full of Zubats and you can't walk without using Repel? Now imagine a game that takes place entirely inside that cave with no Repel whatsoever. 50 hours of dull combats, in which you just mash the "OK button" because the enemies are too weak or dumb to require any attention. Hundreds, if not thousands, of combats like these.

Another problem with combat is the absurd lenght of unskipabble animations during some actions. Many times I just chose not to use my best summoning moves because of how long the animation would take and how boring it is to wait it out. The worst offender is the ridiculous move the final boss has in which he [spoiler]destroys the whole solar system[/spoiler] and the animation seems to never end. And he uses it multiple times. Unbelievable.

And that's the core of Final Fantasy 7.

I say combat is the core of the game because the story is a huge let down. A major disapointment. It's so ridiculously convoluted that instead of being compelling, it's just confusing. So, since you don't know wtf is going on, you just keep on fighting, hoping things will eventually start to make more sense. But they never do.

And there's the big spoiler, the one everyone knows about. The "most heart-wrenching moment in the history of video games". It was definetely not. There was no decent character development up until that point; [spoiler]the death itself was weird and confusing since it's not even clear if Sephiroth exists, if he's only inside Cloud's head, if it was a clone of his;[/spoiler] I didn't know then and I still don't know even after finishing the game.

So, combat is dull (except for some bosses), the story is crap, the map is useless, the game's overworld feels like a big empty desert, the sections added for variety are absolute garbage, specially the snowboarding one (the chocobo race is probably the least terrible of them all) and the list goes on. Playing this game quickly became a chore, but I wanted to see what all the fuss was about. So I finished it and I don't intend on playing one more second of it ever again.

I guess back in the day people were bedazzled by the sight of 3D boobs or by the sheer size of a game divided in 3 discs (the third part is a lot shorter than the first two, and I was really glad with that). The game is big, indeed, but it's full of nothingness for the most part. The other part is a weird and nonsensical story.

[h1]Technical: [/h1]
[b]Mods I would recommend:[/b]
- The Reunion ("Beacause" new Translation, Model Overhaul, 60 FPS Battles, HD Menus, Audio Overhaul)
- SYW Textures

I played through the entire game with these mods running on my Steam Deck. Once I got everything running, it was a seamless experience that holds up very well technically.

[h1]Subjective Thoughts:[/h1]
As someone who has never played the original and has no nostalgia for it, I wanted to play it for historical purposes. I knew the game was wildly influential and held a big spot in a lot of peoples hearts. I always hear mentions of its mechanics, characters, and story.

I can absolutely see why everyone likes it so much. The cast of characters is charming, the story is interesting, and the battles are nice. Any qualms I have with the game I think have been addressed in the past 25 years of game development, so I won't bother.

[b] With a little time spent getting some mods running, its a game I definitely recommend for those like me who have no nostalgia whatsoever. Get a history lesson. [/b]

I know everyone already knows about Final Fantasy VII.
This is not per se a review, more so my experience and anecdotes, mixed in with a few pros and cons (for me personally).

Where to begin? I am playing Games since the early 90s. I owned a Nintendo 64 before I got my Playstation (had to sell my N64 and my Games so I could get the PS1, still don't know why I did that, stupid kid me...) and my first Contact with FF VII was on the Demo Disc that was included in the PS1.
I started it up, played a little, didn't like it and stopped playing. That was it. Those are my FF VII memories.

But I got older, I am nearing my 40's now and I do like to play a lot (!) of Games, including many old school Games that I either want to replay because of fond memories or Games that I never played before because I didn't have them or didn't give them a chance when I was younger.

So, with FF VII it was hard for me. Everyone is praising this Game as one of the best Games ever made, for some it even is THE best Game ever made. I could never connect (also probably because I don't like Turn Based RPG's at all - although I played some very late and appreciated them at least a little).

With that all being said, how did I like FF VII? Is it the best Game ever? For me, no! 
Is it one of the greatest Games ever? For me, tending more to no, BUT I actually found an appreciation for this kind of Game and for FF VII especially.
This Game came out in 1997 and for that time - if you were into Turn Based Combat - I get why many people praise this to high heavens.

One of my thoughts was that this Game didn't age very well, but after a while of playing I found it kind of charming. The World, the Characters, even the Combat and Exploration, everything grew on me.
Did I really love it? No, I liked it, it is (for me) a good Game.

I have to mention that I HATED the missing Controller Options for my X-Box One Controller, wish there was an Update. I could play with my Controller but it was showing on Screen only the Keyboard Prompts. Not even the Keys themselves but the description of what the Key is doing.
I know there are probably some mods or 3rd party Options out there that can remedy some of that, but I played it as it is.

So, I sunk almost 50 hours into the Game, finished it, did some side stuff (Golden Chocobo, got my Knights of the Roundtable thingy, etc.) and missed out on a few things. I didn't fight all the Weapons, don't know how to find them and I didn't really want to look it up. Also I didn't get all the Limit Breaks for all the Characters and stuff like farming for lvl99 or 99Million Gil...no thanks.

So, I would still recommend this Game because at the End of the day I had fun and I was invested.
Not only can I know appreciate the Game, I alson want to play more FF Games and maybe give some other Turn Based Games a shot (I know, in FF VII it is only kind of Turn Based with the Battle System thing).
Looking forward now to playing the Final Fantasy VII Remaster and FF 15. 
Those will be next and some time in the future I will stock my collection up with all the older FF Games.

So yeah, very long story short: Good Game. Check it out. But let's be real, everyone here probably already played this a million times...

[b]⊕[/b] Music has been changed back from MIDI form. Cloud-saving is kind of nice I suppose, since the game is so long (It can also be disabled.) Mistranslations and errors have been fixed. The game itself flows smoothly and is not prone to eye-sore jittering. I have not run into any crashing. FF7 itself is a great part of RPG history and worth a try.

[b]⊖[/b] Logging in with Square is irritating and leads to issues if you aren't connected via internet. I'm not sure that level of invasiveness in the DRM is worth what benefits it gives you. The monster designs in this one are absolutely laughable, to the point of embarrassment. That's part of the fun for some, though.

[b]✎[/b] Solid port that has fixed issues both in the original PC and PSX versions.

What am I going to say in favor of a seminal game like this that a hundred others haven't already said? It's a great game that holds up well and has a lot of emotional value to many of us from the first generation of kids who grew up with video games as far back as we can remember.

The gameplay is solid and a good twist on the FF formula, which any good FF should be. It has plenty of little (and huge) secrets that will keep you digging into all the nooks of the game. The story has all the awkward points you'd expect from an ambitious 90s game, and it's interesting to view it against the smoother retelling in FF7 Remake. And with the added bombshell of smuggling all your mastered materia to a fresh saved game, this is well worth $12.

And if you're coming back for a second (or twelfth) playthrough and want to breathe new life into the game, the Satsuki Yatoshi mod is free and fantastic, and it doesn't require any of the 7th Heaven entanglements. It's a beautiful reskin of the game that keeps all the original intent.

I hit NO for Recommend mostly because of repeated random crashes in the Steam PC version on Windows 11.Usually a couple of hours of play without, but they seem to occur at about any point That is particularly frustrating after 20 minutes or so into a long sequence between allowable saves. Otherwise the game is what it is given it's age. It was cheap on Steam for PC so I bought it.

Review of game itself
Battle system is extremely simple.
Long (very long like more than 30 minutes) stretches between allowable save points often immediately after a boss battle meaning you have to wait to save after a boss battle..
Character control or navigation is often clumsy. Arrow keys are tilted 45 degrees which is sometimes confusing. Objects blocking path may require trial and error to get by them. It is even worse when the picture displayed shows the characters far away or partially obscured.
Character trait development depends a lot on Materia. Materia advancement is very slow.

Final Fantasy VII is an amazingly solid RPG today that's worth playing, in spite of very much being a product of its time.

The game is clunky in a few regards. It isn't the most intuitive to set up and configure everything with a modern controller, the translation while not "bad" has some moments of awkward and campy dialogue and the visuals, especially the 3D models, haven't aged all that great though you could argue these points do add to the charm of FFVII. 

That being said there are many aspects of FFVII that have aged very gracefully, or are just flat out timeless. The story is very engaging throughout it's 40-50 hour runtime, a few very interesting characters and quite a few good plot twists, not to mention this game is pretty hecking funny at times, intentionally or not.

The combat system is pretty good all things considered with some very interesting additions in the Limit Breaks and the Materia system. Pulling out the occasional super move makes for a very nice incentive to having your party being beaten down by the enemy and the Materia system allows you to customise the abilities of every single party member to the way you like it. Unfortunately that also means that aside from limit breaks there isn't much that makes a party member unique from another.

One thing that hasn't aged all is the soundtrack. So many good tone setters and just generally good jams, honestly the game might be worth playing for the soundtrack alone, it's just that good.

While its not my favorite RPG ever made, I absolutely respect Final Fantasy VII and it definitely deserves its title as one of the most important RPGs of all time.
