7.5/10
Final Fantasy VII was when Final Fantasy TRULY became a mainstream franchise. The first time it became 3D with amazing graphics and visuals for its time... it was also the one I was most looking forward to as it is the ff game that generally EVERYONE points to as "the best final fantasy game". While I came into the game with HIGH hopes, just finishing final fantasy VI and LOVING it, I left with a bit of a mixed feeling for ff7.

Story
Final Fantasy VII's story had one of the biggest advantages out of any of the previous final fantasy games, the usage of not only 3d visuals, but cutscenes, multiple dialogue boxes, camera angles like never before, amazing presentation to allow them to fully flesh out what story they want to tell instead of the limitations like before. The story is more straight forward compared to previous entries like 6, which is how humanity is killing the planet in order to fulfill their selfish goals even if it costs the very planet they live on. While people make ff7 a revered story... I think it is fine imo. While it isn't the GREATEST story, it does have some pretty good highs especially when pulling off their twists around the mid point of the game. While I do like the story, it also comes with its fair share of stand out flaws. For example, I don't think midgar was well paced the very moment we entered the shinra tower. Yeah it is the haha funny stair scene that annoyed me, but also the fact that in between every single story bit, you are forced to play through a pointless minigame that are not only not very good, but ruin the game's pacing it had previously. The stories' pacing overall is what really ruined it the most in terms of what I think of it, also with the fact that it has way more outdated story bits like calling barret the R word and women slapping minigame, but also the fact that it wasn't as interesting to me not only cause of its lack of depth compared to ff6, but for also another issue I had with the game.

Character
Final Fantasy VII's characters were simply... very bad. Look, Cloud, Aerith, and Tifa were really good characters, and while I do think Cloud was especially the best fleshed out character, it took him quite a long time to reach that point as before he is just kinda bland till the twist around the mid way point. Still, those early segments with him being a very unreliable narrator, being confused was still very interesting, just took a bit to get there. Aerith, especially her relationship with other characters made her to be a VERY interesting character and had pretty good development imo. Tifa also was a pretty good character, with her only flaw being responsible for one of the worst decisions in the story that can be stretched to make sense, but thinking about it was kinda just dumb. However after that, is when FF7's REAL problem kick in, the rest of the cast you follow with for the majority of the game just aren't that good. Barret seems like someone who would be very interesting, which is cause he is... for 1/5th of the game, till you reach a certain town in which his character development kinda finishes and he becomes a much blander character the rest way through the game. The rest of the cast just simply suck. Cid is an asshole who is annoying at times, Yuffie was just boring and had very little to do apart from lmao steal your materia, Red XIII almost NEVER grows even during his pivotal part in the story, stayed the same beginning to end. Cait Sith idk why he even stayed in the party and is just a terrible member, as he is FORCED into your party, BETRAYS you very early on, and the party is just like "ok we forgive you!"... why. Vincent is also just a very boring, bland character who's only development is his backstory of him being cheated on. Overall the characters being weak def made the story weaker as well, even tho it was a pretty ok story to begin with. Look I know that there HAD to be weak characters, even ff6 had some weak side characters, but the difference is that ff7 has a TON of the character being weak. While they have their moments, overall I do think they are overhyped simply do to them having more development in the side games, which is great, but in the original they aren't that good. Even more disappointing was Sephiroth, who for being the FAN FAVORITE of the community, was overall not that interesting of a character. His motivation was overall bleh, he was at times comedic when it was obvious the game wanted me to take him serious, but he was just eh in terms of character.

Gameplay
Final Fantasy VII, from previous entries, has MUCH MUCH better presentation not only in story telling, but in gameplay as well. Animations went from being cool, to being SPECTACLES. The Materia system as well is just fantastic, in which is feels like the ff6 esper system but much more fleshed out, and while it does remove characters being unique as EVERY ability is linked to materia, discovering which to pair and the feeling that you are breaking the game was fantastic. However, it does have its fair share of issues. While I did mention that the animations are spectacle, it is also one of its bigger issue for the game, the animations are long... a bit TOO long. Battles and random encounters in general take MUCH longer compared to previous entries simply due to the amount of animations, opening camera pan, enemies now having attack and hurt animations, cast time, SUMMONS. While it does look AMAZING, it can get annoying, as there is no way of skipping the animations, and some of them like the knights of the round summon can take a FULL MINUTE which can be really cool at first, but can stretch battles sooo much more cause of it. It is still very cool, but def too long combat wise. Minigames also suck, I did kinda enjoy chocobo racing and maybe snowboarding, but the rest were just bad, and worse of all, forced. While it may seem like I dislike the combat, it is the complete opposite, I LOVED the gameplay as it was my favorite part of the game. While it has huge issues like too long due to animations, it is still the atb system that I love, just much prettier to look at even if grinding feels like an eternity.

Music
The music in this game was as expected, amazing. Cosmo Canyon, Jenova, one winged angel, bombing run, Aerith theme, there was sooo many songs that were just amazing. While it isn't my FAVORITE of the series, I still loved the ost. It can also hit hard especially during one scene, but overall is still really damn good.

Nitpicks/ Last Positive
- The game's difficulty was a bit on the easier side, final boss was a bit disappointing in terms of difficulty, but the endgame was easily my favorite part of the whole game, and while the superbosses just became watching knights of the round for 15 minutes, I still enjoyed the journey to prepping for them.
- Menu searching still annoying, there was an annoying issue where if I moved up or down in the menu and immediately clicked ok, it would skip a tab and choose something else which was really annoying.
- PC port isn't the best, no quicksave (but game isn't that hard so not that bad), no fast forward (made animations feel especially long my god), has bugs, and is overall not the cleanest, but is still good enough to play ff7
- ok I play all my jrpg on keyboard, and while key binding wasn't a big issue, the game did a TERRIBLE job telling me which key to press, and would just show [OK], instead of pushing my keybind which made it really confusing for when it instructs me what to do for a dumb minigame.

Conclusion
Final Fantasy VII was the one I was pretty hyped for, and while I do feel like the game is pretty overhyped, especially when people say its the best ff game, I still enjoyed the game. I liked the game's highs, but the game's low were just too much for  me sadly. I appreciate the game for what it did to the franchise, as it is EASILY the most important one, I don't think its close to the best final fantasy game imo.

an infuriating experience thanks to the menu selection jump glitch, which is still not fixed. when you are using menus, press down and then select quickly. for example, when the cursor is pointed at MATERIA and you want to open the EQUIP menu, press down and select quickly. this is supposed to open the EQUIP menu, but instead the cursor will jump to the next option in the menu (STATUS). this bug happens in all menus, including battle menus, and means you have to use slow, steady hands or else you will end up attacking your own party members or some other dumb shit. if you want the vanilla PS1 experience, AVOID THIS PORT LIKE THE PLAGUE! do yourself a favour and get an original PS1 copy instead. the only reason I didn't refund this trash port is because I want to play the game with mods.

A classic for a reason; music, story, setting, aesthetic, and an epic scale. Mods make it even better. It's superior to the Remake in all but graphics and gameplay. Honestly, the story divergences in the Remake make both versions worth playing.

While what was once a masterpiece certainly hasn't aged like fine wine(especially the graphics which revolutionary at the time, nowadays are so blurry they make navigating certain areas hard and the controls used for minigames), it's a pretty decent game until reaching the last part which is either a cheap, tedious, soulcrushing, unintuitive, frustrating and painful ordeal ,when going in blind or a laughably trivial and short experience when "wikigaming" (comparable to gothic 2's dragons as a melee character vs dragons when using scrolls).
This is especially annoying since the game is trivial for all its duration except for the last part, which serves as probably the biggest difficulty spike I've ever seen, and has ruined any enjoyment of the game for me.
Buy only if you can't afford the remake or your PC is a potat.

If you have issues with creating a local save and the cloud option is also disabled, try the recommended solution below.

Recommended Solution: Try disabling your network/internet connection (not the cloud option, this should already be disabled) before launching FF7 app. 
Result: This fixed both my start up black screen and in-game 'game save' issue.

I didn't have a system to play this on as a kid, so I'm approaching this review without nostalgia-tinted goggles. Overall, I absolutely loved it!

Pros:
-Solid story despite occasionally cheesy dialogue
-BEAUTIFUL soundtrack
-Satisfying progression
-No grinding necessary, unlike many other JRPG's
-Bare minimum of tens of hours of gameplay
-Materia system is REALLY fun to experiment with once you know what the effects are
-Secrets are fun and intuitive to discover as long as you read dialogue. No guides necessary

Cons:
-Controls are slightly clunky on keyboard, so you'll have to remap keybinds just for some minigame sections only to revert again
-Graphics are dated (although this is to be expected from a game released a quarter century ago)
-Some enemy designs make no sense (although you could argue that the eclectic nature is part of the game's charm)
-Materia effects are not clearly explained so you either have to experiment or check the wiki

I think this game is the epitome of "you had to be there". Finishing the game, I have to say that I think I would have enjoyed this game the most when I was at a certain age for it to have effected me in the same way many people say they've been effected by it. I mean this either in the sense of "you had to be there when it came out in 1997", or "you needed to be in a certain mindset to sorta plow through the game and get the most out of it".

First, I want to say that graphically, no matter what mods or upressing or blah blah you do, ultimately, this game was made for a CRT and that's where it looks best. I hooked my PC to an HDMI-to-Composite to my CRT TV, and while I'm sure a lot of quality was lost, It looked 1000x better than it looked on my monitor. If you have the means and ability to play it on a CRT, whether you're on PC or not, do it, you'll thank me later.

Secondly, the original English translation is absolute dogshit. I played through the game with The Reunion mod  which has the Beacause retranslation project, while following along reading the original script and any optional dialogue you necessarily have to miss by using this FF7 Script compilation by letao (https://letao.is-a-geek.net/ff7script/ ) I think this is [b]essential[/b] to play in the modern day. There are many moments in the story that, when I read the original script, are absolutely butchered and lose all of its original meaning and emotion.
The Reunion also features many other improvements, many of which are optional. This includes bug fixes (which fixes duping, sorry), restoring Playstation button prompts, raising the PC-exlusive 15 fps cap in battles to 60 fps, animation interpolation (off by default), switching out all of the low-poly overworld models with something closer to the in-battle models or otherwise based off concept art - if you aren't dead set on the original look or don't like the low-poly models like I didn't, then I'd go for it. (link; https://ff7.live/ )

Alright, on to the game itself. (A fair amount of this I'm taking from what I said to a friend, so it's a little loose);
The story is amazing, but besides a few outstanding moments often it's only in retrospect. I commend the game for having many different themes at play, some that would seem to have nothing in common, and managing to working them together in a way that no only avoids feeling muddled but actually compliment each other. Again, I feel like I
The dialogue itself is stilted and strangely unfulfilling in its goals, often vague or lacking distinct purpose - how do I put it... it feels, fluffy, airy? It has the same feel as a saturday morning cartoon right after you woke up and are half-asleep still as a kid - light, airy, as the words sort of come out and things happen like they should, things are happening but it's sort of stagnant, with no movement, floaty. It feels like nothing is happening while things are happening. I think this is common in a lot of TV shows. 
The pacing is pretty garbage, it's just all over the place whenever it wants to be. There'll be stretches of nothing, or long gaps of gameplay with little story, sometimes they're story all back to back to back and not in a plot point climax kind of way. It's so bizarre, the pacing is both "things just sort of happen" while also being feeling like there's momentum and that there's a force driving it. It can feel so directionless at times, you can leave some big event and for it to kinda tell you where to go but still feel like lost and be like "ok... uh, what now?". Some shit like the key is just absolutely archaic without a guide (if you played you know).
WITH THAT SAID, of course I think the story is excellent. 

All I need to say about the gameplay is:
Materia is a cool magic/ability system, though it's a little claustrophobic. Very good.
[i]FUCK ATB, IN EVERY FF GAME THAT USES ATB IT GETS FUCKING WORSE.[/i] I like turns better. I hate having to purposefully go in a menu to wait just so a group of enemies can't get 20 attacks in before I [i]eventually[/i] get my move out. It's worse here than in FF6, but it's nowhere as bad as it is in FFX-2. 
You can only have a party of 3 of your 6-8 party members, and while your benched members get half the xp (thank god) they get half the xp (oh shit these folks are 10 levels behind). Also, the way stats climb is very fucky and for some reason proportional to both the character's growth chart [i]and[/i] proportional to the current stats, making stat effecting accessories make a character level different? I don't know the technical details all I know is something fucky is happening there.

Again, I think that if I played FF7 at a particular point in my life it would have affected me deeply, and all of the stuff I missed and the secrets would have been fun things to get playing a second time through or whatever. Fun things that add to the depth of a game I already love as opposed to annoyances that make me play the game in a very specific way so I'm sure I'm not missing anything since I'm likely only going to be playing through the game once. All of the optional, mutually exclusive, missable, cryptic stuff which would have been amazing as a kid or as a long time fan just comes off as frustrating and tedious now. Its age and its transitionary-era general jank contribute to that feeling.

Conclusion... uh, play the game with The Reunion and with the script if you're like me at all, on a CRT if you have access to one.

I completely understand why everybody was excited for a remake... and they made a brand new FF7R that has its own continuity and shit going on, okay? Honestly there was nothing wrong with the contuity or story in of itself, it just needed some work on the pacing and, idk, a FFX-esque 3D world but still fundamentally the same FF7.
Not to shit on FF7R, I've yet to play it, it seems cool, but yeah, really bizarre world we live in.

I recommend that people play this version first (if you've got the OG PS1 version, you can play that too). IMO this version is superior to the "remake". I know it's nostalgia goggles and I really DGAF if anyone disagrees. This game was a milestone and if you were not there to see how it changed the game, it's difficult to describe. 

The story is a bastardized version of the original ideas that dev Takahashi (XENOGEARS BABY) came up with. Square deemed it too dark. They did hold on to a good deal of the original darker ideas and incorporate them into the story. There is a heavy influence on gnostic beliefs in this game and in Xenogears/Sagas. These beliefs are woven throughout the game.

The story is tl;dr the Bible. Jenova is the great calamity that fell from the sky (Lucifer) and Cloud/Christ (sacrifices himself to save the others) saves us. That is being too simplistic. I like how the devs wove Western mythos into the story. It's amazing how JRPG devs seem to be able to grasp these concepts and present them in an engaging manner without being disrespectful to the source. Holy crap, digress much? This is relevant though. I love this game because of the mythos woven through it. It's a story of self doubt. Overcoming it and triumphing. I think I can say that without spoiling it. I can't believe there are people who have not played this yet. Play it, play it now.

Definitely play this before you play that abomination remake. Yes it's pretty. Yes it's fun in a way but if you really want to experience the game without all that needless crap they've done to it; play this one. I'm just saying if you are a fan of JRPGs, especially this era, play it now! Did I say that enough yet? Play now!

A classic for a reason. Playing the Remake got me nostalgic for this again, and I can't say I'm disappointed. Much of it holds up. The story goes off the rails around the point you get to the Temple of the Ancients, and is Cait Sith's role in the plot isn't handled as well as I would like, but overall, the game is still fun, the writing is still...  fine, and the graphics are still mind-blowing for a game that came out only a decade after the original 8-bit entry in the series.

Doesn't have all the new achievements of the PS4 version, but has the benefit of being on PC (and thus moddable). Doing a vanilla playthrough now before I try out New Threat, and being reminded why I loved this game so much.

Before all the awful spinoffs that managed to shrink the world by "expanding" it, before Squenix started squeezing the cash-cow so hard it popped, the original stands, a quarter-century later, as a testament to what a great story, solid menu-based gameplay, and a deep, rich world can make you feel.

Yes, corporations are evil. Yes, systems can oppress beyond singular villains, and yes, this game is more political than you remember. If you still don't think it is, you obviously failed every Literature class you ever took.

Dear lord I have no idea where to begin and I suck at writing reviews... I’m also writing this review rather very late since I last played the game, but I will write one regardless. I suppose I can start with the fact that FF7 was introduced to me by someone who means a great deal to me and I’m so happy he did. I found out surprisingly FF4 was my first ever FF game. I wish so badly that my parents let me play on consoles or have consoles back then as a kid cause if I was allowed, I would’ve played this game on release. I’m sad I missed such an amazing game. But regardless I have finally played the original. The story is just something else, it makes you feel. I’ve only ever had one game really truly make me feel and this game being the other. I don’t want to give out much, but just this can make you feel emotions. The characters also get quite a lot of dept, which is one of my favorite things about the game. And of course with a game with such amazing story it comes with amazing music that really sets the tones for scenes and battles. The music is honestly, in my opinion, the best music ever for a video game. I actually still listen to the music from the game for some past time. And lastly, the Materia and battle mechanics are unique and without getting too much into it you can literally decide to do some interesting things gameplay wise with it. You can also do some dumb funny things with the Materia. You have a ton of different Materia and can choose to just try soooo many things. The summons is also amazing and my favorite. The graphics for its time I think are amazing. It’s definitely playable still and I had zero issues with it. 
I recommend this game highly as it has become my all-time favorite game. I plan to 100% the game in time. I’ve also watched the gameplay for remake and now that remake was shadow dropped, I can finally personally play that. Patience is a virtue. 100/10 franchise. I look forward to the trilogy and anything and everything to do with the franchise for FF7. This franchise has my everything.

I missed this one back in the day, so I don't feel any nostalgic appeal. So, judging it from today's perspective... it's bad.

I'm sorry, I know it's a classic. I'm just not into it. I played for a few hours and the story is absolutely linear. It's basically hitting next, next, next, whether I'm going through dialogue or combat. There are a few sections that play more like an adventure game, but a mostly boring one.

There are no choices that matter. It's almost a visual novel with combat, and the combat isn't very good. The original Pokemon games are JRPGs from this same time and they're FAR more interesting - they may also be linear, but team composition and training offer interesting tactical choices. FWIW, what I got to see of the story isn't very good either. There's a cross dressing sequence early on that's just made of cringe, with plenty of jokes trivializing sexual assault. The original Fallout is from the same year as this game, and while it's terribly juvenile in its own way, it's FAR less painful to play than this. 

I dunno, maybe it gets better 10 hours in. But I'm not going to keep playing a game I don't enjoy in order to find out.

While I'm at this... the interface SUCKS. The keyboard controls are awful, the game is meant to be played with a controller even if the kind of controls it uses would be better suited for a mouse. I understand that it's originally a console title, but this isn't an emulated game, it's a port. And I want to use a mouse to click around. It would be a FAR better game that way. Why can't I just click on dialog options or on menu items? This is just poor interface design, and it was poor 25 years ago too, it's not about age.

On top of these things the whole Remake only contains first 4-6hrs of this game's story. Ignore the Remake and play this instead.

At this point, given this game's impact, it's hard to judge it objectively.

It's a fine example of a classic jrpg from that weird border period when the genre was still niche but becoming more popular. Before the Final Fantasy name was the blockbuster it is now. For many, it was their first and so nostalgia will do a lot of the heavy lifting for you in terms of whether or not you like it.

If you didn't play the game before when it was new or your only experience is with newer jrpgs and you're wondering if this one is worth, well it has a lot of crusty old mechanics like save points and random encounters, but the fights are quick and save points plentiful. It still tells a solid story that is different in many ways from what we've seen so far of the Remake, for good or ill. The graphics haven't aged well (tho I'd argue the blocky character models are part of the game's charm and identity) but the game has been modded inside out to make it age more gracefully if that's more your speed.

It's personally not my favorite in the series: I think it kneecaps its own tension by making you participate in too many minigames to advance the plot. Midgar is engrossing and feels vibrant as a location, but most of the rest of the world is sort of bland and seems to lack a kind of singular overall creative direction to make it feel more alive and coherent. Combat is mechanically interesting and the materia system offers a lot of depth but most of the game just isn't difficult enough to justify that much min-maxing unless you're going for superbosses. This has the knock on effect of making most of the characters largely interchangeable outside of small details like Limit Breaks. And for the modern ports specifically, the achievements here are kind of uninspired: mostly just the "Collect all the things" "fill all the meters" "kill superboss" sort of ones. It would have been neat to see more creative ones, such as encouraging challenge runs but that's a criticism I have for achievements in general in video games; nothing specific to FFVII.

Regardless, I think it is well worth the play. Cloud's story really is excellent, lots of exploration of trauma and memory and is well presented too. The wider overall plot of the game can be...a bit uneven in tone and intelligibility sometimes, but there's a good amount of humor and tragedy and character moments. The soundtrack is as memorable as ever, combat is fun when the fights last long enough to let you show off, and the characters are visually and narratively interesting (if same-y in combat).

On the technical side, the pitch blurb on the Store page advertises cloud saving but doesn't tell you that it only works through Square's account service, not through Steam (like almost every other game on this platform.....) so if you don't enable the function in the game's launcher and you uninstall the game, well, say good bye to your local saves. (joke here about Cloud saving....)

The base game runs fine on the Steam Deck. I have not tried modding it on that platform.

I played through again and for the first time defeated all the extra weapons I never bothered with before, and trained a gold chocobo and got all the materia. A true classic all round made better with community mods.

I would say ff7 og is a good game. Played it as a kid and playing it again as an adult and I would say the game was definitely much better in my memories. I remembered the game being much more profound and amazing back then. Which I guess as a child it's kind of to be expected. Playing it over as an adult and while the game is still good. The turn based style of retro final fantasy, collecting materia, collecting summons, and even the side quests. I enjoyed revisiting this world and doing all the shit I did as a child. It is still ff7. However the story is much simpler, much less dense than I thought it was. There were just not that many moments for character development even within the main story, and the side quests you do barely contribute much to the story either. If you don't like a character in your party, be prepared to not even notice they're around at all. Nanaki, Cait Sith, and Vincent who? When you spend 50~60 hours dicking around doing side quests and grinding AP for materia mastery, and so on and so forth. The game sort is just a grindfest, which for my nostalgic enjoyments of this game, is something I could put up with.

But if another game had 60 hours of grinding where I didn't already consume media from this world for the past 20 or so years, and develop bonds with these characters beyond the original franchise? I would probably not have made it that far into that game. 

FF7 remake for all the flaws I think it has, that it didn't really tell the story of the original that well, at the very least when comparing to that, did spend time developing the characters bonds and relationships way more than this game. And flesh out the conflict between you and shinra and the world at large. In the original, I'm not even sure why I liked Aerith so much. I barely spent time with her. And one date at golden saucer does not make for much development.

idk, game's good, it's now in my opinion, a bit overhyped. The remake is doing better at rectifying some of the flaws the OG has, but it's also doing seemingly its own thing differently from the original which is kind of meh, which maybe in retrospect is a good thing, because the original ff7 does not have much going for it narratively. There's maybe two good story beats in the OG and it's midgar and kalm, and then the rest of the game is just you are a battering ram and the story is paper, It's very simple and straightforwards and it felt like no investment by the end of the game.

What can I say except legendary game, albeit with its problems. This game's fame overshadows some of its greater faults that can quite easily be observed by a newcomer. Nevertheless, it is still a fantastic game with a great story, setting, soundtrack and characters (minus the optional ones)

The gameplay is quite straightforward, classic FF ATB gameplay which can feel a bit slow at times especially with the summons but otherwise works fine. Keep in mind that this is a PS1 game and thus has retained a lot of rust from back in the day, some of it which gives it its charm. 
The game isn't super difficult either, and can easily be played and enjoyed by someone new to JRPGs. 
A surprising amount of role-playing is done in this game too, something you're not used to seeing in most JRPGs these days, and the grand exploration adds to that feeling of a real open role-playing experience.

The setting of the game is incredibly unique and one that is very relevant to current world problems in regards to environmentalism and corporatism.
FF7's story does a poor job of explaining the antagonists motives (at least their endgame motivation) but still does a great job at making them seem threatening. Most other characters had a rather spread out development throughout the game which is always great to see rather than them confining it to one single arc. Again it isn't perfect but it certainly works. 

Not the best JRPG or Final Fantasy game for that matter, but one that I consider my favorite simply because it was my first and introduced me to the series. Still a great game overall though like I said. Worth a buy, would recommend you use mods to speed up the framerate though.

First off download the reunion mod, its super easy to install. Change the "Options" file to your preferences, I had to switch 60 fps battle to mode 2 to work for me. Also check out the help file for useful hotkeys (speed up, cutscene skips, etc.). Achievements will be disabled if reunion is on; so if you care for achievements then be sure make separate saves before where each achievement would be obtained. You can then disable the reunion and move your save file to the square enix save file location. Now just load in to right before when the achievement pops are you should be set. (Also use something called black chocobo if you miss something crucial in your playthrough)

The game goes on sale regularly for about $5 so i would recommend waiting for that.

This is easily the worst version of the game for several reasons. For one you need a Square Enix account just to play a SINGLE PLAYER game from 1997, and it seriously lacks a ton of basic stuff. Setting up the controls is a real pain, because you can't configure both the D-pad and the thumbsticks to do the same thing, so you have to decide which control method you want to toss out entirely instead of switching between them whenever you want. I like using the D-pad for menus but the left thumbstick for moving around in-game, and they won't let me do that here. There are also no button prompts, instead replacing it with vaguely defined actions, which screws things up a ton, especially some of the mini-games which seriously rely on you pressing specific buttons at the right time. The CPR mini-game (which is part of the main story by the way) was an absolute pain because I had to spend 5 minutes fumbling with the controls trying to find out which button does which. There are some really nice accessibility cheats in the PS4 and Switch versions that let you fast forward, disable encounters, and one that even heals your entire party instantly. They sound overpowered, but this is an old game and newer players, especially those not used to old RPGs will definitely appreciate those features to be there if they want to use them. At least the fast forward because the game can get a little slow every now and then. BUT of course the PC version of this game has NONE of those, and is instead just an extremely bare bones port that adds absolutely nothing of value that the other versions don't already have and so much more.

I'd say your only reasons for buying this version are either if you've already played it before and you want to try playing with mods, or you don't have any other means of playing this game. If neither of those are true, then just buy it on PS4 or Switch.

This was the first piece of Final Fantasy content that I'd played, and I gotta say, it's really good. Great characters, great gameplay, phenomenal story, and good pacing. The graphics are really the only hinderance, but it's relatively easy to look past them and look at the characters instead.

This game does have random encounters, but they don't deter from exploration. The chance is low and unless you're traveling a long distance, you won't run into that many enemies. It never felt like a chore to explore the area.

It's turn-based combat, par for the course for standard RPGs. It feels rewarding to win and the leveling up system is fairly straightforward. The only gripe I had with the combat is that the enemy will keep taking their turns even if you don't take your turn. Other than that the combat is great.

This is definitely one of my top 5 games of all time. Even if you're doubting, give it a try.

My dudes, dudettes & non-binary ravioles, its Final Fucking Fantasy VII. You know it, you love it. Some want to be with it, some want to BE IT. Others think FF7RE is better and they are wrong. This is an OG, certified, hood classic and deserves that title for a reason. Encounter rate in my mind is a little high, and alot of the subtleties of 7's mechanics and eccentric details like how you get Yuffie early etc are annoying and obtuse at times because the game can be either really easy or difficult depending largely on your knowledge of it, which sounds obvious but isnt once you've played it. Alot of JRPG's are like this, especially ones with alot of plot-based progression. 7 is a somewhat more free and expressive entry in the series with a *somewhat* less linear feel and model for its systems and how you can interact with them, but nonetheless its still a plot-driven JRPG that can drag at times and be too brief at others. Its not THAT long or deep but if you want to dive into it you can do so at your leisure. It doesnt demand any of the genres tropes such as grinding or wiki/forum-browsing for optimal play. As a sidenote, I consider X to be the better entry for first timers to FF simply because its far less dated and clunky. The ATB system is also not a good indicator of the rest of the series unless you keep it set to "Wait" so combat has a semi-unique pace and feel to the rest of the franchise. Regardless, its worth the price and time invested but isnt that great on repeat playthroughs due to the on-rails nature of the plot and how the mechanics/systems can largely be dependant on that plots progress. With all that said dont get the wrong idea of my statements, this is far from a mixed-bag of a game. Its wonderful and whimsically charming in all ways it could be but does suffer from the comparatively MONUMENTAL jump in presentation/gameplay the later entries offer. 7 is a great entry in the franchise and is a MUST PLAY for all video game enthusiasts. Historically, this game marks the departure from 2D-sprite based RPG gameplay being the gold-standard and instead reminds us that presentation, aesthetic, and clarity plays just as big a role as mechanics when it comes to JRPG's. So whether you're new to the genre/franchise or familiar you'll be able to appreciate its qualities independantly. Have fun, and dont forget to speak to every npc and explore every location/building/zone.

Greatest JRPG of all time

There's something magical about Final Fantasy VII that is simply hard to describe. It set the standard for JRPGs at the time of its release in 1997, and has been re-released on many platforms since its debut on the original PlayStation. I admittedly own this game on every available platform and my first proper experience with it took place when the PS4 version came out. Unfortunately, I was too young to appreciate the complex themes of FF7 when I was young, but I kept seeing videos about it on YouTube when I got a bit older.

If you missed it the first time around, or have somehow have managed to ignore everything to do with the game up until this point (well done), I highly recommend that you play this before FF7 Remake. Going into the remake after experiencing the original has interesting results, and you may be interested in checking out the other games in the FF7 canon, such as Crisis Core. However, if you're someone who enjoys pouring over video game lore, "The Legend of Final Fantasy" is an excellent analysis of such a colossal universe.

In short, FF7 does something that other games do not, and I'm playing through it again - it's such a wonderful experience. The world, characters, and story are a good representation of what to normally expect in a FF game, and of course it has the classic turn-based JRPG combat. 

Play it!

Obviously this is like the cult-favorite of the Final Fantasy series, spawning tons and tons of spin-offs, sequels, merchandise, movies, crossovers, and most recently, a full remake. This is really impressive for a game that initially released way back in 1997, barely a full year after my birth, on a series that has gotten 8 other main game entries. No other Final Fantasy game has had near the success that VII has, and it's not hard to see why.

FF VII was the first Final Fantasy game to be released for the Playstation 1, and in my opinion, can still outclass games put out today, even though it operates on what is now defunct technology. The turn-based combat was nothing new even at its time, but you don't have to be innovative to be good. There's the standard attacking and magic system that everyone's used to, but there are also summons and limit breaks that function as a sort of special move, and you can unlock multiple limit breaks per character by leveling them up and choosing which you prefer.

Even the magic system strayed outside of the bounds of typical mage-play. This system used Materia, which were equippable items, and depending on the materia that you equipped to certain characters, this could give them different magic abilities to use, or certain buffs, or other random attributes that was a cool way to build your character outside of just upgrading your armor and weapon.

SE-PHI-ROTH! "One Winged Angel" could be argued as one of the most iconic videogame songs of all time, and honestly set the tone for Final Fantasy being so highly regarded in terms of soundtrack. All of the music is pleasant, and even the victory theme has become a sort of anthem for gamers' achievements. It's really cool to hear all of these songs and sounds in-game after having heard them in other sorts of places for a long while now.

FF VII was my first experience with secret bosses as well, which is always such a cool feature to have in games. The Ruby and Emerald Weapon fights were so crazy hard and so cool, and they're not even remotely required to finish the game. I can't imagine how cool it would've been to discover something like that before the days of internet and having all of the guides and information you could want at your fingertips.

I'd highly recommend this to any Final Fantasy fans, though it's likely that anyone entwined in the series already either played this as their first entry or played it after hearing how influential it was for the series. That said, it would make an excellent first game as someone who hasn't yet delved into the series too!

It's a classic for a reason. This is arguably one of the best final fantasy games to date and for good reasons. The story tells a tale of friendship, love, revenge, desire and the wanting to keep the planet going for future generations. Along the way enemies will be made, people will die but through all of it the characters keep pushing through even when things seem bleak. For its time it was a head of the curve but sadly it does not hold up well in terms of graphical standards. Still the low spec requirments mean it will run on just about anything short of a potato. 

Gameplay wise this is turn based combat done well. There are depths to it and you may find yourself looking a guide on how best to proceed and what to look out for as well as how all the systems work together in terms of combat. 

For its time it was far ahead on is still considered a classic by many. So the question is should you buy it? Full price I'd say maybe as the game is farily old at this point and the price doesn't really reflect that. One sale? Hell Ya! If you love the Final Fantasy series this is a no brainer. Get it and enjoy. Plenty of memorable characters, moments and a great story.

i like this game for many reasons: the materia system, (it feels like you are programming your character to be what you want!) the story, (can be kinda confusing because of translation errors.) the atmosphere and the music. (the music is AWESOME!) but sadly this game is not very hard, at least not in my opinion; there are only a few parts that i found difficult but even those parts aren't that bad if you prepare, this game is just not very hard at all. unless you want to fight the super bosses, aka emerald and ruby weapon, each character has materia slots, the better the equipment the more materia slots that character has. there are 5 types of materias: magic materias and/or green materia, (if you equip them you unlock spells the higher level the materia the more spells you have from it) summon materia, and/or red materia (if you equip them you will unlock a summon) command materia, (they unlock new commands for that character) independent materia and support materia. (independent materia give the character passive buffs and are pink, the support materia are blue and if paired with another materia it will upgrade that other materia in some way though they cannot be paired with independent materia example: "all" which will make other materia multi-target) you may think this will make all characters the same, but there are a few unique aspects for each character. every character has a different range of weapons only they can equip. also every characters has some ultimate attacks unique to them. also some support materia work different if put in an armor slot then if it was put into a weapon slot. the combat is turn based obviously as this is a some what old final fantasy game. nothing else i can really say about this game without giving spoilers. i hope this review was helpful!

Final Fantasy VII is probably my favourite game of all time. Nothing exciting in that statement – it is for a lot of people. I was so excited for the remake but was bitterly disappointed in it. Gone was my beloved turn-based adventure, replaced by some action-based nonsense (all be it, very pretty nonsense). 

Now, FFVII is pretty old and creaky by todays standards, but I recently discovered the modding scene for this game and what a transformation it has made! Installing the 7th Heaven mod manager and watching a few YouTube vids have transformed this game to be more appealing to modern eyes.  

It now runs how my brain remembers it back in the day.  Higher rez graphics, upscaled videos, 60FPS battles – amazing stuff! I highly recommend people returning to this game check out the mods for it and watch this game fly once more!

[b]There is no  doubt that "Final Fantasy" is one of the most popular RPGs series out there and this seventh part is considered to be one of its best. And there are many fair reasons for it. "Final Fantasy VII" has a brilliant, big fantasy world filled with mysterious atmosphere, unique places, adorable NPCs, emotions, legends and hidden things to discover. The main characters are unforgettable with solid backstories and special personalities. The gameplay is deep with addictive battles and tons of available abilities. Music is simply fantastic. Unfortunately during the second half the story gets a bit unbalanced, pompous and messy. It feels like they have packed all shorts of fancy action things along with some pretentious plot twists in an attempt to impress. Control mechanics have some problems while certain gameplay choices (random battles system) are annoying. Nevertheless, if you like this genre, "FF VII" is a classic great fantasy experience you have to try.


Manometer: 7/10[/b]


The good
- Great world design. Steampunk/fantasy environments are so imaginative and convincing. The word is immersive, big and feels alive. Each place and village is visually unique and hides a small story.
- Gorgeous graphics. Prerendered backgrounds have tons of details and a high artistic value. Cut scenes videos are technically far ahead of its time.
- Fantastically designed, unforgettable characters. Well written dialogues. Each of them has a solid, unique personality and a rich backstory that is revealed gradually. You will love the main characters (such as Cloud, Tifa, Barret, Aeris). You will sympathize some of the bad guys too. Even the more insignificant NPCs have something interesting to tell you.
- Genius music. This is one of the best soundtracks ever written for a video game with both energetic and relaxing tracks. Some of them can stick in your mind.
- Deep gameplay. There are so many materia, items, abilities to discover and unlock. There are so many ways to evolve your characters and there are much more different strategies to follow.
- Good battle system. You will need some time to get used of it but after a while the battles become one of the most addictive elements of the game. Animations and sounds can give you great pleasure. Also there is a big variety of enemies and mini bosses so that they never get boring or repetitive.
- Cool, dark atmosphere full of innerness and romanticism. Dreamy moments, memories and flashbacks will give you some strong emotions.
- The plot is deep and imaginative and it is based on an interesting fantasy concept. Action and relaxing moments are in balance and the story has good pace during the first half of the game. Unfortunately things change drastically at the second half.
- It is a great cinematic experience for its time with good direction and cinematography. Unlike most of the RPGs back then (that had a fixed angled or top-down orthographic main camera), "Final Fantasy VII" uses lenses with different filed of view and cameras in various angles. So it achieves to enhance the atmosphere and the action of each screen.
- It has a clever, distinguishing sense of humor. It is hilarious at least until it gets too serious.
- There is a lot of extra content besides the main story. Easter eggs, activities, items, characters are scattered around the world waiting for you to discover them. It also packs some ultra harsh optional enemies if you want something more challenging.
- It comments on the ecological problem along with issues about society's structure, big corporations politics etc. giving you food for thought.
- It is cheap when it goes on sale considering that this is one of the most popular RPGs out there.

The bad
- Although the initial establishment and the story are solid, emotional and well balanced, halfway it gets messy, pompous and ostentatious. It seems like in an attempt to impress they tried to fit in as many showy things as they could. The main characters go almost everywhere. They fight on trains, airplanes, motorcycles, submarines, rockets. They shoot, explode things, summon mythical creatures and... parachute. They go underwater, in caves, at snowy wastelands, in outer space and finally underground near the planet's center. Some things make no sense at all and some plot twists seem too pretentious. Unfortunately with all this mess it sometimes feels like a cheap action movie you cannot take for serious. Also there are many cliché things (like the big bad guy that talks a lot and seeks for limitless power and the self sacrificed heroes that want to save the whole planet).
- Control mechanics have some serious problems. The characters tent to stuck here and there when moving while sometimes you don't understand where to go because of the unclear backgrounds' perspective. Interacting with objects inside the world is unresponsive and constantly you try to find the exact interaction point by luck. Most importantly, during the battles there are some cameras that make it impossible to choose the right character causing annoying defeats.
- Random encounters are frustrating. I felt that they were totally ruining the game's flow and atmosphere. The worst of all is that I wasn't feeling free to explore places. I was always in a hurry to avoid more unwanted battles. The sound and visual effect when entering a battle is probably the most tiresome thing I've met in a video game.
- Summons' animations are way too big with a result of ruining battle's pace. They should have been the battle's climax instead of getting you bored every time you summon Bahamut Zero.
- Most mini games are silly and don't fit the rest of the game's aesthetics. Snowboard level is badly designed.

[h1]#tinygamereviews[/h1]
The genre-defining game that helped my dork-ass make friends and continues to inspire me in ways it never meant to.
[list]
    [*][b][u]Overall Score[/u][/b]: 4/5 (+lots, because reasons)
[/list]
[hr][/hr]
[h1]Full Review[/h1]
[table]
    [tr]
        [td]Playability[/td]
        [td]3/5[/td]
        [td]The PC version has some quirks with field movement that make some areas slightly frustrating.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Difficulty[/td]
        [td]2/5[/td]
        [td]Most Final Fantasy games aren't too difficult to begin with; this is no exception. As with most older JRPGs, you can easily just outlevel everything and power through it.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Graphics[/td]
        [td]3/5[/td]
        [td]HD displays really highlight the shortcomings of the original graphics. Outside the cutscenes, most of the graphics were never [i]fantastic[/i], but those cinderblock arms and legs give the game an odd charm. What's more, you can mod this copy and make it an unofficial remaster![/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Sound[/td]
        [td]5/5[/td]
        [td]I'm gonna go ahead and use the word "iconic," because it is. Soundtrack's all bangers, all the time.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Story & Writing[/td]
        [td]4/5[/td]
        [td]As an adult, the cuts that were made and the spots of poor translation [i]really[/i] stand out, but not much really makes the story hard to follow or understand, but you can often tell there's a whole lot more that's going unsaid. On the flipside, that helps build intrigue, I guess.[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]
So, this is [i]Final Fantasy VII[/i]. The nostalgic dork in me can't really recommend it enough; it's a genre-redefining title that really brought JRPGs into the mainstream.

It's a tough game for me to clearly review for anyone looking to get into it. I've played it so many times - [i]including an ~11-hour speedrun[/i] - and read and talked so much about it that it feels like I know it inside-out: the developers and its development, its story and backstory, its mechanics, everything. Nevertheless:

[list]
    [*][b][u]It's a piece of gaming history.[/u][/b] [i]Final Fantasy VII[/i] didn't bring JRPGs to the west (we'd had at least 8 other [i]FF[/i] titled precede it, and hundreds of other games like them across platforms), but it definitely brought the genre into the mainstream. The soccer kids who bullied me for smuggling a Game Boy in the pocket of my cargo pants were talking about how to breed chocobos at the lunch table months later. Kids passed around and hid the strategy guide in their desks in English class. [i]I have teenage students talking about this game more than twenty years later[/i] - not just the remake (though, maybe now [i]because of[/i] the remake...).
    [*][b][u]The materia system is great.[/u][/b] It's a small pain in the earliest stages of the game, and it eventually becomes pretty easily-exploitable, but finding those "exploits" is part of what makes it fun in the first place. Equipping and using magic in this game is like a game in itself.
    [*][b][u]The characters are iconic.[/u][/b] (Except Cid.) There's that word again. While some of them are unevenly-developed, and several are walking-talking-tropes (lookin' at you, Barret), they're well-executed in the narrative. Combined with the art direction (which considers its original graphical capabilities/limitations), the characters come to life in ways that modern games of any genre no longer do, and may never again without changing their delivery. It's like watching a Saturday Morning Cartoon version of some dark classic sci-fi, and I'm here for it.
[/list]
In spite of its history/status, my nostalgia, and the gameplay elements that help it stay strong nowadays, the Steam release has its share of flaws.

It doesn't appear as though any bugs have been fixed from the original release. MDEF is still apparently meaningless, and all clipping/glitching/exploits/etc. remain intact (making aforementioned speedrun possible). The graphics look weird in spots on HD displays (did you know that the character models originally had [i]mouths[/i]? You can see them in this version, and it's...[i]weird[/i]).

Since I'm (apparently) practically incapable of gushing about [i]Final Fantasy VII[/i]: Whether you're coming to this for the nostalgia, or starting anew, it bears saying: this is only [i]mostly[/i] the original game.
[table equalcells=1]
    [tr]
        [th]BEST[/th]
        [th]WORST[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]The materia system (mostly). The soundtrack. The overall plot, for all its flaws. Maybe I see it through rose-colored goggles, but I think the game is still groundbreaking and holds up to the test of time well.[/td]
        [td]It still has bugs that were never fixed (nothing game-breaking). I also think it looks strange on high-definition displays.[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table] 
[list]

Everybody should play this legendary JRPG once. The influence it has had on games moving forward is tremendous, not just JRPGs.

STORY
FFVII's story is tremendous and, at the time of release, deliberately went against the grain. It's still a great story now, although it's often confusingly conveyed, and the addition of more entries in the FFVII universe, some of which are even more confusing or outright contradictory, has only exacerbated the situation. The world is gigantic and runs the gamut between bleak and charming. The characters are deep, compelling, and memorable. And the story takes the player on an emotional journey fraught with twists and turns. What's more, FFVII features something that many modern games have forgotten: multiple unique instances of integration of story and gameplay. I would recommend this game on the writing alone. 10/10.

GAMEPLAY
The game is a party-based JRPG using Final Fantasy's Active Time Battle system, where every participant in a battle has a bar that fills up over time. Once the bar fills up, the character can act, emptying the bar. This gives FFVII's turn-based battle system an element of real-time interaction and decision-making. Characters can be customized using the Materia system, which allows players to transform just about any character into what they want or need, whether that be a frontline fighter, a mage, a cleric, etc. The sheer amount of Materia and the number of ways they can be combined make for a very deep customization system. Every character also has a set of cinematic special attacks called Limit Breaks. Otherwise, the player is asked to explore a massive world, traverse dungeons, and solve puzzles: standard JRPG fare. However, it's not perfect. Battles are either pointlessly easy or weirdly difficult. Controlling movement is clunky and in some minigames byzantine, complicated by forced camera angles. It can be difficult to distinguish between objects the characters can interact with and the environment. While character customization is extremely deep battles rarely are. These flaws hold back an otherwise excellent game. 8/10.

LOOKS
FFVII came out in 1997, so it's no surprise that by modern standards, it looks like crap. In 1997 I'm sure quite a few minds were blown by the inclusion of FMVs in the gameplay and flashy summon animations, but unlike 2D sprite graphics which are now retro and timeless FFVII has not aged well. Unfortunately, 3/10 by modern standards, but at the time FFVII was cutting edge and would have been a 10/10.

VALUE
This is a long JRPG, and there's a crapton of stuff to do, some of which is permanently missable. Even just blundering through and only following the main story it's probably a 30 hour game. The world is sprinkled with secrets (some of which are completely inscrutable, like I have no idea how anybody could be expected to discover them), mini-games, and sidequests, many of which would be extremely difficult without a guide. Even better, this game is ancient, which means it's pretty cheap. The only problem is that since it takes so long, there's a substantial opportunity cost, and I can't say that everything in FFVII is worth doing. 9/10.

OTHER NOTABLES
Nobuo Uematsu's music is incredible.

OVERALL
30/40. 7.5/10, most of the points lost being because its graphics now look terrible. This is a wonderful and legendary JRPG which deserves its popularity. Unfortunately, this has also caused Square Enix to revisit the universe with mixed results, because money. Please play the original as a standalone game before Tetsuya Nomura retroactively ruins it with more of his Compilation nonsense.

"Here, this is for you," said my grandpa. "I'm gonna get a GameCube, so you can keep this." He handed me a plastic shopping bag. Inside was his well worn PlayStation, a jumble of cables and controllers, and a single, jewel-cased game: Final Fantasy VII. "That's one of my favorite games," he told me. "I think you'll really like it. Play it and let me know what you think!"

I was 11 years old, and thus I obtained my first PlayStation. I'd never played an RPG of any kind before, or even any games that required very much reading to get through; I was more of a Tony Hawk, Pokemon Snap kind of kid. I was also exceptionally dumb, and when, in the very first pseudo-boss fight of the game with that stupid red scorpion, Barrett kept telling me, "Attack when its tail is up!", I took him at his literal word, and kept getting laser murdered. Looking up an answer to my dilemma online could not have occurred to 2001 Me. I shrugged, relegated the game to the basement bin, and went back to Tony Hawk.

Ten years later, when grandpa passed away, I decided that it was finally time. I was older now, smarter, and I KNEW I could defeat not only that stupid laser scorpion, but the evil Shinra Corporation and Sephiroth himself. And so I did, and then I cried, because I'd finally forkin done it. For grandpa, who thought I'd really like it all those years ago. And now I replay it every year, and enjoy it immensely.

Everyone has said it enough. But this was the first game on PS1 to really transcend gaming as a whole on another level. VI, VII, VIII,IX,X,XII and you can't really go wrong depending on the flavor you like.

[h1] "A timeless marvel of gaming that shall never be forgotten." [/h1]

As somebody who rarely plays JRPG's in general despite working on one, Final Fantasy VII had always been regarded as a gaming classic no matter who you were. Yet for me, this game never came into my mind until the remake hit PC on the blasted Epic Games client.

The game had been on my mind when a coworker of mine had told me about it and I told them that whenever it hit PC, I'd gladly play it. Even if that meant giving up a portion of my gaming loyalty to Lord Gaben. 

Despite that and the tears a shed over it's price, i bought the remake and loved it from start to finish. But in the end, I knew that I had to play the original FF7 for the simple fact of, what was it that i missed all those years ago.

And well... honestly. It should be illegal to keep playing games without playing FF7. 

It took me a total of twenty three years to play FF7. 

23 years. 

That alone is my punishment.

[h1]Review[/h1]
It should come without question that Final Fantasy VII shaped the gaming industry and RPG's as we know it. Many internet and gaming historians will gladly monologue for hours with you of what Final Fantasy VII did for it's time. As a game created back in 1997, we already know the story of what it accomplished then but in 2022, we are still hearing more about the FF7 universe with many of us both old and new Final Fantasy fans eagerly awaiting the future parts of the remake. 

That being said I'm not recommending FF7 for it's prestige alone, rather instead I'm recommending it for the fact that this game nearly three decades later has still aged like a fine wine. Sure the graphics have aged terribly, but the story, gameplay, features, and scale is something that i feel this new age of gamers have yet to still experience.

As a matter of fact, experience is the best way to describe FF7. It's not a great game for it being some crazy innovative and moddable piece of gaming such as Skyrim and Minecraft. FF7 doesn't pride itself on being a game you play for it's playtime, it's a game that gives you an experience so good that you replay it to relive it's convoluted story, revolutionary characters that created the cliches, and a unmatched soundtrack.

This isn't even the tip of the iceberg that is FF7. I haven't even dug into the list of mini games at the Gold Saucer such as the battle arena, grinding for a Gold Chocobo, moments and cutscenes such as the motorbike, Cloud infiltrating Don Corneo, and materia system. FF7 is without a doubt a game with more than just one thing it exceeds at which led to it's universe being grown substantially over the years. 

The odds of another FF7 ever coming to the world is possibly slim to none. A marvel such as this game has seen it's fair share of clones and inspired creators who to this very day have yet to even accomplish a small number of it's accolades. It's unfathomable to how much this game achieved all those years ago and how it's legacy still remains untouched. 

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Final Fantasy VII may have aged graphically and does have it's fair share of exploits and bugs that can be abused, but even these few shortcomings honestly add more to it's legacy. Final Fantasy VII isn't a game for that matter, it is as i stated before, an experience. 

Something I believe a lot of games should start aiming to create more of, for the simple fact that everything in this game (outside of the Gold Chocobo grind) has been created to accomplish just that. 

[h1] Final Score [/h1]
10/10, A timeless masterpiece. Play it for it's historical value or if you're looking for a memorable and fun experience.

First of all, this is my favorite game and everyone knows FF7, so I'll comment on this version specifically.

This is the best way to play the original FF7. They upped the resolution of the graphics which makes it look much nicer than the PS1 version, but it still looks like the same game, and they fixed a few serious game breaking bugs from the original (such as the Magic Defense that doesn't work on armor in the original). Otherwise, everything is the same, everything runs great, and the achievements are perfectly fine (unlike most square enix games that have awful achievements). It's a much better port than FF8 or FF9 steam ports. This is also a better version than a lot of the ports that are on consoles like PS4.

If you're looking to get more out of this game, there is also a huge modding community for FF7 and pretty much all mods are made to run on this version of the game.

If you want to play the original FF7, this is the version you should get.

Fantastic game for its time. Was the first 3D Final Fantasy game and it shows given they tried to make everything look at least somewhat decent for the Playstation and PC scene.

Graphics - Blocks, sweet delicious blocky textures, even snakes look rectangular upon dying. Sephiroth? He had such a square jaw that Clould could use it to grate some cheese to be honest. Could use Cloud's sword as a somewhat decent cheese grater too.

Fighting - Still learning how to make it better and it did well, summons, magic, swords, ninjas and fist, a mopey old guy named Vincent who still likes pretty kawaii for his age. Decent battle system and all, bigger weapons, bigger damage. <3

Soundtrack - Aside from VIII and XIII saga, this is probably my favorite soundtrack out of the whole series (sans Gilgamesh's theme <3 ) Although the soundtrack suffers from Final Fantasy syndrom at times where happy or sad music plays at incredibly unfitting times....

Story - Neo-Resistance group finds that their actions uncover they actually were doing good in the wrong way and they go on a quest to stop an insane guy with an overly long hair that needs a haircut and attittude adjustment and stop a corrupt orginazation and Hojo at the same time. All the whole, discovering real memories, friendship, romance, Nanaki, food, villiages, weapons, really large weapons you have to fight, more villages, a crater, and a chick who dies too early.

The only downside to this game is if you decide to use an Xbox 360 controller, you need to mod some of the game files so the buttons are mapped correctly as the game will NOT give you the option to edit the controller scheme for an Xbox based controller.

Overall, beautiful game, classic, overrated due to fanboys but the game is still fun to play. :)

What do you get when you take a typical JRPG formula and give it a dash of Hollywood spectacle? It turns out you get a beloved classic that to this day is still loved by many new and old.

Final Fantasy VII is a very special game. Very much a product of it's time, yet still holding a message that we can learn from today. What starts out as a crusade against Shinra to stop them from killing the planet becomes a globe spanning adventure to ultimately save the planet and learn a little about or cast along the way. It's clear to see where a lot of the style of this game came from. It is very by the by a 90's anime influenced piece of work. Between the designs of the characters and the general world, you wouldn't be wrong to say this game is an amalgamation of what made 90's Japan a pretty cool media outlet. You have your bio-organics, plain old mechs, and a few designs the creators lifted from Gundam and changed up a little here. Despite taking quit a bit from the anime of the times, the world really comes into it's own. Starting out in Midgar, you take your party through a ton of varied and beautiful pre-rendered areas that are so striking that you'll find yourself taking a few moments just to appreciate the art direction this game has. Despite the game being early 3D, it has a charm to it that you can feel even to this day. Your party members are also a great example of the overall art style and variety this game has. Each one of them have a unique look and you might be hard-pressed to choose your main party as you go through this game. 

The music for this game is definitely one of the highlights here and played no small part in putting Final Fantasy VII on the map.  Nobuo Uematsu and his team of composers did quite an amazing job on this game. It's incredibly varied and each track seems to hit a new chord with the player and fits the areas perfectly. 

The gameplay is your typical JRPG fare, with a twist! This twist is the materia system. The materia system is a pretty fun and enjoyable way to allow the player to have freedom of character growth and make their party the roles they want them to be. With the proper set up and a little thought, you can make any of your party members fit the healer, support, mage roles, or even get rid of those roles entirely and have your own fun with everything spread out between all of your party. This system allows for a ton of flexibility and definitely makes this game have a little more depth for the player. As you play you'll probably see ways to abuse this system and get the most out of it. Honestly, for someone like me, breaking games with their own systems is half the fun, and FF7 has this in spades.

At the end of the day, if you're a fan of JRPGs, or just want to see why people love this game and still hail it, why not give it a shot? You might find your next new time sink.

I can't speak for other people or their computers, but this is what happened when I played this Steam port of Final Fantasy 7. 

It did require making a Square Enix account, but I was able to make one and launch the game in about 4 minutes. 

After I made the account, the game launches perfectly fine with no Internet connection. I tested this multiple times. 

Default controls are a bit weird. I recommend changing them so you can easily reach the direction buttons with one hand and reach all the other buttons with the other hand. 

I occasionally ran into glitches. Most of these are just things getting rendered weirdly (such as Cloud's model being huge and taking up the entire screen), and all but one of them went away when I quit the game and reloaded my save file. The one exception is the master materia achievement, which requires mastering a 5 star materia when it should work with any materia that can gain AP.

What can I say that hasn't already been said about FFVII? Game's got a well earned reputation.

Overworld graphics can be a bit rough at times. The cutscenes, in-game models, and 
scenery backdrops hold up surprisingly well, though I'd be lying if I said they didn't show their age. I'd argue however, that the game still holds up, despite that.

The materia system allows for a deep level of customization, and this is without mentioning all of the different combinations and their various interactions.

The music is iconic, for good reason. Good luck trying to get the various ear worms out of your head once you've heard them.

I won't even bother trying to explain the story. It's a Final Fantasy game. The story is super convoluted, yet still manages to hold it's own charm.


You've got lots of side content (Chocobo breeding/racing anyone?) to keep you distracted while you chase down the main story.

There's some real challenges near the end of the game in the form of super bosses, if you're looking for that, though they can be cheesed with specific strategies and set-ups.

FFVII is one of those games that I'm able to pick up and just replay when the mood strikes.

If you're reading this, and you haven't played VII, give it a go. If the normal price tag is a bit much for ya, wait until a Steam Sale and pick it up on a reduced price. You'll get plenty of hours for your dollar.

Hasta el día de hoy no he probado un jrpg que me haya enganchado tanto (exceptuando "Chrono Trigger").
El diseño de los personajes es altamente iconico si hablamos sobre final fantasy, y no solo de final fantasy sino de la industria de videojuegos en sí.
Pese a que es un juego de hace mas de 20 años, graficamente hablando es aceptable, se lanzó en 1997, no esperes mucho, joder
Ahora, hablare de lo mas resaltante de esta obra, a mi parecer,(cabe resaltar que yo no sentí ningún tipo de nostalgia ya que nunca jugué ningun FF)
Somos cloud y vamos a hacer un atentado pare evitar la sobreexplotación de un recurso altamente vital para la subsistencia industrial, aunque a cloud solo le importa el dinero.
De por sí en la primera hora nos introducen personajes con buen carisma y personalidad, la introducción es directa y rapida, lo cual destaco porque en otros final fantasys se demora algo para darnos un contexto basico de la historia.
Los mapas los encuentro algo divertidos y atrapantes, el soundtrack es igual de bueno y es de lo mas destacable de la entrega.
Tras haberlo jugado por solo 4 horas me resulta imposible dar un veredicto final debido al hecho de no haberlo completado, pero hasta ahora me resulta una de las mejores cosas que he podido comprar en steam.

This FF7 game for Steam is a shame. I managed to play it for ~10 minutes and had to shut it down, never to open it again. Glad I got it on sale: it means Steam/Square Enix "only" stole 6€ from me. Among the things that shocked me:

1/ you need to log into a Square Enix member account to open your game. Too bad that membership thing is super clunky and not documented. I had to browse the community messages to get passed that. Why is it my (well, the community's) job to fix Square Enix's stuff? Isn't that their job?

2/ The game menu (control selection, graphics, etc.) is the worst I've seen in probably over two decades. Unusable. The good thing is that this is a simple game so you don't need any fancy keyboard setup. But still. That shows how much effort Square Enix put into this game (ie: none).

3/ The game itself is EXTREMELY pixellized. And don't get me wrong, I definitely remember what PS1 games looked like and I played tons of ports on my PC. This one is shockingly bad. What used to be gorgeous hand-drown backgrounds are now just a trash of huge pixels. Disguting.

Honestly, given the stature of this game (this is FF7, probably one of the biggest video game of all time, remember?), Square Enix could have done a little more than the bare minimum. 

To Square Enix people: if you're not willing to put the work in it, just don't do it. Stealing is much worse than not servicing your clients. I'm never buying any "old" game (ports) from you. Not to mention that I'll read through the community's comments before buying any "new" game from you. You should be ashamed.

To Steam people: I totally understand you're here to sell stuff. But in such cases, you should have a very clear notation system to tell potential buyers the community isn't happy with the game as is. Otherwise, that make you an accomplice. You can be ashamed too. A disgrace given the quality of the Steam product as a whole.

Overall a real shame. Do not buy this game, find a worthy alternative elsewhere.

[i]Final Fantasy VII[/i] has been on my radar for a long time. I know the characters, I've listened to the amazing soundtrack, I've even enjoyed that most forbidden fruit, the CIoudxSephiroth fanfiction... but since I never owned the original Playstation, I never got to actually play it. Now that I have, what did I think?

Firstly, I loved being thrown into the action right away. No tutorials, you're immediately doing something exciting. I also appreciated how there were no difficult gameplay mechanics to learn off the bat - I can see how this game would've appealed even to non-RPG fans, or those that hadn't played RPGs before. The game starts you off in the city of Midgar, a kind of cyberpunk technopolis crossed with industrial slum, full of personality and charm. Running round the different Sectors, evading the law, meeting and getting to know each character, while slowly learning more about the world and story...this was wonderful, and for me the best part of the game.

Once you leave Midgar, the pace slows considerably and things become similar to other [i]Final Fantasy[/i]s, wandering round the world map, working out where to go and slowly moving the plot forward. It isn't bad by any means but I missed the breakneck speed of the early game. On the other hand, the Materia system was interesting without being too complicated to understand, and I enjoyed the increased battle options it opened up - Magic, Summons, Commands, etc.

I was a little surprised that the game wasn't longer. It's not a short game of course, but my experience of JRPGs that came after FFVII - [i]Skies of Arcadia[/i], [i]Tales of Symphonia[/i] - prepared me for something longer by at least 10 hours. I was able to beat the game and get all achievements in around 70 hours. Additionally, I was somewhat nonplussed by how certain characters and story elements seemed to be finished with in kind of a rushed manner. Again, maybe that's me judging the game by the standards of what came after.

If there was once thing I disliked, it was the Gold Saucer area. None of the minigames were any fun in my opinion, some being downright frustrating, and the whole GP system was irritating. But you don't have to spend much time there if you don't want to.

So for the most part, I thoroughly enjoyed [i]Final Fantasy VII[/i]. I can see how influential it was to JRPGs in the 3D-era, and how many of the creative and humourous little touches echo down into modern indie-RPGs. Though it wasn't as polished as perhaps I was expecting, I could understand its enduring appeal, there's something very likeable about the characters and setting. I look forward to going through the game a second time, to see all the things I missed on my first playthrough... and to experience that Midgar early-game again.

Quite possibly the best FF game out there. The materia allows you to go as crazy as you want. Want to be immortal? sure! Wan't to just scrape through the game at level 50, you can do that too! The story is great and the game play is great. Who cares about block hands if the game is really good?
