For years I've avoided this game, mainly going by the kind of reviews that currently plague this Steam page.  But, I decided to take a leap of faith, and guess what?  The game is awesome, and highly recommended if you've been playing the PSX version through an emulator to get slightly better graphics, and especially to those that have been rocking the older PC version, which was buggy and contaned inferior music tracks.  Let's check off the list of improvements, eh?

- Overall smoother looking graphics AND backgrounds

- Same music as the original PlayStation game

- "Easy" mode that boosts all of your stats so you just enjoy the story (requires Cloud save and to be online)

- Can be modded if you want (though outside of Steam)

To be clear, you DO have to create a Square Enix account, but I've only had to login once and never again.  Try that with your Origin or UbiPlay games.  And to all those people complaining about have to be online, this is what happens if you want Cloud saving and are online with Steam.  If you don't want this, turn off Cloud saving and you can take Steam offline.  You lose the ability to use your save between computers, but you can also be offline all the time.

Now, things aren't perfect, but this is more indicative to it being based on the PC game.  While I am primarily a PC gamer, FFVII just feels unnatural on the keyboard.  I'm sure that if I played a few hours I wouldn't care, but right now thinking about juggling all that materia whilst using the keyboard gives me the cold sweats.  Luckily, it does have partial controller support.  You know the drill for Steam; get a compatible controller or an app that can get you own working.

So, to recap:  This game rocks!  You have to create a SQ account, but since you only login once, I don't see what is the big deal.  I mean, you have to login into Steam to get this far, don't you?  Plus, you get to cheat right out of the box (no mods required).  So, if you've always wanted to get a better looking version of FFVII, or haven't played the game but was curious as to why it is lauded so, go ahead and pick this game up.

EDIT: Years later and I would like to add that while I've signed into and downloaded FF7 on Steam literally dozens of times over the years on many different machines (most of them NOT Windows) I've still yet to sign in more than that first time to the SQ account!

This is a good distribution of a good game. However it is built on an infamously terrible localization of FF7, so bear that in mind if the dialogue has you scratching your head. This isn't really much of an RPG of course - just a story-driven game with items, loadouts and linear experience progression. And lots of silly little things you only get to do once in the whole game.

FF7 is not difficult to breeze through if you understand the basics of the tactical system and you can further trivialize the entire story mode with a short grinding session on disc 1, or a little insight into how some of the lategame materia works, routinely using Steal and Morph, or hell, just saving regularly. The hardest unavoidable fight in the game comes smack in the middle of it.

Music's nice, minigames are fun, every boss is a very cool fight that you look forward to on next playthrough. Chocobo breeding is by far the worst part of the game. If you get too rich you can throw money at your problems and it ignores their armor.

So, I played through this again earlier this year, and had the same experience I did my first time -- a JRPG story told great, awesome gameplay, with a few late 90's quirks and graphical limitations, but it really sucks you in, so much that you find yourself ignoring a lot of that once you get invested in the story.

Playing the PC "remake" intergrade really made me want to play this again, for more than a few reasons.  I believe turn-based combat is pretty integral to the game. Action, pressing the X button repeatedly against Shinra soldiers may make for cool looking trailers, but actual boss fights turn into tedium, long, drawn out fights, rather than actual strategic ones like in the original. 

Which is another cool thing about the original, it's as hard or as easy as you want. You can get the enemy skill materia earlier on and beat sephiroth by using bubbles, or you can level up standard materia and play however you like. A lot of the things to complain about the remake for are because it's so short. where's my bahamut summon? oh right, they havent even left midgar yet. Where's Cid? Oh wait, they haven't even seen Rocket town. Why the fuck does Sephiroth keep appearing this early on? Why's there weird purple blood in Shinra tower? Why is everything being padded so hard?

The soundtrack has yet to be bested, the closest the remake came to outperforming it was the airbuster fight in the remake , which was an AWESOME song, and the second phase of the jenova dreameater fight. Most of it takes far too long to get going, while this game's music doesn't fuck around. So many iconic moments, and the biggest tragedy is that the game REALLY gets going after you leave midgar, which is where the remake ends. If you haven't played the original, DO NOT play the remake, I beg you. As an extension to the original, it's not a bad game, but it's horrible for new fans, probably the absolute worst way to start the story.

FF7 is probably square's best game. I'd rather them have made an ARPG remake of Chrono Trigger. That game would have way more sense, and wouldn't have to be split into a bunch of parts. The remake is good, definitely not worth $70 when you can buy this for $5 and have way more content. This game is amazing, if you enjoy turn based and haven't played it, FF6 or FF7 are great intros to turn based games.

There are a lot of reasons why Final Fantasy is one of the most renowned JRPGs of all time and why it is still played to this day. Being the seventh installment, it had a legacy to uphold. It adopted a more science-fiction-oriented style than previous entries, more so than VI. With this darker atmosphere of technology becoming an asset and enemy, tensions are high; that is not to say that more light-hearted moments exist within it: It is just that it feels a bit different. However, the skill and prowess with which it was created enables it to shine. 

The mysterious, initially aloof mercenary Cloud Strife joins the bio-terrorist organization AVALANCHE to subvert to the mega-corp Shinra Electric Power Company. Along the way, he crosses paths with old friends and new comrades alike throughout the game, but the story ultimately evolves into something far grander as the fate of the planet is at stake at the hands of Sephiroth. Characters become developed and fascinating as the story progresses, being multi-faceted.

The intergration of the Active Time Battle system of combat into battles is very much welcome. The game can be configured into making the difficulty linked with the player's skill level. The Materia system for commands is easy to learn--battling is enjoyable, not grind-heavy. Sounds and themes are of excellent. I find myself listening to the OST often.

A game that does not stand the test of time unless you are a hardcore fan of FF games or JRPG’s with a case of severe nostalgia. 

[b]Music: [/b] 8/10

The music is actually really good and does stand the test of time. In most cases it does create a wonderful atmosphere. There are a few tracks here and there that feel a bit annoying, but nothing too serious. Overall, really solid, but nothing that will remain in my memory.

[b]Visuals: [/b] 3/10

That score is fully towards the backgrounds and the FMV’s. Those looked really solid for its time. However, the models in game and in battle, are really behind and saying they were something groundbreaking would be an insult considering Mario 64 came one year before and managed to look 10 times better than this game.

[b]Gameplay: [/b] 3/10

A really mediocre combat system which you can simply win with auto-attacks. An insane amount of grinding required to actually have useful Materia and Limit Breaks. Useless mini-games that plague the game from the get-go and don’t add anything. Plus, all the things you need to do to get the ultimate limit breaks. And that is without counting how the game doesn’t help you find the locations, the characters barely interact when meaningful events happen and much more.

[b]Story: [/b] 3.5/10

There is a story and it sort of promises that it can be good. However, the localization errors plus the fact that most characters don’t react to different events or that without a guide, a lot of information is simply not found because you need to go out of your way to access it, means that the story is barely there. 
While some might try and excuse it because of the era. Chrono Trigger came before and it had a better story by far, same as Earthbound and Final Fantasy Tactics that came out the same year.

FF7 is a true classic, with a timeless epic story, fantastic character design and a wonderful soundtrack.

FF7 is also 24 years old (at time of writing) and it is reaaaally starting to show it's age.

I'm old, so I played this back in the day as a young teen and thought it was the best thing ever. Replaying it recently as an adult it's a lot easier to criticise and find faults in some of the design choices. 

The combat gameplay is not particularly good, the mid-game story is all a bit of a wild goose chase and - yep, i'm gunna say it - the materia and equipment systems are a chore of endless menus and confusion. The game also looks like a bunch of jagged polygons that kind of hurt your eyes to look at. Because of course it does. It's 24 years old. And you know what? Those things are not that easy to ignore any more.

But still, the story and setting of this game are uniquely charming and captivating.

The soul of this game is still there, sparkling, waiting to greet anyone who'd care to come back one more time for old times sake, as I have, with warmth.

FF7 isn't just a game - it's a work of art.

I know this is highly against the grain, but I just can't fully recommend this game. It has some remarkable pacing issues for something so beloved by the masses. 

The first section of the game is amazing, wonderful pacing and good character development, and the story is fairly focused. Throughout the entire stay in Midgar, it manages to keep a great sense of urgency and drive.

Then you leave the city and... all that urgency and direction just vanishes. You're just kind of wandering around aimlessly, and eventually bump into the only direction you can actually go, and kind of wander that way until you randomly run into a nugget of random plot here or there. It loses the sense of direction that the first act had, and yet doesn't replace that with a sense of exploration as you're very obviously being railroaded into one path with little to do outside it. I'm honestly not at all surprised that the remake decided to stop after leaving Midgar, as that whole arc was far better than what came after (and the "after" part will probably require extensive rewrites).

Further, the battle system is just unpleasant in my opinion. I hate when games want to mix real-time and turn-based mechanics. I either want to actually [i]control[/i] the character in fully real-time combat (as the remake decided to go with), or have the time to carefully choose what I want a character to do in a fully turn-based combat (as Final Fantasy went back to at least as of FFX). Instead, this game forces me to simply wait for my turn to be "ready" (sometimes with me and the monsters just sitting there), while I can't actually look away or else the monsters will continue attacking me despite it being "my turn". It's just the worst of both worlds.

I've tried my best to get into this game twice now (as my almost 30 hours spent on the game can attest to), and both times I loved the opening and then slowly lost interest and just couldn't force myself to keep going during the parts after that. I made it further on my second go, through the introduction of Cait Sith and a bit further, but I just wasn't having fun.

Final Fantasy VII is one of my favorite games of all time. I think it is a beautiful, amazing game, worthy of everyone's time.
This is among the worst ways to experience the game. It looks worse, has more bugs than, and lacks the QOL features of the modern console releases (and even on PC, the Microsoft Store version). Unlike the original PC release, the port is no longer laughably, entertainingly incompetent, and instead just incompetent enough to be wholly inferior to the original. And on that note, the game runs, looks, sounds, and overall is just worse than the original PS1 version. Many people will say that mods improve this, and there are quite a few mods that help with the backgrounds or the audio quality or the framerate. However, many mods go even further and completely change the way the game looks, sounds, feels, or is written. And while these are still incredibly interesting and passionate mods that should be respected and applauded for the work put into them, they make for a lousy experience with the game outside of the context of "I want a completely different Final Fantasy VII experience."

Overall, you should play Final Fantasy VII, but not on Steam. Either play the PS1 version, or if you need the speedup from the modern rereleases, pick any version on any console you like and play it.

UPDATE: While my overall thoughts have not changed, I must add that the online DRM for this title is genuinely inexcusable. It had never been an issue for me before, but I recently wanted to play the game and was completely unable to due to servers being down. This happening for a PS1 game is inexcusable.

This is a great classic game, my favorite of the Final Fantasies and one of my favorite games all around. The story, setting, characters, and gameplay combine to make a fun and memorable experience that's worth playing through multiple times.

I love the materia system used for combat, I don't understand why people complain about it because it's the more interesting magic system of any Final Fantasy game. Collecting and levelling up the materia can be a lot of fun, and it gives players more options when deciding which characters to use because anyone can be a mage by equipping the right materia.

There's an in-game arcade with some enjoyable minigames you can play (and win prizes!), and eventually you get the ability to capture, breed, and race chocobos, which is mostly unnecessary for the storyline but happens to be a lot of fun.

On my most recent playthrough I installed the mods "Symphonic Remasters Redux", "The Reunion", and "Satsuki Yatoshi Mod - SYW"  to enhance the game's graphics and audio. FF7 had nice graphics for its time but they're now looking pretty dated, so I would recommend installing such mods for first time players. The updated character models aren't as charming as the original, but I do think it's an improvement for the most part. However, I recommend disabling the remastered translation included with The Reunion. It may be more accurate in some places, but I still think the original is superior.

It's funny how after all these years this game still holds up. I don't have any nostalgic connections with this game, cus even if I did finish the game as a kid, I skipped every dialogue (I had a brain sized like a peanut) and if I was stuck I'd let my brother play it for me. So, I can't really say I experienced the game fully and this second time felt like a first time, and boy was it a great time.

I'll address the bad before the good, the pacing of the story is dogshit. Especially the start, they don't give you time to think about anything, characters are introduced just for them to not matter in the next hour, a bit slower approach would have been better for this game.

That's all for the bad, now the good. The characters are amazing, I love them a lot and I mean A LOT. Especially Aerith, her cheeky charms were so fun to experience, Cloud as a main character can be a little hard to love at first but he grows on you in time (starts out as the wettest towel out there though). They all have their own unique personalities and their own reasons to do what they do. I also really love the world building, you can feel the effects of Shinra almost everywhere which connects the world of FFVII really well and makes the world feel real. I also really liked Limit as a mechanic, unlike in FFIX where Trance appears in places you don't need and you have no way to save it for bigger fights, Limit works cus its so easy to save. You can unleash a big move and do massive damage or keep it and increase your speed, but you can't use your normal attack that way, but you can use magic or other skills, this gives the player multiple choices in how to approach combat and led to a very nice experience for me.

This game is pretty old now, and yeah the visuals are dated but there's still a lot to love about this classic that shaped the modern games we play now, and somehow it still feels so fresh. I give this game a 7/10.

An established classic hit, Final Fantasy VII is the definition of the quintessential JRPG, and the first one in the series that applied 3-Dimension to its models and visuals, which, for its time, was probably something to admire for its step forward to new boundaries. However, being the first one in the series to take this form, the graphics hasn't really aged well and would probably turn off a lot of those coming from the younger generations just getting started in the series. What it lacks in graphics, it makes up for storytelling and its soundtrack. Two decades later, several video games that served as spinoffs, prequels, and a remake, as well as two films, is a testament to the impact the original game has on the RPG genre.

Final Fantasy VII's legacy is undeniable. The graphics might be outdated, but if one is able to get through that, then the experience will be worthwhile.

AHEAD OF ITS' TIME...

Final Fantasy VII is the most popular game in the franchise. Everywhere on the internet searching up "Final Fantasy" will always show Cloud, Aerith, and other elements and characters from this game. I was only interested in Final Fantasy XV back in the day and try out this game to see what's all the fuss about. 

Positives first, being a very old game this game have a very strong and interesting narrative. I thought the story is gonna be some anime soap opera like Final Fantasy XIII or maybe God Eater, but no. The main story is more interesting than that. The world, lore is very fun to explore throughout the story. The whole story is very long and takes place in many ages without spoiling anything. Kinda suprised how compact the content is for a very small game. Well it did originally came out for the PS1 which uses discs with little roms. But still blew me away how big they manage to fit the story in.

And the characters are amazing. Again, expecting FF7 is gonna be like some tropey anime story in gaming form, all the characters are very unique and blew my expectations away, especially the main character, Cloud. This character is like the icon of edginess or some sh*t when I first learned about him. But Cloud in the story is more than that. Not gonna spoil the whole story but, Cloud became very much my favourite character in the whole game. There's also other amazing characters like Tifa, Aerith, and other party members I won't spoil. The antagonist (I won't spoil but the internet kinda spoiled it already) is very menacing and everytime the characters encounter him has feeling of dread in the atmosphere. Easily one of the most interesting villain I've ever experienced.

The soundtrack of this game is amazing. Again, Nobuo Uematsu is at its prime when this come out. Every track is a certified banger.

The combat system is ok. Having a turn based system and you can customise your party's actions and skills with materia. Materia are magical items that can make your character perform any actions. Think of it like Final Fantasy II but more portable and adaptable. On my first playthrough I breezed through the mechanics to reach the ending fast. But on my second playthrough where I turn the dial down a bit and start to learn and invest in the Materia system, its kinda fun to switch Materias between characters to see how it all plays out. 

For the negatives, kinda hard to mention since its an almost 30 year old game but the visuals can sometimes bleed my eyes out. It really does not age well. Luckily, theres a button to guide the players where the exits and entrances are so you can know what you're doing and seeing. Second, some texts and translation have some mistakes. But I can see how that can be charming to certain players because to show how this franchise started its footing in the international side of things. But in todays' standards, sometimes some sentences the characters just does not make sense and you have to perform multiple mental gymnastics in order to understand whats' being said. And lastly, seeing theres a fast forward button during combat in newer versions, I hope the Steam version also have this feature. There is an option to speed up the battle animation though in the configuration menu. I dunno, maybe the recent Pixel Remasters is spoiling me when it comes to turn based combat.

Overall, this game is ahead of its time. The story is well crafted and had amazing characters. The combat and Materia system is fun. I can see how this game is beloved for most players, and deserves the reputation its got.

Final Fantasy VII is that game Square Soft made to make Nintendo mad.

Released in 1997, Final Fantasy VII was considered a triumph of the imagination, a master class of story, gameplay, music, and especially graphics. Absorb yourself into a journey revolving around the fate of the world, evil corporations, and characters that are still beloved twenty four years later. For many, Final Fantasy VII is the greatest game ever made, but does it still hold up today? 

Ye, I think its pretty good.

You play as Cloud, a funny little square man with pointy hair. Cloud is a mercenary and Former SOLDIER. That’s SOLDIER with capital letters, not Soldier as in the job, an elite military organization formed by the Shinra corporation, who are basically BP Oil but less evil. 
After doing a favor for his old friend Tifa and helping literal Eco-Terrorists blow stuff up, Cloud is thrust into a world of intrigue, conspiracy, and a hot guy with a big sword as he and his party of lovable hooligans try to save the world, and kill a lot of people while doing so.
I mean, a lot of people. 

FFVII is a Turn Based Role Playing Game where you control three party members at a time, stand in a line, and murder the other guys until they explode into experience and money. Turn based is kind of controversial in this day and age, but I kind of feel like its timeless, if you like it you like it, you know? 

What really fondles my groin is the materia system, FFVII doesn’t really have a class system, instead allowing you to junction little magic orbs called materia into your weapons and armor. Materia is basically just magic, you got fire, ice, murder, San Andreas Fault line, lightning, the god of all dragons, Actual Satan, and the power to call down rocks from space to smoosh your enemies.
You know, the usual. 

The Materia system is really cool, since you can also combine them to add stuff like status effects to your attacks. Or you can do what I do and put Cover and Counter Attack on Cid and let him beat cheeks from part 2 onward. Experimenting with Materia can be fun, but when you find something you like, you usually stick with it. 
When you start wasting bosses in one move, you’ll know what I mean. 

After the first six hours, the world opens up and you really embark on your adventure. FFVII does that thing that older games did where you had an overworld, where everything was big and you were scaled up to be walking across the world, visiting towns and other locations on the way. Its something I’m actually nostalgic over. Like the smell of burning wood or house arrest. 
It always made the world feel bigger and grander than it actually was, giving this feeling that you’re really on a journey, doing a lot more for that feeling than some of the newer Final Fantasy games have. 

The game isn’t perfect, but I’m not going to make a 30 minute long video explaining why its “FLAWED” 
Some enemies take so long to make their moves that they may as well be mailing the attack to you via envelope. Some of the encounter rates can blow me, and the late game grind can be, well it can be something if you’re going for the secret bosses.

Not me though, I tried and they put me right back into the ground like I was an overeager potato or something. 

But you can beat the game at around level 50, its kind of an uphill battle but its doable. I finished the game at level 80 because I saw Advent Children and want that Twink to stay dead this time.

It didn’t work.

There’s also cool side content like the battle arena, Chocobo Racing, Chocobo breeding which is vital to get the best summon in the game. You can be pretty busy with Final Fantasy VII if you like it enough.

My biggest problem is with this port of the game, the PC version of FFVII seems to be built off the janky PC port from the 90s that was handled by, like, 20 people. I looked it up, it was actually 20 people, and then it was published in the west by Eidos Interactive because they made Tomb Raider at the time or something. 
The game works, but you’re gonna have a bad time with the controls.

What I did is I went to the controller configuration on Steam and found a community uploaded configuration that uses the Xbox 360 controller template on your Keyboard to emulate controller support. There are other ways to do it like Xpadder and flat out modding the game, this made the game perfectly playable for me, so hurray.
Shoutout to AceKobayashi for uploading their controller configuration for everyone to use, you get a banana sticker for being a big smarty. 

I still like Final Fantasy VII a lot, but you need to understand that everything on the NES to current gen are perfectly playable to me, and even then I still enjoy Pong and Space Invaders. If you’re a stickler for modern conveniences or graphics, then FFVII may not be for you. You can go, I dunno, watch paint dry or something. But to be Final Fantasy VII is something special, and its something I won’t forget until Alzheimer's and dementia rends my brain from this mortal coil.

9/10 – Growing up having never played FF7, or any of the FF games really, I always thought it was over-hyped and couldn’t be as good as everyone remembered it being. But having now played it, I understand. The Story, the characters, the world-building! Nearly every part of the game held up amazingly and kept me interested and wanting to see what happens next. This is a must play for any RPG fan!

Pros:
+The Story – I somehow made it this far in life without getting this game spoiled for me, minus the death of a certain popular character, and my experience was better for it. The twists and details of character’s backstories and motives kept surprising me over and over!

+The Characters – I can see why they are so beloved. Even some of the characters I started out not liking generally won me over in the end. The party also had a really nice dynamic outside of combat. Though in combat I generally stuck to 3-4 certain characters.

+The Visuals – While some elements, such as telling where you can go on certain maps, haven’t aged the best, overall the visuals are still a joy to look at and seeing how they worked with their limitations was great.

+Midgard – The over-hyped part of the over-hyped game, but once again I see why. It is an excellent opening to not only the world, but the characters and their motive. My only complaint was that some of the parts following Midgard did not live up to it and felt like the story slowed down. But it quickly caught back up!

Neutral:
+/-World Navigation – I loved the world itself, but navigating it, mainly in the first half of the game, felt like a chore.

+/-The Gold Saucer – Coming from Final Fantasy XIV, I was generally surprised to find the Gold Saucer in this game, but it was a bit of a let down and I didn’t find myself returning to it at all outside of the story.

+/-The Localization – This is probably beating a long dead horse, but the English Localization isn’t the best. Outside of some grammar issues here and there, my main problem was the weird writing choices that pulled me out of the game, like Cid mentioning the Greek Language.

Cons:
-The Final Dungeon – The final boss was great, but the dungeon leading up to it was awful. Fun Fact about my play through: I didn’t know you could flee from battles until right before the final battle, so I had to fight through a horde of battles with Tonberry’s and other extremely high HP monsters that drained nearly all of my resources before I even got to the ending. While this was mainly my fault, in my defense I don’t remember seeing it explained and it’s not in the command menu. I only figured it out by looking it up. (I had to hold Page Up & Page Down at the same time. I played on controller but the PC version didn’t give me controls for a controller.) The final boss was still quite fun though.

At the time of writing, all of my hours in this version of the game are using Sega Chief's "New Threat 2.0" mod on the qhimm forums. This is a mechanical rework of the game focused on making the gameplay more engaging through deeper mechanics, adjusted values on stuff, an expanded materia system, and increased difficulty. It is not intended to be a "difficulty hack", more of a "midcore" difficulty that encourages a little more mindful play in general.

and WEEEEEEEEEEEEW LAD IT'S INCREDIBLE. Can't recommend it enough. The dude did God's work on this game.

FF7 has always been one of my favorite games story-wise, but the battles are so mindless that it's hard for me to actually sit down and play these days. New Threat mod fixes this pretty much entirely. It isn't so hard that I need to pull out all the stops, but most bosses take 2-3 tries with some strategy adjustment, I have a party with defined roles based on a new stat growth system, and I spend way too long before every major fight adjusting my materia builds. I love it.

I have nothing really more to say other than if you like FF7 (or just ATB turn based games in general) but you're on the fence since you find the gameplay tedious, try this. If you happen to see this review and you've already played FF7, try this anyways. It's like a whole new game.

Speaking of "whole new game", there are two modes available in the New Threat Mod, "type A" and "type B". "type A" is the original game with the mechanical changes I've mentioned. There are also a few minor story changes, like you get Yuffie and Vincent for free. But "type B" is essentially the mod author's OC FF7 game, it is like an actually new game with entirely new story beats and such. I'll be trying that next.

Finally, I'd be remiss if I didn't mention that FF7's localization is garbage, but there is nothing you can do about this because no better translations exist, so get owned I guess.

In this game, you play the part of a disgruntled former power plant security guard, and you've come back to kill energy executives for creating GMOs and disrupting ecosystems. Meanwhile, you're racing against them to find a former coworker who's trying to use his famous mom's power for political gain.

I've played for thousands of hours, but it doesn't show on Steam because this is the third time I've bought it. That's how much I enjoy this game. It's the only game that I've ever bought 3 times without first losing the previous copies. To be clear, the Steam edition is only marginally better than the original Windows release, except for an increase in resolution for the 3D elements, but that's not very helpful because the low-poly 3D and low-res textures they used in 1997 haven't aged well, even when rendered at much higher display resolution. A key issue with the old graphics is many of the characters have cubes for forearms with proportions worse than Popeye. At such a reduced price, I decided to get this anyway when I bought the rest of the FF franchise just for the convenience of having everything on Steam. More of the old games have been released for Steam since then, so I now have more to buy.

I recommend using the 7th Heaven mod manager to update the graphics, The mod manager also adds support for typing names with the keyboard, which was available in the original Windows release but missing from the Steam edition. The downside is that the mods don't update most of the enemies and NPCs, so some things stand out beside your modded character.

Fun fact: My favorite ad for this game says, "more than 200 animators and programmers, a multi-million dollar production, over 2 years in the making, and a cast of thousands! They said it couldn't be done in a major motion picture," then finishes by gloating, "they were right," and revealing that they were describing a video game. The ad is retroactively wrong, because "the Simpsons Movie" was released 10 years later, matching the ad's description of FF7, except it's unclear how many characters there are because I can't find a complete list but there are at least several hundred.

[h1]A Flawed Diamond[/h1]

I truly understand why FFVII is so beloved, it has a phenomenal story, the gameplay can become very involved and challenging compared to prior (and later) entries in the franchise, and the art style can still be charming regardless of its age and errors.

However I think this game shows some serious cracks with all the "stuff" they shoved into the game in the form of crappy minigames like marching in a military parade, snowboarding etc etc; the list goes on. these all feel like shitty versions of better games that existed at the time and end up just annoying me as all I want to do is get back to the combat and story. 
I also think that they made a serious error in going with the chibi style for the field models, I KNOW that this is a product of them not knowing 3d games yet but they figured it out for combat models so they should have just delayed it a year and reworked the game. 

OH and my largest complaint with the game is how much shit is missable, I used a guide only on parts where I was completely stuck and/or lost so as a consequence I missed alot of side content and quests, namely[spoiler] Vincent and Yuffie.[/spoiler]

So do I recommend FFVII? yeah absolutely, I also recommend using a walkthrough so you can find the 2 missable party member and all the side quests you want to do. 

And side note I used The Reunion mod which retranslates the game so the story makes more sense. (I recommend using it as well)
[i]and Advent Children was kinda fuckin weird eh?[/i]

I still think that this game is a must-play for jrpg and final fantasy fans. I highly recommend it.

It's the best JRPG ever made. Hands down. I played the original Final Fantasy back in the day. I remember it and was so validated when I found a picture of myself at 3 years old playing it on an old CRT TV back in the day. That being said, after that I got heavy into Nintendo for a long time and wouldn't even consider the Playstation as an option. Then I saw the advertisement for this game. I needed it. It completely changed the trajectory of my gaming path and then delivered on the promise so god damn hard. This game has a very special place in my heart and I will forever be grateful for it. Obviously I cannot objectively review it but take my love of it as a good indication. If you have never played FF7, please for the love of god do so. You have no idea what you are missing. Explore, talk to everyone, take your time and enjoy the boxy graphics, wonky dialogue and amazing story unlike any other FF game. There are so many tiny easter eggs and bits of dialogue worth finding that really make this world feel complete and whole. I have played this game through probably legitimately at least 50 times, and every now and then I still manage to find something I missed in every play through before it. It's a treasure trove of nostalgia and glory.

So if anyone is having an issue with using a controller on this game, here is what i found:

start the game using Steam - after ensuring you have activated the controller on the game through steam - when you start it, you will see a message that says the controller is overriding - start the game or continue from a save.  now the  game knows you should have a controller so quite out, and then when at the starts screen, controller is now not grayed out.  go to controller, you can see that, hit OK, and then start the game again - this time your controller will work :)  hope that helps someone.

Final Fantasy 7 is a top five game for me, and I replay it periodically like people re-read Lord of the Rings. This review is, of course, in regards to Square Enix porting something to PC in their usual fashion.

This port is a sham. It used to be worse. Now it is only atrocious. Prompts on the screen refer to internal variables within the program. So when you suddenly find yourself needing to swing to one side of a pit you're falling down, a prompt will tell you to spam [CANCEL] or [PG UP] to accomplish the task. You'll of course fumble to figure out what the hell that is, and mess up the minigame event.

There is no toolset to assist in any way with what is essentially 240p (slightly worse) JPEG still backgrounds blown up to 1080p or greater. The game looks like a Lite Brite. (thats a toy from back before everyone had internet)

The models in the game however do not share any kind of matching resolution to these background or FMV moments that they are placed in. Because of this, they literally look like stickers shoved onto the painfully blown up backgrounds. At all times, the characters look like they're walking on top of a canvas.

There is audible popping in the soundtrack and special effects if you're wearing even a modestly solid pair of cans while playing

Mouths are broken, and are passively turned on in scenes that completely ruin the tone. Imagine someone with blowjob mouth as they fall to their knees in sorrow. Now don't laugh, and try to convince yourself that moment wasn't ruined.

Sadly, the name of the game for this classic is still either emulation or its vastly superior console ports on the Switch or Playstation 4. There are still background issues in those ports, but they are lessened, the prompts are correct, the mouths are correct, the audio is correct and so on and so forth.

Okay. As for the game. Its not cool to love this game, so if your emo lock is firmly gelled into place I'd suggest you move along and find something thats not 'mainstream' to love. Having said all that, this game works on every level. As a classic of JRPG storytelling, as a high water mark of JRPG combat, as an exploration game, as an easter egg hunt, as a source of some of the greatest game music ever composed, and even in 2021, a source of spectacle.

Yeah. Its old. Really old. But Final Fantasy 7 was a look into the future of the AAA game in all its glory (and horror). It promised a AAA, blockbuster, cinematic experience and it delivered even by today's standards. By 1997 standards it literally reorganized the games industry overnight. So if you dig game history at all, this is a mandatory chapter.It is far from flawless, and theres some underbaked spots on this gargantuan game, but it deserves being brought up in the same conversation with Zelda, Mario, and the like.

But this port makes my eyes bleed. You have to mod it halfway to China to make it viable. Please tread lightly... and maybe buy a console version.

Seriously like you have to ask.  I played this game when it first came out and it is what got me hooked on all things Final Fantasy.  There will never be a time when I can play this game that I won't take the time.

RPGs where you choose combat actions through a menu are engaging for the character-building, strategic choices made in combat, and/or compelling story. The decision to incorporate real-world time into combat is painfully lazy (we can't make combat engaging? make it a time crunch) and runs contrary to the core engagements of the genre. It's not that I dislike action games, or action RPGs. But if your "action" is navigating a menu, it's not good action, and it shouldn't define the skill of your gameplay. Turn-based RPGs are good, action RPGs are good, but "turn-based, but actually time-based" is a flawed design yielding the worst of both worlds.
Fucking Classic

I was born after this game originally came out, so unlike a lot of older fans, it's not a game that was part of my childhood. I knew a little bit about it, but I didn't have any nostalgia for it, or any Final Fantasy game for that matter. Now that I'm older, I played it because I wanted to understand what made this game so popular among gamers of the previous generation. Going into it, I wasn't sure how well it would hold up, but I can safely say that it does hold up and its longtime praise is earned. This game quickly became one of my favorite JRPGs, possibly one of my favorite games in general. I even grew to like some of the characters so much they're my favorite characters of all time.

It didn't take long for me to get engaged in the story despite knowing about a lot of major plot points; I was enjoying every part of the ride this game takes you on. While controls were sometimes clunky, I immediately fell in love with the battle system as well - experimenting with Materia combinations is the most fun I've had spent in game menus. The story sometimes left me confused and the writing in the original translation doesn't always land, but I personally found this very easy to overlook as I enjoyed all my time spent with the characters anyway.

Visuals and music are subjective; unfortunately I feel that the graphical limitations of the time couldn't fully realize the artists' vision - but the blocky characters do have their own charm in my opinion. The music on the other hand is wonderful, and immediately became one of my favorite game soundtracks of all time. I found the many themes to be instantly memorable and filled with such emotion, it feels as if I've known the soundtrack all my life.

Many may say that this game is overrated, and while it isn't by any means a perfect game, I truly believe it has earned its reputation. This is the kind of game one would treasure as part of their childhood, but it can be still be enjoyed by a newcomer to the series such as myself. For me, there is something truly special about this world and its characters that immediately drew me in and found a place in my heart. I hope others who haven't played it yet can have a similar experience if they look past its quirks. It's a true classic.

Ive played ff7 since my brother bought a ps1 from his job in 1998. The original is great but I recommend the New Threat Mod from Sega Chief for the definitive experience. I could go on all day but to cut this review short, try the new threat mod.

Final Fantasy 7 is a very average rpg by today’s standards. I can see why people thought this was amazing back when it came out but still claiming that it’s one of the best rpg’s ever made I just disagree with. I think it’s mostly just nostalgia talking, this was my first time playing this game, I have played and beat Final Fantasy 4 and 6 before this and I do think that this game is slightly better than those, I thought those were very average as well. I find it very difficult to get invested and care about sprites on a screen or in this games case very low quality looking characters that can’t emote especially after playing recent rpg’s like The Witcher or Dragon Age. The poor writing/translation doesn’t help either. But there has been games like Chrono Trigger where I did like the characters and the story so I don’t know, maybe I just didn’t find the characters compelling in these games. I didn’t care in the slightest when a character died. In this game in particular I was so bored at the amount of time they spend on these drawn out backstories of Cloud, Tifa, Barret etc. These games do tell decent stories but I wouldn’t call them good, the journey these characters go on always devolves into having to stop the big mean bad guy which is ok because there is so many different ways you can tell that same story it’s just nothing too riveting. 

I also don’t like the pacing because of the amount of diversions the characters get thrown in, it feels like it’s done just to extend the length of the game it doesn’t feel like it has a purpose. I do like how each game tries to change up the world it’s set in though it keeps the games from feeling too similar to each other and I did like the setting in this game. The music was also pretty good the final boss theme in particular sticks out and it’s just epic. Moving on to the gameplay I’m not a fan of turn based combat, I think it’s very slow paced, boring and a chore especially when you have to grind to level up. I do like the turn based combat in FF7 more than I did in the 2d games but it still felt like a chore, I had to put music or videos in the background to keep myself playing during dungeons or when I was grinding. There are some sections in the game that were just very boring to get through like the gold saucer for example where you have to run around for quite a bit to find and where you have to go and what you have to do to progress. The mini games are so clunky and awful I wish they just didn’t bother. 

I don’t think this game is still worth playing today, if you are curious about it then I would say give it a try but if you are looking for a genuinely good RPG to play then no because by today’s standards I don’t think this game is good. I can’t see myself recommending this game to any of my friends, I have a few that tried it and couldn’t get into it and I checked my steam friends who own the game to see how many hours they put into it and the most I’ve seen is 3 hours. I think there are multiple rpg’s released every year that are more fun and better than Final Fantasy 7. I hope the later games in the franchise that I plan on playing get me invested.

This game not only has my favourite story but my favourite score as well (mostly). The characters are dynamic and unique and once I finished the game, I felt like I lost a part of myself. Im probably a little crazy for liking this game so much, but in the end i know ill never play another game like it.

This isn't really a bad port per se, although some of the features it advertises, such as save editing, are not available anymore and so you'll need to grind just as hard as in the original game.

Personally I love the game's plot, music, and characters, but everything else is really not that great. 
The graphics haven't stood the test of time as well as some of its contemporaries, and this is especially noticeable with the maps, which are just extremely crusty JPGs that can be very confusing to navigate.

Materia is interesting conceptually but with how often you need to rearrange it (because the game sometimes straight-up takes away your established equipment when there are major changes in the party) and how much grinding it requires, it's a massive pain in the ass compared to other games' learning systems (FFX, for one, I believe does a great job at making it unique without it being too complicated).

But the game's biggest problem comes in the form of the constant minigames that frequently serve no purpose and feel like just tacky, barely-finished tech demos for other games that Square just wanted to shoehorn in to flex on cartridge consoles. Not a single one of these minigames feels fun or relevant to the plot, and you can't even replay them later for the most part (not that anyone would want to do that).

But still, this is a really important game. If you want to play it, use an emulator so that you can fast-forward and skip grinding. Or watch it on YouTube.

I was looking for a game to help me relax, a seemingly oxymoronic mix of familiar and nostalgic with a fresh story to keep me enthralled.  FF7 managed to hit the spot perfectly;  Having never had a playstation growing up I had never experienced it myself but lord knows I watched enough friends trying desperately to get their materia back in Wutai or whatever.  

With my odd circumstances out of the way, I can confirm that despite many J-RPGs seeming impenetrable to me, this game struck the right amount of accessible and fiddly (though I made exhaustive use of a strategy guide and thank god I did because it turns out the game would be much harder without finding the useful Enemy Skills).  And I am aware that for those interested there are whole seams of gameplay I haven't explored.  I don't even have a Chocobo in a stables anywhere.

The story (apart from Cid's presentation and the cross dressing) really holds up and, having just finished it, has left me moved and aching in the way only the best stories can. The themes resonated with me deeply and Cloud and Barret's struggles in particular struck a chord.  There are many lines that stuck with me, especially around keeping going when things look impossible.  Presentation wise too, I will admit it took me a while to look past the 'playmobil' character models, but in those key scenes the cgi is still great and the framing and direction are always top notch.  The cinematography in that opening shot is a stellar example of both.

Late to the party though I may be, I feel this game richly deserves its reputation.

Bought this game quite a few months ago and suddenly decided to make a review now. FF7 is my first introduction to the Final Fantasy series and to be honest, I'm super excited to try out the other games now. For a game from the late 90's, I think it still makes for a great experience.

The graphics put me off at first (coming from a guy who's into boomer shooters) but I was able to get used to it in about 5 hours. I liked its turn-based combat system, and it felt it had a good amount of depth if you take the time to understand its mechanics (don't let others deter you from turn-based combat just because they don't like it themselves!). And I was actually very invested in the story as well.

Overall, great game. If you're looking for a classic JRPG to play, I can say this makes for an easy recommendation.

Final Fantasy 7 planning meeting:

Manager: "Okay, it's decided.  Our new game will be on the PS1.  Are you all ready to make the leap to 3D?"
Writer: "This is going to be awesome!  We'll finally be able to show the players the world I've been imagining!"
Game Designer: "We can have dynamic set-piece battles instead of fighting on a 2D plane!"
Background Designer: "We can have dramatic camera angles for every move the player makes!"
Animator: "Our fight scenes will look anime as heck!"
Developer: "...uh, guys, our hardware can render, like, 20 polygons at a time."

*everyone ignores him*

Every single part of the game that isn't rendered in real-time is built to an absolutely decadent quality level.  Detailed backgrounds, creative camera work, good animation, good action direction, engaging story, hours of content, dozens of silly minigames...

...and the stars of the show look like they're made of origami.  I've never seen a game struggle so hard against its hardware limitations.  But they made something pretty impressive out of that struggle.

[h1]My Introduction to the Series.[/h1]
[b]Final Fantasy VII[/b] was my first introduction to the [i]Final Fantasy[/i] series. Played the game recently and absolutely loved it, so this review has no [i]Nostalgia Goggles[/i] on. So...let's start.

[h1]"The Planet Waves a Cruel Fate to Men..."[/h1]

[b]Final Fantasy VII[/b] follows the story of [i]EX-Soldier[/i] [b]Cloud Strife[/b], who is hired by the eco-terrorist group [i]AVALANCHE[/i], Led by [i]Barret Wallace[/i] to help fight the mega corporation [i]Shinra Company[/i], who attempts to drain [i]The Planet's Lifeforce[/i] as an energy source to further their profits. Apathetic to the cause, [I]Cloud[/i] initialy fights for personal gain, and for the promise he made to childhood friend [i]Tifa Lockhart[/i]. [i]Cloud[/i] eventually join forces with many others to save the planet , wich is threatened by [i]Shinra[/i] and Cloud's nemesis [i]Sephiroth[/i], and discovers a reason to fight for a cause other than his own.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
[b]Final Fantasy VII[/b] uses the [i]Active Time Battle[/i] system, which means that you have to wait the [i]Time Bar[/i] to fill so you can attack the enemies, this goes to all three party members. The enemies also have this [i]Time Bar[/i] (But it doesn't show), wich means, even if you don't attack, the enemies will still make their moves. If you use [i]Limit Breaks[/i] or [i]Summons[/i] this [i]Time Bar[/i] will be stopped until the action ends. [i]Limit Breaks[/i] are skillsets unique to each party member. Each character has a [i]Limit Bar[/i], which fills as the character angers as they are attacked by enemies.

We have a total of nine playable characters:
[list]
[*] [b]Cloud Strife[/b]

[*] [b]Barret Wallace[/b]

[*] [b]Tifa Lockhart[/b]

[*] [b]Aerith Gainsborough[/b]

[*] [b]Red XIII[/b]

[*] [b]Yuffie Kisaragi[/b] (Optional)

[*] [b]Cait Sith[/b]

[*] [b]Vincent Valentine[/b] (Optional)

[*] [b]Cid Highwind[/b]
[/list]

[h1]Materia System[/h1]
[b]Materias[/b] are made from [i]Mako Energy[/i], allow a character to cast [i]Spells[/i], [i]Summons[/i], [i]Boosts Stats[/i] and give [i]Support Abilities[/i].

There are five types of [b]Materia[/b]:
[list]
[*] [b]Summon Materia:[/b] ([i]Red[/i]) - Summons creatures to cause devastating effects to foes or positive effects to the user.

[*] [b]Magic Materia:[/b] ([i]Green[/i]) - Used to cast magic spells which can deal damage, heal or various effects. 

[*] [b]Command Materia:[/b] ([i]Yellow[/i]) - Adds abilities beyond summons and magic to the user, to various effects.

[*] [b]Support Materia:[/b] ([i]Blue[/i]) - Enhances the power of other materia when paired with them.

[*] [b]Independent Materia:[/b] ([i]Purple[/i]) - Provides support, auto-abilities and stat boosts to the user.
[/list]
[h1]Soundtrack[/h1]
The [i]Final Fantasy Series[/i] is well known for having one of the best soundtracks in videogame history, [b]Final Fantasy VII[/b] is no different, composed by the Legendary [i]Nobuo Uematsu[/i], all songs emerge perfectly with the game theme, with epic Boss battle tracks and even normal battles tracks. It's simply perfect.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Always heard people talking how great was [b]Final Fantasy VII[/b], i wasn't very much into [i]JRPGs[/i], but last year, decided to buy this game and see why people loved so much. After finishing, i understanded why people loved this game so much, was such a unique experience and a great introduction to the [i]Final Fantasy Series[/i]. i totally recommend [b]Final Fantasy VII[/b].

[i]"Embrace your dreams and protect your honor...as Soldier !"[/i]

Duration: 33 hours. 

First-time played. 

Wow! That was quite the ride. I can see why Final Fantasy VII is considered one of the great games of last millennium.  The story is nothing short of epic.  The game itself is huge with tons of (written) dialogue and heaps to explore.  

The use of animations to assist with the story telling was well done.  
And sometimes with a very effective use of the pixelated graphics,.

A clever use of travel opens up the map.  First you travel on foot, then jeep, then boat, then by air, and finally in a submarine.  This allows clever use of the map as new areas open up as the story progresses, without any fake walls or the use of "level guardians" which keep you out of an area if you aren't strong enough.  This also serves to provide an open world experience yet still have a story that is quite linear lie behind it.  

There are also numerous side quests and other things to do in this game, which added to the sense of "this is a BIG game!"

Although I finished in a 33.6 hours, if I wanted to I could have bred chocobos, played lots of mini-games, and further explored.  I know I missed a lot of extra material.  What stopped me is that FF7 is not without its flaws. 

For one, the combat system itself, although containing a lot of depth and quite interesting, is confusing and clunky.  I got turned into a frog one fight, and I couldn't remember how to cure myself, but there are no hints at what items do once you get into battle.  The Materia system is very cool, I could figure out "fire" and "ice" but a lack of a glossary doesn't tell you what "ultima" actually does.

So, what could have been an excellent system ended up being quite bland, as I pretty much just button-mashed "x-x" most of the time to attack the nearest enemy, with a liberal use of "regen" and "cure" as the battles progressed.   I'm sure I didn't use more than 25% of the available attacks.  Enemy skill looked cool, but I only learned 3 by the end of the game. 

This combat system was exacerbated by two other things: 1. The high frequency of random encounters.  Geesh, in the final level I was getting so annoyed... and 2. Super long special attack animations.  Summoning monsters/gods was cool, but the animations took so long.  But the worst of the worst was Sephiroth's supernova attack...  

... the first time he cast it I thought it was pretty cool.  But it was so long (like 30-60 seconds?) that I thought it must be a special one-off shift in the battle.  In the final fight he cast it 4 times!  I was about to leave my chair and go for a walk by the fourth time...  Most animations aren't that long, but lots of them, even the enemy ones, get pretty tedious watching for the thirtieth time as you randomly encounter the same enemy for the fifteenth time...

Inventory management is also awkward, being designed for a controller. Difficult when you acquire 50, 60, 70+ different items and a similar number of materia...

Still, for a game made in 1997, I was very impressed.  It's aged a little bit, but the story is still epic enough to make it worth playing through.

They are scented with thirteen kinds of perfumes, including Rose and Vanilla. Apparently, the scent in the air after Sephiroth tosses his hair changes daily!

This is my first (and probably last) review of the Final Fantasy series. I've avoided this game time and time again because I wasn't sure if it was worth buying or not (was the story interesting or not, interesting game elements, etc etc); and I can for sure say that it was unfortunately not. I'm probably halfway through the game already and whilst the story and game mechanics we're very well put together, it is an EXTRAORDINARILY CREEPY game. This game is nightmare fuel if you play it long enough. I can allow things to a certain extent but man this game can give you the heebie jeebies if you play it long enough. Yes, great story, good game mechanics, character development and all but the main thing that the story always revolves around involves alot of elements that are probably not for anyone to watch (and in my case, hear). I wanted to like this game, but I just can't; so I'm uninstalling it.

TL;DR: Great game, epic story, good game mechanics and all, but the elements that which the story eventually revolves around takes a super extreme dark turn and whilst I can tolerate that to a certain degree, this game takes it to a whole nother' level. Not for me personally, so I don't recommend it to anyone in case they're not trying to have nightmare fuel for $11.99.

The original FF7 on PC. FF7 is probably one of the best JRPGs of all time. A classic. Port is decent, controls with Mouse and Keyboard are a little weird at first, but there is also controller support. Probably what is the greatest reason to get it for PC too, is the mods. You can customize how it looks and plays with various mods. Some mods can be found on the Nexus, but I would suggest looking into 7th Heaven. Can probably find it really easy with a simple "Final Fantasy 7 PC 7th Heave mod loader" on Google. The mod loader will help you find and install a lot of good mods for the game. There is a couple Youtube videos out there too to help set up the mod loader and how to get mods from other locations and use them with the loader as well.

9.5/10 - If you're a fan of JRPGs and haven't played this one, it is worth it. If you loved it on the PSX when it first came out, then the PC could have a nice and new way to play this timeless classic with the help of mods. In both cases I highly recommend. Plus the price is pretty good, pretty sure I remember paying like $40-$50 for this back in the day on PSX lol.

It's Final Fantasy Dude.....

Characters have mouths! The controller options doesn't work, I had to go through Steam controller options! It's the 1998's PC port with little to no changes. 

It's definitely not a game I dislike, but I feel like that there's much more better games in the same genre nowadays. Especially those that aren't restrained from the late 90s design choices, obligatory grinding and super easily missable stuff. I think Final Fantasy 9 has a similar plot with similar design choices that ends up much, much better than its previous counterpart. Much better for series newcomers wanting to try PS1-era JRPGs. 
-- Hence the negative review. This is probably down right the worst way to currently play Final Fantasy 7. 

I probably wouldn't have enjoyed it has much, has I already played a chunk of it during childhood, giving me lots of nostalgia for it. As a kid, I only got far enough to the partt where you need to reach the city of the Ancients for the first time, a bit before the end of Disc 1. Once the nostalgia was gone and I was now at the part that I don't remember playing, it got... Kinda worse? I used to play it in English back when I barely understood English; so it kinda felt like a new-old experience for me, now that I would understand the game. 

The game is also not as good as I remembered. Lots of downtime, way too many missable stuff, characters that are either completely useless to the plot (mostly optionals like Yuffie and Vincent) and a whole character that is basically a plot device (looking at you, Cait Sith) 

Most sidequests are about grinding for little to no reasons, inconsequential minigames with awful controls, of stuff that you pretty much have to read a guide to understand. 

I know people loves to praise the story, but it's just... Fine? I mean, it's good, but the pacing is really awful, and I kinda expected more from the antagonist. Also from Rufus, the Turks and Scarlet; who kinda is just "there" for like half the game, and you only get the option to slap her once. I guess it must have been pretty groundbreaking for a videogame back then, especially with a certain character death; had I not been spoiled by it I would have been so shocked, along some few scenes where I would have been scared of losing other party members. 

Also I have a few complaints about the other characters: he's pretty much useless to the plot once you leave Midgar. His next story bit Is in Gold Saucer, and that's it. He also seems to realize how his action also impacted lots of innocent people near the end? Damn, must be nice being this dense. 
Red 13 is also pretty much useless, except for one single scene in Cosmo Canyon. He's just... There, for the rest of the game. He could have easily been written off. 
I wished they had been more prominent in the plot and not just party member that you forget about, which I thought would be Did; who ended up having much more story beats than the others who joined way earlier. 

I liked the Battle system, but it felt pretty barren before levelling materias, it definitely was hard to start with so little. Made the beginning way more harder to enjoy. Way too many animations are also too long for what they are, making me avoiding most of them despite their huge damage potential. I saw Knights of the Rounds once, and that was enough, I don't want to waste 2 minutes watching it again. It got boring after a while due to the long ass animations. Kinda sad since near the end the possibilities with the materias gets so much more complex and interesting; which should have been much better explained. 

Talking about how slow animations are, l also find most of the moving options to be super slow too. Either due to the general speed or the map that is too big.  So many maps where it feels like I have to walk for an eternity, spend a few minutes just to get to the top of the ladder, or climb stairs for 5 minutes, or use the different transportation options in the overworldthat are still super slow. And even the first one comes in with random encounters, which I don't get because chocobos don't? 
My favorite is definitely the submarine where each movement felt like an eternity; I was so glad to learn there's so little to do with. I even made sure to skip one part by using chocobos instead. 

The music is definitely the best part of the game, along with the first part of the plot. Once the first part is done, the plot just try too hard to unravel everything in a pace too slow. Also, Weapons, they have little to no explanations to them, which is a shame. I don't get why they didn't wake up much, much more earlier with the Shinra projects. 

The ending is a huge joke, too. But that's not something I'm going to address here. It got kind of retconned with the tons of sequels the game's got.

If I could describe Final Fantasy VII in one word it would be ambitious.

The reason why I have 10 minutes or so on record only is because I used the 7th Heaven launcher for the Remako visual mod and a couple others which disabled achievements and did not record my play time for whatever reason.

After having played FFVI and feeling quite a bit underwhelmed after having heard so much about it and its comparisons with its younger brother FFVII and the legendary Chrono Trigger, I was expecting great things. And considering this was Square's first go at a 3D RPG my expectations were not only met, but far exceeded by the quality of the game. 

And I have got to admit from the start, I was going into FFVII 100% biased and knowing I was biased before I even hit that NEW GAME button. I was expecting something not as great as Chrono Trigger, and something not even as good as FFVI. Let me explain: with a lot of older games and media people have an obscured view of the past and so I always go into older games thinking that people only remember the good parts. But this is also coupled with the fact that a lot of the stuff from the 90s is just overhyped, overrated, or just doesn't hold up. I'll give a few examples: Gundam Wing, Dragon Ball Z, Quake, Doom, FFVI, and others. What do all of these things have in common for the most part: they are explosive and essentially mindless. The story is bad, the actions of the characters don't make sense, or there is really nothing much of real substance. And FFVII was giving me the same vibes before playing. 

So, I went into FFVII thinking that it would be mindless and full of explosives that get the adrenaline going but nothing else. I was dead wrong, FFVII actually holds up really well and I am embarrassed I even felt like it was going to be nothing but one of the greatest games I have ever played. 

However, before I get into the good stuff, here's the bad: the most spoiled thing quite possibly in video game history (why can't FFVII fans shut up about major events in this game? I guess it's because the fanbase is too big?), the world itself is kinda boring and it just seems like it's there for the characters to have this specific story play out, you need to turn the battle speed to max right away unless you love waiting around, the materia system (magic) is not that great at the start, you can't hold 2 accessories like FFVI, it takes a bit too long to get the Highwind (the airship you use in the game), the Chocobo breeding necessary to get to areas for hidden materia is tedious, the mini-games do not hold up at all, after leaving Midgar and until leaving that first cave the enemies give very little XP, Vincent is kind of a weird character to throw into the mix although he is highly miss-able if you are not thorough, the pacing after the first time at northern crater is a bit worse, the final dungeon might be worse than all of the dungeons in the game as it's a bit random, the inability to reach certain bosses during fights just drags them on and isn't interesting, the dread I felt while chasing the final boss did not seem warranted after having beat them fairly easily at the end despite only being level 71, reading deeper into the story kinda worsens it although you won't really worsen it for yourself if you don't seek it out, the inventory is a mess, the pathing in caves is definitely not perfect, and there are really random mechanics thrown at you that kinda takes you out of what's happening like when you have to actually press buttons for a gauge to do mouth to mouth on someone you just saved from a boss. Oh, almost forgot, this game might have my least favourite enemy in a JRPG to date: the stupid grasshopper enemies in Mount Nibel because they take forever to finish attacking. 

But here's the good stuff: basically all of the dungeons (and puzzles), the music is fantastic, the bosses and enemies are far more interesting than FFVI, there is explosive action like I was expecting, the video sequences are epic, there was far far far less grinding necessary to be able to finish the game unlike FFVI, the pacing was mostly excellent throughout the entire game, the characters have great interactions, Yuffie's side quest is great, each chunk of the game felt a bit different and cool in its own way, there are a lot of touching moments I was honestly not expecting due to Cloud's perceived edgeiness before playing the game, Cloud's edginess is actually exaggerated, the materia system becomes really great in the mid to late game because it enables more strategy and interesting combinations for the player, the chase of Sephiroth is really cool, the story takes a lot from Neon Genesis Evangelion and uses its own twists and characters to make it cooler imo, the inventory management is heavily reduced, and FFVII has the best start to a game in video game history. 

Honestly, if Square had just improved upon what I disliked about the game and brought the visuals to the modern age for their remake I think it would be my favourite game of all time and that's crazy because I really enjoyed Chrono Trigger, and Dragon Age Origins is currently my favourite game of all time. 

However, due to all of the negatives, I would have to say it is a worse game than Chrono Trigger, but a better game than Persona 4 and FFVI. That is not to say that you could not select FFVII as your favourite game ever over Chrono Trigger, I just think there are less negatives about Chrono Trigger in general and the bosses and dungeons are actually even more fun in Chrono Trigger. 

Grading this game I would give it a low to mid 80. 

But why am I not recommending this masterpiece? This port is like a waiter spitting in your face before they serve you one of the best meals you've had in your life and I don't even have any nostalgia towards the game. The people who recommend this port to others really need to raise their standards because it is bare bones and the only good thing I can say about it is that it's stable.

EDITED REVIEW:
I have changed my review for this game because Square Enix finally fixed the game to work. I've already played this game at least a half dozen times on PS1 (originally) and other platforms that the game has been on since then. 

FINAL FANTASY VII is perhaps one of the best JRPG games ever released. "What is a JRPG?" you might be thinking. A JRPG typically, or at least traditionally when FF7 was released, is a party or sometimes rarely single character game that a single PLAYER would play. It would have a strong, mostly linear storyline. It would have lots of playable and non-playable characters that may or may not enter into the "party" to be playable. Typically these kinds of games are TURN-BASED combat, or sometimes they're action-RPG but even then they're less demanding on hand-eye coordination than a typical platformer or shooter game. So JRPG are basically turn-based, single-player games, heavy on story, with lots of interesting characters. 

Final Fantasy VII is typical of its genre, but what set it apart from many other JRPG of its day was that it created a complex and unique world where magic and technology co-existed, but that the energy used to power the technology of this world was literally being sucked out of the planet's "spirit" or "Gaia" force. This energy was called "Mako" and gigantic building-sized reactors called "Mako Reactors" are used by a large mega-corporation called "Shinra" to control the city and most everyone in it. It is a dystopian setting, very Cyberpunk in its feel, along with a magic-feel that was reminiscent of earlier Final Fantasy games that were strictly (or mostly at least) swords and sorcery. This gave the game an edgy, "take down the man" kind of a feel to it. You weren't saving the planet from some crazed sorcerer or monsters. You were saving it from normal people who have let their corporate-oriented society run away from them.

Full of memorable characters and scenes, Final Fantasy VII has a long and interesting storyline that weaves around and offers some chances for exploration and non-linear progression some of the time but overall is fairly linear. There are a few places where you might need to "grind" which means to "just sit around killing monsters to level up" until you can get powerful enough to beat a boss encounter to progress the story further. Make sure you save in several slots so that if you do encounter something like this that you can't get beyond, you can revert to an earlier save point and grind to get more powerful. 

Also this game has specific places you can save, save-points, but it DOES NOT AUTOMATICALLY SAVE. So don't forget to save the game when you find the (?) shaped save points. You'll also want to be sure to stock up on healing and ether (magic) potions often when you have the chance to, and "phoenix down" for reviving downed party members. There are a billion guides on the web for this if you get stuck.

Have fun, I do recommend this to anyone who likes good story games even if the graphics are now kind of dated. There is of course the new FF7 Remake, but first of all it's on PS4 now only, and second of all it is only about 1/3 of the original game story, they're going to make us all pay $60 x 3 to get the full story it seems (original game was 3 separate discs on PS1). They also changed the combat for the remake and it's far more action-oriented, and not really my bag although I'll probably slog through it if I can to see the new graphics.

PREVIOUS REVIEW:
Game is straight up broken. There's a good chance if you buy this while it's on sale April 2020 that you will not get to play. Game requires registration with external Square-Enix account, then claims it is waiting for your email to be confirmed, claims to send email, but never actually ever sends any emails. Spent two weeks since April 18 trying to get this game to launch and it still refuses to get passed the stupid DRM. SQUARE-ENIX FAIL.

It's a good game, but there's some issues with this version. It has DRM for starters, you have to log into some Square Enix account. The controller support is just bad, remapping is not straightforward and the default controls are really stupid. The pre-rendered backgrounds look like garbage on any resolution past like 1080p, so try not to go above this. It really has not aged well. On top of that, Square's bad decisions never cease to amuse me; a game like Final Fantasy 6, which STILL looks beautiful on the SNES to this day, needed a "makeover" for the PC version where the sprites and UI have been turned into an ugly mess. BUT, this PS1 game that looks awful should be preserved 1:1. It just blows my mind how these choices are made.

Honestly, just skip this crap. Just like the Grandia 2 remaster, they contract these ports out to incompetent dip shits that are paid to do a worse job than some nerd sitting in his computer who creates mods for free. If Steam didn't have in-built controller support and achievements, I would definitely skip this. If you do buy this, get the 7th Heaven mod manager, the game is nearly unplayable without some basic QOL.

Just a nice little fun fact too, this game does not cloud save out of the box, you have to go into the settings and enable it. Like why the hell wouldn't I want cloud saves? I'm serious, this port is dumb as shit, so is Square Enix for forcing their idiotic launcher. Now I have to dig up my old computer and turn it on just to enable that shit.

ファイナルファンタジーVIIはシリーズで最も象徴的なファイナルファンタジーのゲームであり、かつて存在した最も人気のあるビデオゲームの1つです。その成功は、ファイナルファンタジー7のリメイクを含むオリジナルのFFVII宇宙に基づいた他のファイナルファンタジー7のゲームや映画の制作につながる世界的に知られています。 FFVIIの物語は、ゲームの歴史のなかで最も愛され有名なキャラクターの1つであるクラウド・ストライフの主人公であるあらゆる面での傑作、戦い、キャラクター、謎、全体の感情を組み合わせたものです。それは間違いなく経験する価値のあるゲームです。 UwU

It may be vanilla to say this, but this is one of, if not, the best RPG ever made. While the graphics may be dated, blocky visuals don't bother me in the slightest. 
The writing is just on a whole 'nother level. Each party member has their own distinctive personality and they each get their spotlight in the story, even the optional characters! My favorite character is Cid! 
The soundtrack is perfectly composed. The soundtrack has it's happy moments, downers that hit you in the heart like Aeris' theme, and inspiring music such as Cid's theme (the best song in the game). 
As for the gameplay, it's turnbased, requiring strategy with managing your magic and items. I did not grind for levels once in the game and beat it perfectly fine, which is a win in my book. Just don't run away from random encounters and you'll be fine.

You will not regret playing this.
