[h1]10/10[/h1]

Final Fantasy VII is a timeless classic in the JRPG genre, with an innovative story and engaging game-play that has stood the test of time. The story will have you pulled in and have your full attention right off the bat, you'll fall in love with our heroes, laugh with them, cry with them, and conquer with them. Every time a wild event takes place you'll think the story can't keep getting crazier and more intense, but the game never stops until you reach the satisfying conclusion to the team's journey. Though the graphics are dated these days, this port of the game offers minor enhancements that make the game more presentable. Despite the dated graphics, that is the only part of the game that feels dated. The adventuring, combat, and world-building game-play were all revolutionary at the time of FF VII release and are still standard to this day. Final Fantasy VII is an amazing game that holds a special place in my and many people's hearts. It isn't revolutionary by today's standards but is an amazing piece of history of what was revolutionary in 1997 and is well worth playing. 

[h1]Highlights[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Ground breaking game-play
    [*]Insane and creative story that will keep you griped and play with your emotions
    [*]Magic and ATB systems at their best
[/list]
[h1]Pitfalls[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Square fix your launchers, damn. I should be able to start the game without using a keyboard or setting a hotkey on my controller. This was especially a pain since I was playing on a living room rig without a keyboard. 
    [*]Controller support is half baked, it works well enough but you will encounter issues with it. Especially during events such as marching.
    [*]Chocobo racing
    [*]Game made me cry when I was 9
[/list]

First of all, i'm gonna say that it's the first time I play this game, I did NOT play this game when it came out.

I've heard alot of stories about this game, like it was one of the greatest game of all time, an awesome rpg etc, but I never managed to play it despite having it on my steam library since forever. I decided to give it a go, I wasn't ready.

First I'm gonna speak about gameplay, the gameplay is actually very good, sometimes it feels abit slow and repetitive but the materia system is good enough to keep you thrilled during the entire game. But for me this game is not about the gameplay, it's about the story.

Speaking about the story, It's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ amazing. Even for today standards, it is really THAT good. The game is gorgeous, beautiful, poetic, you cannot play this game and not be hooked into this beautiful story. This game makes you laugh, cry, and feel. Sometimes you're in the middle of the story and the game randomly throw at you a heartbreaking scene that makes you tear up (nanaki and seto for exemple). There is a lot of plot twist in the story and you really feel like you're part of the story and you want to know more everytime. What's very good is every question you have in this game are answered and the final is beautiful as hell. The game is also very mature and the relationship beetween the characters is greatly handled.

Then you have the OST, I have no word to describe how good it is, there isn't a single ost that is forgettable , they are all so amazing and you will love each one of them, we are in 2021 and i've played a ♥♥♥♥ ton of games, but I think it's actually one of the best music i've ever heard in a videogame. (I played with a modded version with ps1 og OST, and also remako HD mod , you should definitely check it out if the old school graphics bother you).

To conclude, I'm gonna say that if you never played this game, you HAVE to. It's honestly one of the best gaming experience i've ever had in my entire life. And even in 2021 this game is one of the best i've ever played. Just go and experience the game, live the story and dive into that stunning fantasy universe, you will not regret it.

I absolutely love FFVII! I've never been one for playing video games (unless Oregon Trail counts LoL!) but while in college in 1998 a friend introduced me to this game and although it took me a little bit to get into it, I was soon spending every free moment in his dorm room (to play the game, you sickos lol!). I will start by saying, Final fantasy 7 is one of my favourite games, and the only final fantasy game i finished. With and immersive story, Lovable Characters, as well as Sephiroth being, in my opinion, one of the best video game villains ever, you're in for a treat. 

Gameplay wise, its your basic JRPG with turn-based combat, in other words, Not the best (Unless you're into that kind of thing, Then its perfect) Now i hate turn based combat, i think its far too slow and random encounters can eat my ass, but this is one of the few JRPGs that i have enjoyed enough to finish. If i can play ff7 and say its one of my favourite games, i think most people will enjoy it. 

BUT, the steam version is lacking in comparison to modern ports of the game. If you have any other gaming platform, weather it be Playstation, Xbox or nintendo switch, I would recommend getting it on one of those. For example there is a 3X speed option on console ports, which fixes my only issue with the game and that is slow gameplay. Personally my  This of course is lacking on the pc port. My personal favourite is the Switch port, both for portability and it gave me the least issues. That being said. If those other platforms are not an option, or you are really adamant to play it on nothing but PC, Or you are looking to mod ff7, this is still a great game at its core and i would highly recommend it to anyone that is yet to play it.

This is an old remaster of Final Fantasy VII, the hallmark franchise for JRPGs.  The remaster allows the game to run, but the characters are still low poly and the game still only displays in 4:3, so it's below standards for PC. 

The control scheme is a mess because it's still a console port, and there's no mouse control, just obscure keyboard commands. 

This really only exists as a nostalgia gouge, and an expensive one at that... $18 for abandonware.   The old saying is true, you can't go home again.

Final Fantasy VII is definitely in my top three favorite Final Fantasy games (along with IX and X most likely). This version of the game is probably the most realistic and true version to the original PS1 game and that is both a blessing and a curse. I think most JRPGs being remade should always have modifiers to speed up the game and reduce some of the tedious "cutscenes" but unfortunately this Steam port is so much older that it doesn't come with any modifiers besides gil and character level adjustments which requires you to visit an external website to adjust. The PS4 port of Final Fantasy VII (not the remake) is probably my favorite version of this title because of said modifiers.

I still recommended this game because I love it and although it is plagued with some dated approaches to remakes/remasters it is still fun to dive back into the world of Final Fantasy VII on PC.
One of the all time great RPGs, an easy recommendation to fans of the genre.

It's Final Fantasy VII. You know exactly what it is.

I did too, but I had never played a Final Fantasy game before. As my first foray into the series, I was a bit hesitant and also extremely intimidated. I didn't know what to expect; or if I'd have the willpower, dedication, and perseverance to make it through *the* JRPG. After two attempts at playing through the game (one where I dropped it very early on), and two breaks in between, I made it through the entirety of it about a week ago.... and let me tell you that Final Fantasy has now become one of my favorite video game franchises.

The lovable cast of characters you get attached to, Nobuo Uematsu's masterfully crafted musical pieces, and the gameplay is just *chef's kiss*. I will admit that this game is from 1997—and it plays like a game from 1997. But even this has a certain charm about it. The beautifully painted backdrops for each screen are great. The sense of scale, journey and exploration in this game is also phenomenal. If the chibi 3D models bother you, then I recommend Kaldarasha's ChaOS mod, which gives all player and NPC models in the game an updated yet time/PS1-appropriate new look (very similar to the in-game battle models). I also highly recommend Mike Bettencourt's FF7 walkthrough/guide on YouTube if you're having trouble; I used this one and it is super helpful and handy.

I can't comment on whether this is the best place to start in the FF series, as it is my first. However, all-in-all I highly recommend this game. Whether you're a JRPG fan, or looking to get into the genre, this is a near-perfect game if you can get over the 1997 quirks.

All of that being said, I'll leave you with this quote regarding Final Fantasy composer's previous work on FF6:
"For a musician, the SNES sound engine is like an artist using Crayola crayons. Nobuo Uematsu used Crayola crayons to paint the Sistine Chapel." -JeremyJahns


EDIT: Forgot to add this, but this is also an excellent port of this game. Modding capabilities also give it a great edge over other ports

Pretty solid JRPG, and a decent entry-point to newcomer Final Fantasy fans or even newcomers to the genre in general. It's not the "BEST GAME EVER!!11!!11" material that literally every fanboy on the entire internet hails it as, but there is a fun time to be had here and it shouldn't be overlooked just because it's overrated. Despite some flaws and admittedly really bad mistranslations, this is still a good game that not only played a part in redefining the turn-based RPG genre, it even mainstreamed JRPGs here in the west, making it an extremely important must-have title. 

Just make sure you set your keybinds because, trust me, just do it. Knowing which button is which is vital for several *mandatory* mini-games. 

And they kinda derped some of the character's faces on their character models for this PC port of the game, and that issue wasn't even in the PS1 version...

And some pretty sweet graphics-upgrade mods exist for those of you who want a more faithful remake/remaster than the one Square actually made. Oof... Sometimes, we just gotta remake the game ourselves...

I initially wasn't going to bother writing this. I mean, it's Final Fantasy VII for Christ's sake. Reviewing this at this stage holds only slightly more worth than writing a piece predicting who will win World War II. It's not even like I can say I'm coming in with a fresh set of eyes. For years this was my favourite video game of all time. Literally nothing touched it.

This then, is the quite probably wholly redundant review of Final Fantasy VII for gamers who played it back in the nineties and are wondering whether it still hold up. The short answer to that question is yes, but not by as much as you might hope.

Context is everything, so who the hell am I? I'm the guy who:

-Played Final Fantasy VII when it came out, and absolutely adored it.
-Followed the series since then, coming out with a preference of VII > X > IX > VI > XII > XV > VIII
-Routinely go back and play games from my childhood, clocking 100 hours of Baldur's Gate this year
-Loved Final Fantasy VII mainly for its emotional impact

Before we begin, we must first be clear that this is the much-maligned PC port of the game. So if you played the original on the Playstation then be ready for several changes, many of them badly advised. The fact that characters now all have their mouths open in constant "O"s does very little for the experience, and a few of the jokes from the original have been edited out for some reason. For the most part it's the same game.

The first thing that is immediately striking about the game is how insanely easy it is. It isn't just the fact that I died only twice in the whole playthrough (Lost Number and Tonberry King, if you're wondering), it's the fact that only at those two points did I feel imperiled. Obviously this is a game that I have known very well, but I wouldn't say I was being particularly strategically diligent. I think, if you've played other RPGs since, you may find this to be surprising in its level of challenge.

Graphically - the PC port not withstanding - it generally sits comfortably in its 1997 niche. The environments are expressive, and it continues to have the locale colour that many other entries in the series lack. However it must be said that both the FMV's and summons have suffered. These were AAA things back on release and such things rarely age well. The summons particularly are awkwardly ignored because most of the time simple melee attacks are sufficient and the time for the animation - so cool back in 1997 - now is an irritation. I used a very, very small selection.

The soundtrack, for me, has transitioned from "incredible" to "often incredible." Having played a few more recent offerings by Square Enix, the compositional quality and thematic expression remains absolutely top notch for most of the game. However not every piece makes the leap. "Sending a Dream into the Universe" sitting rather awkwardly next to pieces like "Holding My Thoughts In My Heart," "Aeris' Theme" or the quite simply tremendous "Hurry!"

Materia somehow remains fun despite the lack of challenge and I was not far off gaining master magic materia when I managed to get hold of myself and not grind the game out for the fifth time in my life!

So. That's all that dealt with. Now, the story.

Stories seldom get better with the telling, and Final Fantasy VII has been told, retold and retconned into oblivion. Does it still hold up to the adult eye? In many places yes, but in other places no.

I've always rated the simplicity of how Final Fantasy VII tells its story. You have obvious antagonists and although there is the potential for exploration in general you always have a straightforward idea of where and how you should be proceeding. In turn each step that you take brings with it and exploration of how the characters got where they are today. The story itself is told through well established (although often underrated) cinematic devices, from the low angle shot of the reactor at the start to display the dominance and reach of the ShinRa corporation, to the morality questions that Cloud and Barrett strive to ignore.

There are problems, though.

Sometimes the writing that I and so many others beloved is, objectively, a bit ham-fisted. I think back in the day we filled in the blanks or else were just much more forgiving, but there are bits and pieces that could easily have been lifted out of FFVX. I remembered the clever and nuanced bits of FFVII in my heart, but the reality is that there is an awful lot of "this happened because reasons, but look at how cool the outcome is."

My friend, 12 years my junior, has been playing FFVII for the very first time and they asked the question "why are there so many party members?" As my playthrough progressed I thought, although possibly for differing reasons, that they had a very good point. From my very first playthrough Yuffie and Vincent were core party members to me, and I could never understand why they didn't make the cutscenes. This time I've viewed it with a more critical eye and Yuffie's dialogue is largely an afterthought, and the Wutai quest is immensely irritating for very little payoff. Vincent, meanwhile, remains a disaster whose character is a blight on the narrative. Yet the character that I had the most gripe with this time was Cid. I remember liking Cid as a teenager and associating him with the good guys, but as an adult I find him to be a total prick at best.

For all this, though, the core party are as strong as ever. Cloud, Tifa, Aeris and Barrett are the people around whom the story revolves and their stories remain poignant. I'm a bit of a sap but Tifa and Aeris both managed to draw a tear to my eye. So don't fear, FFVII still has that. It's just a shame that at times they are fighting for screentime with the likes of Cid or Yuffie. Still, the positives remain.

Beyond the breakdown, what was the feel of replaying Final Fantasy VII? Well, first joy gave way to irritation at the PC ports' differences, but joy quickly resumed. It was a bit frustrating that the game posed less of a challenge than I remembered, but I still rattled through "disk 1." As I got to "disk 2," however, my interest waned. At times I did push myself through rather than being pulled along by the story. All was forgiven for the point of Tifa in the lifestream section. I was then more than ready to grind up to beat the weapons before realising that's not a terrible productive use of my time and I pulled myself away. I did get KotR though, which tells you something about the hours put in.

So does it hold up? Yes. Just. However if like me you've been harping on about this game for the last twenty three years telling people that it's better than modern jRPGS....well. Caution is probably advised. Final Fantasy VII stands as a monument to storytelling in video games (and subsequently to hideous retcons and flogging of dead horses, but that's another story), but it's important to realise that it is a game of its time.

Of course it's still much better than the drivel Squeenix puts out these days. Rest assured.

Very special game. It's one of the all time greatest games. I've been playing it every few years since I was 13. It blew my mind when I was 13 and every time I go back I discover some new magic. It is a masterpiece. The Steam version has slightly updated character models over the Playstation original. I am in love with the music, and I also really appreciate the lovely illustrated background art for the various areas, especially the interiors. Extremely charming. Also, the materia magic system is unparalleled in gaming for creative application. Good for casual gamers just reading through the main story or for more hardcore RPG gamers who want to really dive deep into the combat system and complete all the side quests and optional bosses. Highly recommended unique shining gem of a video game. I don't recommend any spin off or remake, only this one game as a stand-alone.

I am one of the many that played this game in '97 on my PS1. I remember my friend and I calling each other up and comparing notes on what we had just experienced in-game and the cool materia combinations we put together. There are a lot of games that don't quite hold up to our rose colored memories, but this ain't one of em. I still love this game, Sure, the graphics cannot compare to the triple A titles of today, and the dialogue translations can sometimes leave you scratching your head, but when evaluating the game as a whole, it can stand up to many of today's big budget games.

Most of today's young players will need to get used to the combat system, but it will only take a couple of rounds of fighting to get the hang of it. The materia system is where you'll really need to put some thought into. Combinations, enemy damage, hero boosts...all make for a very in-depth game that really can't be beat; even by today's standards.

I cannot recommend this game enough. I do recommend playing this before playing the remake (I have not played that yet btw). It will give you some insight on why this game is one of the most talked about games in history.

Revisiting this classic has not disappointed me at all. I'm getting every little bit of nostalgia I had hoped for. There are a few issues that can be really annoying, however. First and foremost are the mouths that have been put on every single NPC in the game. Half of them look perpetually surprised with an "o" for a mouth. some of them even have extended faces because it must have been difficult to render them otherwise making the models look extremely ridiculous. The other thing I've experienced that is really irritating is sounds hanging on, particularly in the Gold Saucer when Chocobo racing. If racing on the long track, once you pass through the waterfall, the waterfall sound continues until the race is completely over. Same with the short track except it's the space sound. The space sound is a little more tolerable, but these are some basic issues that should have been caught in testing. Movement is a little wonky, but nothing that can't be worked with. Overall, if you're playing for nostalgia, it'll hit all the buttons. If you're playing for the first time, I'd recommend playing the original on the Playstation 1 for your first time.

Probably the best story of any game I've played in my life. I'm so glad to have finally played it. The gameplay was fun although I only found out you could run from battles until the area before the final boss which would have been good to know much earlier since constantly getting into random battles that often would take awhile got kind of annoying. Also the last area as well as the final boss has a huge difficulty spike and for the first time in the whole game I had to do some grinding. But that's all that I have to say about this games flaws. Everything else was amazing. The characters each had well thought out back stories, rich personalities, and fun interactions among each other. The story makes you care so much for the characters and everything they're going through and there's a lot of character development as they piece together the mysteries of the story. Also Cloud is way more interesting than I expected. Not just some edgy quiet guy but actually a really fun main character with silly dialogue and lots of emotion. 

If you haven't played this game yet I recommend it. It's top 10 or even 5 favourite game material if you're into story heavy games :)

You've heard it all before; this game will change your life, it's the greatest thing since sliced bread, all of that stuff. And yes, it's definitely talked up a lot, but I went in to it as a sceptic too and was genuinely surprised by how well it still holds up since 1997.

The Steam version has some odd controller button prompts but nothing that a little Google search won't fix. There's also a number of mods for seasoned players to check out too.

But the game itself is incredibly strong in it's pacing and delivery of the story, as well as allowing it's mechanics to shine throughout. The materia/magic system was a joy to mess around with and can be as simple or as deep as you want to make it. The pace of the game never lets up throughout and is always throwing new and interesting situations, minigames, story beats, enemy types and so much more at you as you progress. There's always a clear direction to move in, with plenty of optional exploration on the way, and always a clear reason to be progressing forwards.
The story and the characters themselves are extremely well presented and not dumbed down at all, they respect your intelligence and I was thankful for that.

I could probably go on for a while about FF7 and I already have done.

Further thoughts, gameplay and a more in-depth review on my channel:
https://youtu.be/TCZmpdaHfYI

Final Fantasy 7 is an amazing game, seriously. One of the best game I have ever played and if you haven't you should try it (if you can get past the outdated graphics). The story is amazing, the music is legendary, the gameplay is great. It is an all time classic and every gamer should have played it at least once.  
 it's also available for free all over the internet, just google it. This review is not about the game itself but the DRM that blocks you from launching it.

So I bought this because I wanted to re-experience the feels of playing FF7 with a few mods to give it a second youth. For convenience I chose to purchase it instead of getting an emulator and ROM for free off the internet as I usually do with PS1 era games. I'm not a broke student anymore so I can now afford to spend money for both my rent AND my entertainment at the same time (Fun times). 

So i spent 2 hours making sure everything was properly installed, that every mod was correctly setup and had no compatibility issues (there is no steam workshop so everything had to be done manually). Everything was properly set up and as I launched the game I got a Square Enix app loading, getting stuck at 10% and display "Error 9000". 
Whaaaaaaaat?
A quick google search turned out hundreds of search results! Turns out the Square Enix servers are offline so I can't play... Oh and this seems to also be a frequent issue, i found posts from 2013, 2015, 2019, 2020 and this is just from the 3 top results of google for "error 9000 ff7"
Whaaaaaaaat? It's freaking FInal Fantasy VII not World of Warcraft. There is no reason to be connected to play. Most people didn't have internet when the game came out, it's from the mid 90s! Consoles couldn't even connect to the internet if you had it and didn't do so for the next 10 years or so. This game released on steam in 2013 and it doesn't work as well as the game that was released 16 YEARS before. This is madness.

Instant refund, I will keep my money and play the game for free, Instead of paying 12 euros to not play the game. If you choose to have a crappy DRM system you better make sure it is working AT. ALL. TIME. 

I would like to add for posterity that I have yet to see a DRM system that wasn't cracked in the week that followed its release (and I'm being generous, it's usually more like a day or two). Devs please stop shooting yourself in the foot with these online DRM thingy. They do not work and actively turn people toward piracy. 

Ok I'm done venting. Don't buy this game, get it for free, it will work better.

Man. I went into this game thinking it'd be overhyped. "There's no way it could be as good as everyone says", I thought. 

It totally is. The story is tight, there isn't too much lore needed to understand it but plenty of lore to uncover, the soundtrack is amazing, the active battle system and materia system provide new elements to the old turn based JRPG formula to keep things fresh. Every piece of it is so tightly crafted and deliberate.

As for the port, I played a bit on my PS1 copy before switching over and as far as I can tell it's identical with slightly better character models. The cloud saving support is great if you're like me and enjoy playing on the go (laptop) and at home (desktop). Really cannot recommend this game enough.

Final Fantasy VII is one of the best games of all time, and one of my favorites, since the original PlayStation. This game is NOT overrated, but I agree that it's somewhat overhyped, in the sense that fans (like me, eg.), always use it as reference for basically any other game. So, in this review, I'm not going to review the game itself, but Steam's version.

And I can say that this version is completely faithful to the original, with graphics in higher resolution, although the scenarios and movies have been upscaled, leaving them a little blurry. Nothing that compromises the quality, though. Having said that, there are mods that further improve the graphics, which I recommend, if achievements are not important to you.

I had to make a few changes to controls. I use an XBOX Series X controller, and I had to download 2 files and change a configuration on Steam so that it would work perfectly throughout the game.

Some tips for those playing for the first time:
- It's useful to use a guide, or at least a wikia. There are many interesting missables in the game
- Enjoy the story, it is one of the best of its time and still very good today
- Start evolving Materia as soon as possible, as this will save you a lot of time in the future
- Do not worry too much about which characters to use during the game, as in terms of abilities they are quite equivalent. Stay with your favorites.

I mean, not really a whole lot to say here that wouldn't be a hit or miss with most people: You either like it, love it, dislike it, or hate it.

I grew up with this game on PlayStation (the original PS1) and I was in a constant competition with a group of friends to both discover secrets, and beat the game. I may not have won the speed competition, but I was the first in my group to find Added Cut, and Alexander Materia. Granted, I didn't find Alexander until my 2nd or 3rd play through when we were mostly focusing on finding secrets. But, when I explained how to find Added Cut, it blew their minds. I had to literally drew a route I took to the Materia for them. Also yes, that is a bit of a spoiler in the sense that yes: Those are two Materia in the game, and their hard to get, so my apologies.

But, anyways, enough about my childhood stories, onto the review! Having played through this game over 50 times from PlayStation 1 to PC and back, I can honestly say this game is one of the most relaxing games for me. Don't stress it if you can't find something your first time through the game, I can't express that enough! Just slow it down, and enjoy your first time through. Read the dialogue if you want to, or don't. I'm not the boss of you. The story has a deep lore that seems to change a bit through the various games associated with Final Fantasy VII (such as Dirge of Cerberus (PlayStation 2 game), Crisis Core (PlayStation Portable game), etc), but that said, you only really need to play this game to get the whole story, even if you need to play it a few times to find those hidden lore gems that connect the dots in ways that connect (at least Crisis Core) to the other Final Fantasy VII related games. 

Honestly, I will say this game is kind of technical in the sense that you have a 3 party set up, and have to use a combination of equipment, items, and Materia to battle tougher, and tougher enemies. Granted, you can pretty much steamroll through the game just by using the right tactics, but 100% completing this game can take many hours to do. I have my record down to under 26 hours, and that is just using my own shortcuts, and things I've found, not looking at guides, or routes people use to progress through the game easier. I don't exploit glitches, bugs, but I will use game mechanics to make the game easier.

In closing, I feel like if you want a game that you don't mind the pre-2000's graphics, and playing as a blonde spiky haired guy who wields a big sword (Not saying that's a bad thing!) then this is your game. This game in my opinion is one of the more unique Final Fantasy games, as it dropped the class systems from the previous Final Fantasy V, and VI which are both good games! But also lacked the card games (Triple Triad & Tetra Master) from Final Fantasy VIII & Final Fantasy IX respectfully. But, it still is a standalone game that I continue to go back to every few years, and usually I put hours into the game, and beat it each time I play it again. So enjoy it if it's something you think you could get into! Most people aren't disappointed!

*Note: I played this game utilising the 'ReMako' Mod which replaces the abysmally blurry background textures with AI upscaled backgrounds, giving the game a significantly cleaner look.

I mean, what can be said about Final Fantasy VII that hasn't already been stated by so many. Let's just say there are clear reasons for the hype and positive reception it has garnered since it's release in 1997. In a word, this game is stunning. Not in a visual sense but in the manner in which it had endured over time and remained so relevant in the hearts of those who've taken the time to explore it's seemingly boundless world. The story is enthralling (despite some admittedly obvious pacing issues), bearing a plethora of infamously memorable moments that need to be experienced rather than simply explained. It offers deep characters, dynamics and themes with several stand-out moments. However, it should be noted that the translation of the game to English is not always perfect, and therefore I highly recommend a mod which replaces the in-game text with a much more faithful fan re-translation. Additionally, the combat is surpirsingly customizable for a game this old. Allowing for self-directed character builds through the unquestionably complex materia system, the game can hold the attention of all those who greatly enjoy deep JRPG-style turn-based combat. All of which is complemented by outstanding music and stark visuals (which were of course cutting edge for the time). Thus, this is a game I cannot recommend highly enough to everyone, despite bearing some minor flaws.

This review will be split into two parts: Story + gameplay, about the DRM


Story: I haven't finish FF7 as of the time I'm writing this. I am a MOTHER / EarthBound fan (I love the games and play them again each year.) and I played FF6 (FF3 in the west) and I couldn't get into it, I prefer modern times in terms of the setting of RPGs (You can have other opinions). But, this is set in (a bit more future) modern times. There is still comedic moments, but not as much as EarthBound / MOTHER. I like the story and it is emotional in some parts (Not the saddest game). 

Gameplay: I enjoy turn-based RPGs (sue me). This style of turn-based gameplay is enjoyable. I truly liked the gameplay. THERE ARE SOME GLITCHES AND THEY AREN'T GAME BREAKING (EXCEPT ONE IN LATER GAME (NORTHERN CAVE). I think you should print out the controls in case you forget.

about the DRM (Square Enix account thing): It isn't much of a turn off, I found it not that hard and you never have to do it again. It takes like two minutes. THEY DON'T PUT SPYWARE ON YOUR COMPUTER. Anyway, I wasn't bothered by this and you shouldn't ether. It is a good port, just takes some time to set up because of the account and downloading two items. This isn't that bad people.

Q&A 

Q: does SquareEnix install Spyware? A: NO!
Q: Is this just a port? A: Yes it is, nothing new besides achievements 
Q: Speed up A: I don't know in the PAL and NTSC-US regions, but in Japan you can.
Q: Is this fun? A: I found it fun, so you might find it fun too, you should look up videos on this port before you decide to buy FF7.
Q:Is the music still MIDI A: NO!
Q:How long is FF7 A: I checked and it is about 30 hours for the main story and if you are playing casually and do all the side quests, about 160 hours and 5 minutes.

I will edit more Q&A by using your questions in the comments ↓↓↓↓↓↓↓

Classic RPG. 

Okay, in case you're new, let's just say this game represents the best and the worst of Japanese RPGs.

Greats: Long drawn story, fully developed characters, an addictive if sometimes repetitive combat system.

Not so greats: This is pre-2000 gaming so, grinding is a must! Also, no hand holding. Miss or skip a conversation and you're left pretty much on your own. Get ready to see the game over scene frequently. 

Also, this game was made for the Playstation. There was a PC port even back then (which I had, yay!) and it wasn't great. Sound is in MIDI and still is. Controls are a bit worse because back then the expectation was that you're playing off the numberic keypad. How many people have one nowadays?! You can remap keys but the game isn't too helpful when they tell certain sequence has to be achieved by.... you guess it, keys on the numeric keypad!! 

But still, it's possible to play through the game again. If you are a perfectionist / completionist, then I'm afraid some of the minigames are a bit off. Example: there's a mini shoot the hoop basketball game like you see in arcades. I remember I pretty much aced in the past, which made it a pretty quick and nifty way to earn in game (in location?) credit. Can't do it here, the CPU clock is all upset! 

Graphics have been upscaled as much as possible, so that's nice.

The game that pushed the franchise into the larger, mainstream video game consciousness, “Final Fantasy VII” could be considered the most-important entry. Square-Enix left the Nintendo consoles behind for their main series and transferred to the larger world of CDs for the PlayStation. For many players, this was their first “true” RPG, and as such has a particularly-powerful place in their minds and hearts. This port is faithful to that original 1997 release, allowing a new generation of players to experience the game as many others did before them.

The battles still use the ATB mechanic, but get a few adjustments, one in the form of Limit Breaks. A new take on the Desperation Attack / Hidden Blitz mechanic of “Final Fantasy VI,” as your characters take damage, a “Limit” meter gradually fills. Once filled, you’ll be able to do a particularly strong attack as a get-back-in-the-battle move. In a good touch, they also take precedence over all successful battle inputs, allowing you to use them as soon as you select them. As a technique, Limit Breaks themselves can level up throughout the game, unlocking new abilities. However, they are quite exploitable, either through waiting to use them once the Limit meter fills (it only depletes after the move is used, not by other actions the character takes such as using items), or by filling the meter in the first place. Certain crafty players will be able to execute them almost willingly and make difficult boss fights markedly easier.

The other notable adjustment is the materia system, again drawing inspiration from “Final Fantasy VI’s” esper system.  Every character’s weapon and armor have slots for materia, or little crystals that you find throughout the world. These teach your characters their abilities like magic, summons, passives like HP or MP boosts, and miscellaneous battle abilities like Morph, Deathblow, and Double Cut. As materia levels up with AP, the abilities get stronger, so a fully-leveled Fire materia will teach your character Fire3 (or Firaga, if you prefer) and spawn a new materia of the same type, albeit with zero AP. Materia can also be linked together to create some intriguing combinations. Link Ultima with Quadra Magic and wreak destruction upon the battlefield, or Time with Added Cut to inflict Stop with your regular attacks! A sizable portion of the game’s fun (and it is!) comes from fiddling around with the materia system and seeing what crazy combinations you can come up with. Materia also provides stat increases to your characters, though I’ll remark that they aren’t enough to feel too significant.

As vast and fascinating as it is, there are some drawbacks to this system. For one, your characters cannot “learn” magic from materia. Once the materia is unequipped, your character cannot cast that materia’s spells. This means that your characters will likely just exchange materia with each other in dungeons to ensure you always have the same spells regardless of party formation. This also leads me to say that your party is increasingly homogenized compared to previous installments. Since every character can be given the same materia, “classes” or “jobs” are nonexistent. Certain characters may have a proclivity to use magic more than others, but not to a degree that it affects play. Aerith / Aeris is perhaps the only exception to this rule, as she’s specifically geared for magic.

Aesthetically, the game is certainly PS1-era. Character sprites look a little funny and look stiff as they walk, even in the FMVs. But utilizing the new space available for discs makes the backgrounds beautiful. Now as you navigate dungeons, you get the sense that you are in different locations within it, so your mental map is more-thorough. Seeing your characters actually run across the battle screen to attack enemies, complete with better-looking sprites, works wonderfully. Summon animations are awesome, as long as you accept that you’re going to be sitting by not doing anything for some time. Musically, the game has some standout tracks. Cosmo Canyon’s music, the boss theme, flying on the Highwind, and of course “One-Winged Angel” are personal favorites. Since the game’s was Square-Enix’s first outing on the PS1, the music does have occasional problems with contrasts. The brassy sound from Rufus’s welcoming ceremony got grating rather quickly, constantly hammering the speakers.

Before I continue, I say this as a fan of this game: it’s important to remember that “Final Fantasy VII” must be taken separately from all the extra material that has since come out; the game must stand alone if it’s to be reviewed fairly. It does not get credit for things that are not in the game itself. With that said, story and characters are handled well in certain instances. This tale of Shinra, the eco-terrorist AVALANCHE, and the Cetra unfolds in a compelling fashion, with moments that will certainly affect you. Cloud’s unreliable narrator quality was a great idea, and Aerith is memorably-written. Unfortunately, the rest of the main cast doesn’t get quite the same level of care or attention. Vincent and Yuffie as optional characters have virtually nothing (and anything they had is completely skippable), Barret’s development largely stops after Corel, Cid’s grouchy / flat-out rude old man persona gets old quickly, Red XIII’s character is more about his father than himself, and the list goes on. This does not mean these characters don’t have interesting moments after their development is over, but moments are not the same development.

And then there’s Sephiroth, the longsword-wielding, grey-haired wonder. The main game is a pursuit of him and the mystery of what he’s after. However, since you’re constantly fighting proxies rather than the man himself, it takes away from some of his mystique. It sadly reduces him to a “Sephiroth was controlling them” trope that gets too overused, like Golbez from “Final Fantasy IV.” While he has his moments of showing how powerful he is, the mythology surrounding Sephiroth is far and away more fascinating than the character himself. Truthfully, I found Jenova and Hojo far more intriguing. He’s still a cool villain, but he’s not the greatest.

While the game is long, it keeps the adventure moving. If you want digression, the Gold Saucer can provide that for you with its fun battle square or numerous other not-nearly-as-good minigames. There’s also Chocobo breeding, but good luck doing this without a guide! As for the outing overall, it’s a rather easy game as I only got a few game overs playing the main story. There are of course the superbosses which will really make your head spin, so if you want a brutal challenge at the end, the game provides.

While it may not be the paragon of perfection that others have made it out to be, the “Final Fantasy VII” experience was most-definitely worthwhile. It’s far too important to the franchise and RPGs in general to not be given an honest chance, and the good things in the game shine. A surefire recommendation!

Hey all, as a huge FF7 fan I wanted to give this review of the steam version of FF7.  I have completed FF7 numerous times since 97/98 when it was released and have 100% completed it on the PS1, PS3, PS4, Nintendo Switch, Emulators, Iphone/ipad.. pretty much everything its been released on so I would say I have a good understanding of how well they port the game over onto these systems.

That being said, I'll start by saying FF7 on anything is great, however.. the steam version did irritate me a little bit because of the poor control system when using a controller, very odd button combinations which is documented in the forums which for me does let the experience down especially when it comes to mini games, however.... you can get good fixes on the community forums with steam so this is why I would recommend it.  If you don't want to do the changes then it could be a bit frustrating for you but if you do want to spend a bit of time mapping the controls quickly then it is just as good as some of the other ports.  

If you have various platforms you can play it on I would still recommend just the good old disc original for the best version :)

Dernière partie : Février 2021
Lorsqu'on apprécie les jeux de rôles, il est difficile de ne pas avoir entendu parler de Final Fantasy 7 tant il a marqué un grand nombre de gens. J'ai pour ma part découvert la série avec l'épisode 8, donc l'aspect nostalgie n'a pas joué. Il est également difficile de juger un jeu plus de 20 ans après sa sortie sans avoir un avis biaisé par tout ce qu'on a connu entre-temps, mais je vais essayer. Je ne parlerai pas de l'histoire en détails mais il s'agit d'un des deux points forts du jeu (avec les combats). Elle est un minimum travaillée et plusieurs grandes révélations viendront ponctuer votre avancée. Dans les combats, le système de matérias (source de magie permettant de lancer un ensemble de magies) qui se combinent entre elles est très efficace et récompensera vraiment ceux qui chercheront à les faire évoluer et à les dupliquer. Malheureusement, les plus utiles et les plus puissantes sont obtenues uniquement vers la fin du jeu, ce qui donne l'impression d'un système un peu inutilisé. Seule la volonté d'aller battre les boss les plus puissants du jeu vous donnera une raison d'exploiter au maximum ce système.
Pour finir, ce n'est pas un mauvais jeu, mais il accuse son âge et je me suis probablement habitué à moins d'obscurité sur le contenu et le fonctionnement du jeu avec les jeux modernes. L'ergonomie est également moyenne. Je le conseille à ceux qui veulent l'expérience originale avec la sortie récente du remake, mais sachez à quoi vous attendre.
Mention spéciale pour le français : la traduction semble avoir été bâclée et de nombreuses incohérences sont présentes dans le jeu. On comprend ce qui se passe, mais certaines phrases n'ont pas de sens et pourront vous sortir de l'immersion.
Côté succès : La plupart concernent l'évolution de vos personnages, mais une bonne moitié ne seront pas aussi évidents que ça à obtenir sans un minimum de connaissances du jeu au préalable. C'est un jeu à l'ancienne, où il fallait aller parler à tous les personnages dans tous les villes pour être sûr de ne rien rater. Pour ceux qui ne veulent perdre du temps à refaire une partie pour un ou deux objets oubliés, un guide est fortement conseillé.

Last played : February 2021
When you like role playing games, it is difficult not to have heard about Final Fantasy 7 as it has left its mark on many. On my side, I discovered the serie with the 8th episode, so nostalgia was not here. It is also difficult to review a game more than 20 years after its release with no distortion due to everything you have known meanwhile, but I will try. I will not speak about the story in details but it is one of the two strengths of the game (with fights). It is enough elaborated and few big revelations will come through your progress. In fights, the system of materias (magic source that allow to cast a set of spells) that can be combined is very efficient and will reward people who develop and duplicate them. Unfortunately, the most useful and the most powerful ones are obtained only near the end of the game, giving a impression of a unused system. Only the will to beat the best boss of the game will give you a reason to exploit this system at its maximum.
Finally, it is not a bad game, but it is old and I was probably used to less austerity on content and game systems with modern games. Ergonomics is average. I can recommend this game to people who want the original experience with the recent release of the remake, but you know what to expect.
About achievements : Most of them are about story or characters progress, but a good half will not be so easy to obtain without a minimum knowledge of the game first. It is a old school game, where you had to speak to every character in every city to make sure to miss nothing. For those who do not want to lose time to make a new game for one or two missed objects, a guide is strongly advised.

First of all, purchase the game on Steam & then play the modded version on 7th Heaven. The original hasn't aged well, and once you discover the alternative, you'll forget the classic. 

After an easy install of 7th Heaven, you can easily download & apply the mods you want. I've download about 3/4 of what's there, resulting in a true HD remake of the game. 

Coming from someone who looks at the PSX era of JRPG games as the very pinnacle of the genre, the 7th Heaven version is as good or better than classics like: Suikoden II, Xenogears, Tales of Destiny II, FFXI, Front Mission III, and others. EVEN if you've played the modern remake... this version still has value, mostly because of the classic turn-based combat. Hour after hour, scene after scene, battle after battle, I'm constantly amazed by it. You NEED to have this experience! 

Loved the music, story line, characters, battle system, mini games, and character development. There are several optional characters you can acquire as well. I didn't spend much time on side quests, but there's plenty to keep you busy. 

One knock against it is that the final battles were a bit much. At times, the story progression was a bit disjointed too, leaving you unsure on how to proceed. Overall, I think it lives up to the hype. 

Hope this helps,

The game is a classic and was pretty stoked to hear that it came out for Steam. The computer controls are weird and getting a controller to work for the game is a bit clunky as well. I personally would play it on a console over a PC since it plays better on it. The materia system was a favorite of mine and I loved the character designs they made for the game (minus Cait Sith.) The story is pretty mediocre since 25% of it is about fighting a corrupt organization from destroying the environment and the other 75% is stopping a megalomaniacal super soldier from hurling a space rock at the planet so that he can absorb the planets essence to become a god. However, the story is indeed dated from the old PS1 days which is why it will get a pass. The only major gripe I have with the game is that the late game has not aged well. In order to take down the super bosses, you need to do it in a specific way. This shows the lack of creativity for those bosses in letting the players use the collected materia, items, and weapons in whatever load out they choose to take them down. I also don't like how some things within the game are permanently missable (which people complained about in games like Golden Sun yet Final Fantasy 7 was far more egregious with it.) Outside of those things, the game is a great game and is indeed a classic from the PS1 days.

Final Fantasy VII is something I believe every gamer should experience at least once. Its such a unique experience, and I can not think of another game that made me feel the way this one did. 

This games story is unique and creative. I have never heard anything like it, and it kept me hooked for the entire 55 hour adventure.

The combat is simple, yet fun (for a turn based jrpg), and the Materia system keeps things fresh and exciting, allowing you to come up with all different kinds of combinations and strategies. And the fact that you can put any Materia on any character, means you can have any character fill any role, witch is extremely useful.

The characters so are lovable and memorable. With the exception of Yuffie, there was not a single character I disliked. Cloud acts cold but truly cares for his friends. Barret is super passionate about everything. Tifa always puts herself into danger to help others. Aerith (NOT AERIS) was always cheerful and would motivate everyone to do their best. Red XIII had no admirable traits whatsoever, but I loved him anyway because hes a good boi. Cait Sith is pretty strange and goofy, but always has the best intentions with his actions. Vincent was just cool and I liked that he could turn into a beast for his limit break. And Cid, while a jerk at times, always did what he thought was best for everyone.

This game also has one BANGER of an OST. There is not a single song in the soundtrack that I dont like. Some of my favorites in no particular order are: Bombing Mission, Anxious Heart, Tifa's theme, Those Who Fight, Flowers Blooming in the Church, Oppressed People, Those Who Fight Further, J-E-N-O-V-A, Cosmo Canyon, Aerith's Theme, and One-Winged Angel. Oh and the best song ever created, ELECTRIC DE CHOCOBO BABY! This game has my favorite OST of all time, and I don't see that changing.

And then there are the moments, the most unforgettable part about this game. There are so many moments in this game that are forever embedded in my mind. The first bombing mission. The plate falling on sector 7. Rescuing Aerith from Shinra tower (take the stairs, trust me). Learning about Nibelheim. The first fight with Jenova. The date at the Gold Saucer. Learning about Sephiroth's plan. The big spoiler at the end of part 1. The Reunion. Clouds character development. The final battle with Sephiroth. All of these moments were written so well. I am not someone who gets emotional very easily, and I went into this game knowing a big spoiler. And even with that knowledge, when the spoiler happened in game I felt my chest get tight and my eyes start to water. This is one of three games that have actually made me emotional while playing.

I can not recommend this game enough. Even if you don't like turn based rpg's just give it a shot. It is one of the most important video games I have ever played. This was my first Final Fantasy game, and I can't wait to see what the rest of the series has in store. If the other games are anything like this one, they are all going to be unforgettable adventures.

Final Fantasy VII is an experience that everyone should try at least once. I have played through it a few times and I can say that this game truly deserves a medal. I honestly believe that it is the best game that has ever been made based on several factors.
For me, Storyline is a big factor. FF7 is a game that actively progresses through the story. There are no long breaks where nothing seems to happen. The plot is immense, with surprises, twists, and excitement.
The actual battling is turn based, rapid, and thrilling. Containing an almost never ending assortment of difficult and amusing enemies and bosses that will keep you entertained throughout all three disks(physical copy).
Graphics wise, the game is not lacking. Considering it was released 1997(EU) when this game actually was THE game to revolutionize RGP-genre. Although the characters may be somewhat blocky, the battles and cut scenes are magnificent.
The soundtracks is my second favorite parts of the game. The soundtrack fits very well with the gameplay and the battle themes are just amazing.

Overall score. I give it a perfect 10.

I might be a little bias here, because I played FFVII when it came out back in 1997.  This game blew me away then and it's still good now.  It has an amazing story and good combat system.  

While it definitely isn't a modern RPG, this has all the roots that made modern games the way they are and was the standard by which all other RPGs of the time were judged.  As long as you go into this game expecting a slightly turn based battle system, polygon characters, dialogue bubbles instead of voice overs then you won't be disappointed.

The Materia system which this game uses is one of the best systems of the early JRPGs.  It allows the player to be flexible with their characters and choose the combat style that best fits them.  And the further into the game you get the more complex it becomes.

But the big reason people keep coming back to this game is the relateable characters and the amazing story.  Each character has realistic emotions, and problems.  Their back stories are some of the most flashed out on all of the Final Fantasy games, even to date.  The main villain, Sephiroth, is iconic and well deserving of his notoriety.

This story is so grand that the current remake has to be split into several parts in order to tell it again.  If you play FFVII Remake, it'll leave you with tones of questions that the original will answer for you.

This is where it all started 23 years ago.

8.7.2020.									Game #142

[h1] It’s really hard to review your favorite game of all time… [/h1]

I’m sure some of you are rolling your eyes after reading the sentence above. “OH, how original! Another person who says that FF7 is the best game of all time. YAWN”. Well, I can’t say I blame you,  but that’s just the thing, I don’t think I am in the same boat when it comes to why I love FF7 so much, and if you give me a chance, I would like to tell you why. Now, I’ve been trying to review the game properly but there is just so much to write about that I simply can’t fit it into an entire review. So, instead of giving you a proper review, I will instead tell you my story about how I first played Final Fantasy 7, how I finished it and how it is still my favorite game of all time.

[h1] I just wanted a game where I could name the main character after myself… [/h1]

I’m pretty sure it was 1997. I was in the 7th grade of elementary school. While all my friends were busy playing Counter Strike https://store.steampowered.com/app/240/CounterStrike_Source/, I was busy playing whatever I could play on my Playstation or some really ancient games that still worked on my half-working PC. Anyway, in my class, there was this one boy, let’s call him Pete. He was kind of a bully to everyone, except for me. He didn’t bully me because we shared a similar topic, which was video games. Whenever he went on a bullying spree of bullying anyone he could see, he would skip me, and even chat with me for a while about games. It was a weird relationship but I am glad that I got to know him because if it weren’t for him, I never would have gotten into JRPGs. We would often talk about our favorite games and would ever swap them between us. Now, back in the day, in my country nobody could afford to buy 50$ games so we, of course, had pirated copies that we burned. I should feel bad but I really didn’t know any better, heck, official stores sold burned copies of games. 

One day, I asked Pete if he had a Playstation (1) game where I could name my character after myself. He thought about it for a minute and told me that he had one. He didn’t know much about it and he hadn’t really played it for all that long but he could lend it to me. Great, I thought, and the next day, he brought me Final Fantasy VII … on two disks. Final Fantasy veterans know that the original game was on 3 CDs (the PC version was actually on 4 CDs), so did Pete bring me only the first 2 disks? No, he actually brought me two exact copies of the first disk but more on that later.

Anyway, I came home, put the disk in, named Cloud after myself and there I was, ready for my adventure.

[h1] An RPG? What’s that? [/h1]

If it wasn’t very obvious from the above paragraph, I’d like to point out that I had ZERO prior knowledge about this game’s popularity, its cinematic trailers or what JRPGs were in general. Again, I just wanted a game where I could name my character. 

I have never played a game before where, out of nowhere, enemies would appear but I really liked the main character Cloud (named after me) because he had that huge sword. I loved how after each battle he would get stronger and eventually level up. It took me quite a while to get how to play this game but I was determined to learn. This was also one of the first games that made me stop and read what was on the screen. As I progressed more and more through the game, one thing became perfectly clear to me: [h3] I definitely got more than just a game where I could name my character [/h3]

[h1] My friends and family were with me [/h1]
It really seems silly to think about this today but all other party members I named after my friends and family. My best friend got Barret, my sister got Tifa (man, that was awkward), my elementary school crush got Aerith, Red XIII got my cat’s name, Caith Sith got my cousin’s name, Cid got my other best friend’s name, Yuffie got my best friend’s sister's name and by the time I found Vincent, I had no more names to give, so I just named him after my dad. So there we were, my little army of friends and family all on a journey to save the planet from the evil corporations, or were we?

[h1] A villain I actually feared [/h1]

If you play this game today, it mostly plays like any other JRPG. The graphics are a little hard to swallow sometimes but the overall gameplay is still very much playable. Sure, sometimes it can be grindy but most of the time it’s very much tolerable. What always gets me through the game is leveling up my materia (magic and abilities earn xp and level up). After I learned how to manage my materia properly, and it took me quite a while, I felt like a genius. It still didn’t prepare me for what was about to come.

 Unlike all the heroes, I couldn’t name the main villain. When I first heard of Sephiroth, I was genuinely afraid of him. Not afraid, like hiding under the covers, but afraid in a sense of thinking about eventually facing him in battle. Even today, I don’t think there is a single villain in any medium that gets a better build-up and introduction like Sephiroth does. I remember saying to myself: “There’s no way, I could ever beat him”, yet I kept going. It didn’t help that as the game progressed and as I reached the end of disk one, I was learning more and more about Sephiroth’s amazing power, but that’s when it happened. [spoiler] When Sephiroth killed Aerith (she had my elementary school crush’s name) [/spoiler], that’s when I really came to fear him as I had never experienced something like that in a video game before. And, then Disk 1 ended and I didn’t have Disk 2. Rembmer, I had two copies of disk 1.

[h1] I went looking for disk 2 (and 3) and it took me months to find them [/h1]

In my country, nobody really cared about any other game if it wasn’t Counter Strike, so locating a Playstation game, let alone a multiple disc one, was a hard feat. I eventually managed to find a copy and the shop owner was surprised why I only needed the second and third disk. After getting home and inserting the disk, my save game wouldn’t load. Why? Because, they were from the NTSC region and I had the Pal region of the first disk. I went back to the shop and got the first disk (NTSC) and played the game again from the beginning. After witnessing IT again, I finally loaded disk 2 and was ready to continue the game.

[h1] The last boss kicked my butt [/h1]

I managed to get to the last boss and he kicked my butt. I was really underleveled and my material sucked. So, that’s when I went on a grinding journey where I leveled up all my characters and material to the max level after which I finally did it. Yes, my family, friends and I saved the world in Final Fantasy VII.

Only years later did I go online and find out that this game was actually really popular. I had no idea but was really glad that many people shared my love for the game.

[h1] Sorry for the lack of review but I felt like this game deserved something special [/h1]

Sure, nostalgia has a lot to do with why this is my favorite game of all time, but even years later, when I have less tolerance for games, I still think Final Fantasy VII is a great RPG. It’s fun to grind material levels and it’s fun to do all other extra activities in the game. The story is incredibly complex but dear to me and it always makes me laugh when I remember how all the main characters used to have the names of my friends and family.

When FF7 was originally launched on the PS1 I didn't play it since I never owned that console (jumped from 16 bits straight to 64). I later played it a bit on the ancient emulator Bleem!, which didn't work that well and had the game freeze on me at an important part.

Several years, later, tempted by the incredible FF7 PC modding community (Reunion, Remako) and the new remake, I purchased it on Steam and played it until the end.

What an experience. I grew up with the incredible experience of its predecessor on the SNES and held it on a separate level than most other JRPGs, and safe to say that this one is right up there with it. The music, plot, mechanics and even graphics, somewhat improved by the Remako mod (neural upscale of the textures) are great and hold up incredibly well today.

At one point in life I ditched consoles for PC and with it I focused more on CRPGs than JRPGs. I'm glad I'm returning to them and playing those greats I missed.

Since both have isometric (mostly) graphics, pre-rendered backgrounds, a rich story and were both cornerstones of their genre, launching it to new highs, I'd say that Final Fantasy VII is a Japanese Baldur's Gate, a feeling I had from the beginning to end and from my part, a gigantic plus.

The game itself is great. However, make sure to not rely on cloud saving because it can screw your save files.
One day I reinstalled the OS and wanted to continue my game thinking that my save is fine and dandy.
It worked some time ago when I needed to play on another device. So I thought that it's reliable. Well... It is not. It said it synced my saves but lo and behold... when I go to the main menu, my saves are gone.
Now I wanted to see if this issue was fixed. It was not. My saves are still gone.
Also, this version has Square Enix's DRM online launcher and on top of that the cloud saving feature it comes with isn't at all reliable and can cost you your saves. Yeah. An online DRM launcher on top of Steam. And that's for a game that's more than 2 decades old. That's downright insulting. Buy the game on another platform, get the original PC release and mod it or emulate. But whatever you do, stay away from the Steam version.

For years I had heard this game hyped up as one of the greatest and most important video games of all time. This game was made in 1997, two years before I was even born, so I have no nostalgic connection to this game. Hell, I've never even played a Final Fantasy game prior to playing this one. Finally, I got around to playing it and I can say that I think it is completely worth the hype. I personally love the timed turn-based RPG combat system and the materia system is also great. But where the game truly shines brightest for me is in its story, characters, and soundtrack. I cannot tell you how much time I have spent listening to songs from this game's soundtrack. 

The main fighting theme cues up every single time you hit a random encounter, and while the random encounters can certainly get annoying sometimes, the fighting theme never does for me. The characters have their own themes, and every character is unique from one another.  All 9 party members bring something new to the table, I could gush about them for hours. While the graphics may not hold up beautifully today, the art style and design of each of these characters certainly do. Even the two optional characters matter a great deal. In-fact, in my opinion Yuffie and Vincent shouldn't even be optional, because missing them is like missing a part of the story in my eyes.

Speaking of which, the story is brilliant. What starts as a cool but simple premise continually amps up and evolves throughout the run-time and I love it. There was one moment that is basically spoiled for everyone at this point thanks to the internet (and if it's not spoiled for you consider yourself lucky! Play before you do get it spoiled), but the moment still had an impact even when I knew it was coming. Yet the game follows that up with what was, at least to me, an even bigger twist that I had no idea was coming. There were several twists and turns and moments that left my jaw on the floor or had me react viscerally, sometimes verbally in one way or another. From the sweet character moments to the insane plot twists, this game has it covered for me in the story department.

I'm excited to play this game again someday. I consider it now to be one of my favorites. I know it's over 20 years old and the graphics are nothing special by today's standards, and turn-based combat with random encounters may not be for everybody, but I truly hope that more people in my generation will play this game at least so I have someone to talk to about it.

MASTAPEECE!

Final Fantasy VII is just as fucking incredible today as it was decades ago.

The greed of mankind has pushed the world to the brink of destruction. The folly of mankind evokes imagery of globalization-gone-wrong, the economic boom, and the destructive force of nuclear power. Yes, it's a Japanese story from the '90s. It plays with the concept of spirits and life force persisting through our physical bodies. To construct a mechanism around mining the spirits of the planet is so extremely twisted beyond reason. Shinra isn't simply just destroying their world - they are, in a sense, eroding their own memories, the spirits of their ancestors. It's a cautionary tale for the next generation to not forget themselves, to always respect their elders and the natural world. But this story was plenty powerful to me as an American in 2020, too. How much the people of the planet had given away over time for the convenience of a corporation that supplies easy energy and transportation. The folks in FFVII know their world is falling apart but they are hopeless against infallible systems that distract them by permitting tiny freedoms. It is insanely topical. 

But like the best FFs, there's that juicy, grounded emotional core about the very human experience. Moving away, dealing with the loss of the parent, feeling left out. No matter how grand these fantasy tales get, there's always that acknowledgement that the human struggles in the real world are just as fantastical. FFVII addresses its audience with a thoughtfulness that gamers are already prone to isolation and insecurity. It explores how to navigate those feelings, where they come from, and what life can look like if you live it with honesty and self-actualization.

So yeah, I love this game deeply. And these kinds of stories are critically important for people to experience. But it's also got random battles, the translation can be memey, and the steam port has DRM. So. You know. I guess it's just the same kind of trash as every other video game at the end of the day.

The port is...fine. It takes a bit of finagling with the button mapping to get it to run decently on a controller, and in the update to PC it's less been remastered than just reconsidered and smoothed over slightly. In general, this is almost the exact same experience people will have had on the PS1 back in the day.

The game itself is very good. The story goes on a lot of interesting tangents, the music is top-notch superb, the gameplay is engaging. It's got a lot of small minigames which don't really come up again or have a great deal of depth, but a lot of them (such as the motorbike, the submarine, the snowboard, etc) are all replayable at a later date. Things like the submarine and the Fort Condor minigame feel less like key parts of the story and more like aspects that Square were just incredibly excited to work on and were shunted into the game – and it's quite hard to criticise in good faith that amount of enthusiasm from a dev team.

The real star of the game is the Materia system, which is incredibly elegant. Your characters grow and level as the game progresses, but all of their magic/summons/extra commands are independent of them, levellable separately as the game goes on with their own improvements. While I've seen some people criticise this for making the characters feel interchangeable, I never had that – Cait Sith is never going to be a physical attacker regardless of how much you buff him, and Barrett will never be the best mage. It consists more of making you think about the best choices. This especially came to the front with the Battle Square – with one character only and (if you're late-game) an absolute deluge of potential choices, it becomes more like a puzzle than anything else. That said, I would have killed for a simple “save these Materia to this character” button to prevent the inevitable unequipping and re-equipping when I decide that I really should give Vincent a try.

Here's the thing. This game is a PS1 classic that has good gameplay, a good story, and a god-tier soundtrack; however, my experience with the steam port of this game isn't perfect. When I started my first playthrough I had issues with the audio not coming through which hurt my initial experience. When I went to resolve the issue steam didn't do anything, it was only with the help of the community that I was able to make it work. Other than that the port is fine with an exception to the  initial controls (hotkeys) which are a nightmare to deal with, just change them and you'll be fine. Once the audio was fixed I got to a certain point and my first PC died, leading to all my progress being wiped (other games still had saves, just not this one). I started it again and got pretty far, only for square enix to wipe my save file even though I created an account with them specifically so I could create backups. I ended up going to the PS1 version of the game to start a third playthrough. Overall, this game is seriously a must play so I'm still recommending it but keep in mind that there are other ways to play it. The game itself gets a 9.5/10, this version (along with steam/ square enix support) gets a 3/10.

Look, everyone has either heard of this game or played it. It is an iconic RPG for a reason. Not only was it graphically groundbreaking for its time, but it also has a story that stands the test of time. The gameplay def feels dated now, but as long as you don't mind turn based combat, there are still many ways to make it fun. The Materia system allows you to replay the game and build the characters in different ways. You can make someone who would otherwise be a melee weapon character into a spellcaster, and vice versa. There is also tons of side content beyond the main story that turns this 26-30 hour game into a 60 hour+ adventure. With the Remake out now, it may be tempting to just play that to get a modern version, but trust me, the Remake is far more enjoyable if you have played the original as there are numerous instances of foreshadowing to later parts of the original story, that haven't happened yet in the Remake (which only takes place in the game's opening act). This is a classic that deserves playing by any fan of the genre, and if you want to update its looks, then look into modding it (search for 7th heaven FFVII) and look for the Qhimm forums, has instructions and a mod installer there. If you're a FFVII veteran and looking for a more challenging adventure, I highly recommend the New Threat mod which increases the difficulty substantially and demands that you use all of the game's mechanics (and even adds more gameplay mechanics) to win. If you're curious about what the game can look like with mods and New Threat, look up the playthrough on Youtube by Maximilian Dood.
