It is likely that potential players of [i]Final Fantasy 7[/i] fall into two categories: newcomers to the game and veteran players.  This is likely particularly true with the recent release of the FFVII Remake.  So, this review will be split into two for each potential player.

Review for new players:

With the video game world marching forward into the third dimension with the Playstation, Square endeavored to bring one of its most popular franchises into new territory with FFVII.  Thanks to the massive global marketing of the Playstation system, FFVII brought in the most newcomers to the series than each of the previous titles.  The game brings many established elements of [i]Final Fantasy[/i] into a new generation while contributing its own unique elements to varying degrees of success.

After leaving a corporation-controlled special forces unit, Cloud Strife finds himself in Midgar working with a childhood friend in a terrorist rebellion group opposed to that corporation.  After crossing paths with a sweet, seemingly-naive girl called Aeris whom is being hunted for being an "Ancient," Cloud is forced to acknowledge a dark part of his path in the form of Sephiroth.  Determined to stop the corporation and to ascertain Sephiroth's plans, Cloud and company embark on a journey of identity, redemption, memory, and perseverance.  The world will be destroyed in seven days.  Cloud's group of misfits are the only hope of salvation.

FFVII has one of the biggest legacies in video gaming.  FFVII has developed such a voluminous following, that it has reached the point of the "Kardashian effect": It's really popular because it's popular.  This is not to demean the game in anyway.  It is very good.  However, newcomers should come into the experience with the proper expectations thqt are not biased from twenty-three years of nostalgia.  

Those who had played FFIII (US title) found a lot of similar game mechanics in FFVII.  The method (and look) of world traversing, the battle system, the ensemble cast of characters, and even the 2.5D movement feel very similar to FFIII.  FFVII introduces several new aspects to the series in its limit system (a.k.a. overdrive, limit break, and trance mode), the CGI scenes, a heavy usage of mini games, and a much darker atmosphere.  FFVII left the realm of high fantasy for urban fantasy.  This journey into urban fantasy was met with mixed reception.  Newcomers to the series found a lot to love about the atmosphere.  Many established fans were so dismayed that Square essentially created FFIX as a "return to [i]Final Fantasy[/i].  Whether or not a potential player will enjoy the darker atmosphere will largely depend on whether they want a journey of magic and whimsy with very real moments of tragedy or a journey filled with strife and tribulations with some moments of whimsy.

FFVII does many aspects of JRPG's extremely well.  First, its story is deep and immersive.  While loosely done in earlier [i]Final Fantasy[/i] titles, FFVII puts great effort into the backstory of the antagonist on top of the main party.  There are a few moments that will elicit genuine strong emotions from the player.  The battle system is intuitive, particularly those familiar with FFVI's esper system or FFV's job system.  The soundtrack cannot compare to those of FFVI or FFIX, but the music has many haunting tracks and a great variety of arrangements that flow very well with different situations.  The music is one of Uematsu's better endeavors.  

FFVII does some things poorly.  The pacing of all the Playstation-era [i]Final Fantasy[/i] games can be atrocious, particularly with regard to battles.  Battles quickly become a series of pressing the same button(s) repeatedly with no real opportunity for player immersion (except for the boss battles, of course).  The mini games are mostly awful and seem to only be included to showcase the 2.5D world.  Anyone who says that the bar-swinging or dolphin-jumping sequences (You'll know them when you get to them.) are intuitive is lying.

What is FFVII's greatest strength might also be one of its weaknesses.  FFVII has a few huge, epic, series-defining moments.  In fact, if you've never played the game, you probably still know the biggest event in the game (in terms of emotional power).  However, FFVII then becomes what is a small sequence of powerful moments with a less grandiose story connecting them.  Some of these moments do not fit exceedingly well into the world as a whole as well as they could.  FFVII is epic in all of its various aspects.  And yet, this epic-ness does not leave room for subtlety.

Any fan of JRPG's should give FFVII a try.  It has a fantastic story to tell and does so in an immersive way.  It embraces many of the characteristics of what a [i]Final Fantasy[/i] game should be while maintaining a unique identity.  That being said, a player would be better served trying FFVII on a console as opposed to Steam.  The Steam version of FFVII requires that you connect to Square Enix's online servers to play, which is utterly unnecessary and burdensome.  The controls are adequate but awkward (but can be rectified with certain controllers).  Also, the sound uses MIDI versions, which are not nearly as crisp as the original.  If a player only has access to a computer, then the Steam version will suffice.

Review for veterans of FFVII:

As a source of nostalgia, the Steam version of FFVII is adequate, but it is completely lacking compared to other ports.  Simply put, the Steam port negatively impacts the game.  Players should play FFVII on a console, if possible.

The best part of the Steam port is the visuals, which have been updated and smoothed from the Playstation original.  Cutscenes are made more immersive with these improved graphics, and the summon scenes are even more breath-taking.  Unfortunately, that is really all the positives regarding the port.

The audio uses MIDI versions of the the music.  As MIDI usage is becoming less popular, many computers do not have high-quality synthesizers.  Thus, the audio may very well sound objectively worse than on the original version.  There are mods available that replace with music with other versions, however.

The keyboard controls are somewhat intuitive but still awkward.  Some controllers work well with this port, however most do not seem to allow usage of the D-pad.  Those interested in buying the Steam version should have a controller or plan on purchasing a controller.

The Steam version of FFVII requires that players connect to Square Enix's servers.  For a twenty-three-year-old single-player game, this connection is unnecessary and needlessly burdensome.  

Overall, I cannot recommend the Steam version of FFVII unless it is the player's only option.

Great action, charming visuals, and a gripping plot.

It's a totally influential game, totally important and iconic, and for that reason it is a part of the history, no doubt. I never could really say I liked it much. It has countless cool moments from hour to hour, and I appreciate the little things. But the overall translation / localization is so poor that it really takes me out of the experience. I can never shake the feeling that it's a poorly translated game, and I just don't think anyone would deny it. I guess that's part of its charm. As a JRPG it is hella complicated, and because the dialogue is so poorly translated I often don't know where the hell I'm going, or why, or what is going on, or who the hell these people are and why they're doing what they're doing. The music is great. Graphics have aged poorly but I'll just call them great, because they are appealing in a retro way. Gameplay ranges from solid to tedious. For real, this game is totally overrated and I could never get into the characters or story, but dunking on it is of absolutely no value to anyone because the game is just too important. It is one of the most iconic games of the 90s.

[h1]ZRatings: Final Fantasy VII (68/100)[/h1]
[url=https://www.minds.com/ZakkiOrichalcum/blog/zratings-final-fantasy-vii-68-100-1187870314516856832]To get the full breakdown, click here[/url] and [url=https://www.minds.com/ZakkiOrichalcum/blog/zratings-1187751717029240832]if you are new to this system, click here to find out how this system breaks down games and explanations for the categories![/url]

Quick Ratings for those that do not want to scroll too far:
[table] 
[tr][td]Writing[/td][td]29/40[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Gameplay[/td][td]32/50[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Music[/td][td]4/5[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Subjective Rating[/td][td]3/5[/td][/tr]
[tr][td][b]Total[/b][/td][td][b]68/100[/b][/td][/tr]
[/table]

This was my first time going through Final Fantasy VII. I had had many people over the years talk a lot about it in both being the greatest FF game and also being overrated. I thought it was final time to go through it entirely to make an honest assessment. 

I always be honest with these ratings and will show how much I went through the game. In most cases and since these are mostly RPGs, I will go through them in their entirety and pick up all of the trophies along with that. And now the breakdown:

[h2]Writing (29/40)[/h2]
[h3]Narrative (12/15)[/h3]
Final Fantasy VII has a pretty good narrative. This being the first time I have ever played VII, I was pleasantly surprised how much it held up after years of hearing about it from basic pop culture.

[h3]World Building (3/5)[/h3]
FFVII has a pretty good narrative. This being the first time I have ever played VII, I was pleasantly surprised how much it held up after years of hearing about it from basic pop culture.

[h3]Character Building (5/5)[/h3]
I have been hearing for years about how "emo" Cloud is and how his character is wrapped up into his pain. I would disagree after actually playing it. Cloud has great characterization and changes over the course of events. Definitely stand up to time. Sephiroth is not that great of a villain (nor is he really the villain; he's more of a lackie for JENOVA) but I can see his appeal from his design and build up. All other characters are built up very well including Avalanche even though they do not make it to the end.

[h3]Lore (3/5)[/h3]
There is a fair amount of history that is implied by the game but its not terribly deep. Basically you have the lore surrounding the ancients and that's about it. Not much greater depth than "there were ancient peoples and technology/magic"

[h3]Dialog (3/5)[/h3]
Dialog is fine. Nothing terrible about it but textboxes can only go so far in implying emotions.

[h3]Originality (3/5)[/h3]
The story overall is most unique at the beginning of the game: eco-terrorist group Avalanche verses corporation trying to drain the planet of its resources. The Rest of the game trend back into ancient civilization vanished and left behind technology (Magic) that can destroy the world. Tack on the villain "thinks they are better because they are <whatever the villain is other than human>". Looking at history, one of the first video games to do this well but not the most interesting story over time.

[h2]Gameplay (32/50)[/h2]
[h3]Main Game Mechanics (10/15)[/h3]
This is the basic FF ATB system. IV had it. VI had it. Now with Materia. Materia is a great way to allow characters to have different roles throughout the game and change them as needed. Levels matter but not by a ton. Both are not my favorite systems in games but they certainly work.

[h3]Side Game Mechanics (5/5)[/h3]
There are side content everywhere in this game, sometimes to the games determent. Minigames to block progress is not a fun mechanic but most of those did not require good scores. Plenty of things to do if you don't want to do the rest of the games content: Chocobo racing, an RTS game, entire section of just minigames to earn possible prizes.

[h3]Game Balance (2/3)[/h3]
Limiting moves to what Materia you have greatly constrains the player to how powerful they can be at one time. There is no way to completely jump power stages and potentially ruin the challenge. Late game I think the ceiling is too high for what competition is out there. This hampers it, especially with...

[h3]Post Game Content (2/5)[/h3]
...the Weapons being joke post bosses. Ultima Weapon is a pushover for being called Ultima. I believe I took him down at Lvl 60. I had had Ruby and Emerald built up for years as difficult bosses. I ruined the Ruby fight because I figured out the power of Mime and more importantly the power of Final-Phoenix. I expected since that was an easy association to find there would be post game bosses that actually required that sort of set up. This didn't happen once in the Ruby fight. Hades and Knights of the Round with W-Summon is much too strong. I was so disgusted that for Emerald, I didn't use any of that after I got to Level 90 and just took on the boss (with 8 Materia on everyone) and no cheap 7777 tricks or spamming Mime. Just a straight fight and Emerald was a joke. I like challenging extra bosses but I think the ATB system hampers interesting tactical endgame bosses. There are some other quests in post game like the Battle Zone and getting the Complete Materia if you like Grinding. If you are a hunter of trophies, there will be lots of AP grinding in store for you.

[h3]Graphics (2/5)[/h3]
The graphics on the original are serviceable. Not great but they work. There are times that the graphics started to get in the way of my ability to do things properly but mostly works fine.

[h3]User Interface (4/5)[/h3]
Generally clear and working. This may only be for the PC port but there were several times that button choices for minigames were very unclear since it did not use "X" or "B" buttons but instead "SELECT" and "MENU"

[h3]World/Level Design (3/5)[/h3]
I do not like games with Overworlds as compared to connected pieces of land. I think the latter adds the realism and world depth. VII is an overworld style game that works fine. The interiors are great mazes and mirror their environments well; the twists of haphazard construction in the slums of the different sections of Midgar to the uniformity in the Shinra building.

[h3]Accessibility (2/2)[/h3]
The ATB battle system is easy to grasp and Materia easily explain themselves how they work; its just a different form of equipment that has spells inside it. 

[h3]Replayability (1/3)[/h3]
There are not very different ways I could see trying to play this again and since Materia make characters more or less interchangeable, there is very little reason to replay this again.

[h3]Originality (1/2)[/h3]
Materia is really the only thing the makes the game original in gameplay. Almost every other aspect has been done by a Final Fantasy game before it.

[h2]Miscellaneous (7/10)[/h2]
[/h3]Music (4/5)[/h3]
Overall, the music is quite good. I wish there was a different battle theme for regions to shake things up but otherwise I can see myself jamming out to it later.

[h3]Subjective Rating (3/5)[/h3]
There game is fine. I would recommend for people to play once in their life. I would say its narrative is better part of the game than its battle system. 

[h1]Total (68/100)[/h1]
In closing, Final Fantasy VII was a good game. It definitely is a product of its time but mostly holds up until now. I do not think it is fitting of the greatest game of all time but most of our old favorites are not. If its your favorite game ever, don't let this dissuade you from liking it, and definitely recommend someone who hasn't played it to do so at least once.

Final Fantasy remains a videogame series that is stuck in the age of Atari or the Commodore 64. Very vague ideas are tossed around without much thought put into how they work or what their intended purpose is. While VII is far from the worst in this regard, its nature as one of several chances for the series to move into the NES era of game design - when games began understanding their own fundamentals - turns it into something utterly disappointing. While it exists as a standout in videogame stories and story-telling even to this day, attempting to find any value in its combat system is a fool's errand.

In any turn-based game, strategy and decision-making are pivotal. Turn-to-turn decisions that can change the outcome of a fight are important, as is enabling the player to think several turns ahead and make plans that can ultimately decide the outcome of the battle. These are both things missing from this franchise. Various mechanics in this game, while theoretically sound, are completely invalidated by the iron fist of Square's enemy design. Do you want to build around status effects? Sorry, most enemies are immune to them. Is a boss giving you trouble? Well don't go looking for better strategies, just optimise your damage output.

As an RPG, FFVII, like the rest of the franchise, tends towards being brainless. You just get into the habit of Nuke > Heal > Nuke > Heal. Your strongest attack every turn, while your healer keeps the party topped up, even if they're at fairly high health already, as it's very common for an enemy to randomly pick one of their much stronger moves when you're not expecting it. This problem is exacerbated by the lack of a need to manage resources. When you can store such massive supplies of every item, the need to ration them out or be discerning with them ceases to exist.

The argument could exist then, that the games are supposed to be more casual, to encourage a laxadaisical approach to the game, something to enjoy on the side while you consume the story. And yet if such is the case, then why are so many of the game's mechanics completely unusable? Enemy Skill is a very interesting concept, effectively adding a neat sidequest for the player as they collect weird and unconventional abilities... but the vast majority of the moves it provides are either useless, or their narrow conditions for activation are deliberately avoided by the developers (ie. setting most enemy levels outside the multiples of level-specific skills).

If they want the game to be breezy and let players do whatever they want, then it needs to actually *let them*. If the game wants to be tactical, then it needs to actually open the door to tactics beyond the overly simplistic loop of Nukings. A DPS race simply shouldn't be the start and end of the gameplay.

[b] Final Fantasy VII Review [/b]

[b] Overview/Summary [/b]

Cloud Strife is the main protagonist of this game, he is an EX-SOLDIER socially distant Mercenary with a dark past, who will take any job for money. Careless to the condition of his world or society, he lives solely for himself. He is enlisted by the eco-terrorist insurgent group known as AVALANCHE, though he often bumps heads with the groups leader, Barret Wallace, due to Cloud's disregard for life and anything but his own goals. AVALANCHE opposes the action's and goal's of the Shinra Electric Power Company, who seek to misuse Mako for profit, and eventually kill the Planet, Gaea. The question is will Cloud come to term's with his past? And save the planet from destruction?


[b] Graphics [/b]
An Old RPG classic, what's not to like?

[b] Music [/b]
One of the most stunning and beautiful soundtracks in gaming. 

[b] Pros and Cons [/b]
Pros:
Perfected battle system
Incredible gear and materia
Amazing story and game design

Cons:
Minor things like PC port bugs.

[b] Final Rating [/b]
A game well worth paying for twice, it is an amazing adventure, a timeless, classic RPG that is full of fun and content.
A nearly perfect game to this day

TLDR: It's good, but the Switch and PS4 versions are worth looking at because they fix some of these issues.

Pros:
-It's Final Fantasy 7
-You can mod it
-It has cloud saves*

Cons:
-Because it's an update of the old PC port, the button prompts are all generic terms like [confirm], [switch], etc. making quick time events a pain in the ass.
-Cloud saves are through Square's own service, not Steam.  It sometimes goes down around the holidays if there are too many new players logging in.
-Some mods disable achievements and cloud saves.
-The "character booster" is currently broken.  It requires that you save the game and upload it to their cloud service.  You then need to log into your "online profile" to enable the booster but there has been a change on their website so you can no longer access it.  The booster just maxes your HP, MP, and give you 5 million gil.  Because of this, it can mess up your progress on unlocking the Limit breaks so you're not missing anything.

One of the best games ever made with tons of gameplay. The diverse, engaging, and numerous minigames make this more enjoyable. One thing I didn't like about the early Final Fantasy series and other RPGs around this time were the random encounters. I thought that it was a weaker entry than Chrono Trigger in one the of the best games ever made. It can also get grindy with a lot of repetitive gameplay for small rewards very late game. But hey, you don't need to do it all to get to the end. 
This is still a must have for anyone like me revisiting their childhood and remembering looking through Gamefaqs to learn how to get Knights of the Round (I needed to consult a guide to experience all the features in this game). 
But what about the port to the computer?
I thought that this version of the game was terrible. It took me five hours to figure out how to use third-party software to get my Xbox One controller to work. To get it to work I had to use Xinputplus and follow someone's guide here on Steam. Apart from being a bad port; I think that that this is an opportunity to own one of the most engrossing stories in a work of art that made videogame history.

Of course, a classic. Never got to finish it when I was a kid so it feels good to finally get the opportunity. What I noticed, however is that, while it's possible to use a gamepad, this port of FF7 is not optimized for it. Keyboard seems rather unnatural to play this game. But it's such a nostalgic experience that I let it slide.

While there can be slight pacing issues at times, I have found the game to be look into JRPG's past to see how systems evolve. The real time battle system seen in games like Chrono Trigger works fairly well here. I know most will come here expecting Midgar, but that is merely the beginning. Be willing to stick through some of the down parts and the now-dated graphics, and you will find a game with charm. The only thing I wished was different is the complete dependence on materia for everything except weapons and items. Giving the characters some abilities as they leveled up would have improved the feeling of leveling up. However, the flexibility offered by materia can be great for the strategy-minded.

A pretty alright port of a classic game. I can tell you, my gameplay hours on Steam don't reflect the many hours I've sunk into this game across several platforms now. 

In terms of ports, it looks pretty polished for being a polygon mess from 1997. The required log-in to Square is annoying to say the least, but it's a decent port that doesn't feel too different from the original experience from the Playstation 1. 

All that aside, FFVII is my definitive favorite video game of all time. Is it Basic to say that? Probably, but frankly, I don't care. I was 5 years old when this game came out, and I spent many hours watching my mother play it, as it was her game initially. It left a huge imprint on me, and I would try my hand at playing it myself a few times before our PS1 was killed by my cat and before we eventually moved on to the Xbox 360 and I stopped using the PS2 as much. It wasn't until I was in my early 20s that I finally forced myself to finish the game on the original PS1 disc set on our ailing PS2. I don't regret it for a moment. 
The journey of Cloud and the rest of AVALANCHE is one that I could follow over and over. Cloud in particular was the first of several amnesiac (and ambivalent) swordsmen that Square Enix would throw at gamers. Back when this game came out, he was a new kind of protagonist. Tifa was and still is Best Girl, and Barret was the first time I ever saw an African American character in the main cast of a video game. His portrayal hasn't exactly aged well since, but it was very impressionable for me to see Barret in a position of leadership, fighting for the planet. I will never forget the scene at the Temple of the Ancients, nor my shock at what takes place there.
It's been over 20 years since then, but the struggle against an evil corporation bent on profits above the well-being of people and the environment is still quite topical, and I find myself drawn to it more and more. The remake reignited my love of this game and I found it to be a highly enjoyable experience playing that one, too. 

By no means is this - the original Final Fantasy VII - a perfect game, and I know that everyone has opinions on the "best" Final Fantasy game. For me, it's this one. I can't recommend it enough.

My playtime doesn't include my PS1, PS2, PS3 or Switch playtimes.

Square Enix's PC re-release of Final Fantasy VII (FFVII) is a much-welcomed surprise for old school gamers who have fond memories of the original PlayStation. This edition of FFVII brings Steam achievements, "Cloud Save" and the character booster. The last two features are directly from Square Enix so for them to be enabled you must register an account on their website. Once the "Cloud Save" feature is ticked on you will then be able to use their character booster on the Square Enix website. As for the game itself, FFVII is a fantastic role-playing game (RPG) that has an interesting story, fun characters (except for Cait Sith), RPG progression and a large world to explore. It should be noted that the partial controller support is for the fact that you must click through the game's launcher window and the intro videos.

Final Fantasy VII is an enthralling classic that is certainly among the best the Final Fantasy series has to offer. 
It features a captivating [b]story[/b] full of mysteries to unravel with intriguing plot twists. The story is also surprisingly mature for a FF game focusing on corporate greed, the apathy of common folk who feel powerless to change the status quo, and environmentalism, all topics that are still very relevant today. The characters in the game are also especially well written with complex backstories and motivations, and each clearly has their own personality. The first third of the game is particularly strong in these regards as you work with your fellow insurgents to undermine the efforts of the omnipresent SHINRA Corporation while exploring the city of Midgar. 
The [b]gameplay[/b] is generally engaging with the materia system allowing highly diverse and adaptable customization of your characters' abilities as opposed to the more narrowly focused class system of other Final Fantasy games. The combat keeps you on your toes with it's real time battling system; if you spend a long time scrolling through your spells deciding which one to cast your opponents are probably going to get a free hit or two on you. The speed of combat is adjustable in the games settings however, to suit personal preferences. The system does have some downfalls however as 85% of all the enemies you face can simply be beat by spamming the basic attack command, and magic's strength falls off gradually after the early game, which in turn encourages you to just spam more basic attacks. My personal favorite part about the gameplay are the small interactive moments scattered throughout the story where you're called upon to do an unusual task using your controls in a completely new way. You're never really punished if you do poorly at any of these tasks, instead it just offers a unique way to connect with a moment in the game's world. 
The [b]graphics[/b] despite being very early in the 3D era still do a good job of depicting an interesting and elaborate world and showing off cool combat animations and cutscenes. However, the low resolution of the backgrounds can sometimes make it difficult to tell what the terrain of an area you're in is like (i.e. what parts you can walk on/how to follow the path forward) or where the entrances and ladders are in a particular area. For the latter issue you can use the game's help key which highlights the player (which helps if they are obscured by a wall in the foreground for example) as well as any ladders, entrances, and exits, most of the time. I have to say this is the first time a game's low res graphics actually hindered my ability to play slightly, but on the whole this is a minor complaint.

TL;DR:
Story: 9/10
Gameplay: 8.5/10
Graphics: 8/10 (taking its age into account)
Overall: 8.5/10

There are two kinds of people: Those who love Final Fantasy VII and those who are wrong. 

Is it the most complex FF game ever? No. (FFX holds that unnecessary title.) Is it the most compelling or well loved FF game ever? That depends on what you're looking for. It is a really fun and engaging story with fun gameplay though. 

Unless you've been living under a rock for the last 23 years you've likely heard of this game and have heard it rumored as the best JRPG ever made. That's a fan-argument that I don't intend to wade into. 

FF7 is my favorite game in the ongoing Final Fantasy franchise. It came at a specific period of my childhood so I have serious nostalgia-goggles for this game and dearly love it. The game does have faults, but none that are derailing. To judge this game you have to look to the era it came out. The late 90's were the end of an era facing an uncertain future. Game companies were still fighting over graphic mediums like cartridges or CD's. Many games were going to fully rendered 3D graphics while others tried to hang onto the already semi-nostalgic pixel art styles of the 80's NES and SEGA generations. FF7's story is about the loss and grief process, coming to terms with your identity, and confronting uncertainty, even learning to cope with it. Needless to say it spoke directly to my generation which was too young to hang with the 80's kids and old enough to see uncertainty on the horizon. Us 90's generation kids grew up confused. No wonder we were messed up we've always had one foot in the past and one stepping uncertainly toward the future. FF7 wonderfully encapsulates this feeling. 

Ok, maybe I'm putting too much into it, but can you blame me? It's my favorite game for a reason and one that even almost a quarter of a century after its release I still keep coming back to play. I love the story, the characters, and the world in which it lives.

This is a great classic RPG..although either people like it or hate it..i do not consider this the rpg that made all the modern rpg's....i still think OLD FF3 /FF6 was the one that changed rpg on SNES and made the way for more rpgs in north america to come over. The fight between squaresoft and enix is why we got so many great rpgs on the later systems.

Anyways, here is my pro/con list:


PROS:

- A story of classic love, betrayal, and many twists.

- Secret characters to find and other things.

- Many unique characters to learn about and discover their pasts.

CONS:

- This game does not really work well with modern controllers. It is best recommended to play with Keyboard and mouse. There are parts in the game where you need to click on certain things for puzzles and the controller is hard to use in these sections. If you really need to use a controller for this game, there are mods you can look at to allow this.

There are many things that make this game a great game, and many things that can also turn off people from this game. I believe this was one of the gateway games in making the next generation of rpg's games more popular. I don't think this was the defining game that changed the gaming industry, but i believe it contributed to it changing the game styles on console usage and pc games.

I remember seeing the adverts on TV when FF7 was about to release. The game was like nothing I'd ever seen. I remember going to Target on the day it released in Australia and buying it. Not really knowing what to expect I loaded it up. I watched an epic cut scene and jumped off a train. For the next few hours I played what was for me, a new genre of game. After a few hours I stopped and thought, I just wasted all my pocket money and birthday money on this??? Sure the story seemed cool, but for a kid who played FIFA, racing games and shooters, the combat was slow and there was too much talking. I returned the game and bought some other piece of trash. 
2 months later something told me try it again. 
I went and bought it again. I slogged it out through Midgar (to me the start is still a chore lol). And the rest is history. I finally completed what is still today, my favourite ever game. I have played it through on every PS release, on the original PC CD release, on the Square Store PC release, on the Steam PC release and on Switch. No game even comes close to the enjoyment I get from entering the open world map, playing through the story finding and maxing materia, breeding Chocobos, Farming the magic pots and the underwater plane, taking down the weapons, and when that's all done, descending the crater...
Still waiting for a game since that ticks all the boxes, and to me, it still doesn't exist.
If you've never played it before. Forget about the graphics, just get it and enjoy a piece of video game history that still can't be topped in so many ways.

I was afraid to start the franchise, there's so much hype behind it that I thought I would not enjoy it, I'm glad I was wrong, Final Fantasy 7 is a joyride start to finish. All characters are so much interesting, the story is amazingly engaging and even though the graphics are way over dated, it has it's charm and was my favorite part of the game. The downside of this old game is the abundance of missable items, if you don't know when or where you can get certain item, you will miss it forever, I was going to platinum this game but half-way I learned I already missed one materia and I didn't wan't to lose my 30 hour save to start over, maybe one day. The one thing I'm certain is that this game is my most memorable game I've played all year, I had to study a lot to even finish it, learning about enemy drops, items location, materia combinations, and it was one of the most satisfying experiences of the year. The final boss was a delight to beat, after losing two times to him, I dedicated another 10h to grind for some items and levels and when I finally defeated it was totally worth it. Another point I have to make is that this soundtrack is 10/10, there's not one bad track, it's been on repeat ever since I finished playing it. And yeah, she's gone but not forgotten.

As of writing this, I am in the middle of a Final Fantasy marathon and currently playing 9. I also have plenty of time on FF12 original and Zodiac Job sytem on PS2. This is my 4th time playing through Final Fantasy 7, once on PS1, 2 and a half times on PS4 and one final time on Steam just recently last month.

As an overall, this game is fine, it doesn't excel anywhere other than the Materia system. With boring characters heading the main plot, a very bogged down trite and contrived "We need things to happen" Disk 2 and a very bland over-world divided into 3ish sections I'm left with very mixed opinions on the game. The game is seen as a classic given it's the first PS1 Final Fantasy, but FF2 is far more customizable and gives me characters I care just as much about. (Which is none to very little.) 

I would suggest either FF2 PSP, FF5 SNES, FF8 PS1 or Steam Release (Not Remastered) or FF12 Zodiac Job System for PS2. If you must play it, stay for the Materia system and don't get your hopes up.

Easiest abusable combination to grab is Choco/Mog + Added Effect to inflict stop using your normal attack. The summon also can inflict stop. 6/10 no real objections here but bland compared to other games in the series. (Maybe I'll elaborate more in the comments if anyone asks. Yes, I genuinely enjoyed Final Fantasy 2.)

Final Fantasy VII is a game I grew up with on PS1, and it's something I have carried with me for my whole life. I have replayed the game recently on Steam and this version is nearly identical to the console release.

FF7 is full of charm, humour, sadness, action, and clever writing. On it's surface its an eco-forward, anti-corruption message game in a dystopian industrial setting which leans into fantasy and magic very tastefully. The game and characters are all fully realised and it's excellently paced as an ever looming darkness seeps into the story. 

I sincerely recommend everyone to play this game.

Recommended, BUT MAKE SURE YOU TURN OFF SQUARE'S CLOUD SAVES.
So, let me first get something out of the way: I never played this as a kid. My first time playing this classic was in 2020.

Overall, I do recommend this game, but I have issues with it. Some issues are with the game itself, and some issues are with the port. Port issues: first, anybody playing with a Nintendo Switch Pro controller is going to be disappointed. This port does not support or recognize the Switch controller at all, even though any other game launched through steam has no problem, including if I launch the Epic Game Store launcher to play Dauntless. There is no legitimate way I found to make it work(more on this later).
Second, the controls are clunky. The game does not pay attention to your set buttons. It lists buttons as [OK] or [SWITCH] or [MENU]. So if the game is teaching you how to unequip Materia, it says, "Press the SWITCH button to unequip." This is extremely unintuitive, especially when minigames pop up. "Press OK, CANCEL, AND SWITCH in order to do a squat." Okay, I'm going to have to look at my configuration to know what you mean.
Third, and the reason for the capital letters at the beginning of this review, is that Square's cloud saving sucks. I lost 20 hours of gameplay because the save files synced wrong. My friend had the same thing happen, and lost even more time. So do yourself a favor and disable it.

Now I'm going to review the game itself, for those like me who have never touched it. I have not actually beaten the game yet, (Partially due to the save erasing itself) but I have a pretty good idea of what this game has to offer.
This game did not age as well as The Legend of Zelda, Ocarina of Time, another classic from just two years later. FFVII really tried to show off the graphics capabilities of the original Playstation, and it did. There are fully animated movies that look really good for 1996. But outside of the movies, the models are wonky. Character's arms are shaped like long hourglasses. It can be hard to tell where this path is that you need to go.
Gameplay itself is pretty good. The combat runs like Chrono Trigger's, with each character having a bar fill up before they attack. The party characters don't feel very different in combat, though. Actions and spells are granted though "Materia," which allows the character equiping them to use the corresponding action/spell. The physical characters are interchangable, same with the two ranged ones. Since any character can use any spell or action, there is literal 'plug and play' to the characters. There can be some interesting trade offs, like a weapon that grants high attack power, but won't allow you to use spells, but most of the time, you're going to want the Materia slot.
The story is great. It has problems sometimes, where you have to do a clunky, one-time minigame to progress the plot, and get old after a while. But eventually, you get invested, and twists start happening, even before the famous death scene.

Now I'm going to share some knowledge with you. There are mods for this game. You can't find them on the Steam workshop, but are easily found on Google (not sure if I can/ should do direct shoutouts here). They fix nearly all the problems I've mentioned here. But there is a cost: no Steam achievements.
I'll let you decide which is better. But for me, the mods I found after losing my motivation because I lost 20 hours of gameplay took this from a 3/5 star game to a 5/5 star game.
Overall recommendation: Buy if you're nostalgic. Mod or buy the remake if you want a better, more balanced and complex experience. Either way, disable cloud saves.

There's no game I've played more of than FF7, picked it up as a kid, was completely hooked. Always came back to it.

This PC port is terrible. At impactful moments in the story, the music cues are completely wrong, or absent. This game has frozen and crashed on me, which I can never remember the PS1 version doing to me. Either way, a game made more than 20 years ago should run stably on modern systems. There are obvious animation errors in the game, where Cloud won't be holding his sword in scenes where he's miming holding it. 

The translation is strange too, but I'm just used to one version rather than this one. Calling Jenova "crisis from the sky" instead of "calamity from the sky" feels like a worse call to me. Otherwise, the translation seems clean enough. This would be a good buy if you're a committed fan, but I think if you're new to the game and want to follow the hype, you should check out mods to fix these issues, if the port won't be supported. Alternatively find another to access the game.

[h1] Information / Review English [/h1]

FINAL FANTASY VII is an action role-playing game that was developed by the makers of Square Enix.

[h1] Gameplay / Story [/h1]

The metropolis of Midgar owes its progress to Mako energy, but the mining of the raw material has fatal consequences for the planet! A truth that greedy energy company Shinra is trying to cover up. The resistance group AVALANCHE opposes this. For their mission, they hire the mercenary Cloud Strife, who was once part of the Shinra's elite unit. In search of truth, his past leads him into a conflict that decides the fate of the planet.

The story of Final Fantasy VII begins with Cloud Strife joining the anti-Shinra organization Avalanche when they attacked one of the eight Mako reactors in Midgar. On the way back to Avalanche headquarters, Cloud meets the flower seller Aeris Gainsborough. During their next mission, the Avalanches are trapped by President Shinra, but are able to escape before the Mako reactor they sabotaged explodes. However, the reactor explosion hurled Cloud from the upper levels of Midgar into the slums below. He falls through the roof of a church ruin in Sector 5 and lands unharmed in a flower bed, where Aeris introduces himself correctly. Cloud soon agrees to take on the role of her bodyguard, an agreement that comes when a Shinra Turks unit appears at the church to arrest Aeris.

[h1] Combat system [/h1]

Like the three previous Final Fantasy games, Final Fantasy VII uses a combat system called Active Time Battle (ATB). The group members have a bar that fills up continuously. As soon as this bar is full, an action can be selected and carried out. Unlike earlier games in the series, which allowed four to five controllable characters in combat, the group in Final Fantasy VII can consist of a maximum of three characters.

[h1] Pro [/h1]

+ exciting story
+ good scope
+ beautiful graphics back then
+ coherent soundtrack
+ every single side quest is actually a little story
+ Skill trees
+ many weapons are available
+ a lot of activities
+ Achievements and trading cards

[h1] Contra [/h1]

- Requires Square Enix account to play
- Boss fights are rather sluggish and easy
- bad keyboard layout

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

With FINAL FANTASY VII, a cult classic returns to the PC. If you like the series, you should definitely grab it here, as this is really one of the first and best action role-playing games. Clear buy recommendation.


[h1] Information/Review Deutsch [/h1]

FINAL FANTASY VII ist ein Action-Rollenspiel, welches von  den Machern um Square Enix entwickelt wurde. 

[h1] Gameplay/Story [/h1]

Die Metropole Midgar verdankt ihren Fortschritt der Mako-Energie, doch der Abbau des Rohstoffs hat fatale Folgen für den Planeten! Eine Wahrheit, die der habgierige Energiekonzern Shinra zu vertuschen versucht. Die Widerstandsgruppe AVALANCHE stellt sich dem entgegen. Für ihre Mission heuern sie den Söldner Cloud Strife an, der einst Teil der Elite-Einheit Shinras war. Auf der Suche nach Wahrheit führt ihn seine Vergangenheit in einen Konflikt, der über das Schicksal des Planeten entscheidet. 

Die Geschichte von Final Fantasy VII beginnt mit dem Beitritt Cloud Strifes zur Anti-Shinra-Organisation Avalanche, als diese einen Anschlag auf einen der acht Mako-Reaktoren Midgars verübt. Auf dem Rückweg zum Avalanche-Hauptquartier trifft Cloud die Blumenverkäuferin Aeris Gainsborough. Während ihrer nächsten Mission geraten die Mitglieder Avalanches in eine Falle von Präsident Shinra, sie können aber fliehen, bevor der von ihnen sabotierte Mako-Reaktor explodiert. Jedoch wird Cloud durch die Reaktorexplosion von den oberen Ebenen Midgars in die Slums darunter geschleudert. Er fällt durch das Dach einer Kirchenruine in Sektor 5 und landet unverletzt in einem Blumenbeet, wo sich Aeris ihm richtig vorstellt. Cloud erklärt sich bald bereit, die Aufgabe als ihr Bodyguard anzunehmen, eine Vereinbarung, die zustande kommt, als eine Turks-Einheit des Shinra-Konzerns in der Kirche erscheint, um Aeris gefangen zu nehmen.

[h1] Kampsystem [/h1]

Wie die drei vorangegangenen Final-Fantasy-Spiele verwendet Final Fantasy VII ein Active Time Battle (ATB) genanntes Kampfsystem. Hierbei verfügen die Gruppenmitglieder über eine Leiste, die sich kontinuierlich auffüllt. Sobald diese Leiste voll ist, kann eine Aktion ausgewählt und ausgeführt werden. Anders als frühere Spiele der Serie, die vier bis fünf steuerbare Charaktere im Kampf erlaubten, kann die Gruppe in Final Fantasy VII aus höchstens drei Spielfiguren bestehen.

[h1] Pro [/h1]

+ spannende Geschichte
+ guter Umfang
+ damals schöne Grafik
+ stimmiger Soundtrack
+ jede einzelne Nebenquest, ist eigentlich eine kleine Geschichte
+ Fähigkeitsbäume
+ viele Waffen stehen zur Verfügung
+ etliche Aktivitäten
+ Errungenschaften und Trading Cards

[h1] Kontra [/h1]

- Square Enix Account benötigt zum spielen
- Bosskämpfe sind eher träge und einfach
- schlechte Tastaturbelegung

[h1] Fazit [/h1]

Mit FINAL FANTASY VII  kehrt ein Kult-Klassiker zurück auf den PC. Wer die Serie mag, sollte hier unbedingt zugreifen, da  dies wirklich eines der ersten und besten Action-Rollenspiele ist.  Klare Kaufempfehlung.

[b]Final[/b] [b]Fantasy[/b] [b]VII[/b] has always been my favorite game for the Playstation 1, and I was able to play it again on the PC Port. 

Its a Great game for fans of JRPG and for introducing new fans of the [b]Final[/b] [b]Fantasy[/b] series, and here is why:

[h1]-[/h1] [h1]THE[/h1] [h1]GAMEPLAY[/h1] [h1]-[/h1]

Its a real-time turn base game, basically where time dont stop for you when your strategizing your tactics and enemies will attack you unless you act fast on what you have in your arsenal. 

The gameplay itself is good, pretty strong system wither you use magic mechanics or physical damage orientation as your personal play style against obstacles through out the game.

[h1]-[/h1] [h1]THE[/h1] [h1]VISUALS[/h1] [h1]-[/h1]

Comparing the graphics between the PS1 vs. PC port, the PC port's graphics on the models are enhanced and cleaned but the weird part of the models that bugged me is some of them have a black oval shape on the mouth area look like their mouth is broken and cant close it.

The backgrounds is pretty much the same as the original however since its enchanced, its looks like paintings of landscapes.

[h1]-[/h1] [h1]THE[/h1] [h1]STORY[/h1] [h1]-[/h1]

Personally, good stories in any game interest me from the characters to the world building, it is fascinating to learn and to understand for how their world works.

The Story is the best part of this game, its tells you what the characters want, what drive them, and what is the meaning of that drive, and this includes the villain of what push him into insanity of want to burn the world before him. Exploring the world and understand its rules and its history, and whats at stake.

[h1]-[/h1] [h1]THE[/h1] [h1]CONCLUSION[/h1] [h1]-[/h1]

The game is fun, but can be bit weird in terms of gameplay or character models. The PC port is somewhat the same as the PS1 version but with slightly enhanced visuals, and the story is fantastic.

If you just back home from work or school and looking a fantasy JRPG, then this game is for you.
Tifa is in this game. Therefore it is a 10/10 game

The game is great, if you can play it on another system, but there are just too many bugs in the Steam PC version. I've lost hours of gameplay when the game simply freezes in the middle of play several times. Going to certain places causes graphic bugs (going back out of the first elevator area toward the train again caused the character to appear upside down under the world so all I could see were the bottoms of his feet). There's no option to remove the 'pause when in the background' default. The game doesn't support a 'WASD + mouse' gameplay style, it's all on the keyboard. It's all doable, but it's just not comfortable for me. The camera view while running around the outer world is annoying trying to get it pointed where you want.

The game claims 'elemental + materia' gives you resistances, and I recall there being a screen that shows that explicitly in the console version but it's gone in the PC version* [EDIT: Found it, requires hitting 'OK' in the status screen]

Switching screens causes the game to crash, and that's not a great thing to have on a game where SO much is missable that it's almost mandatory to play while having a walkthrough open to make sure you've gotten everything. With the 'pause while in background' going, I can't even switch the music on Pandora while the boat is sailing between Junon and Costa without coming back to exactly where I left it and having to sit and watch it sail (and that has to  happen several times to get all the Condor attacks completed. There's just too much that's annoying about this version and topped off with random game crashes it just isn't worth it. Save your $$ for a different version or the new remake.
Timeless

Well I think it's time to rewrite this review, since it my first one is a little meh (you can find it down below).

This game is, without doubt, the most popular of the saga. This game was the first Final Fantasy I've ever seriously played (my first one was FFVI, via PC, and saved after getting a Game Over in Mt. Koltz lmao 9 year-old me was a bit of a mess). My brother kept telling me to train and reach a certain level before going on with the story. He made me reach lvl 50 [spoiler]before entering Junon for the first time[/spoiler] and it was crazy, I spent hours grinding there. I think I even cried because I was afraid he would catch me progressing without him knowing (???), but I was soooo bored at that point that I think I did it anyway. Now, everytime I play it, I grind a lot at the same spot lol.

Ok, talking about the actual port, this game had a graphic update from the PSX version. The character models, cities, items, etc. are cleaner, not pixelated I mean, but the 2D backgrounds are the same. It doesn't really bother me, since I just got used to it and didn't think about it anymore. 

The story is also pretty good, but I have to say that I am surprised I understood the story back then. I am Spanish, so I first played it in Spanish, and didn't really understand much because of the translation. Then I played it in English and everything made sense. Now, [b]I am playing it with The Reunion mod and the retranslation is [i]SO GOOD[/i] that it is like playing the game for the first time. The mod's translation is [u]REALLY GOOD[/u], everything is explained well and makes the OG translation a hot mess. I don't really know how I understood the back then, seriously.[/b]

I really encourage you to play it with the mod. You can even change it so it displays the PSX buttons instead of "Press [ENTER] button" for example.

I still don't know why people complained so much and saying it's not a good port? I play it with mods now, but still, when I didn't know about them, I really enjoyed it. Maybe I am biased because it's my favorite game... But I don't really think so. The game is playable and enjoyable! So [b]I definitely recommend it[/b], and if you have never played a Final Fantasy game before, check it out! It's worth it!!  

[b][u]OG review[/u][/b] 
I don't know why people are complaining so much about this port. I think it's good, I enjoy playing it. The only thing that is a little bit confusing to me is the buttons, I barely remember them by "Press [OK] button" or "Press [SWITCH] button" (dem minigames) since I just go by the PSX ones haha. 

Anyway, about being online, if you are not "cheating" you can turn off the cloud sync and just go with local files.

Do you really not know this game? Seriously, do I even have to write this? I want to note, that this was the first game I played when I upgraded from a Genesis to a PS1. I had never played an RPG before. This game introduced me to video games with true stories, even if the story is pure insanity. That said, instead of listing why it is awesome, I'm gonna tell you all the things that I know suck about it. Also note, I recommend it. I own it on PS1, PC hardcopy, and on Steam, so I want you to buy it.

1. The graphics. Holy shit are they awful. Like seriously, so blocky and distracting and if I didn't love it so much I wouldn't even be able to play it and get past the shitty graphics.

2. Summons are so fucking long! They are beautiful, yes, even with shit graphics, but they get real tiresome after the 75th Knights of the Round.

3. As previously mentioned, the story makes zero sense. Yes, in broad strokes, there's supposed to be a pattern and such, but as you get to the details it is nonsensical. Yeah, the death scene was tragic and yeah I cried, fuck you I was young and had no idea and had raised that character as one of my powerhouses, but despite that the rest is just crap. Also that death still seems to have no reason behind it.

4. Angst. so much angst! So much sad drama angst. Am I who I think I am? Are any of us truly human? Just... let me hit things with my giant phallic sword.

There's more, but I'll stop there. So yeah, buy the game. You'll still love it.

My 10/10 fiancee just recently discovered this new game that all the kids are raving about these days. It was called The Final Fantasy 7 Remake. After beating the game with her superior gaming skill we knew that it was going to be an instant 10/10 hit. That's when it hit me. If they made an FF7 Remake, maybe they made an FF7 Original. After several months of searching I finally found this little gem and let me tell you friends; IT LIVES UP TO THE NAME. This fantasy will be the final one you want to play. The characters are unique and the story is captivating! The blocky pixelated characters will give you a gut-wrenching headache that you're sure to talk about for ages! Some of your favorite characters will die and all your dreams for a brighter future for the heroes will be crushed! This game is truly a 10/10!

This game has to be my favorite Final Fantasy the story is very engaging and delivers very impacting emotional scenes and events throughout the game. Most characters are very interesting and have there moments. The music is probably the best thing about this game it is so atmospheric and puts the mood just right, the boss themes are amazing especially near the end game. The Materia system can be a bit complicated but after you find out how to use it the combinations of effects and abilities you can get from them are endless. The down side of the game of course is how it looks being released in 1997 it looked good then but now it hasn't aged well but there are a variety of mods to make the game much better if your willing to do the work. The combat is turned based personal I don't mind turned based I find it very fun it can be very easy at some parts especially if you know what you are doing but can also be very difficult in certain parts of the game. The story in this game is amazing has some good twist and a good villain I don't want to ruin anything so that is all i'm going to say. Overall the game is a classic and should be played or least given a chance by everyone. 10/10

I have been a fan of FFVII since its release and by far this is the best release version of this game. Although it lacks the range of speed increase and save state functions that many will have become a custom to in the (Often lacking in remuneration for Sqaure experience) Emulator world. Its stability, No discs and near infinite save slots make up for this. 
But it is its modding scene which truly makes this game the only Version worth handing over cash for the decades old game. Mods like Scavenger, New Threat and Necrosis give this game a challenge while still staying true to the feel of the base game.

The feels. When I was kid my neighbor friend had a PS and i had a SNES and later an XBOX. I never owned a Playstation but from time to time we would go to each others house to play on each others console and talk games. So I had tried FF on his console a few times. One year my friend spent the entire summer off skool inside playing this game. I made fun of him for it because I had no one to play at the park with. Because of that, I hated Final Fantasy and Square Enix along with PlayStation. It was one of those child hood things that stuck with me. Now as an adult square Enix has produced some undeniably good modern titles. So all grudges aside I decide to give FF a try. I am so glad that I have had the opportunity to experience this game a decade and a half later. It is fantastic. the mix of retro pixel environments and 3d characters is really something. The music is great. Combat is perfectly balanced I had 8 health while dealing the final attack on the first boss. I guess this game takes a whole summer to play. With Cloud save you never lose your progress. So i can take as long as i need to catch up and experience FF7.
i love this videogame!

This is by far my favorite game from my childhood. The story was one of the greatest in an RPG of it's time. The game is closer to turn based so people seeking a fast paced game probably won't enjoy it. The combat has plenty of room for customization from equipment to materia combinations. If you really get into the game you could easily sink 50 to 70 hours into exploring everything the game has to offer.

I didn't think this game could live up to the decades worth of hype it has accumulated, but I was surprised: it's an extremely solid RPG (in addition to the various technical achievements related to being the first of its kind).

A couple things are clunky: navigation is harder than it needs to be (so interacting with objects can be tough), the key mapping is strange (and the xbox gamepad I use for every other game on windows doesn't work), and menu operations take more steps than they would today. But, most games released in the mid-90s (especially for consoles) show their age mechanically worse than that.

Yes, the graphics are primitive. At the same time, what they lacked in polygons they made up for in expressive animations, and in some situations (not so much the cutscenes as the battles) the polygon quality is actually extremely detailed. (That Tifa stretch tho)

If you want to play this game with a controller, be aware that this port forces you to play with the analog stick and completely disables the D-pad, and apparently there's no way to fix this other than using stupid external shareware to map controller buttons to keyboard keys, which really is not a fix at all.

I appreciate being able to move around with the analog stick, which wasn't a feature in the PS1 because the game was released before the Dual Shock came to be, but in a game where 80% of gameplay involves navigating around menus, having a floaty cursor that moves out of control [i]actually makes the game unplayable[/i].

There's a settings program that starts up before the game, which is supposed to let you customize your controller configuration, but it's broken, not responding to any user input, [i]and[/i] the buttons are shown with DirectInput-like numbers instead of XInput-like Xbox button names.

[h1]Final Fantasy 7: A JRPG Classic Through The Eyes Of A Newcomer[/h1]
(Disclaimer: I played the game modded with 7th heaven 2.0 which is why there's only about a couple of hours of playtime in my steam account)

I was never really a big fan of Final Fantasy. The only game that i've played and finished through (besides FF7R) is FFXV, and lets just say that that game left a bitter taste in my mouth. Meanwhile, i've always heard the hype surrrounding FF7 for the better part of the decade now, and i've never really been personally interested in the game until i gave the recently released remake a try. The Remake, particularly its characters and story, hooked me right out of the gate which is why i then decided to just buy the OG game since the remake only covers the midgar portion. And while i dont like everything that this game offers, it's truly a piece of art and i can finally see the hype surrounding it. Even though alot of newer people will probably see this game as 'outdated', i highly suggest you try to stick with the game until the end.

[u]Pros[/u]
+ Story and Characters. While the base plot of the game isn't really that complex, its the story and characters that really resonated with me personally. The story does get pretty deep later on though which is why i highly suggest you go in the game blind. While some of the translation can get abit weird, There are ALOT of things in the story here that are really worth it to get through.
+ Music. Perfection. Do i really need to say anything else about the music? I mean cmon, it's a Final Fantasy score.
+ Combat. I'm not a big fan of turn based combat, but i was surprised by how still engaging and addictive the combat is even to a newcomer to the turn-based Final Fantasy. It's intuitive, easy to understand, and pretty enjoyable.
+ Content. Another thing that i almost forgot to mention, is the amount of content that this game offers. From minigames, to battle arenas, to sidequests, there are alot of things to do besides the main story, which just adds a whole lot more to the value of the overall package.

[u]Cons[/u]
- Random Encounters. While i enjoyed the combat, i cant say the same about the Random Encounters that start 90% of said combat. At first i didnt mind them, but around the mid-late game, i just straight up HATE its existence. It's a really annoying mechanic and i wish that this game had a system more in line with something like the Persona games. If there's one thing that i can say that's outdated about this game, then it would be this. I know there are alot of people who'd defend Random Encounters to death, but this is my personal opinion as someone who never really played the old Final Fantasy games, so i hope you'll get that.
- The Grinding. This is one other con that is also related to combat which i'm also not a big fan of. Around mid-late game, you are essentially required to grind and level up your characters to progress. While it's definitely possible progressing through the game without grinding, there are enemies that'll be able to just straight up one-shot you which just feels kinda cheap at times. Maybe it's just me that's not really used to these types of games yet, but it is just one other thing that i liked to note in my review since it annoyed me while i was playing the game.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
These are just the things that i listed from the top of my head about what i like and what i didnt like about the game. I didnt want to make this review to be very long as i want to make it abit more concise. But overall, my thoughts on Final Fantasy 7 as a 'Newcomer' is very positive. The hype surrounding this game IS real, and i highly recommend you to play this game if you're a fan of the new remake, or just looking for something to play in general. There are some caveats here and there that might make or break the experience of new players, but if you can get through them, its a damn good time for a game that was way ahead of its time.

Final Fantasy VII. There's a lot to say about this game, but I can summarise it pretty easily. From the top-down, it's an item-based RPG that breaks the typical moulds that other Item-based RPGs (think Legend of Zelda) fall into. The materia system is fantastic, and offers plenty of opportunities to customise your characters and their abilities. As a turn-based RPG, it's fast-paced and incredibly engaging if you set it up for that. 

Even ignoring the story, there are enough things in this game (both legitimate and exploitative) to keep you engaged for weeks, if you somehow haven't played it yet. 

I'd recommend it, even despite some of the issues this version has.

The battle system is okay, though I don't think the 'real time' aspect of it adds anything beneficial and is really just more of an annoyance.

I wanted to like this game, I really did. Cloud was my favorite character in smash 4, and I wanted to know a bit more about my main. But honestly, I just can't get behind the hype. First off, this just isn't a great port, having to make a square enix account and go through their launcher while staying online at all times. Granted, if that was the only problem I wouldn't be too upset, so I'll just put the rest of my complaints as a list.

1. Compared to other games from the same era, the graphics are atrocious. The difference between the roblox character models and the hand drawn backgrounds honestly made me nauseous. 
2. Party roles are not well defined. Perhaps others would like having flexibility, but when I look at Cloud, Tifa, and Barret I have no idea who the mage, damage dealer, tank, or healer is. 
3. Too many flipping characters. It's a problem in a lot of rpg's, but you've leveled your 3 characters every character after that is an extra. They'll inevitably be underleveled compared to your main party, and their strengths aren't well defined enough to justify changing.
4. The tone. The game starts out as a grim fantasy, but then it tries to be all happy and fun with crossdressing, Cait Sith, chocobo races. The shift is a bit jarring.
5. Lack of direction. After you lead Midgar you're left with very little idea what to do or why. You can kind of find the plot by wandering around for a bit, but it's more than a little tedious.

I'm sure someone else would like this game, but honestly it just doesn't live up to the hype. Hopefully I'll be happy when I get the chance to play the remake, but until then I'd just recommend FF9 for anyone who wants their fantasy jrpg fix.

Still one of the greatest games of all time, and this is an excellent port. No mods needed, uses PS1 music. Helps if you turn on Big Picture controller configurations so you can use D pad instead of analogue stick, especially for menus. Having just replayed it again for the first time in many years, it still holds up to be incredibly fun and enjoyable. Still has amazing replay value. I used Yuffie for the first time ever in any of my runs, I wanted her to focus on high DEX and command materia. She actually did great by late game, Mug + Added cut = cheap way to get 2 attacks while leaving Double Cut for someone else, so with her high speed, she was able to pump out some decent damage for a non-Cloud's Ultima Weapon character. I also tried Vincent again, gave him tons of +MATK materia and W-Cast Mega-All Flare (Cheaper than Ultima for same 9999 damage). Good fun. For anyone wondering, it didn't seem like having Vincent in back row affected his melee attacks on his limit break, so I think they're long-range, not actually melee (I didn't use Long Range materia on him). Even with all the -STR from his materia, Chaos was still doing decent damage in final dungeon, so I think he's underrated and misunderstood in terms of usefulness.

[h1]Final Fantasy VII[/h1]
What's to say about Final Fantasy VII that hasn't been said already? This game is truly a masterpiece. A masterpiece that, despite its graphics, has aged quite well. The beautiful thing is that since it's the PC version you can mod this game to hell and back. I decided to play the vanilla version for the achievements. I wanted to beat the game 100% and Steam achievements give me some sense of completion. This version of the game is excellent since it supports cloud saves. I was able to play on my desktop and then play on my Surface when I was on the road.
Now that there's a remake (of the first portion of the game), I feel that some might skip this version entirely which is sad. I decided to revisit this game because I was having trouble remembering the story details, and I'm happy to say that the story is even better than I remember. Give this game the opportunity to truly get its hooks in you and you won't regret it.
I've climbed the mountain. Typically when I beat a game in the fashion I did this one, I never touch it again. In my mind, I've truly completed it, like conquering a mountain. Well, I still have the remake, and I do own this game on multiple platforms like my PS4 and Nintendo Switch. Let me not think about that now, and let me savor this moment of completing a childhood favorite. Onto the remake!

I wish I could recommend this port to people, because FFVII is one of the most engaging RPGs I've played. However, there is a critical error with this port. All saves for the game are stored on a cloud owned by Square Enix. 

Normally, this isn't an issue, but I have found multiple occasions of the cloud not updating the save file when I save the game. In other words, the game isn't actually saving my progress, and it's caused me to lose hours of gameplay multiple times. It sucks that I learned of this error after the refund period, because now I refuse to play this version at the risk of losing more progress and wasting more time. If you want to play this game, get it on a console instead. Those save on the console's hard disk, avoiding this issue altogether. The PSN version even comes with a custom theme that plays Aerith's Theme. 

If anyone knows a way to fix this, please let me know. Otherwise, I refuse to buy another Square Enix game until I know they have either fixed this error or have discontinued cloud saves.

This is the best way to play FF7, imo. Do yourself a favor and download some mods, though, such as the fantastic Reunion mod, which I used for my recent playthrough. I hear Seventh Heaven is also really good.

As for my thoughts on FF7 in general, I played it years ago when it was still relatively new. However, much of its plot had been spoiled for me by friends, so I never felt like I got full experience it properly. I enjoyed it, and I considered it a great game. But there was just always something about it I never got that other people seemed to get. Something that made it truly one the greatest games of all time. In my recent playthrough, I finally got it. It's the relatability of the characters and the story. The characters spend the entire game trying to save the planet because it's the right thing to do. But there is a certain hopelessness to it. Everyone wonders if they can actually succeed. And, honestly, the game does a great job at making you think you won't succeed. It's the same thing in real life where we are always trying to do the right things but we get frustrated because everything feels hopeless sometimes. This time playing through the game, I really felt that in the characters, the story, and the setting in general. I won't be too specific in the interest of avoiding spoilers, but I definitely recommend playing this amazing game if you haven't before. And if you're like me, and you let the hype around it keep you from enjoying it for so long, then give it a second look. One of the greatest video game experiences you can have is waiting for you.
